HEADLINE: Where Necessity Ends for Hospital Care

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLD SPRING, N.Y.

 BODY:
The Julia L. Butterfield Hospital, which sits on the outskirts of this tiny town, is not much to look at. Its melon and gray facade is hardly beautiful. There are cracks in the tiles on the upstairs halls. Although the emergency room was renovated last year, the X-ray machine dates back four decades and the ventilation system is almost as old.
For years the 2,200 residents of Cold Spring have seen the hospital as evidence that they have a basic right to immediate and total health care. Reluctantly, others came to a different conclusion: that the price of keeping the hospital open -- $2 million to save 35 beds -- is too high. 
 The difference in views illustrates a central question of the current health-care debate: where is the line between medical necessity and economic luxury? Across the United States, 642 hospitals have closed since 1980, forcing patients to drive extra miles to deliver their babies, recover from their illnesses, have their surgeries. The next-closest hospital to Cold Spring is about 20 miles away. How far is too far? How much is too much? Does the right to health care include the right to a community hospital?
"The current economics of health care don't allow a community hospital in every town," said Donna Gaidamak, a spokeswoman for the association.
Butterfield Hospital was founded in 1925 in a bequest left in the will of its namesake, a wealthy local woman whose son had died in childhood after a fall from a horse. If only there had been a hospital nearby, Mrs. Butterfield believed, her little boy might have been saved.
The institution has been on financially shaky ground from its first year of operation, when it had a deficit of $1,500. Since then, there have been economically good years mixed with the bad ones, but national trends were not in Butterfield's favor.
The cost of providing health care coupled with a push by insurance companies to reduce the length of each hospital stay have strained small hospitals to the breaking point. Since 1980, 404 hospitals have entered merger agreements with neighboring institutions. More than half of those mergers took place in the last five years.
"A small place like this can't keep up with technology," said Marcel Martino, chief executive officer of Butterfield. "Our radiology equipment is 30, 40 years old, we can't get parts. We can't expand our physician base, because doctors want to work with larger hospitals. People feel secure knowing we're here, but they don't really want to come here, either. They want to go where the doctors are and the technology is. Most people in the community have never been inside."
 
Unable to Meet Payroll
 Ten years ago, Butterfield nearly merged with Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, 20 miles north of Cold Spring, which is 55 miles north of New York City, but the agreement fell through in its final stages. Five years ago the hospital was scheduled to be closed, but another small hospital in Beacon closed first, and the New York State Department of Health urged that Butterfield remain open so that the area did not lose two hospitals at once.
The latest threat to Butterfield began in March of this year when the board of trustees found itself unable to meet the hospital payroll. The board turned to the Hudson Valley Hospital Center, which had formerly been the Peekskill Community Hospital. Hudson Valley took control of Butterfield in exchange for an infusion of $500,000 to meet immediate expenses and allow the hospital credit with which to buy medical supplies.
Shortly after Hudson Valley took charge, it announced that it would close Butterfield's 35 beds on July 1, when the building would be turned into a nursing home. The Butterfield emergency room would remain open for as long as possible, Hudson Valley said, but if the economics proved impossible, it too would be closed. All patients from Cold Spring would have to travel 18 miles to Hudson Valley's 114-bed hospital for care.
In response to that announcement, the governing boards of Cold Spring and neighboring Nelsonville formed the Joint Commission for Butterfield Hospital to find alternatives to Hudson Valley's plans. The group found another hospital -- St. Luke's Community Medical Center, across the Hudson River in Newburgh, N.Y. -- which was willing to consider running the hospital and keeping the beds open.
 
Another Option Pursued
 Hudson Valley, in turn, said it would relinquish control of Butterfield, if it could recoup the $500,000 already spent to acquire the hospital, and if there is evidence that the community has raised an additional $1.5 million toward an operating endowment.
The Joint Commission set out to meet that challenge.
"We should do what people do in Mudpuddle, Utah," said Jacqueline Lofaro, a commission member whose elderly parents are regular users of Butterfield. "Make quilts, bake cakes -- it seems like an awfully cheap price for a hospital."
To their surprise, members of the commission found that others in the community did not share their optimism. Business is slow in the antique shops and cafes that are the primary livelihood here, since the flood of weekend tourists ebbed with the recession. Raising the equivalent of $1,000 per person, some residents said, was simply not possible.
"This community cannot raise this kind of money," said Katherine O'Donnell, owner of the Main Street Cafe, where the conversation over eggs and muffins is often about health care. "You have to sell a lot of cupcakes to raise $1.5 million. These are working people."
The commission said the money could be found -- in time. But time was the one thing it did not have.
"We'd gone as far as we could go," said Ms. Lofaro. "But we just couldn't meet the July 1 deadline."
And so the cost of health care in Cold Spring will change soon.
"That's a price of living away from everything," said Shawn Luther, who grew up in Nelsonville and is working at the Hudson Land Company real estate office before he leaves for college in the fall. "You have to drive 15 minutes for shopping. You have to drive 15 minutes for everything. Now you have to drive that far to the hospital. At least it isn't further."

HEADLINE: Cuba Willing to Discuss U.S. Reparations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 15

 BODY:
Cuban officials made a gesture of peace toward the United States today, expressing willingness to negotiate reparations for American properties confiscated in the 1960's.
Cuba also announced today that it had cut the size of its armed forces because of its desperate economic problems. 
 The two announcements, carried by the official Prensa Latina press agency and monitored in Mexico City, indicate the depths of Cuba's economic crisis as well as its hopes of forging a less hostile relationship with the Clinton Administration.
The account did not say how far the military had been or would be cut. Cuba, with 10.8 million people, has about 380,000 regular troops and 1.5 million paramilitary forces, as well as about 65,000 Interior Ministry forces.
Cuba's economy nose-dived after the breakup of the former Soviet Union, its main trading partner and provider of aid.
The president of Cuba's State Committee on Economic Cooperation, Ernesto Melendez, expressed willingness to discuss American claims for payment on properties nationalized by Cuba in the 1960's as part of broader talks on normalizing relations.
President Clinton has not yet shown an interest in such talks.
The State Department said that 5,911 Americans had lost $1.8 billion in the nationalizations, a figure that has grown with inflation and interest to $5 billion to $6 billion.

HEADLINE: James Madison High School's Tradition of Success;
From Cousin Brucie to Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Students and Graduates Earn Top Honors

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
There's plenty of talk at James Madison High School about Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the 1950 graduate who was nominated on Monday to the Supreme Court. But in the halls of the red brick school in southeast Brooklyn these days, there is even more talk about State Regents exams, scholarships, colleges and all the other academic hurdles that are to frame the students' futures.
Just as in Judge Ginsburg's day, James Madison today seems to be a rarity in American education -- an ethnic melting pot of scholastic overachievers, of whom Judge Ginsburg is only one of hundreds who have made names for themselves in the professions and the arts. 
 In the main hall next to the office of the principal, Constance M. Ranieri, for example, is the latest meaningful honor roll. In this case the names of the five James Madison students who won first-place prizes in New York City's 1993 Science Fair: Berenice Belizaire, Anthony Perez, William Kwok, M'Tchaka Warren, and Lisa Wong.
 
Reinforcing Success
 "Sure we feel glad for Judge Ginsburg," said Miss Belizaire, a Haitian immigrant who first spoke English on a daily basis only six years ago. "The kids here realize it's an honor. But it's the sort of distinction that only reinforces our desire to do well in class, and forces us to study when we get home at night."
Indeed Miss Belizaire -- who has won a score of honors at James Madison since arriving from Haiti in 1987, who is the school's current valedictorian and who is now headed for M.I.T. on a scholarship -- would seem to be the updated personification of the 1940's Ruth Bader.
As a student at James Madison, Judge Ginsburg was a star pupil, a cheerleader, the treasurer of the Go-Getters Club, a student pep group, an editor of the student newspaper, and the winner of a number of awards.
James Madison has traditionally labored in the shadow of more famous schools like Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant High School. But administrators and students say community involvement, innovative programs and a history of past success have combined to make James Madison something special. Its dropout rate is less than 6 percent -- a third of the citywide average -- and Miss Ranieri, the principal, said that more than 90 percent of the graduates go on to college.
The school is on Bedford Avenue near the Midwood and Kings Highway sections in a middle-class neighborhood that is so neat it seems to squeak. It is a neighborhood of hard-working families who have high aspirations for their children, and that attitude seems to be reflected in the school's success.
About half the students are black, Hispanic or Asian, with large numbers of recent immigrants from China, Russia and the Caribbean.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat and a James Madison alumnus, said the school "did more for my education than Harvard, which was my next stop."
 
'Steet Smarts'
 "James Madison not only gave me a wonderful education, but going to a big urban high school gives a kid street smarts that put him ahead of the competition in a place like an Ivy League school."
Miss Belizaire, the valedictorian, said, "Yes, Judge Ginsburg might be considered a role model, but a lot of the students here are the sort who want to achieve in life anyway."
In any case, Miss Belizaire has taken life very seriously in her 17 years, resulting in an acceptance at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where she will study computer sciences.
Miss Belizaire grew up in Port-au-Prince speaking Creole and French. She arrived here with her now 19-year old sister, Beatrice Belizaire, who is studying economics at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on a scholarship, and her mother, Rosette Versailles, a nurse at the Green Park Health Center in Brooklyn. The family lives in Hollis, Queens.
It is no accident that James Madison has ties to the fields of law, in which Judge Ginsburg has risen to prominence, and science, in which Miss Belizaire would seem to be heading toward a bright future. Miss Ranieri noted that for many years James Madison has had special ties to Manhattan law firms, like Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, and regional science centers, like Mount Sinai Medical Center.
Joseph Markowitz, 16, a James Madison junior and already the winner of half a dozen science awards, said there seemed to be a community spirit about the school that involves many people in the neighborhood beyond the students and faculty.
Mr. Markowitz knows whereof he speaks, living across the street from the school with his father, Dr. Marvin Markowitz, a retired cardiologist, and his mother, Julie Markowitz, a travel agent.
His sister Jennie is about to graduate and head to the University of Pennsylvania as a prelaw student.
Dr. Markowitz, himself a member of the James Madison Class of 1943, said he was delighted that his children attend the school, adding, "And God willing, my grandchildren will be going to James Madison -- it's a wonderful school."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nordstrom Plans Men's Boutique

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc. removed the wraps yesterday from its plans to open a men's boutique on Fifth Avenue in New York, which may be the first step on a new growth path at the specialty store company.
The boutique, which will open Oct. 1 at Fifth Avenue and 54th Street in the location formerly occupied by Gucci, will be called Faconnable (pronounced fas-o-NA-bleh) and will feature a line of tailored men's clothing, sportswear and furnishings by the same name. It will be Nordstrom's first presence in New York City, although it has three full-line Nordstrom stores in New Jersey. 
 Nordstorm has carried the Faconnable line in 50 of its Nordstrom stores since 1989 under an exclusive licensing agreement with Faconnable, a French apparel manufacturer and retailer. The option to open a Faconnable store as a joint venture with the French company was part of the original licensing agreement.
"Right now, it's the only one planned, but we'll see how it works," said Jack Irving, the executive vice president in charge of Nordstrom's men's division. "Ideally it's just the first one of many."
 
Obstacles to Growth
 Sales at the $3.4 billion retailer have been relatively stagnant, in large part because almost 60 percent of its selling space is on the West Coast, where the economy has gone from bad to worse. But its growth has also been impeded by efforts of competitors to block its entrance into new markets and by the growing pains associated with the company's expansion from its Seattle base.
Nordstrom has been experimenting for more than two years with offshoots of its full-line stores. It has a chain of close-out stores called Nordstrom Rack and it plans to open its first Nordstrom Factory Direct, an outlet store that would carry designer labels and Nordstrom's private-label brands, outside Philadelphia in August.
Mr. Irving said Nordstrom had decided to open the New York store based on the success of the brand in its full-line stores at a time when the men's clothing business, particularly at the high end of the price range, has been anything but brisk. Faconnable shirts sell for between $65 and $75, ties for $55 to $65 and suits for about $1,000.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bad Weather Has Been Very Good for Elcor, But Can It Last?

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
TAKE some folks on a drive through Dallas and at some point, someone may say, "My, don't these homes have nice-looking roofs?"
They certainly do, because a large portion of the housing stock in Dallas was damaged during the last year by huge hailstorms that stripped off hundreds of thousands of roofing tiles, all of which had to be replaced. 
 And of course, when disaster appeared, Wall Street saw opportunity.
Shares of the Elcor Corporation, a Dallas-based maker of roofing tiles, have been, well, going through the roof since last August. The shares, which never topped $16 throughout the booming 1980's, have traded as high as $36.50 this year, more than four times the $8.125-a-share price fetched in July. They closed yesterday at $29.75, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
And small wonder. The hailstorm damage in Dallas, along with damage caused by Hurricane Andrew and fires in Oakland, Calif., helped raise demand for Elcor's products significantly, allowing the company to put through price increases during the slow fall and winter quarters that traditionally see heavy discounting.
Low interest rates chipped in their part as well, as increasing numbers of homeowners took out loans to replace their roofs. Elcor also benefited from an increasing shift toward laminated fiberglass roofing tiles, which it makes, away from the more traditional asphalt or wood tiles.
Those factors showed on the bottom line. In the 1992 fiscal year, which ended June 30, Elcor's revenues jumped almost 16 percent, with some $6.5 million in operating earnings, compared with a loss in 1991. And, as reroofing picked up, operating profits jumped even more, to $16.2 million for the nine months ended June 30.
But does that strong performance signal a major market shift? Or, as some investors and industry executives argue, is Elcor benefiting from the aberrations of heavy storms and low interest rates, which may soon disappear?
Elcor argues for the shift. The company plans a secondary stock offering to build a new roofing-tile plant in California that would increase its manufacturing capacity by 65 percent.
In its registration statement, Elcor predicted significant growth. "The laminated fiberglass asphalt shingle segment is the fastest-growing segment of this marketplace," the company said, adding that the sector grew some 55 percent in 1992 over 1991.
But when the effects of the bad weather are set aside, the industry demand does not seem quite as impressive. "Half of the growth rate, comparing 1991 versus 1992, was because of unusual weather phenomena," said John Sergey, president of the GAF Building Materials Corporation, an Elcor competitor.
Some investors are also not as convinced as Elcor that it will be able to take significant advantage of the growing popularity of laminated tiles in the face of growing competition. "For Elcor to claim that demand is going to keep up, they have to ignore how much capacity is coming on and how easy it is to add capacity," said Charles Biderman, editor of Market Trim Tabs, a Santa Rosa, Calif., newsletter that specializes in short-selling recommendations.
Indeed, executives in the roofing tile industry say that the growing demand for laminated tiles has not only been noticed by Elcor. Numerous companies, including GAF, Owens-Corning Fiberglass and Celotex, are rapidly moving to expand their capacity.
"The industry in total has probably added 60 percent more laminate capacity than existed three years ago, and now that's going to grow even more," said one senior industry executive, speaking on condition of anonymity. "That is a stunning amount of additional capacity for this business, and demand is already slowing substantially. The hailstorm needs have been pretty much satisfied."

HEADLINE: Ex-Kremlin Figure Returns to Power in Azerbaijan

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, June 15

 BODY:
In a remarkable political comeback, a former K.G.B. general, former Communist Party boss and former Politburo member in the Kremlin has maneuvered his way back into power here, saying he is a democrat and promising to turn his native Azerbaijan back from the brink of civil war.
"Let there be no doubt about my purpose," Heydar Aliyev, 70, said in his acceptance speech upon being voted into the office of Chairman of Parliament today. "I will devote the time God has left me to protect the independence of Azerbaijan and promote the rule of law, democratic pluralism and the development of a market economy." 
 Mr. Aliyev also called on a rebel commander whose forces are within 60 miles of the capital to end his revolt, promising that those responsible for bringing the country to the brink of collapse would be punished.
Mr. Aliyev repeatedly referred to the beleaguered President of Azerbaijan, Abulfez Elchibey, as his "host," but the selection of Mr. Aliyev by Parliament is widely regarded as signaling that he has won a struggle for supremacy in the oil-producing former Soviet republic. In the week since he arrived in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, he has waged a campaign against the dwindling authority of the Government, meeting with foreign diplomats, summoning international oil executives and promoting an image of himself as the savior of the country.
But Mr. Aliyev appears to have bowed to United States and other Western official statements of support for the "Government of the democratically elected President." A flight of foreigners involved in the oil industry seems also to have played a role in his decision not to oust Mr. Elchibey.
Whatever the sincerity of his recent embrace of political pluralism and market economics, Mr. Aliyev was almost a perfect child of the Soviet system, even down to the Russification of his first name, which for years was spelled Geidar. After joining the local K.G.B., he made his way up the ranks of the Soviet security forces, achieving the rank of general. In 1969, he was promoted to First Secretary of the Azerbaijani Communist Party and was one of the most faithful members of Leonid I. Brezhnev's inner circle.
 
Dropped by Gorbachev
 In 1981, Mr. Aliyev was brought into the Soviet Politburo by Mr. Brezhnev's successor as Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. He served as Deputy Prime Minister until he was dropped from the inner circle in 1986 by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and branded a corrupt, anti-glasnost hard-liner.
Mr. Aliyev resurfaced in January 1990, when he appeared at a Moscow rally to denounce Mr. Gorbachev for ordering Soviet troops to move into Baku to put down anti-Armenian riots that had actually ended several days before the troops arrived. Resigning from the Communist Party, Mr. Aliyev made a heroic return to Baku as an anti-Soviet Azerbaijani nationalist.
Regarded as suspect by the Communist Party apparatus he once controlled in Baku, Mr. Aliyev set up camp in his native Nakhichevan, an autonomous republic of Azerbaijan that is separated from the rest of the country by Armenia. Becoming chairman of the Nakhichevan legislature, he presided over the introduction of the Latin alphabet to replace the Russian-imposed Cyrillic script and the abolition of Soviet holidays even before the collapse of the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Lawmakers Balk at Anti-Crisis Plan

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 15

 BODY:
The Ukrainian Parliament balked today at President Leonid M. Kravchuk's latest attempt to solve the country's growing economic and political crisis, and gave the Government two days to come up with an emergency economic recovery plan.
As labor unrest continued to spread through eastern Ukraine, Mr. Kravchuk called for parliamentary elections this winter, along with a referendum on his leadership. But that proposal was voted down by Parliament on a vote of 331 to 138, according to the news agency Interfax. 
 Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma, who has repeatedly pressed Parliament for extra powers to stop runaway inflation and push ahead with economic reform, warned today that unless his request was granted, the country could slide into dictatorship within a month.
Mr. Kuchma urged striking miners and industrial workers in the Donbas, a region where a majority of the population is ethnically Russian, to go back to work or else face the prospect of starvation in a few days.
The strikes in the Donbas began after Ukraine was hit with another round of price rises, set off after Russia, its main supplier of gas and oil, increased energy prices. In the first quarter of this year, inflation in Ukraine was 314 percent, more than three times the rate in neighboring Russia.
In Parliament today, Mr. Kuchma accused the miners of staging a "political" strike, and blamed Russia for bringing the Ukrainian economy to a crisis point.
"Russia's position toward Ukraine could hardly be called friendly and normal today," Mr. Kuchma said, according to Interfax. "We are being robbed because of our weakness."
As the weeklong strikes picked up support, some of its leaders have been pressing for greater autonomy for the Donbas, as well as a referendum on the the future of the Kiev Government and its economic policies. This demand was rejected in Parliament today by Ukrainian nationalists, who view an autonomous Donbas as "a violation of the territorial integrity of Ukraine."
Ukraine's quickening political and economic crisis comes at a time when Parliament is scheduled to consider ratification of the first Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty between the United States and the former Soviet Union, which the Ukrainian leadership committed itself to a year ago. Parliament's continued delay in voting on the 1991 treaty, as well as in a related vote to join the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons as a non-nuclear power, has caused anxieties in the West, raising the specter of two nuclear powers -- Russia and Ukraine -- rising from the ruins of the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Kuchma, still fighting to get the emergency powers he says he needs to put economic reforms on track, said Mr. Kravchuk's proposed national referendum should focus on Ukraine's economic as well as political future.
"There should be a referendum with just one question -- what kind of society are we building," Mr. Kuchma said in a fiery speech. He said the powers he was seeking last month -- which would have given him control of the Ukrainian Central Bank, among other things -- were "ordinary, intended for a relatively soft way out of the crisis."
Now, he said, he needs real emergency powers to amend laws and dismiss recalcitrant officials. "If such powers are denied today, dictatorship will be unavoidable in a month," he said.

HEADLINE: Man Kills Boy and Injures 2 With Machete

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROOSEVELT, L.I., June 15

 BODY:
A man whose parents took him in last year after he had spent months living on the streets took a machete this morning and hacked to death his 17-month-old grand-nephew and injured his 3-year-old grand-niece and his father, the Nassau County Police said.
The man, Mark Mitchell, 36, was arrested about 9:20 A.M. as he sat calmly on the steps of his parents' home, across from his bleeding father, Thomas, 67, said Lieut. Frank Guidice. 
 His grand-nephew, Brandon Guzman, was pronounced dead on arrival at Nassau County Medical Center, and his grand-niece, Amber Lee, was in surgery all day as doctors tried to save a leg that had been cut to the bone, Jean Bladykas, a hospital spokeswoman said.
In this suburban neighborhood of modest homes, neighbors said they were not surprised by the crime. They said Mr. Mitchell had a history of bizarre behavior and was an accident waiting to happen.
 
'A Time Bomb'
 They described a troubled young man who often practiced karate in the front yard in his underwear, was in and out of jails and psychiatric institutions and one night built a foxhole in his front yard and shot at imaginary foes with a broomstick.
"He was just a time bomb waiting to go off," a neighbor, Harold McKnight, said.
Lieutenant Guidice said that Mr. Mitchell had been in jail repeatedly since 1986 on misdemeanor and felony charges ranging from harassment and sale of narcotics to assault and burglary. One former neighbor had an order of protection placed against Mr. Mitchell, he added.
Mr. Mitchell apparently attacked the two children and his father after he became irritated with his grand-niece for something she said to him, then struck the girl with his hand, the police said. His mother, Ruth, began to yell at him, and when he argued back, his father joined in and the two began to tussle. He then left and returned with the machete, Lieutenant Guidice said.
Mr. Mitchell was unemployed, and neighbors said he had been unsuccessful for years in his efforts to find work. He had left his parents' home last year, and Lieutenant Guidice said that for a while he had "fallen on hard times" and was "living on the street and moving from residence to residence."
His parents agreed to let him move back in October, and for at least a month he had been sharing the four-bedroom home with his parents, his niece and the two children, the police said.
Neighbors said that over the years Mr. Mitchell's family had been scarred by violence, and they recalled incidents in which they saw Mr. Mitchell hit a sibling or a parent. The police said that two of his brothers had been slain, and Mike DeLouise, a spokesman for Hofstra University in nearby Hempstead, said that a woman who is believed to be Mr. Mitchell's sister killed herself by jumping out of a dormitory window more than 10 years ago, though she was not a student there.
Mr. DeLouise also reported that a Mark Mitchell, who lived at the address where the killing today took place, 318 Park Avenue in Roosevelt, was a student at Hofstra briefly in 1978 and was banned from the campus because of his behavior. The student listed a different birthday than the one Mr. Mitchell today gave the police.
Mr. Mitchell was charged this evening with one count of murder and two counts of attempted murder. He is to be arraigned on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Senator Commands Stage Far Bigger Than Oklahoma by Defying Clinton

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
At home in Oklahoma, Senator David L. Boren was once portrayed by newspaper cartoonists as the Pillsbury Doughboy. In the cloakrooms of the Senate, he was dismissed as a glad-hander who craved approval more than power.
That was before Mr. Boren went on a diet and reassessed his career after the death of his father, an irreverent Democratic Congressman who rebelled against Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Then the Senator took on President Clinton's economic package. 
 More than any other member of Congress, it was Mr. Boren who forced Mr. Clinton to abandon his broad tax on the energy content of fuels. First he threatened to withhold his swing vote on the Senate Finance Committee, and then, breaking an unspoken rule of Congressional conduct, he forcefully lobbied House Democrats to break with their leadership and President.
Further embarrassing the President and infuriating his Democratic colleagues, he is now threatening to withhold his vote unless they cut an additional $50 billion in spending in politically sensitive programs like Medicaid and Medicare.
 
Like Paul Revere?
 His critics -- and there seem to be more every day -- say he is a shill for big oil who is on an ego trip. Mr. Boren compares himself to Paul Revere, saying he is a man with a mission to save President Clinton from the Democratic Party's liberal wing.
The 52-year-old Senator said in an interview on Monday that he expected to reach a compromise with the White House this week. But he added: "If we don't, it wouldn't be the end of the world because we would have to start over again, this time on a bipartisan basis. That could be better for the President and the country, though it would certainly mean an uncomfortable time for me."
It is the exceptional Senator who does not possess a robust sense of his own importance and a willingness to step on toes to promote the interests of his state. But Mr. Boren never before appeared to have the strength of personality to withstand so much criticism and pressure. He has made contradictory public statements the last few weeks, sometimes appearing like his old wavering self, but he keeps coming back to defy the President and his party.
Mr. Boren has made waves before, though they were small, few, and far between. As chairman of the Select Committee on Intelligence, he once sharply criticized President George Bush, accusing him of neglecting to take advantage of a 1989 failed coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. And he broke with his party by voting in favor of the Supreme Court nominations of Robert H. Bork and Clarence Thomas. (He has since said his vote for Judge Thomas was a mistake.)
 
A Larger Stage
 But he is now performing on a far larger stage, and much more is at stake.
Actually, he is trying to perform two contrasting roles at the same time. Even as he locks horns with the President on economic policy, he is Senate floor manager of Mr. Clinton's campaign finance-reform legislation. As a Democrat who works well with Republicans, he can help Mr. Clinton unlock a filibuster on one issue even as he stalls the legislative progress on another.
"I'm sort of a split personality right now," he chuckled at a breakfast with businessmen Wednesday. "When I call the White House, the operator is trained to say, 'Is this the good Boren or the bad Boren?' "
He owes his new "bad Boren" image mostly to the nine Republicans on the Finance Committee who have refused to back the President's economic program. Hence, Mr. Boren is one of 11 Democrats on the committee Mr. Clinton must unanimously carry unless the Democratic leadership takes the highly unusual -- and risky -- tack of bypassing the panel and moving the bill directly to the Senate floor.
"I love the direction he's going," said Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee. "But I don't think the poor devil can get his party there."
 
Colleagues Are Upset
 By contrast, fellow Democrats accuse Mr. Boren of breaking his word to the President that he would stand by him. They note that he first enthusiastically backed Mr. Clinton's budget, and even argued against farm-program spending cuts that would hurt his state. "People just wonder if a lot of the things he does is not for parochial interests," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn.
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said: "There are many of us who are very upset with him. It's obvious he would be more comfortable on the Republican side."
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is the powerful chairman of the Appropriations Committee, is so angry with Mr. Boren that he has discussed with several subcommittee chairmen ways of withholding money for military, farming and Indian-affairs programs in Oklahoma.
Mr. Boren concedes that he favors the interests of Oklahoma, and that he was too quick to speak in favor of Mr. Clinton's economic proposals before he read the fine print. But he says the criticism comes mostly from liberals who are overly committed to spending programs that must be cut if the country is to regain its financial footing and competitiveness.
"People say, 'My God, he's left the back of the bus,' " Mr. Boren said. "I was prepared to ruffle feathers. I didn't go into this with my eyes closed."
 
Invitation to Perot
 The anger is particularly palpable among liberal House Democrats, who resent Mr. Boren for not only intervening in their chamber but also for his efforts at restructuring Congressional procedures and campaign-finance laws. Many were outraged when Mr. Boren earlier this year invited Ross Perot to testify before a joint committee, of which Mr. Boren is co-chairman, to study ways to reform Congressional perquisites and functions, an occasion that the Texas billionaire used to lash out at Congress on network television.
Although Mr. Boren has become increasingly identified with Mr. Perot, he has far more in common with President Clinton. Like the President, Mr. Boren played saxophone in high school and college, attended Yale and was a Rhodes Scholar. A lawyer, he was elected Governor at the age of 34, campaigning against an incumbent Democrat by walking across the state with a broom over his shoulder.
Mr. Boren said he inherited his rebel streak from his father, Lyle Boren, who served in Congress from 1937 to 1947. Though the elder Mr. Boren regularly played poker with Harry S. Truman and Sam Rayburn, he frequently broke with his party, against much of the New Deal and most notably when Roosevelt tried to pack the Supreme Court. He was finally driven from office by a campaign staffed and financed by national labor unions.
 
A Father Remembered
 Mr. Boren's Senate office is virtually a gallery of photographs of his late father, posing at the Oklahoma Hall of Fame, whistle-stopping with Roosevelt and relaxing with Rayburn.
Still, for most of his Senate career, Mr. Boren has been known more for hedging his bets than striking out boldly. Bush Administration lobbyists recall how maddening it was tracking Mr. Boren on the issue of capital gains tax breaks in 1989. From week to week, on the Finance Committee and later on the Senate floor, the Senator went from the Administration position in favor to the Democratic Party in opposition.
Associates close to Mr. Boren say he has become more introspective and self-confident after two epiphanies in the last two years, first when he turned 50 and then when he lost his father last July. For one thing, he has kept on a steady regime of exercise to trim down, and for another, he has taken more time for contemplation while gardening.
Mr. Boren considered the observation, then agreed that he does not care quite as much what people think of him as he used to. "You get more at peace with yourself as you get older," he said. "The one thing my father could say at the end of his life was, 'I don't think I ever ducked taking a stand.' Even though he's not here, I often think about what he would say if he were sitting across the desk."
"Whenever you stick your neck out in a very forceful way, on something that is highly controversial where there are influential members of Congress on the other side, you always run the risk of hurting yourself," Mr. Boren added. "I rarely put myself in a confrontational role. I'm a bridge-builder."
But Mr. Boren started burning bridges last month, on the day President Clinton tried to quell an uprising by House Democrats by dramatically traveling down Pennsylvania Avenue to plead with the Democratic caucus to stand by his program. Just as it appeared that Mr. Clinton had nipped the revolt in the bud, Mr. Boren threw a new obstacle in his way by announcing that a group of moderate Democrats and Republicans had designed an alternative budget plan with more budget cuts and fewer taxes.
The next day, Mr. Boren walked over to the House side of the Capitol to buck up moderate and conservative Democrats who were wavering under the intense White House lobbying. His tactics stood in stark contrast with those of Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, the other oil-state Finance Committee swing vote, who lobbied House members in favor of Mr. Clinton's package, promising that changes would come later in the legislative process.
"A tough-guy image is not what I'm looking for," Mr. Boren said. "I'd like to be quietly strong."

HEADLINE: House Passes Bill to Ban Replacement of Strikers

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
The House voted today to prohibit employers from hiring permanent replacements for union members who strike, but Senate Republicans immediately said they would stage a filibuster to kill the measure, organized labor's biggest legislative priority.
The same legislation passed the House last year but was killed by filibuster in the Senate. Its prospects appear somewhat better this year, largely because President Clinton favors the bill and could sway some crucial Democratic Senators. 
 The highly partisan six-hour debate in the House centered on the philosophical questions of what role organized labor should play in American society and what role Government should play in balancing the interests of labor and management during strikes.
While liberals said strong unions were necessary to protect the wages, pensions and health benefits of workers, several conservatives compared big unions to dinosaurs whose extinction would strengthen small business and create more jobs.
 
Trying to Halt Decline
 The House voted 239 to 190 to pass the bill, with 221 Democrats, 17 Republicans and one independent in favor and 33 Democrats and 157 Republicans opposed. The total supporting the bill fell 8 short of the 247 members who favored it last year.
Organized labor says passage of the bill, called the Cesar Chavez Workplace Fairness Act, is needed to reverse the sharp decline in membership and influence that unions experienced in the 1980's. Labor advocates note that the hiring of permanent replacement workers has become more frequent in recent years, like in the highly publicized strikes at International Paper and Greyhound. Businesses hired permanent replacement workers in nearly one of five strikes reported to the Federal Government from 1985 to 1989.
Business groups like the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers are lobbying against the measure, arguing that it would unwisely tilt the balance of power in contract negotiations to the unions' favor.
The measure would apply only to companies where a labor group is recognized by the employer or the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive representative of the workers in negotiations.
"What good is the right to strike if when you do the boss fires you?" asked Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana. "Those members who oppose this bill are for bosses firing workers for striking."
 
Republicans See Dilemma
 House Republicans criticized the legislation as a "strike-maker bill" that would provoke more labor unrest, lower productivity and trade competitiveness, as well as increase prices for consumers.
"If employers who are faced with unreasonable demands from a union cannot consider hiring permanent replacements, even as a last resort" said Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, "many businesses will be faced with a Hobson's choice of either closing down altogether or agreeing to potentially outrageous demands."
Representative Cass Ballenger, Republican of North Carolina, said the bill "would grant big union bosses powers to paralyze small business and the American economy unseen since Jimmy Hoffa began pushing up daisies under the 50-yard line."
But the real battle will be fought next month in the Senate, where Republicans have far more power than in the House because of their ability to filibuster. Last year, supporters of the bill fell three votes short of the 60 needed to shut off debate.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, said "there will be a real filibuster" to kill the legislation. He predicted that the vote on stopping the filibuster would be very close.
Unions are pressing Mr. Clinton to make a concerted effort to win Senate passage. Two of the five Democratic Senators who voted against ending the filibuster last year were Senators Dale Bumpers and David Pryor of Arkansas, who normally try to support Mr. Clinton when he asks. Their aides said Mr. Pryor was undecided while Mr. Bumpers remained steadfast in his opposition to the legislation.

HEADLINE: On Privacy and Equality;
Judge Ginsburg Still Voices Strong Doubts on Rationale Behind Roe v. Wade Ruling

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Standing by President Clinton's side on Monday afternoon as the first Supreme Court nominee of a Democratic President in a generation, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg relied on an unlikely source to explain her judicial philosophy to a public that knew her scarcely, if at all.
She approvingly quoted Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, a bete noire to Democrats for most of that time, as saying that a good judge is bound to apply the facts and the law to come up with a decision, even if it is "not what the home crowd wants." 
 It was a telling choice of a quotation that underscored Judge Ginsburg's own seemingly anomalous role as both an authentic heroine in the legal battle for women's rights and a prominent critic of what many see as the crowning accomplishment of that battle, the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade that established a constitutional right to abortion.
Her criticism of the 1973 decision, expressed over the years but most notably in a lecture at New York University Law School three months ago, has somewhat discomfited her home crowd of feminist lawyers and other leaders of the women's movement. Sound bites suggesting that her commitment to abortion rights is something less than unwavering have been the inevitable result.
 
Divided on Approach
 The difference is not over the ultimate goal of a right to abortion fully anchored in the Constitution and secure against political undermining. Rather, Judge Ginsburg's lecture reflects a long-running debate about whether that goal could have been better achieved by another route, as a matter both of constitutional doctrine and judicial strategy, and over what lessons to draw from the tortuous history of abortion rights in the 20 years since Roe v. Wade was decided.
Judge Ginsburg's critique of Roe v. Wade is twofold. First, she said in the New York University lecture, as she has written for years, the right to abortion might have been more secure had it been grounded in the concept of women's right to equality rather than in the right to privacy. "The Roe decision might have been less of a storm center," she said, had it "homed in more precisely on the women's-equality dimension of the issue."
Given the fact that the right to privacy has become little more than a code word for abortion in current political discourse, it might appear startling to divorce abortion from privacy and seek a home for abortion rights elsewhere in the Constitution.
 
The Notion of Equality
 But the equality argument for abortion rights -- essentially the notion that women cannot participate in society equally with men without the ability to control their reproductive lives -- was in fact part of the abortion-rights movement from its earliest years. An equality argument was among the arguments presented to the Court in Roe v. Wade.
While Justice Harry A. Blackmun's majority opinion took a different path, a theoretical debate continued in academic legal circles throughout the next decade. Judge Ginsburg, who as a litigator arguing cases before the Supreme Court had helped create the modern constitutional law of women's equality, continued to press for equality.
The argument at times became bitter because of a new element: the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution. Some leaders of the long and ultimately unsuccessful campaign for the amendment were concerned that too close a link between equality and abortion would pose a political threat to the E.R.A. by driving away potential supporters of the amendment who did not share the abortion-rights agenda.
In any event, long after the equal rights amendment died and the argument faded into history, it was the Supreme Court itself that revived the equality basis for abortion rights in its ruling last year in Planned Parenthood v. Casey, the Pennsylvania case in which the Court reaffirmed the right to abortion.
 
Sticking to the 'Core'
 Among the reasons that Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter gave in their opinion for adhering to the "core" of Roe v. Wade was a sentence that could have been written by Judge Ginsburg: "The ability of women to participate equally in the economic and social life of the nation has been facilitated by their ability to control their reproductive lives."
The second part of Judge Ginsburg's critique concerns the scope of Roe v. Wade, and it is this part that has made some abortion-rights leaders, including Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights Action League, somewhat wary. Judge Ginsburg has argued that by issuing a broad ruling that swept most state abortion laws off the books, the Court created an inherently vulnerable precedent that led to a backlash and short-circuited a liberal trend then under way in the states.
While her New York University lecture discussed Roe v. Wade specifically, her critique reflected a more general approach to judging and to the development of the law. "Measured motions seem to me right, in the main, for constitutional as well as common-law adjudication," she said. "Doctrinal limbs too swiftly shaped, experience teaches, may prove unstable." She praised the Court's opinion last year in Planned Parenthood v. Casey for opening a "renewed dialogue" between the states and the Court.
Marcy Wilder, senior staff lawyer for the abortion-rights league, said in an interview today, "When she says that Roe went too far and that Casey is progress, we have to know whether she's saying that a lesser standard of protection for abortion is a better standard." Ms. Wilder said it was far from clear historically that most states would have liberalized their abortion laws significantly on their own.
 
'Vision of the Future'?
 Helen Neuborne, executive director of the NOW Legal Defense and Educational Fund, also took issue with the notion that a more gradual approach by the Court might have avoided political fallout from the anti-abortion side. There are many possible explanations for the events of the last 20 years, Ms. Neuborne said, including a failure by abortion-rights groups to protect their court victories by early grass-roots organizing.
"These are very complicated issues," Ms. Neuborne said. "She believes that incremental in the long run wins the race. Some of us want everything all the time, all the way. It's a legitimate discussion. Her vision may be the vision of the future. Her gift may be to be able to build and hold the middle of the Court, to accomplish our goals in her style."
This somewhat abstract debate over style and approach will become concrete soon enough if Judge Ginsburg is confirmed. On abortion, for example, the Court has a substantial amount of unfinished business before it in defining the standard the Casey opinion adopted for judging state restrictions on abortion.
The Court said last year that state regulations must not place an "undue burden" on women's access to abortion. By the Court's next term or soon after that, the Justices will be confronted with abortion regulations that have had full trials under the new standard and that pose the question of what burdens are actually "undue."
Judge Ginsburg's written work leaves unclear how she will approach this second-generation abortion debate, and which abortion restrictions she would be most likely to strike down. Justice Byron R. White, to whose seat Judge Ginsburg has been named, never voted to strike down any.

HEADLINE: N.E. Auerbach Dies; Oversaw the Growth Of Accounting Firm

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Norman E. Auerbach, who as a World War II veteran in need of a job became an accountant at Coopers & Lybrand at the age of 27 and retired 35 years later as chairman, died Sunday at Tucson Medical Center in Arizona. A Tucson resident and former New Yorker, he was 73.
The cause was a heart attack, said his son, Dr. Gary A. Auerbach of Tucson. 
 When he reached mandatory retirement age in 1982, Coopers & Lybrand laid claim to being the world's largest accounting and consulting concern. By then the firm, which has headquarters in Manhattan, had 450 offices worldwide, 27,000 employees to staff them and revenues of nearly $1 billion a year. Now its worldwide revenues are $5 billion.
Mr. Auerbach, a native of Minneapolis, arrived at the University of Michigan in the midst of the Depression with $25 in his pocket. He earned his degree in economics and served in World War II, commanding a supply ship in the Pacific.
He then finished his master's in business at Michigan and shelved his plan to practice law. Instead, he found work at what in 1947 still was Lybrand, Ross Brothers & Montgomery, took his law degree several years later at St. John's University and was admitted to the New York bar. By then his accounting career had taken off. Before his election as chairman and chief executive at Coopers & Lybrand in 1976, he was the firm's associate managing partner.
After his retirement in 1982 he turned to his first ambition, the law, and joined his sons Roger and Richard in their Tucson practice.
Besides his three sons, Mr. Auerbach is survived by his wife of 51 years, the former Judy Genden; a brother, Milton, also of Tucson; three sisters, Evelyn Mandelcorn of Los Angeles, Esther Sahr of Schenectady, N.Y., and Sally Steinberg of East Schodack, N.Y., and five grandchildren.

The Economy
Consumer prices inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in May, all but burying inflation fears. The report, combined with last week's data showing no inflation at the producer level, was seen as proving that price jumps earlier this year were temporary. [Page D1.]
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 15.5 percent in early June, indicating that the auto industry recovery continues. [D13.] 
 Preserving the 80 percent tax deduction for business meals is the goal of lobbying by the National Restaurant Association. [A1.]
The President suggested he would stay out of the budget debate until the measure gets into a House-Senate conference. [A21.]

Companies
Honda Motor is stumbling -- still profitable, but not the powerhouse it once was -- hurt by a strong yen that is forcing up prices and by the many Detroit models that are flourishing on the strength of improved quality and creative design. [D1.]

International

HEADLINE: Manhattan Company Is Coaxed Away

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Claiming another prize in the regional battle for jobs, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut announced yesterday that the Witco Corporation, a Manhattan-based manufacturer, was moving its headquarters -- and 800 jobs -- to a vacant office building in Greenwich. The state is providing Witco with $8 million in grants.
Mr. Weicker took the occasion to defend the state's aggressive economic development campaign and to respond to remarks this week by Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich, who said the states should stop using grants to compete with one another and instead spend the money on schools, roads and bridges. 
 "I would suggest, considering the state of affairs in the Clinton Administration, that Reich should keep his comments to Washington," Mr. Weicker said.
Praising the State Legislature and his commissioners for working to improve the state's economy, he added, "We would appreciate it, sooner rather than later, if the biggest player got on the field and started helping the rest of us tackle this recession."
 
Increase in Region's Jobs
 He made his comments at a news conference in Hartford with William R. Toller, the chairman of Witco, who said the company will move to Greenwich next year. The company, based in Manhattan for more than 40 years, will occupy a huge office building built in the 1970's by the American Can Company on 155 forested acres.
While the move involves government inducements that have become increasingly common in the interstate competition between New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, officials said it was unusual because it will result in an overall gain in employment for the region.
Witco, a manufacturer of chemicals and petroleum products, said the Greenwich headquarters would consolidate operations now based in several states. It said its New York City staff of 200 will make the move, as will 400 workers based in Woodcliff, N.J., and 200 others from Kansas, Illinois, Ohio and other states.
The announcement yesterday followed three decades in which the headquarters of major New York City companies have migrated to northern New Jersey, Westchester County and Connecticut, and in which the financial inducements offered by the city and its suburban competitors have grown richer.
At City Hall, officials said yesterday that they had approached Witco earlier this year about keeping its headquarters in Manhattan, but that the company had already decided to leave and that no financial incentives from the city were discussed.
The inducements provided by Connecticut "demonstrate more clearly than ever how competitive the market has become," said Catie Marshal, a spokeswoman for New York City's Economic Development Corporation.
"Its shows what lengths a state like Connecticut, which has been very badly hurt by the economy, will go to take our jobs," she added.
 
Deciding Factor
 Mr. Toller said the money offered by Connecticut was a deciding factor for Witco, whose best-known consumer product is Kendall motor oil. With 8,400 employees around the world and annual sales of over $2 billion, the company was ranked as the nation's 242d-largest industrial concern by Fortune magazine last year.
Economic development officials said half of the $8 million would be used to refurbish the Greenwich building. The other half can be used by Witco however it chooses, but there is a catch -- unless the company retains at least 800 employees in Greenwich for 10 years, it must pay back part of the money to the state.
The provision is intended to avoid subsidizing a company that might reduce its payroll or shed operations soon. It is similar to requirements incorporated by New York City in recent "retention packages" that have been extended to big companies.
 
Provision Not Unusual
 In the most recent case, the Dinkins administration announced this month that it had persuaded Mastercard International, which had threatened to move its headquarters and 450 workers from Manhattan to White Plains, to stay in Manhattan, but only in exchange for tax credits.
The city said Mastercard would receive $2 million in tax credits, but would be required to keep at least 450 workers in Manhattan for 10 years. And, as an inducement to invest more in the city, it said Mastercard would receive as much as $8 million in grants if it doubled its Manhattan employment over the next decade.
A larger package of city incentives was accepted last year by Morgan Stanley & Company, which had threatened to move to Stamford. In that case, the city is providing tax breaks worth $39.6 million, but only if the company retains its current work force of 4,100 in Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn for 10 years.
 
Long-Vacant Building
 The building Witco plans to move into has been vacant for years, and described by some in Greenwich as a corporate white elephant.
It was built in the 1960's by American Can, then a packing goods manufacturer, which overcame widespread apprehension among Greenwich residents to put its headquarters on pristine land along the town's border with Westchester County.
But less than five years after American Can moved in, it began disposing of manufacturing operations, shedding workers, and turning itself into a financial services company with roots far deeper on Wall Street than in Greenwich.
In the early 1980's, American Can renamed itself the Primerica Corporation, and left Greenwich.

HEADLINE: Sales of Domestic Vehicles Continue Gains

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 15

 BODY:
The auto industry's recovery that began in early April appears to be continuing, according to the nation's auto makers, which reported today that sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 15.5 percent in early June.
Sales of cars built in North America rose 8.8 percent between June 1 and June 10 from the similar period last year, to 203,304. Sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans, pickups and sport-utility vehicles, rose 25.4 percent, to 157,156. Over all, vehicle sales totaled 360,460. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of domestic car sales was 6.8 million, up from 6.5 million a year earlier, but down from 7 million in late May. Light trucks sold at an annualized rate of 5.2 million, compared with 4.5 million in the comparable period last year.
 
Gains in Annualized Rate
 The broader annual rate of total vehicle sales was about 14.7 million, according to an estimate by David Healy, automotive analyst of S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. His estimate compares with total sales of about 13.1 million vehicles in 1992, considered a poor year.
"These are strong numbers, especially for the first 10 days of the month," Mr. Healy said. "We've got a real recovery." He added that the strong auto sales conflicted with surveys that had suggested consumers did not have enough confidence in the economy to purchase new vehicles.
Many dealers continued to offer incentives like low-rate financing and leasing.
"We have a philosophy that car sales are happening all over the country regardless of the economy," said Pete Franklin, general sales manager of Chris Auffenberg Chevrolet in St. Louis. "There are always people who want to buy. If you're aggressive enough, you can attract the buyer."
Earlier this week, Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter, said that early June sales could signal whether auto makers will be able to maintain robust production through September.
Domestically produced vehicles are those produced in North America regardless of whether the maker is foreign or domestic.
Sales by the Big Three auto makers were up 15.8 percent in early June, compared with a 12.5 percent gain for Japanese companies that build cars and trucks in North America.
 
Strong Chevrolet Model
 The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, sold 92,652 cars in early June, a 1.3 percent increase from last year. G.M.'s light-truck sales were 59,597, an increase of 25.6 percent. The Chevrolet Cavalier, whose price was reduced, was a hot seller, up 44.6 percent with sales of 10,576.
The Ford Motor Company's car sales rose 9.1 percent, to 56,123, while Ford's light-truck sales rose 21.8 percent, to 50,650.
The Chrysler Corporation does not report 10-day sales, but Ward's estimated that Chrysler's car sales were 25,100, up 50.5 percent, and light-truck sales were 39,800, up 28.2 percent.
The Honda Motor Company posted domestic car sales of 8,538, down 22.7 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation's domestic car sales rose 37.5 percent, to 10,473, while Toyota's light-truck sales more than doubled to 2,004. The Nissan Motor Company's car sales more than doubled to 5,389, while its light-truck sales rose 30.5 percent, to 3,214.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed in Ho-Hum Reaction to Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The release yesterday of consumer price figures for May confirmed for the stock market what it already knew: higher inflation is not currently a threat.
Trading was mixed, with blue-chip issues down and the broader market showing a little more strength than the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 Traders said the release of data showing that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in May confirmed last week's report on producer prices showing little in the way of inflationary pressure. As a result, they said, the market shifted gears yesterday to look ahead to the triple-witching hour on Friday, when options on individual stocks, index options and futures all expire.
 
 
'The Standard Sell'
 "There was the standard sell on the news reaction to the C.P.I., as the market, in anticipation of a good report, had run up stocks a few days beforehand, buying on rumor," said Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst at MMS International, a Wall Street economic analysis and research firm. "So when the number was released yesterday, investors quickly sold. Then there was, of course, some selling related to the approaching triple witch on Friday."
The Dow fell 22.69 points, to 3,492, with 234.1 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, up from 216.2 million on Monday. Gainers outnumbered losers by a very small margin.
The report on consumer prices lifted bond prices in the morning and helped support equities. But when the bond market rally faded, so did stocks.
The Nasdaq composite gained 0.93 point, to 697.34, and the American Stock Exchange index added 0.27 point, to 435.47. But the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 1.44 points to finish at 446.27 and the New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 0.50 point, to 245.92.
Noting how the broader market had recently outperformed the Dow, Mr. Walberg predicted that the Dow would remain in a range of between 3,480 and 3,530 in the next few weeks.
 
 
Airlines Weak
 Airlines remained weak yesterday amid worries over the impact of proposed fuel tax. Airline stocks have been among the most skittish sectors of late, traders noted. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 1 1/8, to 130 3/4; Delta Air Lines dropped 5/8, to 51 3/8, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, lost 1/2, to 68.
Among big losers of the day that dragged down the Dow were I.B.M., which lost 2 1/8, to 49 7/8; Eastman Kodak, down 1 3/8, to 52 3/8, after announcing the spinoff of its chemical group, and Du Pont,which lost 1 3/4, to 49 3/4.
Shares of the International Business Machines Corporation fell on a Salomon Brothers report that more restructuring charges and a further dividend cut were likely. John B. Jones Jr., an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said that I.B.M. could announce $4 billion to $5 billion in restructuring charges on July 27, the day its board meets to review the quarter dividend. Also, there is a good chance for a further cut in the dividend, Mr. Jones noted in his report. I.B.M. declined to comment.
Du Pont shares fell after a Goldman, Sachs analyst lowered the chemical company's rating. The analyst also lowered his estimates for 1993 and 1994 earnings.
National Semiconductor gained 1/2, to 15 3/4, after reporting stronger fourth-quarter earnings of 35 cents a share, compared with 22 cents for the quarter a year earlier.
Advanced Micro Devices, which is developing a new family of chips that do not use the contested Intel Corporation copyright, was up 3/8, to 21 3/4, in active trading. Intel, which won a recent battle in California state appeals court and is now pressing a copyright case seeking millions of dollars in damages from Advanced Mirco, rose 5/8, to 57 3/4.
Shares of Pepsico fell 5/8, to 35 5/8. The soft-drink maker said it had so far confirmed only four cases of syringes in Pepsi-Cola cans. The company said it was willing to order a recall but that it had been advised not to do so by the Food and Drug Administration because it might hamper the investigation.

HEADLINE: Despite Farm Pact, France Still Talks Tough on Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Despite recent indications that France was seeking to be more accommodating in international trade talks, its Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, said today that he could not accept an international trade agreement that would hurt the French economy.
Last week, France agreed to an agricultural agreement between Europe and the United States that reduced production of the European Community's oilseed crops. But Mr. Balladur said today that this did not mean that France would automatically acquiesce to calls for Europe to shrink the amount of subsidized grain it exports. 
 The reduction in Europe's production of oilseed crops, like soybeans, was negotiated in Washington last November during two days of talks between American and European Community representatives. France had threatened to veto the portion of the accord dealing with oilseed crops. But at a meeting of European foreign ministers in Luxembourg, France said it would go along with the deal.
 "I think it is important that our country should make a gesture concerning the agreement on oilseeds," Mr. Balladur told a few reporters in his hotel suite before his first meeting with President Clinton. "I did this deliberately because I consider that this was an agreement that did not harm the interest of the French economy."
But Mr. Balladur added: "I did this to indicate that my attitude is a very open one. But open does not mean that France should be capable of accepting an agreement that she would consider harmful to her interests."
Mr. Balladur's tough talk indicates that the Clinton Administration still faces a formidable task in gaining French agreement to a farm accord that would be part of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. As part of the negotiations on GATT, France is seeking a number of other concessions from the United States, including greater access to the American financial services market.
 Indeed, in what seemed to be part of Mr. Balladur's attempt to play hardball, he hinted today that while he preferred to see a GATT agreement concluded, the failure to reach an accord might not be so harmful to world economic growth.
"I'll tell really what I have in the back of my mind," he said through an interpreter. "When I read somewhere that one has to have an agreement because that would produce $200 billion a year of growth, no one really knows this; no one can prove that. I note the fact that in recent years -- five or six years ago -- we had a very good level of growth, whereas GATT was still under discussion."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Speculation About Cut in German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar jumped nearly two pfennigs yesterday in a broad rally touched off by speculation that Germany's central bank would cut interest rates this week.
As waves of dollar-buying swept the New York market, the dollar bounced off record lows against the Japanese yen reached earlier during Asian trading, where global currency activity begins. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6460 marks, from 1.6285 marks late Monday. The dollar also rebounded to 105.75 yen, up from late Monday's 105.10 yen. In Tokyo trading earlier yesterday, the dollar had fallen as low as 104.85 yen.
 
 
Signal From the Bundesbank
 Many currency traders expect the Bundesbank to lower one of its shortest-term rates during its regular weekly money-market operations today in an effort to revive Germany's economy. A decrease would be taken as a signal that the central bank planned to lower another benchmark short-term rate during its biweekly policy-making meeting tomorrow.
That, in turn, would help the dollar, since lower German interest rates would make mark-denominated investments less attractive.
The speculation of a German rate cut overshadowed anxiety over a report that American inflation remained under control last month. The Labor Department report showed consumer prices edged up only one-tenth of 1 percent in May.
Ordinarily, a report of low American inflation would deflate expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates to combat inflation. Higher domestic rates would increase the dollar's value.
The dollar's rise also seemed tied to reports that the American merchandise-trade figures for April, due out tomorrow, would show a narrowing of the United States trade deficit with Japan.
That seemed to relieve some pressure for a stronger yen. In theory, a higher yen would help trim the American trade deficit by making Japanese products more expensive abroad while decreasing the cost of imports to Japan.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Show a Decline; Gold and Silver Up Sharply

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Concern over ample supplies of crude oil and oil products weighed on futures contracts yesterday, sending prices lower.
Gold and silver prices surged in what analysts described as a technical rebound from recent weakness. 
 Crude oil for July delivery dropped 31 cents, to $18.58 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. July unleaded gasoline fell 0.61 cent, to 53.93 cents a gallon, and July heating oil declined 0.45 cent, to 52 cents a gallon.
 Traders had expected that the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute on domestic supplies, released after the close of trading, would prove negative to the market. But the report said gasoline was down by 1.04 million barrels, confounding expectations that inventories would rise, with refinery utilization remaining high.
Oil prices have been sliding since last week, when a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended with a nervous agreement that was rejected by Kuwait.
 
'Lack of Anything Bullish'
 "To blame all of this on OPEC isn't all of it," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil, an energy trading company. "What's important now is that refinery runs are so high. With the lack of anything bullish out there, the market has no recourse but to go lower."
Trading at the five commodity exchanges in the World Trade Center in New York was halted twice in the morning for a total of about two hours because of technical problems.
 At the Commodity Exchange, the actively traded contract for August gold rose $4.20, to $370.80 an ounce, while July silver advanced 7 cents, to $4.288 an ounce.
"It appears to be all short-covering," said one analyst of the market's defiance of a strong dollar and fresh signs that inflation was in check. The Consumer Price Index for May rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent.
