HEADLINE: How Honda Slipped From Its Perch

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 15

 BODY:
Honda. For years the name struck fear and awe into the American auto industry.
But with a strong yen forcing up prices and with many Detroit models flourishing on the strength of improved quality and creative design, the Honda Motor Company is stumbling -- still profitable, but not the powerhouse it once was. 
 From 1989 through last December, for example, Honda's Accord was the best-selling car in the United States, and the company's smaller Civic and sporty Prelude also sold well. Honda was in the forefront of companies that were shifting production to the United States, reducing costs through efficient production techniques and exporting cars back to Japan. And Honda, with the Acura, was the first Japanese auto maker to bring luxury cars to America.
But now sales of most Honda models are tepid. Only months after the Accord was barely edged out by Ford's Taurus for honors as the best-selling car of 1992, sales of Accords have plunged almost 35 percent, and this year the car is not even in the top five.
Even worse for Honda, the company, once so canny, was caught flat-footed in the fast-growing markets for mini-vans and four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicles, which many Americans now buy as a substitute for cars. Honda, alone among the large auto makers, offers no competition for Chrysler's successful mini-vans or Jeeps and their many competitors.
Few auto industry people believe Honda's wounds are mortal, and Honda itself says a wave of new designs will soon rekindle its growth and popularity. Indeed, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, Honda's president, has been exhorting staff members to set their sights high and surpass the much larger Nissan Motor Company as the No. 2 Japanese auto maker, after Toyota, by the end of the decade. That would require higher sales in the United States, Honda's largest market.
Indeed, Honda's decline has been so swift and unexpected that automotive rivals, particularly Detroit's Big Three, cannot quite figure why the tables have turned. Indeed, a stunned American auto industry is not quite willing to believe the sky has opened to drop a house on the wicked witch.
Honda "didn't get dumb overnight," said Arthur C. Liebler, vice president for public relations at the Chrysler Corporation, adding, "They will be back."
Like Honda, Nissan and the Toyota Motor Corporation have been hurt by the strong yen and the worldwide economic slump. The yen's value against the dollar has increased 15 percent in 1993 alone, forcing the Japanese to raise prices more sharply than overseas competitors to maintain profit margins. Last week, six of Japan's nine big auto makers reported their earnings for the last fiscal year, and collectively they were down 76 percent.
But the strong yen does not fully explain the problems at Honda, which was the only major Japanese auto maker with declining sales in the United States in 1992. That forced Honda to cut back production at its plants in Marysville, Ohio, and in Japan. And this year has been no better. In May, for instance, Honda's sales were flat, while Toyota sold 12 percent more cars and 15 percent more light trucks than in May 1992. Nissan sold 24 percent more cars and 48 percent more trucks.
Theories abound about why Honda is stumbling, but no one questions the quality of its cars. Rather, many people in the automotive industry say, Honda has had more difficulty than most auto makers in keeping up with changing tastes and demographics.
"The other models are just getting better, and the service at other dealerships is getting better, too," said George Peterson, president of AutoPacific Inc., an automotive marketing company in Santa Ana, Calif.
 
 
Early Emphasis on Value
 In Honda's early days in the American market -- the mid-1970's -- the marketing message focused on value, emphasizing practicality and a low price, said Leon Mandel, editor of Auto Week magazine. Many of Honda's first buyers were young, and they bucked the conventional wisdom that Detroit's cars were best.
Initially, Honda's pricing reflected the low cost of efficient manufacturing and the yen's weakness. The dollar was worth 242 yen before the Plaza Accord was reached in 1985, under which the United States and its allies reduced the dollar's value, hoping to increase American exports and ease the nation's trade deficit. Now the dollar has sunk to about 106 yen, so a dollar has less than half the buying power it used to have for Japanese goods.
By moving some manufacturing to the United States, Honda avoided some currency-related cost increases. Still the base price of its four-door Civic, $8,175 in 1985, had risen to $11,280 in 1993.
In 1990, an Accord sold for less than $16,000, less than the American cars with which it competed; today it sells for nearly $19,000, more than its Big Three rivals. While Honda has never resorted to steep discounting, it is now offering a $239-a-month lease on the Accord, a subsidized rate roughly equivalent to a $1,100 rebate.
Honda has nearly 16,000 employees in the United States, and dealers in every state. Unlike other auto makers, Honda also sells motorcycles -- more than any other company in the United States -- lawn mowers and generators. But more than 80 percent of Honda's business remains in car sales.
Indeed, the popularity of Hondas in their heyday may have set the stage for questionable practices, now the subject of a criminal investigation. In the last year, some Honda dealers have accused some of Honda's American sales and marketing executives of accepting bribes and kickbacks as payment for diverting extra cars to them. Several executives have resigned.
As Honda grew in the United States, its perspective changed from niche marketer to mass marketer, said John Wolkonowicz, an analyst for Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting company in Boston.
"Honda started looking at who its customers were and saw my 65-year-old uncle and an 18-year-old college girl and everyone in between," he said.
But this larger audience seems to have brought more conservative judgments. New models were designed to satisfy several demographic groups, insuring that they would excite none of them, Mr. Wolkonowicz said. "The best example of this is the Accord," he said. "It is one bland machine. It does everything well, but it doesn't excite."
 
 
Civic Sales Are Up
 One bright light for Honda has been the Civic, which was redesigned for 1992; its sales have increased 30 percent this year. Accord sales, meanwhile, are down about the same amount. On the other hand, sales of the redesigned Prelude, Honda's two-door sports coupe, have fallen by more than 30 percent this year.
As a relatively small auto maker, Honda has far less capital than some rivals and has always expanded its line very deliberately. As a result, in an extraordinary gaffe, it missed out on the booming market for mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles, which now account for more than 37 percent of all sales of cars and trucks. Many satisfied owners of Accords or Civics undoubtedly traded for Chrysler mini-vans as their families grew and they needed a vehicle that could haul half of a Little League team.
"We still have a problem with too little plant capacity," said Jeff Leestma, a spokesman for the American Honda Motor Company, the United States sales subsidiary. "People see us as this huge company, but we don't have the physical ability to be a full-line manufacturer."
 
 
At Last, a Utility Vehicle
 Next year, Honda will finally bring out a sport-utility vehicle, a version of the Isuzu Rodeo that Isuzu will build. A mini-van, which Honda will build itself, is rumored to be in the works as well. Honda executives declined to discuss their plans.
Even when Honda broadened its line, adding the Accord station wagon in late 1990, the company stumbled. Honda's stab at a multipurpose vehicle has not impressed car buyers, and at nearly $20,000 it was pricey and remains so compared with its competition.
"The wagon was worth our while," Mr. Leestma insisted. "It has become popular in export markets." In two years on the American market, Honda has sold about 40,000 Accord station wagons.
In luxury cars, Honda actually led the Japanese into the American market. The Acura division, opened in 1986, won high marks, and the Legend and the smaller Integra put a big dent in a segment that BMW and Mercedes-Benz had starred in. But sales have been sliding since 1991, damaged principally by Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti.
 
 
Rapid Price Increases
 The Integra, to be replaced by a new version in a few months, was built for customers in the 20-something age group, the so-called baby-busters. But now, "busters don't have the money for the Integra," which costs about $19,000 typically equipped, said Bob Hall, a product planner for the Mazda Motor Corporation in Irvine, Calif. The Integra's price has gone up faster than the baby-busters' incomes.
Acura's larger Legend was aimed squarely at somewhat older, affluent baby-boomers. But many customers came to prefer an even bigger, more powerful luxury car. The introduction of the Infiniti Q45 and the Lexus LS 400 gave them a choice, said William Jeanes, senior vice president in charge of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines Inc.'s automotive group. "You could say Acura should have built a bigger car," he said. "But Honda is quite a small company and can't do everything."
For the fall, Honda plans a new Acura Integra, then a substantially redesigned Accord, its first since the 1990 model year. It is unclear whether Honda will take a conservative approach, with only incremental improvements over the current model, or whether it will make a bold departure. Toyota, for instance, redesigned its Camry with a more expressive look, and it offers a choice of engines. Will the Accord follow suit or will it stay with a four-cylinder engine while rivals offer six? Will Honda's styling remain muted rather than bold?
"Maybe success breeds conservatism," Mr. Jeanes said. "That's the way it was with Americans."
Perhaps. Detroit's auto executives, whose companies lost billions during downturns, are not betting against Honda, noting that even in its slump, the company remained profitable. Though worldwide revenue declined 6 percent, to $35.5 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, and Honda's profit declined 41 percent, the result was still a profit of $329 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
No-Smoke Ways to 'Burn' Wastes

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Everybody agrees that toxic wastes are nasty. But getting rid of them has become increasingly difficult as environmentalists and regulators have recognized the danger of stashing pesticide residues, chemical industry leftovers and paint sludges in landfills, where the toxins can seep into public water supplies.
Unfortunately, one of the few alternatives to dumping, the incinerator, also has a flaw: the smokestack. As waste is burned, hot gases spew into the atmosphere, carrying with them any toxic materials not consumed by the flames. The Clinton Administration recently imposed a ban on new hazardous-waste incinerators. 
 And so developers see commercial opportunities for two distinctly different technologies that are now emerging from the laboratory and moving to pilot plants.
Both approaches eliminate toxic wastes by exposing them to intense heat in closed vessels, breaking the materials down into simple, safe compounds with virtually no emissions. One method effectively "burns" them in water; the other uses a bath of molten metal to reduce complex chemicals to their elemental constituents.
The first technique depends on the phenomenon of "supercritical" water. When water is heated to more than 705 degrees Fahrenheit and compressed to 3,200 pounds a square inch, it ceases to act like a liquid or a gas, and its physical properties change in other striking ways.
Oily substances, which do not mix with water at ordinary temperatures and pressures, are easily soluble in supercritical water. And salts, which do dissolve in ordinary water, are separated out in supercritical water.
These characteristics of supercritical water have led researchers at the University of Texas at Austin and at some private companies to develop disposal systems in which water, waste and a source of excess oxygen are placed in a big pressure cooker. Once the water reaches the supercritical phase, the waste molecules break down to their constituent atoms. These atoms then combine with the excess oxygen, which may come from injecting gaseous oxygen or liquid hydrogen peroxide. This is the equivalent of burning, but without the flame or smoke.
 
Test Projects Under Way
 Companies at work on such systems include the General Atomics Corporation of San Diego; Eco Waste Technologies of Austin, and the Modell Development Corporation of Framingham, Mass. Supercritical water oxidation is undergoing commercial testing in three or four locations, and the Departments of Defense, Commerce and Energy are sponsoring nearly a dozen projects.
The economics of supercritical water oxidation are such that it works best with wastes that are watery to start with, like sludge from municipal sewage plants, wastes from pulp and paper mills, and the remnants of pharmaceutical and food processing. The technique produces clear water, carbon dioxide and an ash that can be disposed of in a landfill.
Since this "burning" of carbon-based compounds releases heat, the process can be self-sustaining after the initial heating, as new toxic "fuel" is gradually added while the waste products are drawn off or filtered out. And because the combustion takes place in a fluid, there are no air pollutants like oxides of nitrogen, oxides of sulfur or particulate emissions, all three of which are byproducts of incinerators.
 
Variety of Uses
 Supercritical water can be used to treat a broad variety of nonorganic wastes as well, including chlorinated hydrocarbons like PCB's, which come from old electrical transformers and are difficult to dispose of, as well as old solid rocket propellants and nerve gas that has been stashed in Government warehouses since the chilliest days of the cold war.
These more complicated wastes present more problems, because elements like chlorine, sulfur and phosphorus form highly corrosive acids that attack virtually any alloy used in the walls of reactor vessels. The acids can be neutralized by adding a base, like sodium hydroxide, but this does not completely solve the problem, because the resulting salts are sticky and tend to gum up the system.
Nevertheless, agencies of the Defense Department are intent on perfecting supercritical water oxidation to clean up cold war remnants like the five million rounds of chemical warfare ammunition that is slowly corroding in military warehouses.
While some corporate scientists experiment with the watery demise of toxic waste, others are busily adapting an approach, first developed at United States Steel in the early 1980's, that destroys wastes by injecting them into a bath of molten metal, usually iron. The technology was inspired by the steelmaker's desire to lower energy costs by using waste items, like scrap tires, as fuel.
Molten Metal Technology Inc. of Waltham, Mass., has come up with a system for injecting toxic materials into a pool of molten iron at 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit. Such treatment causes almost all compounds to break down into their constituent elements because of the intense heat and the catalytic effect of the metal. Hydrocarbons are rendered into hydrogen, which bubbles off the top of the bath, and carbon, which similarly boils off as carbon dioxide gas if oxygen is provided.
As in supercritical water oxidation, the process occurs in a closed system, with minimal releases to the atmosphere.
The company touts the process as recycling, and indeed some materials, like the gases, can be separated and recovered. Vastly more important is the regulatory reality that once substances are labeled as waste, a company is liable for them forever. If the materials can be broken down and the constituents re-used, however, nothing remains that could become a liability in the future.
If the metal bath is installed in a plant as part of a manufacturer's production system, the material going into it, no matter how toxic, stands a good chance of being considered a "process intermediate" that will be rendered harmless before it leaves the factory. Thus no waste needs to be reported to regulators and a company's environmental liability is reduced.
The process has some limitations. Because of the prohibitive energy costs of keeping the metal molten, the process cannot handle wastes with a high concentration of water, which would act as a coolant. That would seem to leave that part of the market to supercritical water.
And at this point, the company cannot separate out metals while the process is in operation, so it has to market the result as an alloy or treat the alloy in a separate process to recover valuable materials. If a company with a lot of printed circuit boards wanted to run them through the bath to recover the small quantities of gold and silver in each board, for example, the process would require two steps.
 
Mining an Alloy
 "If you operate the technology properly, you could get all the gold to accumulate until you had a gold-rich alloy," said Ian C. Yates, Molten Metal's vice president for market development. Then the furnace could be taken out of operation and the gold leached out of the alloy using mining techniques.
Mr. Yates said a top research goal was to find ways of separating metals out while the bath was still in operation by adding chemicals that would combine with them and have them precipitate out of solution.
Molten Metal has built a small commercial-scale plant in Fall River, Mass., which is capable of processing up to two tons of waste an hour, and it anticipates testing waste for such potential customers as the Du Pont Company later this year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William M. Haney 3d, left, president of Molten Metal Technology Inc., and Ian C. Yates, the company's vice president for market development, with one of the devices used in breaking down toxic elements. (Michael Quan for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "A Hot Bath for Wastes"
 
Molten Metal Technology Inc. is developing a way to destroy toxic wastes by injecting them into a bath of molten metal. The system might work this way.
 
1. Industrial waste material is injected into a pool of molten iron at 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit.
 
2. Chemical reactants are added.
 
3. The intensity of the heat causes the waste compounds to break down into their constituent elements, which then recombine with the added chemicals.
 
4. Some materials are separated and recovered . . .
 
5. . . . And can be used again in the manufacturing process.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 15

 BODY:
Champagne may be the drink of celebration, but the people who make it have little to celebrate these days. Battered by rising costs, a depressed market and growing competition from cheaper sparkling wines, Champagne sales have been slipping steadily for several years. Three events in France last week served to underscore the extent of the problem:
* In case they were unaware of its gravity, shareholders of the parent company of the biggest Champagne producer, Moet & Chandon, were told on Thursday that Champagne was in the midst of an "unprecedented crisis" that was not about to disappear soon. The grim news came from Bernard Arnault, the president of Moet's parent company, the luxury-goods conglomerate LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton. "We're not deluding ourselves," Mr. Arnault said at the LVMH annual meeting. "This is going to last several years." 
 * The previous day, 21 major Champagne producers, including Moet & Chandon, announced that they would join with some 700 restaurants throughout France to cut Champagne prices in those restaurants by as much as 25 percent. Restaurant sales of Champagne have been particularly hard hit because of high prices. Here in Paris, few restaurants offer Champagne for less than 300 francs, or about $55. In a wine shop, prices for a good name-brand Champagne begin at about $25.
* Earlier in the week, the industry said it was being assaulted from another quarter and that it was about to embark on what could be a costly venture, yet another defense of one of its most valuable assets, the name of its product. Roland Chaillon, the director of the Champagne producers organization, said his group was taking Yves Saint Laurent to court for misappropriating the name Champagne for a new perfume.
At the Moet meeting, Mr. Arnault told the stockholders "we believe in the future of Champagne," but noted that shipments of Moet & Chandon fell from 24.6 million bottles in 1990 to 19.4 million in 1992. He noted that the drop in consumption came at a time when the industry had raised prices because of the high cost of grapes in 1989 and 1990. In 1992, Moet & Chandon held 19 percent of the world Champagne market, down from 21 percent two years earlier.
Blaming the recession, Moet & Chandon said it would dismiss 245 employees over the next 18 months at its cellars in Epernay. Pommery, another Champagne house in the LVMH group, will dismiss 89 in Rheims. Yesterday, about 500 LVMH Champagne workers demonstrated against the layoffs outside LVMH's headquarters in Paris. There are seven Champagne concerns in the LVMH group.
Shipments of Champagne to the United States continued a six-year decline in 1992. Last year, the total was 10 million cases, down from 10.2 million in 1991 and from 15.8 million cases in 1987.
The restaurant price cuts here in France are scheduled to begin on Saturday and last until Dec. 31. "We are adapting to the situation," said Jean-Claude Rouzaud, the managing director of Louis Roederer Champagne. "We want to show consumers that our product is not only for celebrating but can also help avoid gloominess."
Under the agreement, the Champagne houses will offer their wines to some 700 restaurants at price reductions of up to 25 percent, so long as the restaurateurs agree to pass the savings on to their customers. The promotion is the result of a survey taken by the Champagne industry that indicated the French are drinking less Champagne in restaurants.
If the promotion is a success, it will be extended to all French restaurants, which account for about a quarter of all Champagne sales, Mr. Rouzaud said. The Champagne houses participating in the promotion include the seven in the LVMH group, Charles Heidsieck, Bollinger, Laurent-Perrier, Mumm and Taittinger.
Champagne, the perfume, is scheduled to be introduced in Europe in September by Yves Saint Laurent in a bottle shaped like a Champagne cork. But not if Champagne, the drink, has anything to say about it. "We are going to take them to court," said Philippe le Tixerant, a spokesman for the Champagne Bureau. Yves Saint Laurent said it bought the rights to the name from a perfume maker, Caron, which introduced a perfume called Bain de Champagne (Champagne Bath) in 1942.
The French cigarette monopoly, Seita, marketed a cigarette called Champagne in 1984, but a French court ordered it to stop and to pay damages to the Champagne growers.
The Champagne industry spends more than $3.5 million a year defending the exclusivity of its name, Mr. Chaillon said, with middling success. The Champagne growers insist that under French law only sparkling white wines from the Champagne region can be called Champagne. They have fought successful actions in Australia, Germany, Spain and Italy to ban local appropriation of the name Champagne for their sparkling wines. Under European Community regulations, even the term "methode champenoise," denoting that the wine was made by the process used in the Champagne region, will be banned.
One place the restrictions have not worked is in the United States, where any sparkling wine can choose to call itself champagne, although fewer and fewer producers actually do.
Since May, Yves Saint Laurent has been a subsidiary of Elf Aquitaine, the petroleum and energy conglomerate, France's biggest company.
Mr. Chaillon said Yves Saint Laurent had offered to pay royalties on sales of the new perfume but that the growers had refused. The Champagne Bureau has asked the Minister of Industry, Gerard Longuet, to intervene on the industry's behalf, Mr. Chaillon said. The Ministry declined to comment on the matter.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau d'Armailhac 1989 (Pauillac). About $20.
 
Vinexpo, a wine trade fair held every two years, will begin on Sunday in Bordeaux, and a highlight of this weeklong event will be a dinner at Chateau Mouton-Rothschild on Monday night. You can be there in spirit if not in person by opening a bottle, not of Mouton, but from one of the other two chateaus that make up the Mouton complex in Pauillac. Mouton-Rothschild is the star; then come Chateau d'Armailhac and Clerc-Milon-Rothschild. D'Armailhac started out as d'Armailhacq. When Baron Philippe de Rothschild bought it in 1933, it became Mouton-Baron-Philippe. After the Baron's death in 1988, his daughter, Baroness Philippine de Rothschild, brought back the original name, minus the q. The 1989 vintage has none of the power of Mouton, but it is much less expensive ($20 compared to about $100). It is a rich, dense, intensely flavored wine that speaks well of its illustrious ancestry.

HEADLINE: In City Budget Package, a Modest Arts Increase

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The city's cultural institutions, their finances hurt by the recession, have received a modest but significant lift from the budget package worked out last weekend between the Mayor and the City Council.
Under the agreement between Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, the funds budgeted for cultural programs and other noncapital expenses were increased by $9 million, bringing the total to $89 million for the fiscal year starting next month. 
 Although the culture budget is just a fraction of the total city budget of $31.2 billion, its importance is always disproportionately greater than its actual amount. Not only are the heads of the city's arts institutions outspoken and articulate in expressing gratitude and grievances, but the institutions themselves are widely recognized to be magnets for tourist dollars. Accordingly, the Mayor and the Speaker were eager to make up for the 24 percent reduction that cultural institutions sustained during fiscal year 1992.
Mr. Vallone said yesterday: "The final budget shows the Council believes cultural institutions are an essential, if not the essential, element to life in New York. And so naturally we supported them."
 
The Big Winners
 Among the big winners is the New-York Historical Society, which will receive the $6.3 million commitment it sought from the city to match a similar state contribution. With these funds available, the historical society, which had a close brush with bankruptcy last winter, can proceed with its financial bail-out plan.
Other major institutions that fared well are Lincoln Center, which received $800,000 over its basic grant for the maintenance of its public plazas, and the Brooklyn Museum, which was given $67,000 over its basic financing of $350,000 for the operation of its new wing.
Though there was often tense and bitter bargaining between the Mayor's office and the Council, in the end the cultural money was distributed according to the same formula used in recent years. Under that formula, some 85 percent of the city's arts funds go to members of the Cultural Institutions Group: 31 major arts institutions that occupy city-owned real estate and include the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the New York Shakespeare Festival. About 15 percent went to the 419 other recipient arts groups in the city.
Among the recipients in the Cultural Institutions Group are the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which will receive a total of $200,000; the Studio Museum in Harlem, which will receive $150,000, and the American Museum of the Moving Image, which will receive $100,000.
The final budget amounted to a rejection of many proposals by Luis R. Cancel, Commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs. Mr. Cancel had submitted to the Mayor a plan that departed from the traditional formula. Under Mr. Cancel's plan, only 13 of the 31 members of the Cultural Institutions Group, most of them smaller institutions like the Bronx Museum and El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan, received increases. Those that did not included City Center and the American Museum of Natural History.
When he first submitted his budget proposals several weeks ago, Mr. Cancel explained that he had been forced to scrap the old formula because there was so little money to go around. If the funds available were spread across the board, he argued, it would be impossible to meet critical needs of certain institutions, like aid to the Brooklyn Museum for the operation of its new wing.
 
Politics Charged and Denied
 But cultural administrators and members of the City Council criticized Mr. Cancel's list of special benefactors. Some viewed his proposals as a means of winning good will for Mayor Dinkins and himself by handing out bonuses to politically useful institutions at the expense of others.
Yesterday, Mr. Cancel said that political considerations had "never at all entered the decisions." Mayor Dinkins agreed, and expressed his support for Mr. Cancel.
Under the final agreement, the City Council also cut $150,000 from a half-million-dollar project in which Mr. Cancel had invested much personal prestige: a voucher program under which seventh-grade school children would be given "passports" to attend cultural events of their choice. Council members said they objected to adding a new program, with uncertain administrative costs, at a time when many proven programs were in jeopardy.
Mr. Cancel's voucher program survived as well as it did, staff members of the City Council said, because the commissioner was willing to sacrifice his department's $100,000 emergency fund. This fund was the source drawn upon earlier this year to help keep the New-York Historical Society open until other financing could be arranged.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 398 words

HEADLINE: Budgeting for Re-election

 BODY:
New York City officials finally came to terms on a budget for the new fiscal year in the wee hours of Sunday morning -- as if pressed by a deadline. The deadline was still more than two weeks away, but perhaps they hoped the dark of night might conceal what they were up to.
State law requires that the city balance its budget each year. So Mayor David Dinkins and the City Council declared it balanced. But no one should be surprised if they have to cut more spending to reach that balance as the year unfolds -- say, sometime after Nov. 2, when both the mayoral and Council elections are safely past. 
 The Mayor and Council know perfectly well that cutting later probably means cutting deeper. If, say, $12 million must be saved in the course of a year, it is less painful to spread the cuts over the 12 months, beginning July 1, rather than waiting until Jan. 1 and cutting the full amount in six months. But the political pain of cuts before Election Day is something else, and so the budget negotiators chose to pray for fiscal miracles. For instance, they financed day care and transportation for AIDS patients for six months; what happens then?
The holes in this budget are so obvious that the new State Comptroller, Carl McCall, said the plan "will obviously not get us through next year, and makes the gaps for future years grow wider and even more difficult." Those unminced words came from a Democrat and Dinkins ally.
Budget specialists fault the city for counting on one-shot revenues and revenues that are unlikely to arrive at all, and for relying too heavily on one-year spending cuts while failing to tackle basic reform of the city's misaligned tax structure.
On the revenue side, one big item is both uncertain and reckless. The city wants to "sell" $200 million of delinquent property tax collections to a bank. In effect, that is borrowing on future revenues to cover current expenses. That's the reckless part. The "sale" can't happen unless Albany approves; that's the uncertain part. If Albany cares for the city's fiscal soundness, it won't happen.
True, the Mayor has no control over some of the factors that have worsened New York's problems -- the inadequacy of state aid for city schools, the state's failure to absorb Medicaid costs and the economy's continued weakness. But political administrators have to make do. As of now, they're not.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trade Sanity With Japan

 BODY:
In trade talks last week with Japan, the Clinton Administration turned from bullying to constructive negotiating. Instead of repeating threats to punish Japan for behavior the U.S. unilaterally decides is wrong -- a tactic designed to curry favor with protectionists in the Democratic Party -- the Administration set out reasonable ways to help U.S. exporters without risking a trade war.
Yet the old threats haven't been disowned, which makes U.S. policy appear contradictory. The Administration's overheated rhetoric risks creating unrealistic expectations that could make the modest gains of reasonable policy look like a retreat. 
 The prominence the Administration has given to trade talks with Japan reflects two beliefs: that trade deficits with that nation harm the U.S. economy and that negotiations can solve the problem. Neither belief carries much weight.
Longstanding trade deficits reflect insufficient saving. Americans buy more goods than they produce, importing the balance. The Japanese do the opposite: produce more than they buy, exporting what's left over. The U.S. trade deficit won't fall -- regardless of what Mickey Kantor negotiates with the Japanese -- until Americans save more.
That's why the strategy of "managed trade" proposed by some in the Administration won't work. Under managed trade, Washington would set numerical targets for Japanese imports of designated U.S. goods like supercomputers, telecommunications equipment and automobile parts -- and retaliate if they aren't met.
But if the Japanese are forced to import more designated goods, they will -- given their unchanged savings rate -- compensate by exporting more or importing fewer non-designated goods (some of which would otherwise have come from the U.S.). Besides, the Japanese Government can't control how much its citizens import unless it replaces markets with Government-run cartels -- a peculiar demand for the U.S. to make.
What's at stake when the U.S. negotiates higher import levels of U.S. supercomputers and telecommunications equipment is the well-being of Motorola and the Cray Computer Corporation -- not the overall trade balance of the U.S.
For now, President Clinton has backed away from threats of automatic retaliation. Numerical targets would simply serve as indicators to identify markets in which Japan unfairly blocks imports and where U.S. pressure ought to be applied. There are encouraging precedents for this strategy: After Japan, at U.S. insistence, changed its laws restricting large-scale retailers, the way was cleared for Toys "R" Us to open up six stores within a year.
The Administration also plans to pressure the Japanese Government to cut down the temporary bulge in the trade deficit by stimulating Japan's sluggish economy. And the Administration is claiming it won't shut out Japanese imports. These are sensible policies, adopted previously by President Bush.
Trade hawks in the Democratic Party will try to hold President Clinton to his promise to make cutting the trade deficit with Japan one of his highest priorities. So far, at least, Mr. Clinton is proceeding to fulfill his misguided promise in a responsible manner.

HEADLINE: John Connally of Texas, a Power In 2 Political Parties, Dies at 76

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
John B. Connally, the former Governor of Texas who served in two Presidential Administrations and who was wounded when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 76.
The cause was complications of pulmonary fibrosis, said a hospital spokeswoman, Blythe Schaffer. Mr. Connally had been admitted to the hospital May 17 with breathing problems. 
 Early in his political career, Mr. Connally was a protege of Lyndon B. Johnson and served as Secretary of the Navy in the Kennedy Administration as well as Secretary of the Treasury under President Richard M. Nixon. After switching from the Democratic to the Republican Party in the 1970's, he was regarded for a time as a serious contender for the Presidency.
 
Tumultuous Public Life
 Mr. Connally's public life was nothing short of tumultuous. On Nov. 22, 1963, while serving his first term as Governor, Mr. Connally was riding in Kennedy's open-topped limousine through the streets of Dallas and was wounded when Kennedy was shot and killed. A bullet passed through his body, leaving Mr. Connally with scars on his back, chest, wrist and thigh. Later, he would recall drifting in and out of consciousness for four days. He said the first sustained consciousness he had was of watching television coverage of Kennedy's body being carried to Arlington National Cemetery.
Mr. Connally also said he thought that the shot that killed the President had been meant for him. He said this was because the accused assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, had written a letter asking Mr. Connally, as Navy Secretary, to upgrade his undesirable discharge from the Marines, and that no action had been taken on the request.
Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic national chairman, who was one of Mr. Connally's oldest friends, described him last night as "one of the ablest men I ever knew, a man who had an uncanny ability to forget the transitory stuff and retain all the vital information in his head, year after year."
"He was a pioneer," Mr. Strauss said. "He was a different kind of governor than Texas had ever had. He spent a lot of money on mental health and education and other things that were verboten at the time. One time he even put a liberal rabbi on the Board of Regents at the University of Texas, with all those businessmen.
"But after the assassination, he moved right and kind of lost his way."
In his 1989 book "Nixon: The Triumph of a Politician," Stephen E. Ambrose wrote that Mr. Nixon's "admiration for Connally grew to the point of adulation after Mr. Connally advised him to go ahead with the bombing of Hanoi and the mining of Haiphong." By 1972, Mr. Nixon says in his memoirs, he believed that Mr. Connally "was the only man in either party who clearly had the potential to be a great President."
Mr. Nixon discussed with several of his aides the possibility of putting Mr. Connally on the Republican ticket that year instead of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew. But they demurred, arguing that dumping Mr. Agnew would anger Republican conservatives, and Mr. Nixon gave in.
Part of Mr. Connally's success as a politician derived from his impressive appearance. In 1970, after he was named Treasury Secretary, he was described in an article in The New York Times: "Mr. Connally is tall, gray-haired, handsome, personable and articulate, and his manners and bearing recall those of President Johnson. Yet he is suave and has a touch of the Eastern establishment."
 
 
Born Into Poverty
 John Bowden Connally Jr. was born in Floresville, Tex., on Feb. 27, 1917, one of seven children born to John Bowden Connally and the former Lela Wright. His father had been a cowboy, a barber and a grocer before turning to dairy farming and finally tenant farming. The family's circumstances were always quite modest; there often were debts and struggles to pay them.
The younger John Connally attended public schools in Harlandale, where his family lived, and in nearby San Antonio. He then went to the University of Texas, where he received a bachelor's degree and then a law degree.
In college he was interested in campus politics, oratory and acting, and was elected president of the Students Association. He also developed a desire to amass land and money, and never return to the poverty he knew as a boy.
Mr. Connally met Lyndon Johnson when he was a young Congressman from Texas in the late 1930's, and was a campaign worker for him..
 
An Aide to Eisenhower
 In World War II Mr. Connally served as a Navy officer, first as a legal assistant to James V. Forrestal, who was then Secretary of the Navy, and later in North Africa on the staff of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower when he was planning the Allied invasion of Italy. Still later, reassigned to the Pacific, Mr. Connally won the Bronze Star for valor.
After the war he worked again in Johnson's Congressional campaigns, and managed his successful campaign for the United States Senate in 1948. During this period Mr. Connally also practiced law, first in Austin, Tex., and later in Fort Worth.
In 1952 he bolted the Democratic Party to help Eisenhower win the Presidency at the behest of Mr. Connally's client, Sid W. Richardson, a wealthy oil executive.
His defection did not bother Johnson, who valued Mr. Connally's aggressiveness and skills and continued to rely on them as he steadily gained power in the Senate.
They were effectively used again in 1956, when Mr. Connally helped his mentor wrest control of the Democratic Party in Texas from Gov. Allen Shivers. Johnson was grateful, but later reportedly told his Under Secretary of State, George W. Ball, that Mr. Connally could "leave more dead bodies in the field with less remorse than any politician I ever knew."
 
A Lucrative Association
 In the early 1950's Mr. Connally had become a lawyer for Mr. Richardson, who ultimately put him in charge of running his business ventures in Texas and Jamaica. The association proved most lucrative to Mr. Connally, who eventually became one of the executors of Mr. Richardson's estate.
In 1960 Mr. Connally managed Johnson's unsuccessful campaign to wrest the Democratic Presidential nomination from Kennedy and worked for the Democratic ticket after Kennedy chose Johnson as his running mate.
Mr. Connally was instrumental in the ticket's carrying Texas, the key to the Democratic victory, and Johnson gave him much of the credit for the narrow defeat of Mr. Nixon and his running mate, Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts. In a letter to Mr. Connally, the Vice President-elect said, "Except for you, I know the outcome would have been different."
As a condition of accepting the Vice-Presidential nomination, Johnson was given control of appointments to the Kennedy Administration from Texas, and Mr. Connally was thus assured of an important post.
He became Kennedy's Secretary of the Navy in January 1961, but resigned the post in less than a year to make a successful run for governor of Texas, a job he held from 1963 to 1969. At the time of the assassination, Kennedy was visiting Texas in the hopes of mending some political fences, and Mr. Connally, as Governor, was accompanying him. Governor Connally had a reputation as a big spender, focusing on the improvement of higher education and establishing the state as a magnet for development during his three two-year terms.
 
Conservative Connections
 Mr. Connally was in the conservative wing of the Democratic Party, and in 1969 Mr. Nixon, who liked Mr. Connally's politics, asked him to serve on an advisory commission to reorganize the executive branch.
Mr. Nixon was so impressed with Mr. Connally that he named him Secretary of the Treasury in 1971. As Secretary until 1972, Mr. Connally was largely responsible for the Federal guarantee of some $250 million in loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, then the nation's largest major military contractor but near collapse because of major cutbacks in military spending and other setbacks in its civilian projects.
It was during his tenure, in August 1971, that the United States went off the gold standard, which had the effect of inaugurating the era of floating currencies and devaluing the dollar. The Adminstration also imposed wage and price controls in an effort to control inflation.
"We are at the end of an era in our economic policy," Mr. Connally declared in an interview that month, defending the moves. "American business and labor may have to get used to the idea of living within certain parameters."
Mr. Connally gave the President some advice on matters not related to money. According to "The Lone Star," a biography of Mr. Connally written by James Reston Jr. and published by Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row in 1990, Mr. Connally urged Mr. Nixon to consider the use of nuclear weapons to win the Vietnam War.
In May 1973, three months after Johnson's death, Mr. Connally officially became a Republican. He said that party was his "true philosophical home" because it "it best expressed the broad view of most Americans, whatever their party affiliation."
 
Special Adviser to Nixon
 In 1973, as Mr. Nixon became more deeply embroiled in the Watergate scandal, he turned to Mr. Connally for help and named him a special adviser, a job that he held for 69 days before quitting. Mr. Reston says in "The Lone Star" that Mr. Connally resigned because Mr. Nixon picked the House minority leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, as Vice President to replace Mr. Agnew, who resigned on Oct. 10, 1973, after pleading no contest to a charge of tax evasion stemming from kickback payments he had received as Governor of Maryland.
Months later, with Mr. Connally out of public office, Mr. Ford was sworn in as President after Mr. Nixon resigned rather than face impeachment over the Watergate scandal.
In 1974 Mr. Connally was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice. Prosecutors said he had taken $10,000 from the American Milk Producers Inc. after persuading Mr. Nixon to back a controversial increase in price supports for milk in 1971. Mr. Connally was exonerated by a Federal jury in Washington in 1975.
But Mr. Connally continued to be active in politics even after this incident. In the late 1970's he unsuccessfully opposed Ronald Reagan's drive to control the Republican Party, and in 1980 he made a costly but losing campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
After that, he abandoned whatever aspirations he had for public office and concentrated on making money, which led to a partnership with former Lieut. Gov. Ben Barnes of Texas.
But in 1988 Mr. Connally declared bankruptcy, placing the blame for his $93 million personal debt mostly on bad real estate, oil and gas investments he made in Texas as the state's economy began to worsen. He was forced to sell most of his 2,674-acre ranch near Floresville, along with his horses, Chippendale and Louis XIV furniture, fine china, rifle collection and ceremonial saddles inlaid with his initials in gold.
Left with his ranch house and a mere 200 acres, Mr. Connally said, "I know what it is to be poor." To the surprise of nobody who knew him, he emerged from bankruptcy within a year.
His survivors include his wife of 52 years, the former Idanell Brill; two sons, John 3d of Houston and Mark M. of Austin; a daughter, Sharon C. Ammann of Austin; four brothers, two sisters, eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 17, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday with the obituary of John B. Connally incorrectly described a picture of him and President John F. Kennedy. The car in which the two men were sitting was not the limousine in which Kennedy was assassinated, but a smaller car they used earlier that day. The caption also misstated Mr. Connally's location in the later motorcade. He sat in a jump seat between the front and rear seats of the limousine, not in its front seat.

HEADLINE: A 25 1/2-Hour German Epic of Discovery and Art

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
The statistics are daunting. The German director Edgar Reitz's 25 1/2-hour epic film, "Heimat II: Chronicle of a Generation," has 2,143 pages of script and consumed more than a million feet of exposed film. It took six years to write, 557 days to shoot and 117 days to edit. The cast includes 71 leading roles, 310 smaller ones and 2,300 extras.
 The product of this prodigious teamwork is an alternately gripping and lyrical 13-episode serial about German life in the 1960's that is being shown in roughly four-hour installments at the Joseph Papp Public Theater through July 29. Handsomely photographed and superbly acted, with English subtitles and a remarkably evocative soundtrack, it might be the ultimate highbrow soap opera for couch potatoes except that there are no plans to show "Heimat II" on television in the United States. 
 The director has emphasized that the 1992 film is not a sequel to his 15-hour film "Heimat," which told the history of a fictitious German village over 63 years. That film made it to television (on the Bravo cable service and then on Channel 13) and ran at the Public Theater in 1986. 
 "Heimat II," which is set mostly in Munich, follows 10 years in the lives of a circle of musicians and film makers who come of age at the height of Germany's "economic miracle." Although it begins in 1960, just 15 years after World War II, the war might as well as have been over for 50 years for all the attention it is paid, at least at the start of the series. All that matters is the future. The musicians are intoxicated with modernism, the film makers inspired by the take-to-the-streets esthetic of the French New Wave. 
 If these young Turks of the arts are openly derisive of those whom they believe to have been Nazis, their contempt is expressed more as social snobbery than as a deep moral revulsion. Most have left their families to make their way in a largely reconstructed city in a fresh new decade. They shrug off such uncomfortable reminders of the past as the occasional unexploded bomb that is discovered and quickly defused. 
 Although the 13 episodes of "Heimat II" move from character to character, the most prominent recurrent figure is Hermann Simon (Henry Arnold), a fiercely ambitious young composer, pianist and guitarist who leaves his provincial village to study at the Munich Conservatory. A hot-headed romantic who suggests a Germanic hybrid of Tom Cruise and Mandy Patinkin, he leaves home in a fury, determined never to return to the town that drove away his socially unacceptable childhood sweetheart. 
 Hermann emerges as the representative young German of a generation that today is in its early 50's. Arrogant, self-centered and passionate, he is much more intellectual than any corresponding figure from an American film set in the same period. One of the most intriguing qualities of "Heimat II" is the intellectual tenor of the conversation. Even in casual discourse, names like Leibniz and Schopenhauer are thrown around without a second thought. 
 Unlike most films about artists, "Heimat II" shows its characters struggling to create. It follows Hermann through an oral exam for the Munich Conservatory and features several of his compositions. These fiery atonal pieces, which perfectly reflect his personality, were composed by Nikos Mamangakis, who wrote the series' voluminous and gorgeous music in a rainbow of styles. The film devotes similar attention to the musical life of Hermann's sometime girlfriend, Clarissa (Salome Kammer), a gifted cellist, and to the studio labors of Reinhard (Laszlo I. Kish), a documentary film maker, as well as to Reinhard's lover, Esther (Susanne Lothar), a tempestuous Venetian photographer. 
 An elegiac thread of the story concerns Foxholes, a lushly appointed estate run by Elisabeth Cerphal (Hannelore Hoger), the niece of a German publishing magnate. Elisabeth, infatuated with youth, allows her home to become a free-floating bohemian salon in the early 1960's. Ultimately Foxholes is demolished. And the house and memories of its carefree romantic nights loom as a nostalgic touchstone for a more innocent and golden time. 
 The house also becomes a darker symbol of an unspoken agreement by almost everybody to regard the Nazi era as an embarrassing historical aberration that is best left behind. But as Elisabeth's family secrets come to light, willful ignorance of the past proves impossible. One of the most shattering scenes is a confrontation at the Dachau concentration camp. 
 At least two dozen memorable characters wind in and out of the series' 13 episodes. If Hermann is the most vivid, the most touching is Juan (Daniel Smith), a Peruvian expatriate musician and man of multiple talents who is refused entrance to the Munich Conservatory because his music is too folkloric. Juan, who eventually attempts suicide, hovers on the periphery of the action like a moth drawn to the flame of a society in which he can never feel as though he belongs. In Mr. Smith's portrayal he is an infinitely sad clown and truth-teller, a Robin Williams waif with the soul of Goethe's Werther. 
 Running through "Heimat II" is a strain of romantic fervor that echoes the lofty swirl of Wagner's operas. Most of the characters take love very seriously. In this still quite Puritanical atmosphere, kisses are not exchanged lightly, and passions run deep and long. Many of the young characters' stories take sharp melodramatic turns, and some individuals die unexpectedly. 
 These sudden reversals, along with the film's moody tone and expressionistic touches (black-and-white sequences are strikingly alternated with scenes in color) make it not quite realistic. Rather like the culturally literate never-never land of Woody Allen's New York, Mr. Reitz's 1960's Munich is the exotic city of a young man's dream. 
 "Heimat II" opened at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, in the East Village, on June 4. Episodes 2 and 3 are being shown through Sunday afternoon with two new episodes being shown each week thereafter, except for an early July recapitulation. The recap will show episode 1 on July 1, episodes 2 and 3 on July 3, episodes 4 and 5 on July 6, and episodes 6 and 7 on July 7. The series resumes on July 9 with episodes 8 and 9.

HEADLINE: EMPIRE SAYS DATA ON INSURANCE LOSS WERE ERRONEOUS

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield acknowledged yesterday that the company had repeatedly sent erroneous reports about its finances to New York State insurance regulators. The action came as state officials accused Empire's executives of obstructing state insurance examiners for years.
Kevin Foley, New York's deputy insurance superintendent, said Empire's executives made "misstatements" to the Insurance Department, told "falsehoods" and were slow to provide information requested by insurance examiners. Sometimes they claimed information did not exist, when it did, he said. 
 Empire's chief financial officer, who prepares the reports submitted to the state, was ordered by the company to leave the building yesterday and his office was sealed. His status with the company is unclear. Harold E. Vogt, Empire's chairman, said the company had not determined whether the financial officer, Jerry Weissman, would be allowed to return.
 
Losses Exaggerated
 The erroneous documents, filed as part of Empire's annual reports to the state in 1989, 1990 and 1991, exaggerate Empire's losses on insurance policies that cover the poorest and sickest New Yorkers. The documents also understated the losses on its insurance policies with some of the country's wealthiest companies.
The discrepancies are significant. In recent years, Empire has sought approval from the state for steep rate increases on the policies it offers to individuals and small groups, frequently the oldest and sickest New Yorkers who could not find insurance elsewhere. Empire has said that losses from these accounts are the primary reason for the company's precarious financial state.
Empire's admission about the figures came after The New York Times obtained internal company documents that showed figures different from those that Empire had filed with the New York State Insurance Department. Mr. Vogt said he began an internal inquiry two weeks ago, after The Times asked him to explain the discrepancy.
Internal auditors reported back to Mr. Vogt yesterday, he said, and he immediately informed the Insurance Department. "It appears that there was some discrepancy and it appears that we needed to address it," Mr. Vogt said.
In an interview on Tuesday, Mr. Weissman acknowledged the existence of two sets of figures for the accounts, but said that the erroneous figures had no effect on rate increases. The discrepancy was the result of different accounting methods, Mr. Weissman said, adding that more accurate figures are sent to the state each time Empire requests a rate increase.
Reached at his home last night, Mr. Weissman said he had no comment on yesterday's developments.
The questions surrounding Empire's truthfulness with state regulators come during the worst management and financial crises in the company's 60-year history.
Mr. Weissman became third in command at Empire last month after its chief executive, Albert A. Cardone, was forced out by the board of directors. Yesterday's developments raised new questions about Mr. Cardone's tenure at the head of a company that provides health insurance to more than eight million New Yorkers. They are also likely to raise questions about the vigilance of the state Insurance Department in monitoring Empire.
 
Executives Freer to Talk
 Mr. Cardone, who was Empire's chairman and chief executive for six years, resigned last month after a newly invigorated board learned that he had kept crucial information about the company from them and that many top executives of the company were highly critical of his management and his confrontational personal style.
In the weeks since Mr. Cardone's departure, Empire executives have felt freer to tell regulators and the board about the company's inner workings.
Reports from these employees led the Insurance Department to conclude that it had been misled. "Our concern is that some senior executives of the company may have frustrated our examinations," Mr. Foley said. He declined to name the executives, but said the department would make public a fuller report on the matter in the coming weeks.
Mr. Vogt, who was named chairman of Empire last month, said he was informed yesterday by the State Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, that state regulators wanted to question Mr. Weissman about "missing data." Mr. Vogt said the superintendent did not elaborate.
 
Books Sent Anonymously
 The erroneous financial reports acknowledged by Empire yesterday had no effect on the company's "bottom line," Mr. Vogt said. But he added, "I'm not minimizing this as an issue. We're concerned that there be no discrepancies."
The internal books, which were sent to The Times anonymously, showed that Empire lost $150.6 million on its policies with individuals and small groups in 1991. But on its state filing for the same year, Empire reported a loss of $181.5 million on those policies.
And the internal books showed a loss of $66 million on policies sold to large companies. The figures filed with New York State showed a loss of $35.1 million.
Empire is a not-for-profit company that receives tax breaks from the state in exchange for offering health insurance to anyone who can afford to pay, no matter how sick. Its self-described mission is to insure as many people as possible at the lowest possible cost.
 
Intended to Subsidize Poor
 In theory, Empire uses profits from its accounts with wealthy companies to subsidize the policies offered to the elderly, the unemployed, small groups and others who are considered bad insurance risks and typically are charged far higher rates. But the big corporate accounts have lost money in recent years. Empire must get New York State's approval to raise rates on small groups and individuals, but can set any price for its larger accounts.
Over all, Empire has lost $250 million in the last two years and its reserves have fallen to a level considered dangerously low by state regulators and the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
Mr. Vogt said yesterday that he has hired the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher to conduct a thorough investigation of the financial discrepancies.
In a written statement, the company said it would "not speculate on the extent of involvement of any current or former employee."
Mr. Vogt said Empire also reported the discrepancies to a United States Senate subcommittee that has been conducting a broad inquiry into the management of Empire. The subcommittee, which has subpoenaed thousands of pages of documents from both Empire and the Insurance Department, has scheduled a hearing for next week.

HEADLINE: U.N. Approves Ban On Shipments of Oil To Haitian Military

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 16

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted today to impose a worldwide ban on oil shipments to Haiti but backed away from authorizing the United States or other countries to enforce the ban with a naval blockade.
The sanctions, which were approved unanimously, are aimed at forcing Haitian military leaders to accept the return of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. They were weakened in response to objections by Brazil to a clause that called for the inspection of ships trying to enter Haitian ports. 
 Diplomats said that Brazil was able to win support for its objections from other Latin American countries because of a longstanding concern in the region about international actions that might undercut local sovereignty.
 
Arms Shipments Banned
 The sanctions also included a ban on arms shipments to Haiti and the freezing of Haitian assets abroad. Under the sanctions, Haiti's military leaders have one week to provide what one diplomat called "something really positive," before the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, imposes the embargo.
Shortly after the military coup in September 1991 against Father Aristide, the Organization of American States imposed a hemispheric embargo on commerce with Haiti, but those sanctions, never enforced, had little impact on international efforts to restore democratic rule.
Violators of the new embargo, which is mandatory and enforceable under the authority of the United Nations, would themselves be subject to United Nations sanctions or other punitive measures from the Security Council.
Since January, in an effort to prevent a large outflow of refugees from Haiti, the Clinton Administration has maintained a fleet of Coast Guard and Naval vessels off Haiti which, under the original sanctions language, would likely have been used to stop ships steaming toward Haiti. Diplomats say that other countries, including France, Canada and Argentina, had also offered to help police the embargo.
It was unclear today whether the Dominican Republic, Haiti's neighbor on the island of Hispaniola, would adhere to the ban on oil shipments. Last week, the country's President, Joaquin Balaguer, criticized moves to impose stiffer sanctions on Haiti.
 
Bad Roads a Factor
 Whatever Haiti's neighbor decides, diplomats close to the crisis said roads linking the two countries are so few and in such bad condition that only a small portion of Haiti's needed oil could be trucked over land.
Addressing concerns that some nations or shipping companies might try to violate the embargo, diplomats said the Security Council could be called upon later to approve measures allowing ships entering Haitian waters to be stopped.
Father Aristide's delegate to the United Nations, Fritz E. Longchamp, said, however, that although the new measures represented an important step, the need to consult continually over enforcement "has given a lot of room for dilatory actions that the people of Haiti cannot afford."
Although the sanctions were weakened, they represent a dramatic increase in the involvement of the United Nations with Haiti.
Acknowledging the concerns of Latin American countries, the Security Council announced after the vote that the sanctions were meant to deal with the "unique situation in Haiti and should not be regarded as a precedent."
 
Question of Sovereignty
 Diplomats said the delicate question of national sovereignty was overcome in part by concerns that Haiti's chronic instability, by generating waves of refugees, affected regional stability. Further easing the way for the vote was a letter by Father Aristide requesting additional sanctions.
A senior diplomat at the United Nations expressed dismay today about the change in language that weakened the sanctions, but said the effect would be only temporary, because the United Nations was determined to bring about a negotiated solution to the crisis.
"Basically, the belief here is that these people need a shock," the diplomat said of the expected impact of the oil embargo on the Haitian military, which has frustrated every diplomatic initiative in Haiti so far.
Advisers to the deposed President said they expected that the measures would quickly exert severe pressure on the military to begin negotiating in good faith on Father Aristide's restoration because there are only four to six weeks of oil reserves now in Haiti.

HEADLINE: Advances in Detection Create Dilemma on Prostate Cancer

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., June 16

 BODY:
Prostate cancer is being diagnosed at a higher rate than ever before, according to new data from the National Cancer Institute. And as more cancers are diagnosed, record numbers of men are undergoing radiation or operations to remove the prostate.
But no evidence exists to show that this aggressive effort to diagnose and treat the cancer has had any effect in improving survival. And most of the increase in diagnosis can be attributed to new, more advanced diagnostic techniques, researchers say.
 
16% Increase Reported
 In fact, they say, more cancers are being caught at an earlier, more treatable stage. The real risk is in the treatment. Removal of the prostate not only has a higher death rate than comparable kinds of surgery, but it can also cause impotence and incontinence in large numbers of patients. 
 At a meeting held by the cancer institute on Tuesday and today to assess the prostate cancer problem, researchers reported that from 1989 to 1990, the most recent year for which national data are available, detection of prostate cancer grew by 16 percent, the largest increase ever reported for a cancer in a single year. Preliminary data indicate the 1991 rate may be up by an additional 30 percent.
The cancer institute estimates that in 1993 prostate cancer will be diagnosed in 165,000 American men and 35,000 men will die from it.
These increases in diagnosed cases and in operations stunned cancer specialists, because they reflected widespread use of a screening test that was all but unheard of four years ago.
"This is clearly a major public health issue," said Dr. Larry Kessler ofthe cancer institute. This year, he estimated, the testing will pick up 20,000 to 30,000 more men who have no symptoms and would otherwise have gone unnoticed. "Yet we don't know if treating them is advisable or whether a lot of the surgery is proper," he said.
A simple blood test, known as PSA, for prostate specific antigen, detects a protein that seeps out of the prostate gland when there is a tumor or when the gland is enlarged or inflamed. The American Cancer Society recommends that all men over 50 have a PSA test each year, but the cancer institute has not taken a position.
Unlike other tests for cancer, including mammography in women over 50 or Pap smears, whose use has been shown to save lives, there are no data showing the test for prostate cancer reduces mortality.
Researchers are discouraged by the finding that prostate-cancer death rates have stayed virtually the same for decades. If diagnosis and treatment make a difference, they should reduce the death rate -- the number of men per 100,000 men in the population who die of the disease.
The cancer institute is starting a study to see whether men who are tested live longer, but the study will start recruiting only in October and its results will not be in for a decade.
 
Sharp Rise in Operations
 Meanwhile, Medicare data show the number of operations to remove cancerous prostates in elderly men, defined as those 65 and over, increased by 500 to 600 percent from 1984 to 1990.
The PSA is becoming so routine that many doctors simply include it along with standard tests for cholesterol or blood sugar, for example, without even asking the men if they want it. The test is most often used in the West. Doctors in New England perform it at half the national rate and those in the Pacific states use it 75 percent more than the national average.
"This indicates that perhaps we don't know what we're doing," said Dr. John Wasson, a health-care analyst at Dartmouth University.
The death rate from the operation is 1 percent among men from 65 to 74 and 2 percent among those 75 and older, the Medicare data show. They also show that 63 percent of men who have their prostates removed are incontinent afterward and that 60 to 90 percent are impotent as a result of the operation.
Some surgeons, like Dr. Patrick Walsh of Johns Hopkins University, have much better outcomes, which Dr. Walsh attributes in part to the age of his patient population, generally men in their 50's. He does not operate on men over 70, he said, because he believes the benefits do not exceed the risks. He said he was uncertain whether operations on men between the ages of 60 and 70 were advisable.
Yet results like Dr. Walsh's are the ones most often cited to patients considering the operation, said Dr. John D. McConnell, a urologist at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas. "The results you read about and are often quoted to patients may not apply to the 70-year-old man who is being operated on in a community setting," Dr. McConnell said.
The issues are all the more pressing because prostate cancer is so common, especially among older men. According to the National Cancer Institute, autopsy data show that a third of men over 50 have microscopic tumors in their prostate glands and 90 percent of 90-year-old men have them.
The cancers arise in the prostate, the small gland at the base of the bladder that provides fluids to nourish sperm. Most tumors remain small and unnoticeable and never cause any problems. But some break free of the gland and take up residence in the bone, causing an untreatable metastatic bone cancer. Researchers say they have no idea which or how many of the tumors will prove deadly and which can be ignored. As a consequence, they are treating everyone.
Patients pay $15 to $40 for a PSA test. But doctors at the meeting spoke often of the slippery slope that ensues from a positive test result, which is found among 15 percent of men over 65 and 5 percent of men from 50 to 65. The next steps are additional tests and biopsies, then treatment and, sometimes, more surgery or treatment to alleviate the side effects of treatment.
Economists have calculated that annual tests of all men over 50, including subsequent tests to confirm the diagnosis, and operations for those with suspicious findings, could cost the nation $28 billion a year. But the real question is what is gained by testing.
Dr. Kenneth Pienta, a urologist at Wayne State University in Detroit, said that whether or not some men were treated unnecessarily, others were saved from death. "I'd rather screen and find the cancer," he said.
But Dr. Michael R. Conger, a urologist at the Group Health Cooperative in Redmond, Wash., had a different opinion. He explains to men that once the test is done, if the result is positive, they are in for "a cascade of intervention," that can be hard to refuse because the result itself is so terrifying. It may be better never to start down that road, he said.

HEADLINE: The Man Behind the High Court Nominee

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
In 1980, a handful of Republican senators appeared to be reluctant to confirm another Carter appointment to a Federal Court in an election year, so the prospective judge's husband mentioned the problem to a client.
The husband, Martin D. Ginsburg, told the client, Ross Perot, along with other influential friends in academic and political and corporate circles. 
The senators were called.
And in the end, only one Republican on the Judiciary Committee, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, voted against Ruth Bader Ginsburg's nomination to join the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington.
 
Extraordinary Record
 Even though she had established an extraordinary record as a lawyer and teacher, Ms. Ginsburg has acknowledged that without the strong personal and political support of her husband, she may never have become President Clinton's choice for the Supreme Court.
For his part, Mr. Ginsburg said in an interview today: "I have been supportive of my wife since the beginning of time, and she has been supportive of me. It's not sacrifice; it's family."
It was also a sign of the changing times that Mr. Ginsburg would have to leave behind a successful career as a lawyer and tenured tax professor at Columbia Law School in New York and move to Washington so that his wife could become a Federal judge here 13 years ago. When Mr. Ginsburg graduated from law school 35 years ago, his new bride transferred from Harvard to Columbia Law School so he could take a job as an associate at a Manhattan law firm.
As women have begun to reach the highest ranks of political and judicial power, Mr. Ginsburg has come to represent a new kind of spouse: the husband as alter ego, adviser and political booster. It is a kind of role reversal that has been performed in recent months by Michael Kramer, the journalist who promoted the candidacy of his wife, Judge Kimba M. Wood, for Attorney General. Judge Wood was dropped by the White House after it was learned that the couple had employed an illegal immigrant to care for their son (although doing so was legal at the time).
Friends say Mr. Ginsburg worked behind the scenes to help persuade Mr. Clinton to nominate Judge Ginsburg for the Supreme Court, calling on leading scholars to write to Mr. Clinton and his counsel, Bernard W. Nussbaum.
When rumors began circulating last month that Judge Ginsburg had opposed the right to abortion, Mr. Ginsburg enlisted academics to tell the White House and others that his wife had criticized the reasoning, but not the result, of the 1973 case establishing the constitutional right.
And in a capital that has grown hypersensitive to the tax histories of nominees for high office, it was Mr. Ginsburg, one of the nation's leading tax experts, who averted any controversy about the couple's finances. On a few hours' notice, Mr. Ginsburg compiled years of financial records over the weekend. He walked Government accountants through years of filings on Sunday, as Mr. Nussbaum was interviewing Judge Ginsburg in another room of the couple's Watergate apartment on a variety of legal and personal issues.
 
Deduction Defended
 When the Government accountants on Sunday challenged a $100 deduction, the tax professor who had structured some of the most complex corporate transactions was able to defend the accounting easily.
The financial records of the couple were significantly simplified by Mr. Ginsburg's decision in 1980 to sell all of his stock so that his wife would not have to remove herself from cases involving companies or industries in which the family had interests.
Mr. Ginsburg played down his role in the nomination, saying he spoke to only a few legal scholars he knew and only after a friend at the White House asked him, "What have you done about generating support from the academics?"
He said he was told: "Given that her background was as a scholar, if the world doesn't generate at least seven letters from academics then the White House will get very nervous."
The letters poured in -- from politicians like Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas and legal scholars like the presidents of Stanford and Columbia (both former law school deans). A number were not directly solicited by Mr. Ginsburg, who said what he did was merely repeat what he was told by the White House friend whom he declined to identify.
President Clinton said today that he was not influenced by the letters and that they showed "only that a lot of people felt a lot for her."
Mr. Ginsburg, 61 years old, was born in Brooklyn and raised in Rockville Centre, L.I. Through mutual friends, he met Ruth Bader at Cornell, and after his two-year service in the Army and the birth of their daughter, they enrolled a year apart at Harvard Law School. While she was developing a whole new area of law involving equal rights for women, he practiced tax law.
He decided to teach full time in 1977, when he did a stint at Stanford Law School. He sought that job to be with his wife, who had been invited to be a resident fellow for a term at Stanford's Center for Advanced Study in Behavioral Sciences.
In 1971, Mr. Ginsburg met Ross Perot when his law firm represented Mr. Perot in a deal, and the friendship blossomed. He did not work on Mr. Perot's Presidential campaign, although he spoke with his economic adviser, John White, on some issues. Mr. Ginsburg said he had supported Mr. Clinton.
By all accounts, Mr. Perot grew particularly close to Mr. Ginsburg after the lawyer resolved a thicket of thorny tax problems that had threatened the acquisition of Mr. Perot's Electronic Data Systems Inc. by the General Motors Corporation in 1984.
Mr. Ginsburg hesitated before taking the assignment because his law firm represented several of Mr. Perot's competitors. While technically it was not a conflict of interest, Mr. Ginsburg said, "It looked unseemly."
But his long friendship with Mr. Perot, combined with his intellectual interest in completing one of the most challenging mergers, prompted him to do the job. To ease tensions with his law firm, he told Mr. Perot that he would work without pay.
Ultimately, he said, Mr. Perot said he wanted to repay Mr. Ginsburg some way, and after the deal was completed his client said he would endow a chair at any university Mr. Ginsburg liked.
 
Unwanted Monument
 "I said, 'It's a bad idea,' " Mr. Ginsburg recalled. "Endowed chairs are only for dead people."
But Mr. Perot said if Mr. Ginsburg did not pick a school, then the money would go to Oral Roberts University.
"Ross said when the founder of Oral Roberts heard it was to be the Martin D. Ginsburg chair, he took a deep breath and then said, 'Well, Ross, we're all God's children.' "
In the end, the money went to Georgetown University Law Center, where Mr. Ginsburg had been teaching since 1980. But Mr. Ginsburg has not filled the chair, because, he said, he is superstitious, and the interest on the endowment has been used to pay for books at the law school library.
On a shelf in the family's Watergate apartment sits a gift from some of Judge Ginsburg's clerks: a six-inch piece of furniture with a small plaque that identifies it as the Martin D. Ginsburg chair.
