HEADLINE: Cash Woes Cast A Long Shadow Over California

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., June 16

 BODY:
In years past during budget-making season, Tom Orloff, the chief assistant district attorney here, would amble across the street to the Alameda County administration building and plead, wheedle and threaten until he got enough money for his department to survive.
But this year, Mr. Orloff said, "even if we fight and scratch and claw on the county level, we'll still get killed" because of Gov. Pete Wilson's plan to balance the state's $52 billion budget by commandeering $2.6 billion in local property taxes. 
 Elected leaders in the state's 58 counties are howling in protest, with law-enforcement officials, who rely almost entirely on county financing, leading the charge with dire warnings that criminals will go unprosecuted.
Those warnings, and the actual suspension of misdemeanor prosecutions in one cash-starved county for a month, have gotten the attention of California's Governor, who dreads a repeat of last year's two-month budget stalemate, which forced the state to issue i.o.u.'s and sent Mr. Wilson's approval ratings plummeting.
 
Deadline Missed Again
 Mr. Wilson, a Republican, has already suggested extending a half-cent sales tax, due to expire on June 30, for six months, with the revenue earmarked for local law-enforcement. He also has called for a special election next fall so that counties can raise their own sales taxes. And he has asked the legislature to give local governments more flexibility in state-mandated entitlement programs.
But those changes have yet to satisfy the lawmakers in Sacramento, who on Tuesday missed the constitutional deadline for passing a spending plan for the seventh year in a row.
And at least a dozen counties, including the population meccas of Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco, have laid the groundwork for legal action against the state's "property tax grab" by passing ordinances that instructing local financial officials to distribute tax revenue as in the past.
With the sales-tax extension subject to legislative approval and next fall's election a crap shoot in this recession-scarred state, Mr. Orloff is assuming the worst: a loss of $10.1 million, or more than 40 percent of the current financing.
That would force the layoff of half the 140 lawyers, Mr. Orloff said, thus ending the prosecution of all misdemeanors, 47,000 cases last year.
That would mean that shoplifters, vandals, prostitutes, drunken drivers, wife-beaters and those carrying concealed weapons would go unpunished in the rough streets of Oakland and its surrounding communities. Even some felonies might not be prosecuted.
When asked which serious crimes would be ignored, he removed his eye-glasses and squeezed the bridge of his nose in a gesture of weary pessimism .
"No matter what happened, we would continue to do homicide, rape, robbery with injury and major narcotics cases," Mr. Orloff said, citing categories in which the county is either No. 1, 2 or 3 in the state.
Other counties face the same situation, or worse. In Los Angeles, for instance, no misdemeanors or non-violent felonies would be prosecuted under the proposed budget, local officials have said. And a computerized gang-tracking system that is used by police departments nationwide would be disbanded. Jails in Los Angeles County, and elsewhere, have begun early release of some inmates.
In San Joaquin County, where lush farmland has given way to dangerous cities, an early budget decision by the Board of Supervisors led the district attorney to suspend misdemeanor prosecution in May, except for drunken driving, domestic violence and resisting arrest.
Some 1,300 crimes (including the vehicular manslaughter of an 88-year-old woman) went unprosecuted before the board last week restored some financing, a move that followed Governor Wilson's change of heart about parts of his fiscal package and could be reversed in 90 days.
The situation in San Joaquin, featured on ABC News's "Nightline," was a powerful lobbying tool in a state where crying wolf has become an art form in the 15 years since Proposition 13 limited property-tax collection and thus put local governments at risk.
 
Bureaucratic Footwork
 Year after year, interest groups have flocked to Sacramento to claim imminent disaster, only to find themselves in a better position than anticipated. Some money turns up that nobody knew was there. A few vacant positions remain unfilled so the police officers can keep their jobs. A bit of bureaucratic fancy footwork allows a threatened hospital to stay open.
But this year seems different, the fiscal problems in the nation's most populous state beyond the reach of bookkeeping tricks and painless service cuts. Experts point to the cumulative effect of a long recession and the staggering health and welfare costs tied to legal and illegal immigration.
Experts also note that the effects of Proposition 13, which in 1978 sparked a nationwide tax revolt, were muted for all these years because the prosperous state was able to bail out counties by paying most of the costs of education.
But those days ended in 1992, when Governor Wilson wrestled $1.3 billion from the counties, cities and special districts to close a $10.7 billion budget gap. Now the gap is $9 billion, and the Governor wants twice as much money from the localities, although he will likely settle for less.
 
A Landscape Altered
 Despite the dispute between the state and the counties, politicians are predicting a speedier resolution than last year's, because nobody has the stomach for a summerlong stalemate.
On the local level, too, hardship has altered the political landscape. Take last week's meeting of the Alameda County Board of Supervisors, which was set to vote on an ordinance permitting a cut in monthly welfare payments for single adults to $308 from $327.
Mr. Orloff attended the meeting, aware that every dollar spent on welfare is a dollar not available for law enforcement. The supervisors, some of them weeping, voted with little hesitation to cut the grant rather than face such grim alternatives as closing the county juvenile detention center.
"Our problems have gone from epidemic to pandemic," said Supervisor Don Perata, who had never voted for a welfare cut. "This year is the terrible future we've all been talking about."

HEADLINE: CLINTON SEES CUT IN SPACE STATION

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided not to kill the eight-year-old space station project but to proceed instead with a slightly slimmed version of the original design, costing about $10.5 billion over five years, a senior Administration official said today.
That price tag would be at least $1.5 billion more than the President said he wanted to spend, but still falls well below the $17.6 billion it would have cost to complete the latest version of the original design. 
 Mr. Clinton is expected to announce his decision on Thursday evening, when the White House has tentatively planned his first prime-time news conference. While it should please the coalition of lawmakers whose districts benefit from the space station, and who opposed killing or radically redesigning it, even this moderately slimmed version is not assured of passing the budget-conscious House.
Space agency engineers last week gave the President three basic design options for a cheaper, smaller version of the space station, which they hoped would spare the project from budget-cutters trying to remove it from the President's economic program entirely.
 
What Kind of Choices
 Two options -- labeled A and B -- involved scaled-back versions of the original space station, named Freedom, drawn up under President Ronald Reagan. Option A was smaller and more streamlined than option B, which closely resembled the original. Both versions would consist of pressurized modules and solar-power panels attached to a girderlike truss that would be assembled in orbit, after pieces were ferried into space by shuttles.
A third design, labeled option C, was the cheapest alternative and involved a radical reduction of the project -- stripping it to a simple, pressurized cylinder with solar panels attached, and launching it into space with a single shot. It was dubbed "the big can."
A senior White House official said the President had picked a combination of options A and B -- meaning a smaller version of the original design, with simplified electrical and data systems.
The official said that, based on the White House's estimates, the project would probably run around $2.1 billion a year to build, over five years.
 
Coalition With a Cause
 Under such a plan, the first flight of the space shuttle to carry parts of the station into orbit would come in 1997. A laboratory module would be added in 1998, and the station would be ready for occupancy by four astronauts in 2000 or 2001.
Aides said the President opted for this version both because it could keep the station alive at a reasonable cost and because it was the only option that would apparently win enough backing from the coalition of lawmakers and foreign backers pushing the project.
Most of the station is being built in Texas, California, Florida and several other Southern states and has strong political support from lawmakers in those districts. Congressmen from these states strongly opposed the radical option C design and said they would not have agreed to finance it. The same was true of the foreign backers of the project. All of them favored option B, which was the closest to the original.
Canceling or radically streamlining the space station would have had international ramifications for Mr. Clinton, since Canada, Japan and member countries of the European Space Agency have invested hundreds of millions of their own taxpayers' dollars.
 
Preserving Contributions
 Many of the international partners had already developed a good deal of hardware and software for their portions of the space station. They were very concerned that option C would have included none of their contributions, and option A only a portion.
What Mr. Clinton chose, aides say, is basically option A, but with enhancements from option B that would preserve many of the contributions of the international partners.
Mr. Clinton met Monday night with White House advisers and Daniel Goldin, director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to review the options for shrinking the space station. Asked about the project at a press conference on Tuesday, the President said he was carefully studying the options, but he also cited an argument often used by its supporters: "It's important to recognize that the space station offers the potential of working with other nations and continue our lead in a very important area and having significant impact."
Some $8 billion has been spent on the project, which has been plagued by mismanagement and cost overruns.
 
Billions and Billions
 The White House spurred the three-month redesign effort by NASA, ordering it last February to come up with some options that could salvage the program by cutting in half the $17.6 billion estimate for finishing it over five years. The team was asked to come up with three redesigns, for $5 billion, $7 billion and $9 billion. NASA could not meet those targets. The option that the President has selected, his aides say, will probably cost just under $11 billion.
Even with the President's backing, the survival of the station is by no means assured. Those lawmakers who do not have any "station pork" -- the term used by some lawmakers in whose districts parts of the station are being assembled -- do not have a strong political incentive to vote in favor.

HEADLINE: CHINA WINS FIGHT ON RIGHTS GROUPS

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 16

 BODY:
In what was seen as a victory for China's campaign to limit international monitoring of human rights, nongovernmental organizations attending the World Conference on Human Rights were ejected today from the committee drafting the meeting's final document.
The nongovernmental organizations, which include powerful groups like Amnesty International, protested angrily that the United Nations had allowed itself to be browbeaten by China, which had threatened to boycott the drafting committee if independent human rights representatives were present. 
 "A number of delegates told us that China said it would have trouble participating if nongovernmental organizations were present," said Reed Brody, a representative of the International Human Rights Law Group, who had been assigned to the drafting committee. "The Chinese said, 'We don't need baby sitters.' "
China is perhaps the most outspoken of a group of Asian countries that accuses the West of trying to impose its values on regions with different religious and cultural traditions and that objects to moves to strengthen United Nations authority to denounce human rights abuses.
Last week China infuriated the nongovernmental organizations when it persuaded the United Nations to ban the Dalai Lama from addressing rights groups here. After strong Western pressure, the Dalai Lama was allowed to speak to a crowd on the grounds of the United Nations complex, on Tuesday.
 
'No Right to Interfere'
 "At a time when the U.N. should be exercising leadership in advancing human rights, it shows itself to be preoccupied with the sensibilities of its most abusive governments," said Kenneth Roth, acting executive director of the Human Rights Watch, which is based in New York. "By succumbing to this blackmail the U.N. sinks to the level of its most repressive member states."
In presenting Beijing's formal position to the conference on Tuesday evening, however, Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu made no effort to apologize for his Government's stance, noting that on human rights "other countries have no right to interfere."
He also reiterated his Government's view that economic development was the most important human right of any developing country. "The argument that human rights is the precondition for development is unfounded," he said, adding that individual rights could never prevail over those of the state and society.
The hard-line speech was no surprise to Western delegates, but its move to clear independent groups from the drafting committee signaled that China also hoped to achieve many of its objectives in the closed-door negotiations on the final document.
 
Exclusions From Meetings
 That document is theoretically to be adopted by consensus, but Western governments led by the United States have warned that they will not accept "the lowest common denominator" simply to preserve the image of worldwide agreement. Last week those governments also appeared to think that they had won approval for nongovernmental participation in the drafting.
But Mr. Brody said he already recognized signs of trouble on Tuesday, when the chairman of the drafting committee, Gilberto Vergne Saboia of Brazil, informed him that human rights groups would be excluded from informal meetings and that most of the negotiation in the coming days would occur informally.
"It's, of course, a fiction, because the committee meets in the same place with the same interpreters, with the same formality, but it just says it's meeting informally," Mr. Brody, an American lawyer, said shortly after the rights groups had been forced to leave the drafting committee. He added that he expected to be kept informed of developments by Western delegates.
Although the conference will continue until June 25 the 1,000 or so nongovernmental organizations represented here have been deeply frustrated by United Nations rules, not least the decision that in formal discussions specific cases of violations not be mentioned.
In practice that rule was violated on Tuesday by the Bosnian Foreign Minister, Haris Siladzic, who began a strong attack on Serbia for its onslaught on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The conference responded sympathetically, urging the United Nations Security Council to take measures to end "the genocide" in Bosnia.
Today it was the turn of Pakistan's representative, Begun Nusrat Bhutto, to accuse India of carrying out repression in Kashmir. India's chief delegate, J. N. Dixit, responded by accusing Pakistan of carrying out its own violations in the disputed territory.
Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, also addressed the conference, demanding that resolute measures be taken to end Israeli military actions in the occupied territories, actions that he said were "tantamount to genocide." In that case Israel chose not to respond.
The final document will not name specific violators. Instead, the battle of words will be between Western nations that are demanding reaffirmation of the "universality" of human rights and mainly Asian countries that favor redefining human rights.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Carol Rasco;
She's the Advocate She Once Needed

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
AT first glance, it seems a simple portrait of privileged Southern living --
a sparkling backyard pool, a family gathered in a comfortable den, a four-foot-wide television that flickers with camcorder images of a relative's sprawling new home.
Only one thing suggests that Carol Rasco has seen more than suburban comfort. That is the figure strapped in a wheelchair. That is her son, Hamp. 
 He is probably the only mentally retarded 19-year-old to have taught a Presidential confidante. Ms. Rasco, the White House domestic policy adviser, says nothing has taught her more about the need for responsive Government than the challenge of raising a son born retarded and with cerebral palsy.
"My children so much form the core of what my view of domestic policy is about," said Ms. Rasco, who also has a healthy 12-year-old daughter, Mary-Margaret.
Ms. Rasco can tell excruciating stories of getting the runaround from Government agencies, and she often does. Her long and lonely road as a mother has shaped one of her policy goals, which she says is to "help all parents be the best they can be."
Some women in power might view their domestic lives as an inappropriate topics for inquiry; profiles of the President's men, after all, do not usually focus on their roles as fathers. But Ms. Rasco invites such inquiries, turning questions about her policy views into a conversation about motherhood.
She did that recently before a group of company chief executives. She scrapped her prepared remarks on global competitiveness to extemporize on reasons why their future labor force, today's children, needed strong advocates.
She remembers thinking, "Oh dear, do I risk this?" But knowing that other speakers would cover abstract statistics, she told the executives how her experiences had led her to see the need for child advocacy. "Without a strong advocate, my own son would not have gotten what he needed," she says.
As a former elementary-school teacher in a White House thick with Rhodes Scholars, Ms. Rasco occupies an odd Presidential niche. She has nothing of the national reputations enjoyed by her two counterparts, Robert E. Rubin, the economic policy adviser, or W. Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
She is happy to describe herself as an implementer of policies rather than their grand architect, and she seems to have taken a back seat on major issues like the budget and health-care reform. Her colleagues often grasp at straws when trying to describe her ideology, or even, sometimes, her policy positions.
But virtually all agree that she has at least one coveted credential: a deep reserve of Presidential trust, earned during a decade spent as a senior aide to Mr. Clinton when he was Governor of Arkansas. "He loves her," said John Podesta, the White House staff secretary.
Ms. Rasco began as a human-services aide to Mr. Clinton in 1983 and rose to the point where she ran much of the state's daily business for the year that Mr. Clinton was out campaigning for the Presidency. She now provides him with daily briefings on staff and policy developments across the domestic agencies, and she has shown a talent for brokering disputes between warring bureaucracies.
Still, no one is quite sure what Ms. Rasco intends to do with her access, which seems to have remained undiminished by the recent White House upheavals and the arrival of David Gergen as Presidential counselor.
If her colleagues call her views mysterious, Ms. Rasco says that's fine with her. "I don't expect that in four, or hopefully eight, years, people will say, 'Carol Rasco is the godmother of X policy,' " she said. "The Clintons know that I'm in tune and that I can help coordinate their goals."
Asked for a definition of an underclass, for example, she answers, "I'm not going to give you big streams of words." Asked whether she identifies with so-called new Democrats or the old ones, she contends that neither camp has given "a very specific definition of what all that encompasses."
Ms. Rasco, who is 45, has a form of Southern charm that sometimes seems more evocative of the Junior League than the Oval Office. She has a sixth sense for putting guests at ease. She uses words like bumfuzzled, as a synonym for confused.
But she can also be unusually direct. The conversation turns to her son, and the air suddenly fills with vivid images: misshapen hip sockets and a broken femur, body casts and their effects on body smells. Ms. Rasco shows no hesitation stepping before a toilet and fumbling with imaginary straps to illustrate the complexities of her son's daily living.
Her father, Frank Barnes Hampton, said he admired what he called his daughter's purposefulness. "She's learned that a million tears don't change anything," he said.
Ms. Rasco grew up in De Witt, Ark., 65 miles southeast of Little Rock, the daughter of a pharmacist and a homemaker. At the University of Arkansas she worked for a fellow student who was campaigning for student-body president. That student, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, is now Mr. Clinton's chief of staff.
In 1969, at 21, she married Terry Rasco, who is an architect in Little Rock. Four years later, an uneventful pregnancy culminated in a traumatic 24-hour labor. It was a Saturday, her doctor was out of town, and today's health-care reformer found herself in the hands of what she calls an inattentive hospital staff.
"I've always wondered if there wasn't more interest in the Razorback game that afternoon," Ms. Rasco said, referring to the state's passion for the University of Arkansas football team. She still believes that the doctors should have performed a Caesarean section, though she cannot say for sure that it would have prevented the brain damage.
Hamp (his full name is Hampton) turned 5 before he talked, and he was 6 before he was out of diapers. With her husband at work, Ms. Rasco's life shrank to a thousand daily tasks -- bolting her son's sandals onto his tricycle, sticking Velcro on his forks and spoons. "There were nights I was so tired, I would think: 'Why am I doing this? Is it ever going to show fruition?' " she said.
She said her son's subsequent development represented their mutual triumph over doubters and unhelpful bureaucrats. She ignored doctors who suggested she institutionalize him as an infant. She fought the elementary school that had wanted to separate him from nondisabled children. She chased the school-bus bureaucracy until it provided him with a seat belt.
Her fights, she said, gave her empathy with those who were reliant on government, from the elderly to young mothers on welfare.
Ms. Rasco's efforts reached a milestone on June 2, when her son joined the graduation at Hall High School and received a certificate of attendance and a standing ovation.
Hamp speaks slowly, with a hint of a slur, and he has been announcing, with a hint of mischief, the onset of a new disease: "senioritis."
"That's when seniors want to get out," he said.
He left home last summer for an Easter Seals group house, where the staff helps him in and out of bed. He said he is looking for a job that will allow him to use his "social skills."
A training program has taught him to fold napkins and stack sugar baskets, and at restaurants he is quick to fault imperfect ratios of sugar and artificial sweeteners. "It's a hoot," his mother said. His favorite activity is to listen to his portable police radio (his sister, her eyes rolling, notes that he carries it even to the mall).
He attended the news conference at which his mother's appointment was announced, but he carried Kleenex with him, knowing it meant her departure from Little Rock. His old friend Bill Clinton, alarmed at his emotion, waded into the audience to soothe him afterward. Hamp will not reveal what they said. "I call that personal," he said.
Ms. Rasco describes their separation as the kind of difficult-but-healthy experience that all parents and children go through. They stay in touch through visits, phone calls and the fax machine in Hamp's room.
Ms. Rasco's daughter plans to move to Washington in the fall, but her husband's architecture practice will keep him, along with Hamp, in Little Rock.
Ms. Rasco first met Mr. Clinton in 1976, when he was a candidate for state attorney general and spoke to a neighborhood coffee gathering. She later befriended Hillary Rodham Clinton as a fellow member of the First Methodist Church.
During his first term as Governor, Mr. Clinton appointed Ms. Rasco to a state board that ran homes for the disabled. She pushed for programs that placed more disabled people in mainstream settings, like those her son has enjoyed. When Mr. Clinton returned to the Governor's office, in 1983, he brought Ms. Rasco as his liaison to the departments of human services and health.
She brought her mediating talents to bear on the nation's governors, helping forge the consensus for the 1988 Family Support Act, which required some welfare recipients to seek education or training.
But she was also overseeing human services policy when the state's child-welfare system fell apart, as state workers failed to investigate complaints of child abuse and placed children in unsafe foster-care settings. It took a Federal lawsuit to force Mr. Clinton, then an embarrassed Presidential candidate, to raise money to hire and train more workers.
Ms. Rasco said a tightfisted Legislature prevented the changes from coming sooner. "Any time there are children dying, you always should be doing more," she said. "Could we have done it faster? I question that."
The low profile, but high access, that Ms. Rasco brings to her current work can be seen through her role in immunization policy. Earlier this year, Department of Health and Human Services wanted to distribute free vaccines to all children, regardless of family income; the Office of Management and Budget wanted a cheaper plan that gave free vaccines only to the needy.
The decisive moment came in March, when Ms. Rasco went to the President and came back with his decision in favor of the more expensive option, which was subsequently rejected by Congress. She said Mr. Clinton understood the risks and made his own choice. But even now, Ms. Rasco's own views have to be discerned by reading between the lines. She says she wasn't "passionately and vociferously" for the plan, but she "would have been happy to have it go through."
A memorable moment in Ms. Rasco's call for a more helpful Government occurred last winter at a Camp David retreat, when she told her colleagues about a woman she had known in Arkansas. The woman, calling a state agency, had been hung up on by a worker eager to get to lunch. She had gone to Federal buildings that were marked "handicapped accessible," only to find they were not. She had seen her child rejected by state programs for the disabled because he was not indigent and the family was not allowed to pay.
Ms. Rasco caught her colleagues by surprise when she explained why those images would never leave her. "Because," she said, "those experiences were my own."

HEADLINE: A Window on Immigrant Crime;
In Jackson Heights, Drugs, Dirty Money and Prostitution

SERIES: Hidden Economy: Immigrants Underground -- Fifth of six articles.

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
No one knows how much criminal money flows through Jackson Heights, but no one doubts the current is steady and strong. On its busy and peaceful surface, the Queens neighborhood is like so many others where immigrants settle into new lives. People work hard, buy houses and shops and send money to the places they once called home.
Most of the enterprise is legal. But Jackson Heights is also the home to Little Colombia -- where high-level drug dealers operate and where much of their cash is laundered through travel agencies and wire transfer services that line Roosevelt Avenue in conspicuous numbers. By coincidence, the community is also the city's new capital for houses of prostitution. 
 Because of the proliferation of these three elements -- drug dealing, money laundering and prostitution -- Jackson Heights provides a striking glimpse into the other side of immigrant success: immigrant crime.
Estimates vary but experts believe that a quarter of the underground economy in New York City -- about $15 billion -- is generated by criminal activity, like drugs or prostitution, as opposed to activity that is simply illicit, like driving a gypsy cab or vending. Law-enforcement officials say most vendors do not traffic in stolen goods, but simply buy wholesale.
Immigrants by no means hold the market on crime. But there could be no more dramatic demonstration of their involvement in criminal activities than the ship that recently went aground off Rockaway Peninsula carrying nearly 300 illegal immigrants, smuggled like contraband halfway across the globe. Slightly less overt, but with much broader effects, are the tons of cocaine the authorities say are smuggled here -- by land, sea and air -- from South America, and which immigrants in Jackson Heights play a major role in selling.
Officials believe that the amount of illegal cash that washes through Jackson Heights could reach into the billions each year.
"The basic goal is to sell the drugs here and send the money back to the big guys in Colombia," said Cheryl L. Pollack, head of narcotics prosecutions for the United States Attorney's Office in Brooklyn.
Unlike some organized-crime groups -- many Italian, some Irish and some Jewish -- whose members brought over families and became citizens even as they exploited their neighborhoods, the cartels are highly mobile, experts say. The cartel members usually come alone from Colombia, stay only a few years and ship profits home. As a consequence, economists see little economic benefit locally.
 
Low-Grade Activity
 Saskia Sassen, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University who has studied the underground economy, said that at best the drug trade adds a low-grade buzz to Jackson Heights's already vital legitimate economic base: drug dealers rent beepers, cellular phones and apartments to stash drugs and cash.
And through money laundering, the dealers also help prop up many of the 200 or so travel agencies and wire transfer places there. But they do not seem to be buying property or investing heavily in legitimate businesses, experts say.
"The capital we are talking about is a capital that does not circulate in the local economy," Professor Sassen said.
The economic impact of the 60 brothels on Jackson Avenue is even less clear, because the quantity of money is so much smaller. The brothels, which open at night in apartments along Roosevelt Avenue, seem more a neighborhood nuisance and a testament to their workers' desperation to survive however they can.
 
Patterns of Crime
Specialties Divided By Nationality
Community advocates and law-enforcement officials take pains to distinguish the cartel representatives from the 30,000 legitimate Colombians in Jackson Heights and Elmhurst, its sister community to the south.
"Immigrant connotes to me that they come here to live and immigrate to the United States to make a better life," said Thomas F. Sheehan, a Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent who has both lived and worked in Jackson Heights. "I don't think that is the case for a great majority of the drug dealers."
Law-enforcement officials say that criminality among the city's more recent immigrants tends to fall into patterns. Poor women from South America like Diana often work as prostitutes, as do some Korean women. Dominicans move cocaine to the streets. Chinese, and to a lesser extent Sicilians, rule the heroin trade. Nigerians are known as expert smugglers. Some Korean grocers are loan sharks. The Russian mob runs bureaucracy schemes, from Medicare fraud to evading taxes on oil distribution.
Chinese also run gambling houses, and as the city witnessed in the grounding of the Golden Venture, smuggle other Chinese here for a price. The practice provides a telling example of how crime expands within groups: the refugees come illegally, at prices ranging up to $35,000 or more, in trips arranged by Chinese crime groups. Some refugees join heroin-smuggling operations to work off their debt, an Immigration and Nationalization Service official said.
There are also cases in which Chinese gangs -- already deep into extortion, robbery and drugs -- kidnap indebted refugees to ransom them for transportation costs. The official said there have even been cases in which gangs have shown up at Kennedy International Airport to pick up refugees, beating out the organized-crime group that actually arranged for the passage.
 
Devastation at the Fringes
 Even if crime has given a marginal economic boost to Jackson Heights, its impact on other neighborhoods is undeniably devastating. Ansley Hamid, an associate professor at John Jay College, said that cocaine, more than any other drug, sucks the poorest neighborhoods dry. Users impoverish places like the South Bronx and East New York by spending what little cash they have on drugs and stealing anything else of value: cars, televisions, jewelry.
"With cocaine the money flows upward and out of the community," Professor Hamid said. The average street seller, he said, "gets arrested quickly. He becomes a user. His rivals shoot him down."
 
Booming Sex Trade
Desperate Women, Lucrative Choices
While the Cali cartel dealers are shipping fortunes home and living at least a comfortable middle-class existence in this most middle class of immigrant neighborhoods, the prostitutes of Jackson Heights offer a far more painful picture of immigrant crime.
Diana, 33, considers herself more victim than criminal. She earns $25 for every 15 minutes with a man, plus tips. But the brothel keeps 40 percent of her earnings. She came to Queens illegally a year ago, washing floors for $150 a week, not enough to support herself and her three children in Cali. Now she measures business by how many Newport menthols she smokes each night.
"Every customer is one cigarette," she said in Spanish. "Sometimes it's 20 to 30 customers a night and that's 20 to 30 cigarettes." She chain-smoked as she spoke, but by her own rules, should have lit up only three times that night.
Over the last few years, Roosevelt Avenue -- a commercial strip thriving with Hispanic restaurants, pushcarts and newsstands that sell old copies of Colombian papers -- has blossomed with brothels filled with immigrant women like Diana.
Local authorities, including in the Queens District Attorney's office and the police, have closed 30 brothels over the last year. But the brothels -- converted apartments where landlords charge high rents -- keep appearing, run mostly by South American immigrants along with a few Koreans.
The brothel where Diana works, she stood in one of eight cubicles slapped together with wallboard and plaster, and described how she has been a prostitute for only three months and earns $300 or more a night, enough to pay tuition for her children in Colombia and to hire a live-in maid to care for them. Like most of the other eight women in the house -- from Colombia, Venezuela and Peru -- she wants to go home. She will work only for one year and return.
"It's a very difficult country for an immigrant," she said, behind a heavy mask of makeup. "It's not the mecca that everyone says to make money easily."
The house's madam, a savvy 23-year-old from Uruguay named Topacio, would agree about the hardship. But she sees in America almost unbelievable opportunities to make money, legally or not. The owner of three brothels, she has transformed the degradation of prostitution into a small personal fortune.
She recalled her decision to become a prostitute. "I said, 'I can't do this,' " she remembers saying to another prostitute. "But she said, 'You have nothing to lose. You will cry the first day. You won't like it. The second day you will cry more. The third day you will adapt to the first clients. Then the fourth day you will see all the money you made and forget completely your problems.'
On her fourth day, Topacio saw the money. "It was decided," she said.
 
Freeing the Cash
Laundering By Computer
The storefronts looked innocent enough until someone counted them. Then law-enforcement officials realized that the travel agencies, wire transfer centers and change houses were actually the most visible sign of the drug trade. Officials say the stores launder hundreds of millions of dollars each year, mostly sending cash electronically to South America, in addition to making many legal transfers for immigrants who are sending hard-earned money back home.
There are so many of these businesses, and their trade is so obvious, that a casual cynicism about the business has settled into the neighborhood, both on the street and within the businesses themselves, which are decorated with neon signs and huge posters advertising cheap fares to South America.
"Some offices, they do it, but the F.B.I. is on top of things," Juan Vasquez, the manager of one such business, Fax Beepers Communications, offered almost off-handedly. "They come to visit." He said his business handled only legal transactions.
The Drug Enforcement Administration estimates that 90 percent of its money-laundering investigations in the New York area trace back to Jackson Heights. And over the last few years, several of the companies have been tied directly to investigations into the cartels, including one huge company, Delgado Travel, that paid a $1 million fine in 1991 but is still boomingly in business.
"Non-bank financial institutions are the new frontier in the money-laundering struggle," said Charles A. Intriago, a Miami lawyer who edits a national newsletter on money laundering. "We are talking billions."
 
Too Heavy to Handle
 During the 1980's, as the cocaine trade rose and banks came under increasing Federal scrutiny, these businesses suddenly began to proliferate. According to law-enforcement officials, the industry works like this:
Drug dealing is a bulky enterprise because it generates vast amounts of cash ($1 million in $20 bills, for example, weighs 114 pounds; for $5 bills, the price of a mid-sized vial of crack, multiply that by four). So high-level dealers take money to, say, a travel agency to wire money abroad for an 8 percent fee.
Federal law requires that all transactions over $10,000 be reported. But in Jackson Heights, people get around the rules: there is, for example, a practice called "smurfing," breaking large amounts into transactions of less than $10,000. (The name was coined a decade ago by a Justice Department lawyer who imagined the blue cartoon figures magically breaking down piles of cash.) And often transactions of all sizes are not reported, officials say, because the laws lack teeth and regulators are not capable of overseeing every company that wires money overseas.
But is much of the money coming from drug dealers?
"The suspicion is there," said Edward D. Saslow, an Assistant Attorney General who heads the state's Crime Proceeds Task Force. "But it's not proof beyond a reasonable doubt at this moment in our legal history."

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Man Held in Killing of Youth, 16

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
A Brooklyn man has been arrested in the killing of a 16-year-old student near a school for the emotionally disturbed, a shooting that the police said was carried out despite the victim's pleas for mercy.
The suspect, Gregory Gooding, 21 years old, is also wanted for questioning in another shooting in a housing project near where he lived, which is about half a mile from the school where the student was shot. 
 The police believe that Mr. Gooding, who was unemployed and had served a year and half in prison for a street mugging, shot Andre Sarvis after an argument that began with a disparaging remark about a leather jacket, said Lieut. Charles F. Dowd, head of the 79th Precinct Detective Squad.
 
Stalked to a Parking Area
 Mr. Sarvis, a student at the Ellory School in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a school for teen-agers with severe emotional handicaps, was stalked by Mr. Gooding until he reached a small parking area in back of the school, where he was shot twice in the chest at point-blank range, Lieutenant Dowd said.
Before firing, the assailant ignored Mr. Sarvis's screams of "Don't kill me! Don't kill me!"
Witnesses initially told investigators that Mr. Sarvis had been chased by two assailants and that one man had kept watch during the shooting. Lieutenant Dowd said yesterday, however, that there was "no indication at this time that anyone else was involved or that anyone had any knowledge of what Mr. Gooding's intentions were or that anyone else was armed."
"Mr. Gooding is charged as the shooter," Lieutenant Dowd said. "It seems he showed no mercy."
 
Arrested in North Carolina
 The police said that he was arrested early Tuesday morning at his father's house in Williamston, N.C.
Lieutenant Dowd said that housing authority detectives had also been seeking to question Mr. Gooding about a shooting in a nearby housing project, though not in the Tompkins Houses at 200 Throop Avenue, where he lived.
A woman who identified herself only as Mr. Gooding's mother and who refused to give her name said: "He's just my son and I know he ran into trouble."
David Ernst, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Parole, said that Mr. Gooding had been released from prison last November after serving 17 1/2 months for a 1990 mugging.
Lieutenant Dowd said that Mr. Gooding was with a group of people leaving a sneaker store near the school as Mr. Sarvis entered with several friends. Mr. Gooding, he said, made a comment about a jacket worn by one of Mr. Sarvis's friends, leading to an argument between Mr. Gooding and Mr. Sarvis.
Several minutes later, Lieutenant Dowd said, Mr. Gooding was seen chasing Mr. Sarvis to the spot between two parked cars where the shooting took place.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Fall Sharply On Home Building Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices plunged the daily limit yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the Government released disappointing home construction data for May.
While the May housing starts rose 2.4 percent to the highest level in five months, it was less than half the 5.1 percent increase the market had been expecting.
 
July Lumber at $273.30
 The July lumber delivery dropped the daily limit of $10 per 1,000 board feet and settled at $273.30. 
 "The key thing to remember is the confidence level," said a lumber analyst, Steve Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago. "That's probably limiting how aggressively people are in purchasing new homes.
"People are not ready to commit themselves to the long term," he said. "Jobs and job security are certainly still rather questionable for a lot of people."
The incentive of lower interest rates has not done the job it was expected to do, he said.
Bud Merrill of Shearson Lehman Brothers in Eugene, Ore., was more optimistic and said the housing starts, which are based on building permits issued, have been historically shy of the true construction level.
"My best sense is to look at where interest rates are," he said. "I look at that as the main key. First-time buyers can get in the market now."
Mr. Platt, Mr. Merrill and Steve Moore of Moore Research Center, also in Eugene, agreed that the sharp decline yesterday could also be attributed to traders who were selling futures because contract prices were too high in relation to the cost of lumber in the cash market.
But Mr. Moore played down the impact of the housing starts data. "That might have a little to do with it," he said, "but the market was already on its way down."
Elsewhere, energy futures prices turned higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, responding to industry data showing a decline in crude oil stocks that was greater than expected.
Light sweet crude oil for July advanced 26 cents and settled at $18.84 a barrel; July heating oil was 0.45 cent higher at 52.45 cents a gallon; July gasoline was 0.86 cent higher at 54.79 cents a gallon, and July natural gas was 4.1 cents higher at $2.193 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rockefeller Center With Clay Feet

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
There is something fascinating about seeing the rich get poorer, and the spectacle is even more engrossing when it involves a storied location -- Rockefeller Center -- and storied owners as well.
It was just a few years ago -- 1989 to be exact -- when the Rockefeller family created an uproar by selling 80 percent of the center's owner, the privately held Rockefeller Group, to the giant Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan. (The other 20 percent of this symbol of American capitalism remained in the family's hands.) 
 At the time, the purchase seemed a coup for the Japanese. Now it appears to be one of the worst buys on record. Income from rents at the center does not cover payments on the mortgage, and the Mitsubishi-Rockefeller owners are suffering big losses. They lost $49.6 million in 1992 and are likely to lose even more this year.
 
Lease Renewals
 A still bigger hit seems certain in 1994 when, because of a historical quirk, leases covering almost half of the center's 6.2 million square feet come due. Renewals for those leases are being negotiated now, amid the worst real estate market many in the industry can remember. And while the center is doing pretty well at renewing leases in a tough market, the rents are less than half of what was projected in 1985 when a public real estate investment trust holding a mortgage on the property was formed.
"The fact that the cash flow from the building would not meet mortgage payments was expected," said Catherine C. Creswell, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons. "What is out of line is the new rents they sign on leases that turn over, which will be dramatically below expectations."
While such losses would be intolerable to many companies, Mitsubishi is a giant organization that is thought to take a long view of its investments. Thus, it is not widely considered likely to walk away from the property. But as the monthly deficits continue, as is likely, Ms. Creswell said, "the question becomes, how long will they be willing to support this?"
The question is a critical one not just for Mitsubishi and the Rockefellers but also for the 60,000 public shareholders in Rockefeller Center Properties.
In 1985, the Rockefeller family invited the public to participate in the Rockefeller Center magic by creating Rockefeller Center Properties -- a real estate investment trust, or REIT -- to hold a $1.3 billion mortgage on 12 of the center's buildings. The trust's main asset is still the mortgage on the buildings.
As the center has suffered, so has the REIT, which offers the best -- or really the only -- window into the economics of the center, because the Rockefeller Group is privately held. Although the center's owners continue to make their mortgage payments to the REIT, the uncertainty hanging over the center has hurt the investment trust. Despite the recent boom in REIT's, the Rockefeller trust's share price and dividend have plummeted.
 
'Bottom of the Well'
 The trust's plunge, reflects the fact that the New York office market "is at the bottom of the well," said Edward P. Fontaine, president and chief executive of the REIT.
The REIT's share price fell to $7.50 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, about half of what it was a year ago. In December, it sliced its dividend almost in half, from $1.92 a year to $1. Then, in January, one of the REIT's bankers, on 24 hours' notice, called due a $20 million loan that Mr. Fontaine said the company had expected would be rolled over.
In late April, the company said it expected to make another dividend cut, of 20 cents to 30 cents a year. That cut will be the result of a restructuring agreement on a $200 million credit line that requires the company to sell securities to reduce the letter of credit.
Still, Mr. Fontaine said he was heartened by the center's progress in filling its office space. Although the rents at the center are down, big tenants are staying, and vacancy rates of 6 percent are very low compared with the rest of the midtown Manhattan market.
Out of 14 tenants that have 50,000 or more square feet, five have renewed, including Simon & Schuster with 195,000 square feet, the law firm Chadbourne & Parke with 265,000 square feet and The Associated Press with 167,000 square feet. The center's strategy has been to concentrate first on the big tenants and then focus on the remaining 200 or so smaller leases that expire in 1994.
 
A Falling Appraisal
 As the leases are renegotiated, the value of the properties continues to fall. This year, for example, the REIT's appraisal of the buildings dropped to $1.2 billion, a cut of $400 million -- or 25 percent -- below last year's appraisal. And many industry insiders say even that appraisal may be too high in this market.
"The concern," Ms. Creswell said, "is that if you have a property that is worth less than the mortgage, might they not want to renegotiate? And No. 2, what's to prevent them from walking away?"
But Mr. Fontaine discounts the owners' turning over the properties. "We get a question a week on whether it's possible that the borrower would walk away," he said. "Sure, it's possible, but it'd be expensive."
Refinancing is a different thing, though. Real estate industry insiders have suggested lately that Mitsubishi is considering how to refinance.
"Is there a chance that they would look at alternate forms of financing?" Mr. Fontaine asked. "Absolutely. Are they doing it? I know they're not. And they haven't approached us."
When the center was built between 1932 and 1940 on the blocks from 48th to 51st Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues (now Avenue of the Americas), it was a modern marvel dressed in austere limestone with Art Deco twists. It included the golden statue of Prometheus as well as a mural by the Mexican artist Diego Rivera, which was eventually destroyed, reportedly because the Rockefeller family was horrified that it depicted Lenin. The original buildings were joined by added constructions and purchases through 1973.
The center was built by the Rockefellers on land owned by Columbia University. For years, the Rockefellers paid rent on the land, and then, in 1984, they bought it. Because Columbia and the Rockefeller Group had agreed on the previous land lease in the last real estate depression in 1973, with a 21-year renegotiation clause, many leases were written to expire in 1994 -- when market conditions would presumably have changed.
 
Expected a Bonanza
 The latest chapter in the center's 65-year history began in the white-hot real estate market seven years ago, when the financial wizards were predicting that the buildings' office rents on new and renewed leases would soar to an average $74 a square foot by 1993. Instead, because of the real-estate crash that followed the overbuilding of the 1980's, rents are about $31 a square foot.
To make the deal more attractive when the public real estate investment trust was created in 1985, the REIT was given an option, effective in 2000, to convert the $1.3 billion mortgage to a 71 percent equity share of the ownership of the Rockefeller Group or to switch the loan to floating-rate notes due in 2007 and leave 100 percent ownership with the Rockefeller Group. While majority ownership of the properties sounded enticing at the time, it may not be so if the market remains weak.
Four years after the REIT was created, the Rockefeller family was able to take more money out of the properties when Mitsubishi paid $846 million for a 51 percent interest in the Rockefeller Group, followed by a $527 million investment for another 29 percent. That deal occurred just as the market was poised for its crash.
Officials at Mitsubishi Estate, which is intensely private, did not return several telephone calls seeking comment on Rockefeller Center finances or their plans. At the Rockefeller Group, which manages the properties through a subsidiary, the Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, there was no comment on substantive issues.
Mr. Fontaine dismissed the likelihood that Mitsubishi would walk away from its investment. By doing so, he said, the Mitsubishi-Rockefeller owners would forfeit a $200 million letter of credit, an estimated $175 million for a special tax on forgiveness of debt and all rights to any piece of the center.
As the REIT moves through these difficult times, it is also going through a fundamental change in its relationship with the Rockefeller Group. On June 1, Mr. Fontaine, who also served as vice president and treasurer of the Rockefeller Group, left that position, becoming an employee solely of the REIT.
All other REIT officers also resigned their Rockefeller Group positions, in a move Mr. Fontaine said was intended to emphasize the arm's-length relationship between the public and private companies. In April, David Rockefeller also resigned as a director of the REIT.
In the same vein, the REIT, which has shared offices with the Rockefeller Group in the Simon & Schuster Building at 1230 Avenue of the Americas, is moving out -- to a 3,000-square-foot new office in 1270 Avenue of the Americas, two blocks north, where Mr. Fontaine says he got "a market deal" on the rent. Thus, the REIT joined the train of other tenants looking at lease renewals in 1994 because of a twist of history.
And despite the upheavals, the analysts' view of the REIT is by no means unanimous. While Alex. Brown has rated the REIT as a sell or a hold since 1985, the Boston-based Penobscot Group discounts the possibility of a default and is less pessimistic. Penobscot issued a report in May saying, "We continue to rate shares a buy at or below a price of $7 a share."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies on Prospects Of German Rate Reductions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rallied to a three-month high against the German mark yesterday on continued expectations of a reduction in German interest rates.
The gains spilled into other currencies, giving the dollar a broad-based lift. But some traders cautioned that the move up seemed driven mainly by speculators and technical factors and the market could face a correction in the near term. 
 Gold, meanwhile, edged higher in New York after soaring overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery rose 70 cents a troy ounce, settling at $371.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for spot gold of $370, up $1.
The rally of the dollar came even though the German central bank failed to cut one of its short-term interest rates during its regular weekly repurchase operations yesterday. Many in the market thought a cut would signal the intention of the Bundesbank to ease its widely watched discount rate at its biweekly policy-making meeting today.
But a widespread belief persisted that the central bank would ease the rates at its next meeting on July 1, said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.
 
Pressure Intensifies
 By easing rates in two weeks, the bank could help stimulate the ailing German economy without appearing to bow to political and market pressures for an imminent rate cut, Mr. Malpede said.
The pressure intensified yesterday amid reports that the German economy was expected to shrink in the second quarter of 1992. The reports, which were attributed to an unnamed German Government official, helped push the dollar through the important 1.6500-mark level in early New York trading.
The dollar ended trading in New York at 1.6570 marks, up more than a pfennig from 1.6460 marks late Tuesday. The last time the dollar closed that high in New York was on March 17, when it finished at 1.6620 marks.
The dollar was also quoted at 106.45 Japanese yen in New York, up from 105.75 yen late Tuesday. And the British pound fell to $1.5050, from $1.5155 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Rose Only 2.4% During May

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Builders broke ground for new homes at only a modestly faster pace in May, despite a reported early-spring sales boom and a rise in construction jobs, the Commerce Department reported today.
The somewhat disappointing 2.4 percent rise in housing starts meant this crucial sector is likely to contribute almost nothing to gross domestic product for the April-June quarter despite the lowest mortgage rates in about 20 years and a reversal of lumber prices that soared over the winter. 
 Moreover, analysts noted that permits for future home construction edged up a scant 1.2 percent last month.
 
 
Expecting Better
 "We've been expecting a better sort of snapback" following a poor, storm-ravaged first quarter, David F. Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said.
In a separate report today, the Federal Reserve said industrial production climbed two-tenths of 1 percent last month, a lackluster rise but about what had been expected based on job and workweek statistics reported in early June.
Two of the depressants on housing, which is considered a predictive indicator of the economy at large, are thought to be some lingering effects of the doubling of lumber prices between October and March and the expiration of tax incentives to build apartments for the poor. Yet these seem considerably outweighed by general uncertainty among potential buyers.
The rise in starts for May, to an annual pace of 1,244,000, was almost entirely accounted for by single-family homes. A small gain in buildings with two to four dwelling units was offset by a decline for apartment houses containing five or more units.
"What we're looking at is steady if unspectacular increases on the single-family side and continued weakness on the multifamily side," Mark Obrinsky, senior economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said. "I would expect to see more of this" in coming months.
The Commerce Department today revised upward, to 8.1 percent from 6.7 percent, its estimate of the starts gain for April while reporting that the March decline, 4.7 percent, was even steeper than had been thought.
Regionally, starts in May were mixed, with the Midwest and South posting gains of 10.2 and 2.8 percent, respectively, while the West had a 3.3 percent decline. The Northeast showed a negligible decline.
New England and California, Mr. Seiders predicted, would continue to be among the weakest markets.
Permits, which some specialists regard as a more reliable statistical indicator of current -- but not future -- activity, were also mixed last month. The 1.2 percent rise, following a 6.5 percent April spurt, occurred mainly in the Midwest and to a lesser extent in the Northeast. The South and West, on the other hand, recorded small declines.
 
 
Earlier Reports
 May's limited gain in starts seemed to belie earlier reports that sales of new homes soared 22.7 percent for the month, leaving inventories at the lowest point since the early 1970's, and that construction jobs rose 103,000 in April and May.
Although industrial production was up only a lackluster two-tenths of 1 percent, output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities has now risen for eight straight months -- the longest such string in a decade.
The operating rate at industrial companies remained unchanged in May, at 81.6 percent.
Manufacturing production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May. Production of durable goods -- big ticket items ranging from computers to cars -- edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, while nondurable goods output advanced three-tenths of 1 percent. Mining output jumped half of 1 percent. A 1 percent rise in oil and gas drilling helped offset a 2 percent drop in coal mining. Output at utilities fell three-tenths of 1 percent.

(Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Good Demand Seen for Trump Notes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
He is still Donald J. Trump. He still has financial problems and a history of stinging his bondholders. But it appears that his re-entry into the bond market with two issues backed by the Trump Plaza casino may be greeted with a lot of demand.
And if this is the case, Mr. Trump's bankers are probably going to be very happy. Because instead of accepting securities with no immediate interest payments they will walk away with cash. 
 People connected with the offering said the demand for the most controversial part of the new offering -- $60 million in payment-in-kind notes that could have a yield around 15 percent -- might be strong enough that the $25 million that Mr. Trump's bank creditors had been expected to hold could now be sold to the public.
"That real possibility does exist," said one official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. But he said Mr. Trump was the one who had to decide if the notes the banks were to take could be sold to the public.
That decision is expected to be made today, when the entire $385 million deal is expected to be priced.
Last night, the Casino Control Commission approved Mr. Trump's plan.
Some analysts said they expected the demand for these notes to come from high-yield mutual funds, which are becoming more popular with small investors looking for better returns at a time when interest rates are low.
Under the deal, there are $325 million in eight-year mortgage notes due in 2001, $10 million more than had been planned earlier this week. While there are portfolio managers who will not touch them because of Mr. Trump's bankruptcies, there has been a pretty good reception nonetheless. One reason is the apparent bottoming of the recession in the casino industry. Another is that the notes are a first mortgage on the casino and it appears, using current numbers, that the assets are there to cover the mortgage.
"Would I lend Donald Trump money on an unsecured basis? No," said one protfolio manager considering the offer, which is handled by the lead underwriter, Merrill Lynch. "But if he has a good property to secure it, I have to look."
The talk in the market yesterday was that the mortgage bonds would yield around 11.25 percent.
But it is the second part of the deal that has raised eyebrows, because of the risks that some analysts argue that it carries for investors given its design and Mr. Trump's history. That is $60 million in 10-year payment-in-kind notes.
A payment-in-kind note allows the issuer to pay the interest by issuing new notes with the face value of the interest owed. In the Trump deal, payment-in-kind can be made for the first eight years on the 10-year note. To make the notes more attractive they come with a warrent that allows the holder to get an additional $1,000 for each original $5,000 payment-in-kind note at no additional cost.
The payment-in-kind notes are expected to be priced to yield 150 basis points more than the yield on the mortgage notes, which means about 12.75 percent. The added value from the warrants increases the effective yield to around 15 percent, analysts said.
If the demand some underwriters were hearing about yesterday holds it may be possible to sell $60 million of these notes to the public instead of the $35 million anticipated in the most recent prospectus for the issue.
The manager who is considering buying the mortgage bonds said he would not go near the payment-in-kind notes. "These PIK's tend to be Pacmen; they tend to eat companies," he said. The official who indicated that the demand for the PIK's was growing acknowledged that there were negative views about the notes.
"That is what makes a market," he added.
 
Corporate Bonds

Time Warner Inc., in another move to pare its debt burden, yesterday sold $2.1 billion of liquid yield option notes, known as Lyons. The notes are zero-coupon bonds that are convertible into Time-Warner stock.
The deal, done through Merrill Lynch, raises about $782 million for the company. The 20-year discounted notes were priced at $372.43 per $1,000 of face value. They pay no interest but the holder gets the $1,000 of the face value at maturity. They are also convertible into Time-Warner stock at $48 a share. The stock closed yesterday at $36.75, down 50 cents.
 
Treasury Market

There was little action in the Treasury market yesterday. The price of the 30-year bond was up 4/32 as the yield dropped to 6.81 percent, from 6.82 percent Tuesday. The prices of Treasury notes were also little changed.
Investors seemed to be taking a break after digesting the good news on inflation in May that came with the report that the Producer Price Index was unchanged last month and the Consumer Price Index was up only one-tenth of 1 percent.
Lawrence Lindsay, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, may have unsettled a little of the good feeling on inflation with his remarks to the National Association of Business Economists in Washington. He told them "the deceleration of inflation has stopped."

HEADLINE: A Troubled Life Ends

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
In a sense, Johnny Ray Cromartie never really left his old neighborhood. In 1971, his mother moved the family out of its apartment at 147th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem, but Johnny kept going back.
It was in that neighborhood, dotted with trash-strewn vacant lots and buildings long missing their window panes, that he had most of his numerous run-ins with the law in the 1970's. People in the area recall that in recent years, a time when he stayed out of trouble, the heavy-set, soft-spoken man still came around regularly. 
 And it was there, a block away from the apartment where he grew up, that on May 22, Johnny Cromartie, 40 years old, was arrested for the last time. Two and a half days later, he died in police custody at New York Downtown Hospital, under sharply disputed circumstances. The Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, has ruled the death a homicide, the result of a severe beating by the police and his inability to breathe properly in the face-down position in which officers had put him.
His death has once again focused attention on the Police Department's handling of suspects in custody, and led to questions about whether officers used excessive force in subduing a man who, a lawyer for the family says, may have been having an epileptic seizure. But just as the facts of Mr. Cromartie's death remain a mystery, so do the details of his life.
His face was familiar to the men who congregate outside Shop Mart Deli Grocery at the intersection where he was arrested. But the men, who would not give their names, knew little about him and nothing of his home life. "He kept to himself," one said. "He didn't say much."
Though Mr. Cromartie lived with his mother, Laura C. Pruitt, a nurse's aide, in a small, neat apartment in the Abraham Lincoln Houses in East Harlem, she confessed to having little knowledge of how her son passed his days. "He never hung around here," she said.
Seated in her living room, surrounded by plants, family photos and prints of Bible scenes, Mrs. Pruitt, 61, described the second of her three sons as a friendly but quiet man -- an account supported by her neighbors. He sometimes did cleaning work, she said, but was unemployed when he died. Five years younger than his brother Curtis and 10 years older than his brother Gregory, Johnny Cromartie was not particularly close to either one, she said.
 
Bouts With Epilepsy
 While not a stellar student, he liked to read and did fairly well at Benjamin Franklin High school, graduating in 1971, she recalled.
Mr. Cromartie developed epilepsy as a young man but controlled it with daily medication, although he had a few serious seizures that landed him in the hospital for a few days, his mother said.
He liked to draw and did it well -- an aspect of his life that the regulars of his old neighborhood knew nothing about. Hanging on a wall in his bedroom, whose windows look out over the East River, is one of his works, a portrait of the music duo Ashford and Simpson.
Mr. Cromartie was married in 1980, but members of his family insist that he never lived with Teresa Cromartie and had not seen her in years. Attempts to reach Mrs. Cromartie, who has filed a notice of claim with the city for an $11 million lawsuit over her husband's death, were unsuccessful.
Mrs. Pruitt refused to discuss either her son's criminal record or suggestions that he was an alcoholic. Despite her insistence that he "never bothered anybody," as a young man he was frequently in trouble with the law.
By 1977, at age 24, Mr. Cromartie had been arrested eight times and convicted once of a felony weapons charge and three times of misdemeanors. In 1980, he pleaded guilty to second-degree robbery, his second felony conviction, and served more than three years of a prison sentence of three to six years. But between a 1984 arrest, on a narcotics charge that was later dismissed, and his final arrest his record was clean.
"As you can see, he was no Boy Scout," said Suzanne Trazoff, the Police Department's Deputy Commissioner for Public Information.
But the prevailing interpretation of his record in his old neighborhood was markedly different. "Around here, if you're a black man, you get arrested," one man said. "The most amazing thing is he didn't get in trouble for nine years."
At 12:09 P.M. on Saturday, May 22, Mr. Cromartie was picked up by the police at the corner of Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 146th Street. An officer called Mrs. Pruitt that day and told her that her son was in jail. "That was the last I heard from them until they told me he was dead," she said.
The next day, at the Central Booking Unit in downtown Manhattan, Mr. Cromartie suffered a seizure, and at 5:35 P.M. was taken to the New York Downtown Hospital emergency room. From there the story become murky.
Ms. Trazoff said she knows only that Mr. Cromartie was admitted to the hospital the following evening. A law-enforcement official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that after treatment at the emergency room, the prisoner was returned to jail on Sunday night, then taken to the hospital again on Monday evening, after a second seizure.
A report filed by an officer says that at 13 minutes after midnight on Tuesday, May 25, in hospital room 409, Mr. Cromartie became violent with officers Mose Walton and Richard DiCostanzo and tried to escape. It happened, Ms. Trazoff said, when the officer who had been on guard duty removed his handcuffs from Mr. Cromartie's wrists to turn him over to another officer.
Dr. Hirsch's report said that the prisoner was restrained for "agitated behavior consistent with delirium tremens," a condition symptomatic of alcohol withdrawal.
But C. Vernon Mason, Mrs. Pruitt's lawyer, suggested that what officers called combative behavior may have been yet another seizure. He and the Rev. Al Sharpton, who claims to have spoken with a witness whom he would not name, said there was no escape attempt. But they acknowledged, and law-enforcement officials confirmed, that the witness did not see the start of the beating.
The two officers called for assistance, and as many as five officers, whose names have not been released, responded, said a law-enforcement official who insisted on anonymity. Three minutes later, the report said, Mr. Cromartie was subdued. The official said he did not know what role Officers Walton and DiCostanzo played.
Citing the witness's account, Rev. Sharpton said that only two officers, both white, struck Mr. Cromartie, and that they shouted racial epithets at him.
Later that day, Mrs. Pruitt came home from work to find a note on her door asking her to call a police detective. "Regarding your son," it said. "Important." She called.
"They said he kept fighting the police and they had to restrain him and he went into cardiac arrest and he died," she said. "I told him, 'You all killed him. You killed my son.' "

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Risks For Clinton in His New Trade Policy Toward Japan.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FOR months, the Clinton Administration has been scolded for failing to spell out a trade policy toward Japan that went beyond rhetorical cheap shots. Now the White House has obliged, staking out a "results oriented" middle ground apparently calculated to disarm Japan-bashers without touching off a trade war.
From this limited perspective, the policy will probably succeed. Hard-core protectionists in Congress will be isolated, at least for the moment. And while the Japanese Government is unhappy with President Clinton's casual dismissal of what it views as major concessions negotiated with the Bush and Reagan Administrations, Japan has a facility for making lemonade out of lemons. "There is absolutely no question the talks will be successful," assured Hiromoto Seki, the consul general of Japan in New York. 
 But that is modest comfort to embattled defenders of free trade, who see the demands for specific targets for import penetration of the Japanese market as a step toward the cartelization of global markets. And it may yet backfire on President Clinton, who could lose control of trade policy to Congress and shore up the waning influence of "Japan Inc." Most ominous perhaps, it could stem the torrent of Japanese capital financing economic development from Malaysia to Maui.
Putting the best face on it, Mr. Clinton is only following the path of Presidents Ford, Carter, Reagan and Bush. All were free traders. But all balanced the political necessity of appeasing domestic industries against the broader national interest in open trade and close ties with the other industrial democracies.
The best face, though, is not the only face. Unlike his recent predecessors, President Clinton has signed on to the trendy view that governments can do better than flawed free markets -- that subtle Japanese barriers to imports leave Washington with little choice but to negotiate about results rather than process. And while the Administration rejects the description "managed trade," Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist from Columbia University and a senior adviser to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, argues that Mr. Clinton's team is "weaseling over terminology."
Whatever you call it, does it constitute a step backward? Nothing Mr. Clinton wants could prove as costly as the restraints on auto and steel imports extorted from our trade partners over the last two decades in the name of realpolitik. Indeed, Administration sources proudly note that this White House will not front for inefficient industries looking for a free ride.
One catch, argues Gary Saxonhouse, a University of Michigan specialist in the Japanese economy, is that import targets meant only as benchmarks have a way of becoming quotas. The semiconductor accord with Japan negotiated by the Reagan Administration, he points out, merely stated that 20 percent penetration by foreign producers was "obtainable." But "every time a number is thrown around," Mr. Saxonhouse concludes, "it's treated as an agreement." And if the new targets are not met, the President will face enormous pressure from Congress to retaliate.
What is more, the only way Japan can enforce these "nonagreements" is to place "nonquotas" on purchases of American products by industries and commercial distributors. That might seem as natural as mom's sweet bean cake to the interlocking directorate of government bureaucrats and business barons who supposedly run Japan.
But Japan Inc. is not the monolith so dear to the imaginations of Michigan Congressmen and Michael Crichton. Coordination of business has never been as great as in, say, South Korea and probably is not much greater today than in France. Ironically, the emphasis on numerical targets would undermine the trend toward decentralization of the Japanese economy. "We would feed a system we do not like," Mr. Saxonhouse argues.
The other risk of the Clinton policy is that America may soon regret its successes in transforming Japan into a nation of world-class consumers. At least some members of the Administration understand that Japan's ballooning surplus earnings abroad, roughly 3 percent of national income, have little to do with import barriers and virtually everything to do with the Japanese recession. Aggressive spending and tax cuts -- the policy recommended by Washington and halfheartedly carried out by Tokyo -- would thus serve everyone's interest by increasing total output.
But once the Japanese economy again reaches full capacity, Tokyo will only be able to reduce its remaining foreign surplus by diverting savings going abroad into domestic consumption or investment. And if Japan does not generate a good chunk of the trillions of dollars needed to transform the third world and the former socialist economies into prosperous democracies, it is not clear who will.
From 1870 to 1914, Britain invested 5 percent of its national income overseas, helping to power a period of spectacular world growth. America and the European Community, natural heirs to the British role a century later, are actually net importers of capital. It would be sad if Japan, the only great economy that saves more than it invests at home, is bludgeoned into conformity at the expense of billions of poor people around the globe.
