HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Wanted: Summer Jobs for Teens

 BODY:
The latest national figures show an increase in job growth and a slight easing of the unemployment rate, from 7 to 6.9 percent. But the picture is not so rosy for teen-agers, particularly urban youths.
Nationwide, about 20 percent of teen-agers are unemployed. However, New York City officials report that 40 percent of city teens were jobless during the first three months of this year. That's about twice the rate of just two years ago -- and the highest recorded level in 25 years. 
 Entry-level job opportunities for teens have dropped sharply with the recession and demands for higher job skills. That's why the Summer Youth Employment Program, run by the city's Department of Employment, and Summer Jobs, run mainly by private groups, are important stepping stones toward employment. They give young people age 16 to 21 practical work experience and show them new possibilities for their lives.
But even as the need rises, the number of young people served by these programs may plummet below last year's level. New York City is likely to have 15,000 fewer public sector jobs this year because of Federal budget cuts.
That puts more pressure on private companies to help make up the difference. The Summer Jobs program is having difficulty matching last year's 42,500 private-sector jobs.
Even more jobs are needed this year to accommodate the 100,000 youths who have signed up to work. Giving them a boost in the job market could improve prospects for their future -- and the city's. Companies that need help -- and want to help -- are urged to call (212) 888-JOBS.

HEADLINE: Don't Treat Air Quality in Planes as a Luxury

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One step forward, two steps back. I was astonished to read "Frequent Fliers Saying Fresh Air Is Awfully Thin at 30,000 Feet" (front page, June 6), on the reduction of circulation of fresh air on newer airplanes. Just as we were permitted to breathe more freely when smoking was eliminated on short flights, we learn that the quality of the air in the cabins has been decreased. 
 Now, in addition to the normal stress of travel, those prone to headaches and the nausea of motion sickness will have to worry about not getting enough fresh air.
Migraine and its associated symptoms of visual disturbance and nausea are a very common human ailment. It is well known by physicians that migraine syndrome or vascular headaches can be triggered by several different stimuli such as reduced levels of oxygen, pollutants, toxic fumes and certain foods.
In addition, you cite studies stating that decreased circulation of fresh air may increase the rate of transmission of contagious respiratory infections among passengers.
Air quality on and off the ground should be a primary concern to all of us. With all of the discussion regarding health care in our country, our best method of cost containment is preventive medicine. Whether or not airline officials have received a "significant increase in passenger complaints" should not be an argument for ignoring air quality on airplanes.
I would hope the scientists and business people of the airline industry would put passenger health above economic considerations. In any case, air quality should be a top-priority item regulated by the Government, not subject to entrepreneurial dynamics.
 
JANE PORTNOY, M.D.
Louisville, Ky., June 10, 1993

HEADLINE: Minimum Tax Closes Corporate Loopholes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Liberals Fight Clinton Plan to Ease Tax on Companies" (Business Day, June 10) states: 
 "For many large companies, the best news about President Clinton's economic package is a little-known frighteningly complex provision that would ease requirements for companies to pay a minimum tax when their profits fall to zero."
On the contrary, the point of the minimum tax is to tax profitable companies that report little or no taxable income because of loopholes in the regular corporate tax system.
For instance, last year, Texas Utilities reported more than $1 billion in profits to shareholders. Without the minimum tax, it would have paid no Federal income tax at all. Because of the minimum tax, the company paid $19.6 million -- better than nothing.
If the minimum tax is gutted, profitable corporate giants will again avoid paying any significant Federal income tax. The proposed change is a bad idea.
 
MICHAEL P. ETTLINGER
Tax Policy Director
Citizens for Tax Justice
Washington, June 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Science Education Must Discover Real World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a graduate of the California Institute of Technology, I share the pain of the capable young men and women who find their futures clouded by the uncertainty in science and engineering careers (front page, June 6). Caltech and its sister institutions are in trouble. The roots of this problem are deep. 
 The first part of the problem is historical. Directly or indirectly, the Department of Defense, the national laboratories and the defense and space industry consumed more than half the scientists and engineers the universities produced. These national needs also affected research and teaching. Now that market for graduates has weakened, and they are the first to feel the pain.
The second part of the problem is the specialization within the universities. Caltech has virtually the same divisional structure as at its beginnings, seven decades ago. The highly specialized training this provides is good up to a point. However, it has to be complemented by interdisciplinary programs that address the broad problems of society. Caltech has generally shied away from these messier, real-world problems.
Caltech, other universities and related institutions must re-examine their roles. Scientific and engineering skills are still needed for a myriad of problems, including preserving the environment, providing a sustainable economy and assuring human health and well-being. It is up to each institution to reorganize or redirect itself to meet these needs, before its graduates are no longer marketable.
At the same time, Federal policy in science and applied technology has to share the risk taking with the universities. The Government needs to reorganize and redirect the way it provides Federal supporting funds. Without Federal flexibility and vision, initiative from the universities will not succeed.
 
KENNETH L. HEITNER
Vienna, Va., June 6, 1993

HEADLINE: Let's Stop Using 'Liberal' as a Dirty Word

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 6 front-page report of a New York Times/CBS News poll finding that most Americans view President Clinton as "liberal" was incomplete and carried a hidden bias. While the poll indicates a growing perception of the President as liberal, another message seeps through: "liberal" as negative. 
 You are encouraging an ill-informed and reactionary "liberal equals marginal" stance that does not reflect the diversity and strength of liberal belief. I do not think you would so blithely present contrasting ideological viewpoints in this light. One cannot imagine your giving such a spin to "conservative."
I was pleased that you analyzed the poll extensively, including the figures that show negative opinions on Congress and Ross Perot. However, this was buried deep in the article, and a casual reader would simply absorb the bias of the first few paragraphs.
A large segment of the American political body is progressive and unapologetically liberal. To many of us, President Clinton's cautious and constantly revised budget does not go nearly far enough. With the President's tendency to placate the right, buttressed by the incessant howling of commentators about the deficit, this view gets little acknowledgment.
We do not all see the deficit as the monster in a cage, isolated and hungry, that needs to be starved into submission. The deficit is the symptom of a complicated accumulation of deficits that we have been subsisting on as a society, most ravenously for the last 12 years. These are deficits in our national body: the drains left open on our educational system, our cultural systems, our health system, our environment itself.
We cannot just "attack" the deficit, a phrase deliberately disarming in its simplicity. We have to rebuild, reprioritize, reorder and deepen our understanding of the integration of all citizens in the economic and cultural system. President Clinton's original stimulus plan was a hesitant step in the right direction; a cautious testing of the public waters we are swimming in. It was quickly drowned.
I hope to see more trenchant and ideologically honest analysis from you.
 
JEFF MC MAHON
New York, June 8, 1993
The writer is a member of the Arts Coalition of Independent Democrats.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Starring in Tocqueville's Crystal Ball

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Commager on Toqueville
By Henry Steele Commager
130 pages. University of Missouri Press. $24.95.
Henry Steele Commager's brilliant new interpretation of Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" offers this astute comment: "He had an instinct for the jugular vein in history." 
 The same can be said for Dr. Commager, the author of major works on the American mind and dream and now professor emeritus of history at Amherst College. For in "Commager on Tocqueville," our premier historian allows the reader to see America today through the critical vision of Commager on Commager.
Pulling no punches, Dr. Commager achieves three things in his invaluable little book. He makes us want to read or reread Tocqueville's 1835 classic, he tells us what's lasting and what's flawed about "Democracy in America" and, more than many of the historians in academe, he speaks out about some imperfections of the United States.
As a historical icon, Tocqueville is generally more cited than read. He could be quaint as well as prescient, better on the political system than on the people. Prepare to be chided if you quote this Tocqueville sentence -- from his chapter titled "The Young Woman as a Wife" -- to a feminist: "In America a woman loses her independence forever in the bonds of matrimony." He can hardly be blamed for failing to anticipate the current society-page phrase "the bride will retain her name."
But selective quotations are always unfair, including Tocqueville's famous but isolated paragraph predicting that the future belonged to America and Russia because "each of them seems to be marked out by the will of heaven to sway the destinies of half the globe." To which Dr. Commager adds that Tocqueville accurately predicted "the Americanization of the Old World," but he foresaw it as impending only within his own lifetime.
"Commager on Tocqueville" explores five areas Tocqueville raised but did not always answer: democracy and the tyranny of the majority, the price of a just society, centralization and democracy, the military in a democracy and the contradictions between political equality and economic inequality. While showing great respect for Tocqueville's profound interpretations of America, Dr. Commager uses these areas as taking-off points for his own humane and liberal views.
It's been a long turning from the Age of Andrew Jackson in the 1830's to the Age of President Clinton in the 1990's, but Dr. Commager finds that Tocqueville's ideas, if not his high standards, remain as instructive today as they were a century and a half ago. Admittedly, Tocqueville's sources of information were inadequate and often misleading: "He made it a point to meet the best people, and the best people, then as now, were inclined to deprecate democracy." Yet Dr. Commager emphasizes that Tocqueville, the aristocrat, admired America's egalitarian government and society.
Balancing equality and justice in modern America, here is Commager on Commager in some of his most challenging words: "We were vindictive toward those who refused to fight in a war in Vietnam that they thought unjust and immoral, but we do not always prosecute those agents of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, whose business it is to enforce the law, for the countless crimes they committed -- committed with official approval, to be sure -- nor did we prosecute those who improperly gave their approval. Is there one justice for the citizen and another for those who regard themselves as rulers above the law, not servants of the people and of the law?"
Tocqueville was certain that war and the military would endanger liberty and democracy in the New World. Here, too, Dr. Commager finds Tocqueville capable of looking into the future. "And though Tocqueville could not possibly have foreseen the form that militarism would take in the era of the military-industrial complex," Dr. Commager says, "he did somehow apprehend that war would increasingly involve business and manufacturers and that inevitably the state and the interests that provided the materials for war would become mixed-up and interdependent."
But Dr. Commager doesn't simply place the blame on the American military for the military-industrial complex during the cold war. He follows up Tocqueville's fear that militarism would harm a democratic Government by pointing to civilian-led administrations in Washington that assumed "something of the military character" and were responsible for creating what he calls the national security state.
Again, Commager boldly on Commager: "It was President Truman who formulated the doctrine that led the United States to replace Britain in the Near and Middle East, and Truman, too, who made the decision to enter the Korean War. It was Eisenhower who sent warships and marines to Lebanon, Kennedy who launched the Bay of Pigs. Kennedy, too, was in part responsible for the initial ventures into Vietnam, which under the guiding and misguiding hands of Presidents Johnson and Nixon escalated into a major war."
Dr. Commager builds on Tocqueville's vision of a democratic society by calling for the next egalitarian goal: a just society in the United States and for the rest of the world. He proposes that international agencies and regulatory commissions, not "some abstract thing called 'world government,' " should handle such basic concerns as the environment, health, nourishment, agriculture and "a hundred other problems that no one nation can possibly solve and which unsolved will affect every nation."
In an eloquent conclusion to a book whose only flaw is that it lacks an index, Dr. Commager writes that the United States should recover the "moral and practical leadership," which inspired Tocqueville in the last century and which existed during times of crisis up to the middle of the 20th century.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Henry Steele Commager (Amherst College)

HEADLINE: Nigeria Suspends Results of Vote That Was to Restore Democracy

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 16

 BODY:
Nigeria's planned return to civilian rule was suspended today when a commission appointed by the military leaders set aside the results of Saturday's presidential elections.
There had been growing indications that the candidate of the Social Democratic Party, Moshood Abiola, was well on his way to a resounding triumph over his rival, Bashir Tofa, of the National Republican Convention. Both had campaigned against military rule. 
 The vote had been heralded by many Nigerians as a historic end to nearly a decade of military rule in Africa's most populous nation.
 
Hope Tainted by Skepticism
 The election was to be only the third time since independence from Britain in 1960 that a president would rise to office through the ballot box and not through military action.
But even before today's announcement, there had been considerable skepticism over whether the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, was committed to democratic rule.
[This skepticism was reflected in Washington. Though the State Department had no official comment on the election, some Administration officials said they were not surprised that problems had arisen.
[While they said they had no reason to believe that General Baba ngida was directly involved in the delay of the return to democracy, "there is a lot of cynicism about the process that has grown up," one official said, "sort of a dark apprehension that it would never happen."]
 
'A Hidden Agenda'
 Beko Ransome-Kuti, chairman of the Committee for the Defense of Human Rights, said today that he had long suspected General Babangida was stalling the shift to civilian rule. "He's always had a hidden agenda," to remain in power, Dr. Ransome-Kuti said.
General Babangida has postponed a return to civilian rule three times since 1990, and the military authorities have annulled a number of gubernatorial and parliamentary elections, saying they had been compromised by financial improprieties and vote-buying.
Since independence, there have been seven successful coups and three of the nation's eight leaders have been assassinated. Two brief periods of civilian rule collapsed after allegations by the military of incompetence and wholesale corruption.
 
A General's Promise
 Still, General Babangida has said repeatedly in recent speeches and interviews that come what may, the military will return to its barracks on Aug. 27, the eighth anniversary of the coup that brought him to power.
Nigeria, with about 90 million people and more than 250 tribal groups, has always been difficult to govern. From 1967 to 1970, the nation was mired in a war to quell secessionists among the mostly Ibo peoples in the Eastern Region known as Biafra.
Despite its great natural resources -- Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer -- the country remains basically poor; per-capita income in 1991 was $250.
The suspension of the election results came in response to a suit filed by the Association for a Better Nigeria, a lobbying group of wealthy business executives, politicians and military officers who have led a highly visible campaign urging General Babangida to remain in office at least four more years.
The association asserted that the transition to civilian rule had been compromised by widespread vote-tampering and corruption, and on Tuesday the group won a court order instructing the national electoral commission not to release election results.
Justice Mohamveg Saleh, the chief judge of the high court in Abuja, the capital, ordered the commission not to publish the results until legal arguments over vote-rigging were heard by the court.
This process could take months, effectively nullifying the election and keeping the military in power.
This morning Humphrey Nwosu, the chairman of the commission, reportedly met with his staff and officials from the President's office to decide how to respond. Late this afternoon Mr. Nwosu issued a statement saying, in effect, that the Government had no choice but to suspend the elections or face being held in contempt of court.
Mr. Nwosu added that he would appeal the court's jurisdiction over the electoral process.
 
Details of Charges
 The association's suit charged, among other things, that officials of the Social Democratic Party had bribed delegates to the party's nominating convention to vote for Mr. Abiola. It also said that the campaigns of both presidential candidates had increased tension among Nigeria's many ethnic and religious groups, and that if an election were to occur now, it would was likely to "lead to chaos and a breach of public peace."
It was difficult to assess the accusations.
Many neutral Nigerian analysts said they were not persuaded that these assertions constituted proof of systematic fraud or posed a threat to security. Foreign observers have generally described the elections as free and fair.
Even though the decision to set aside the election results stunned many, the reaction among people milling in Lagos's crowded streets and in bars and restaurants tonight was subdued.
Salle Lamido, of the Social Democratic Party, said on state television tonight, "The court order is very, very contradictory and that shows the futility of the entire thing. The court has not been fair. I believe at the end of the day justice will prevail."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday showing the distribution of ethnic groups in Nigeria misstated the percentage for those who are members of other than the Hausa, Yoruba, Ibo or Fulani. They are 33 percent of the population.

RECENT HISTORY
 
Nigeria gained independence from Britain in 1960, and has been under military rule for all but nine years sincfe then. A military coup in 1966 ended a brief period of democratic rule and elections were notheld again until 1979. The new civilian Government ruled until 1983, when the military regained control in another coup. The current leader. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, had prommised to hand over power to the winner of last week's elections, but he has postponed the return to civilian rule three times since 1990.
 
GEOGRAPHY
 
Area: 356,667 square mile, more than twice the size of California.
 
Capital: Abuja. Other major cities are Lagos and Ibadan.
 
PEOPLE
 
Population: 88.5 million (1991). It is the most populous country in Africa.
 
ECONOMY
 
Currency: Naira. The exchange rate is about 25 naira to $1 (March 1993).
 
Per-capita G.D.P.: $250 (1991).
 
Exports: Oil makes up 95 percent of Nigeria's exports. Cocoa is the chief export crop.
 
Industries: Crude oil, food processing, vehicle-assembly textiles. 54 percent of the labor force works in agriculture (1990).

HEADLINE: Report Describes Jordan's Aid to Iraq During War

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
As King Hussein of Jordan prepares to meet for the first time with President Clinton on Friday, a Congressional report has confirmed that during the Persian Gulf war, Jordan was simultaneously receiving American military aid and helping Iraq by giving it American technolgy and intelligence information.
While many of the allegations about Jordan's cooperation with neighboring Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait and during the gulf war in 1991 have been known, the recently declassified report provides new concrete evidence about the depth of the relationship between the two countries, despite United Nations sanctions against Iraq. 
 The report also confirms allegations that the Bush Administration misled Congress when it sent $550 million in military equipment to Jordan's official shipping company despite the State Department's assurances to Congress that such aid had stopped. The report also questions public assertions by Bush Administration officials that except for some oil imports from Iraq, Jordan was in compliance with United Nations sanctions against Baghdad.
The report, citing American intelligence officials, says Jordan shared intelligence from the American-led coalition and Israel with Iraq, gave Iraq access to American technology and conducted joint military training exercises with Iraq. It also says Iraq bought military spare parts from Jordan.
"U.S. intelligence services verified four types of Jordanian and Iraqi military cooperation during the gulf crisis," the report said. "These activities included joint training exercises with Iraq, two cases of providing access to U.S. technology, one case of purchasing spare parts and one case dealing with the sharing of coalition and Israeli intelligence information."
The report did not say what technology was sent to Iraq or describe the nature of the shared intelligence.
The report was prepared last fall by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, for the House Foreign Operations appropriations subcommittee, but its classified annex was declassified only this month. The subcommittee released the G.A.O. report today.
Both the State Department and the Jordanian Government have taken issue with the G.A.O. report.
Marwan Muasher, spokesman for the Jordanian Embassy, said: "These allegations are untrue, and the State Department itself disputes the accuracy of the report. We have made it very clear that categorically no military equipment has gone to Iraq after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. We don't put much importance on it."
Richard Boucher, a spokesman for the State Department, said tonight, "The G.A.O. report is not new. We have cooperated closely with members of Congress and answered their questions on the G.A.O. report. Not a single report of Jordanian trans-shipment of defense articles to Iraq has ever been verified. Our exhaustive efforts to follow up on the reports of Jordanian military assistance to Iraq have produced no conclusive evidence to support the original reports."
The report is potentially embarrassing for King Hussein, who is eager to mend the relationship with Washington that was damaged during the war.
At stake is military aid that was suspended by Congress after King Hussein made statements supporting Iraq when it invaded Kuwait. Jordan has already been given economic aid.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Jordanian aid to Iraq in the Persian Gulf war referred incompletely to the aid the United States has withheld from Jordan. Because of Jordan's support for Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait, the United States is withholding $50 million in economic and military aid from fiscal 1992 and $26 million from fiscal 1993. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the year of the Persian Gulf war in some editions. It was 1991, not 1992.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Banker Seeks Uses for Military Technology

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 16

 BODY:
Jon B. Kutler, an investment banker who has been raising money for military industry buyouts, hopes to use that expertise in his own company by hunting for aerospace technology that could be converted to civilian products.
In January, Mr. Kutler founded Quarterdeck Investment Partners Inc. after leaving the Los Angeles office of the investment banking company Wasserstein, Perella & Company, which he had headed since 1988. 
 Quarterdeck will specialize in providing private capital for restructuring weak weapons makers and financing start-up businesses or military industry spinoffs. But there are two caveats: The target companies must use the military technology for commercial products and the manufacturing must be in Southern California.
"Our mission is a for-profit, public interest company," said Michael C. Lambert, the vice president of Quarterdeck and a former marketing vice president of Lear Siegler Inc., an aerospace company.
 
'A Private Market Solution'
 Quarterdeck has grown from a proposal Mr. Kutler made to a public-private Los Angeles committee convened to compensate for the loss of some 150,000 aerospace and weapons jobs in the region in the last five years.
"All their ideas focused on government spending," said Mr. Kutler, 36, a former Navy officer and a graduate of the Harvard Business School. "I tried to come up with a private market solution."
Clearly, the potential influence of Quarterdeck on steering the declining weapons industry toward commercial work would be small. "It's not going to cure California's unemployment problem, except very marginally," said Larry Korb, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institute, a research organization in Washington.
Still, Quarterdeck could provide important assistance to military subcontractors, suppliers and engineering talent "that has been dumped on the street," said Jack Kyser, the chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles. They have often needed help identifying potential markets for technology, he said.
 
First Deal Announced
 Last week, Quarterdeck, which Mr. Kutler said was backed by a handful of private investors, announced its first deal, which he valued at less than $10 million.
The company acquired A+H International Inc., which makes Beeperkid, an electronic alarm device that activates when a child wanders 15 feet from a monitor, which is worn by an adult.
Though the product won an industrial design award last year, it had some technical flaws. Andrew Ha, the owner of A+H, had found a proprietary military technology that would have greatly improved Beeperkid, but he could not afford to license it. Quarterdeck could. Based on old orders and renewed interest by retailers, the company said it expected $7 million in sales of Beeperkid, which would be priced at less than $100, in 1994.
Mr. Kutler said military contractors rarely thought of the broader applications for their technology. "Most defense contractors don't know what they have," he said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Intelligence;
BUDGET CUT LIKELY FOR INTELLIGENCE

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Defying stern warnings from the Clinton Administration, Democrats in Congress are preparing to cut more than $1 billion from a White House intelligence budget request.
The cuts would leave the nation's intelligence agencies with only about as much money for next year as they were given by Congress this year. President Clinton had asked for an increase that would have outpaced inflation, contending that the national security requirements in the post-cold war era justified the steeper rise. 
 The Democratic lawmakers have generally agreed that intelligence programs provide cost-effective insurance against surprises in an unpredictable new world. But in turning aside Mr. Clinton's request, they have argued that the intelligence agencies must share some of the budget-cutting burden being borne by the military.
 
2 Budgets for Intelligence
 While the size of the nation's vast intelligence budget remains an official secret, Administration and Congressional officials say the White House request for an increase next year would bring it to well over $28 billion.
The cuts being endorsed by influential Democratic lawmakers would slash at least $500 million from each of the two proposed budgets that make up the overall intelligence program, reducing the overall White House proposal by about 4 percent.
A clear indicator of that Congressional sentiment came late this afternoon, Government officials said, when the House Intelligence Committee voted to cut about $1.2 billion from the White House request on the two budgets -- the National Foreign Intelligence Budget, which provides for the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency and other spy agencies, and the budget for Tactical Intelligence and Related Activities, which are run primarily by the military.
 
'Devastating Consequences'
 The final budgets voted on by Congress remain to be shaped by four more Congressional committees, which are not due to vote on the issue until next month at the earliest. But the Senate Intelligence Committee is also on track to cut the Administration request, and the House and Senate appropriations committees are likely to recommend even deeper cuts.
The Democratic-led defiance comes despite strong warnings from R. James Woolsey, who as Director of Central Intelligence has served as chief lobbyist for the Administration's request. Congressional officials have said that Mr. Woolsey has contended that cuts below the Administration's request could have "devastating consequences" on the ability of United States intelligence agencies to monitor developments around the world and to assess their significance.
In at least one private meeting, Mr. Woolsey warned members of Congress that the budget cuts could force him to eliminate a crucial intelligence operation, said Congressional officials who refused to describe the secret program. But they said Democrats who control the committees with power over the intelligence budgets had reacted with some skepticism to those contentions.
"I personally think it's part of the 'we'll close the Washington Monument' syndrome," said a prominent Congressional official, who said he and others had concluded that Mr. Woolsey's arguments "just don't fly."
 
Resigned to Cuts
 Administration officials who insisted on anonymity said today that Mr. Woolsey was now unlikely to repeat such complaints. They suggested that the White House had grown resigned to the prospect that its request would be cut.
The White House request for a budget increase had surprised some lawmakers because Mr. Clinton promised to cut intelligence spending by $7 billion over four years. The request is in classified sections of the Defense Department budget, in which it represents an exception to a plan outlining significant cuts in military spending.
But the Administration has contended that a short-term increase in intelligence spending is needed before the reductions can safely be made in the budgets of the C.I.A. and other spy agencies. Nearly all of the proposed spending for strategic programs would be devoted to launching spy satellites that can replace several older ones, Administration aides have said.
Because Congress cut the overall intelligence budget in fiscal year 1993 by $1.6 billion, from its 1992 level, its aversion to Mr. Clinton's request for an increase is not surprising. Some Administration officials have said they would regard themselves as lucky this year if Congress agreed simply not to cut the intelligence budget below its current level of about $27.5 billion.
The fact that the budget numbers are classified leaves Government officials reluctant to discuss them, and the figures they cite are sometimes contradictory. But estimates provided by officials from both the Administration and Capitol Hill make clear that Congress is poised to reject White House requests for increases in both budgets.
Mr. Clinton had asked Congress for authority to spend about $17.8 billion on the national programs next year, an increase from this year's final appropriation of about $17 billion. But the House Intelligence Committee today cut that request to about $17.3 billion, and its Senate counterpart is likely to recommend a slightly lower figure.
Until now, Mr. Clinton had been reported not to have sought substantially more money for the military's intelligence programs. But Congressional officials said he had in fact asked for an increase of $900 million over the current $10.1 billion, a request that the House committee cut today by about $600 million.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SOFTENS OPPOSITION BY U.S. TO DIVIDED BOSNIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
President Clinton signaled tonight that the United States might accept a partition of Bosnia that would allow the Serbs to keep land they seized by force, provided that Bosnian Muslims and Croats agreed to such a plan.
Mr. Clinton, speaking in the East Room of the White House at his first evening news conference, said he still preferred a "multi-ethnic state" in Bosnia. But he said for the first time that "if the parties themselves agree, genuinely and honestly agree, the United States would have to look very seriously" at the three-way partition plan proposed by the Presidents of Serbia and Croatia. [Excerpts from the news conference, page A19.]
 
Only Practical Solution
 Until tonight, the Clinton Administration said it would never endorse such an alteration of internationally recognized borders by force. But American officials now acknowledge that such partition is probably the only practical solution, given that neither Washington nor its European allies are ready to use force to hold Bosnia together and that the Bosnian Muslims do not have the power to do so alone. 
 Mr. Clinton's remarks come on the heels of declarations by America's European allies also supporting partition. An alternative peace plan for Bosnia that had won international support was declared dead today by its co-author, Lord Owen. [Page A8.]
 
Pressure on Muslims
 Together, those statements will generate heavy pressure on the Bosnian Muslims to accept some form of partition, even though it means ceding parts of their territory that the Serbs seized by a brutal campaign of "ethnic cleansing."
Mr. Clinton began his news conference, which was broadcast by only two of the four major television networks, with a 10-minute political speech promoting his economic programs. Returning to his campaign theme of soaking the rich, Mr. Clinton used four-color chart to make a case that he was determined to drive down the Federal budget deficit with spending cuts and taxes on the wealthy.
But he spent a large chunk of his television time discussing foreign affairs, trying to reassure Americans that his diplomacy in Bosnia and Somalia would not draw the United States into foreign quagmires. Using language drawn up during the afternoon in consultation with Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Mr. Clinton declared that the United Nations military operation in Somalia had achieved its aims. He said General Powell had reported to him earlier Thursday that "this operation was over and that it was a success" even though the Somali warlord against whom it was directed was not captured by the United Nations forces.
Perhaps mindful of the trouble his predecessor, President Bush, had in his showdown with Iraq, Mr. Clinton went out of his way to try to avoid turning the Somali operation into a personal conflict between himself and the Somali warlord, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid.
"The United Nations, acting with the United States and other nations, crippled the forces in Mogadishu of warlord Aidid and remains on guard against further provocations," he said. "His forces were responsible for the worst attack on U.N. peacekeepers in three decades. We could not let it go unpunished."
Mr. Clinton, who went out of his way to avoid formal news conferences for most of the first months of his Presidency, has suddenly held three this week as he has finally received a small flood of good news and legislative successes.
This sudden interest in give and take with White House reporters reflected the strategy of his new communications adviser, David R. Gergen, who once used such prime time events to showcase his previous boss, President Reagan.
Mr. Clinton said that while his early months have been messy at times, his legislative agenda was moving forward. He cited the fact that various Congressional committees this week have made progress on his proposals for campaign finance reform, with voluntary spending limits for Congressional campaigns and a ban on contributions from political action committees, plus progress on the issues of national service, and $500 billion in deficit-reduction. These favorable developments followed closely on Mr. Clinton's nomination Monday of a Federal appeals judge. Ruth Bader Ginsburg, to the Supreme Court, a choice hailed by Democrats and Republicans alike.
In his opening statement, Mr. Clinton listed a string of what he called successes for his Administration, emphasizing the recent military action in Somalia and the progress of his budget proposal.
With the first question, however, he had to shift from a focus on areas of progress to the thornier topic of the war in Bosnia.
 
Not 'the Way I Hoped'
 Asked about the Croatian-Serbian plan to carve Bosnia into three ethnic states, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the plan would grant to Serbia territory captured by force. The crisis in the region, he said, "has not been resolved in the way I would have hoped."
But he said the reward to Serbia reflected the inadequacy of a Bush Administration arms embargo that gave Serbian forces an advantage in the war. He called the ethnic fighting in the region "perhaps our most difficult foreign policy problem."
Turning to Somalia, Mr. Clinton said troops under United Nations command had "crippled the forces" under General Aidid and would remain on guard against further provocation in the Somali capital.
 
'Heroism Knew No Flag'
 "In this battle, heroism knew no flag," Mr. Clinton said of the United Nations response, which has involved air strikes by United States AC-130H gunships and a ground operation by United Nations forces today.
The President was asked whether General Aidid had been captured. Mr. Clinton said that he had not been, but that military forces were seeking his arrest. If when he is captured, Mr. Clinton said, "the United Nations will have to determine what action to take."
"The purpose of the operation was to undermine the capacity of Aidid to wreck havoc in Mogadishu," said Mr. Clinton, adding that the general was responsible for the recent attack that killed 23 Pakistani soldiers.
While General Aidid remains at large in Mogadishu, Mr. Clinton rejected a suggestion that his declaration of victory was somehow incomplete. He said there was "a big difference" between the situation in Somalia and the one the United States faced in the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Hussein remained in power in Iraq.
 
Could Tolerate Aidid
 Mr. Clinton stressed that General Aidid does not control the Government of Somalia and insisted that his elimination had never been an objective of the United States or the United Nations. He suggested that the United Nations would tolerate General Aidid if he proves willing to live in peace and said his fate would depend on "what he does in the future."
Regarding Haiti, the President said he still believed there would never be peace and democracy there without a multi-national force, which both the Haitian Government and the opposition have rejected.
"I have always assumed, to facilitate democracy in Haiti, there would have to be a multi-national force there," he said.
But Mr. Clinton added that economic sanctions approved by the United Nations "will make a difference."
 
Balkan Update
 One of the chief mediators for the BALKANS, Lord Owen, conceded yesterday in GENEVA that his plan for 10 semiautonomous provinces in BOSNIA has failed, and he urged Muslims to negotiate with the Serbs and Croats over their alternative plan to divide the country into three parts.
In VIENNA, Foreign Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia sought a United Nations emergency session to "prevent the dismemberment" of Bosnia.
United Nations officials, preparing for a countrywide cease-fire for noon Friday, said it was unrealistic to expect the guns to go silent right away.
United Nations monitors were finally allowed to enter GORAZDE after waiting three weeks. They reported heavy damage. New clashes were reported near the Bosnian towns of TESANJ, MAGLAJ, TUZLA, GRADACAC, and BRCKO. Bosnia Serb forces continued their bombardment of in SARAJEVO.
In BONN, Radio Free Europe said it had gotten the go-ahead to turn its transmitters toward the former YUGOSLAVIA.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: The Budget;
Democrats Pushing Plan Toward a Vote

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Shrugging off Republican accusations that they were raising taxes and cutting services for millions of Americans, the 11 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee today started muscling the first big chunk of President Clinton's budget toward a Senate vote and enactment into law.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton focused on shielding his budget from further attacks within his own party. At a televised news conference, he said he was "drawing the line" on more concessions to conservatives in Congress who, he said, would lower the deficit by cutting deeply into Federal benefit programs rather than taking the money from the well-off. 
 While Republicans have proposed deeper cuts in Federal programs, it was conservative Democrats on the Finance Committee who built additional cuts into the Senate version of his plan. Some of them had threatened to block the budget entirely unless their demands were granted.
 
Call for Fairness
 Mr. Clinton labored to put some space between himself and those lawmakers, saying sharply that he "did not negotiate" the version of the budget now before the Finance Committee, and that "you know where I have been on the issues."
"We can't simply balance the budget on the backs of the old, the sick, the veterans, and those who work hard but are just barely making ends meet," Mr. Clinton said. "It's not right."
The President nevertheless praised the chairman of the Finance Committee, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, for what he called a remarkable job of moving the budget package toward a Senate vote.
Mr. Moynihan's committee spent a full day today explaining and debating the five-year package, which is dominated by a near-record tax increase of $249 billion and a $67 billion paring back of the explosive growth of Medicare spending. They were expected to approve the measure and send it to the full Senate for a final vote on Friday.
Today, the panel's nine Republicans harangued the Democrats mercilessly on those issues, and others. The Senate's Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, dropped by to complain that the Democrats were raising taxes on Social Security benefits "to be used for social investments." A Missouri Republican, Senator John C. Danforth, accused them of playing a shell game with the expiration dates of tax breaks in a "gimmick" to make spending seem smaller than it is.
 
Attack Over Medicare
 Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who ran the Finance Committee when the last major tax bill passed in 1986, assailed them for "taking one more whack" at Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals instead of raising Medicare premiums for the well-off.
Most of all, the Republicans groused about being left out of the real negotiations over the budget, which the committee's Democrats thrashed out among themselves and behind closed doors during two wrenching weeks that ended on Wednesday evening.
The Democrats politely ignored them, and rejected an initial effort to amend the bill before recessing for the night. Their unanimity insures that the budget bill will make it through the Finance Committee and to the Senate floor, where the Democrats hold a more comfortable 56-to-44 majority. A vote there, almost surely to pass the bill, is expected next week.
Mr. Clinton praised Congress's action this week on his deficit reduction plan, his national service program and campaign finance overhaul as "an impressive and important series of victories" for the nation. But he saved his most forceful words for his economic plan.
Pointing to a series of charts reminiscent of Ross Perot's television lectures, the President tried to cast the debate over his program in terms of stark terms of fairness toward the poor and middle class.
Declaring that Congress had made "remarkable progress" on his economic plan, he said: "Make no mistake about it. This means we are putting our economic house in order."
Painful though it may be, he added, "It's necessary, it's fair and it will work."
The Senate version of the bill differs significantly from the House-passed version on several basic tax and spending issues. It discards a proposed tax on the heat content of fuels, which would have raised $71.5 billion through 1998, and substitutes a meager 4.3 cent-per-gallon tax on gasoline, diesel and kerosene that would raise $24 billion.
The Senate bill also rejects a proposed tax on barge fuel that the White House had first pegged at $1 a gallon and that had been whittled down to 50 cents a gallon in the House. But it leaves unclear the status of two fuels, ethanol and methanol, that had been exempted from taxation in the House.
The Senate bill cuts $17 billion more from Medicare spending than did the House bill, but it gives retirees somewhat more generous tax treatment than did the House, raising the income threshold for proposed additional taxation of Social Security benefits by $10,000 over the House version.
 
Ban on Filibusters
 Ordinarily, Republicans could stall or alter the bill on the Senate floor. But the budget package, known as a reconciliation bill, moves under special rules that ban filibustering and allow the Democrats to sharply limit unfriendly amendments.
The Senate will then try to meld its version of the budget with a House version, passed earlier, that differs on the critical issues of Medicare spending and a tax on energy. Congress has pledged to have a compromise bill on the President's desk by the time lawmakers take their annual vacation in early August.
Mr. Moynihan contends that the bill is the most progressive economic legislation since World War II, and figures made public today by Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation support that.
 
Smaller Burden for Some
 Focusing only on tax changes and not on spending cuts, the committee concluded that the Senate bill would cut taxes for any household earning less than $20,000 a year in "expanded income" -- that is, household income plus any employer's contributions to Federal taxes, health insurance and a grab-bag of other benefits. Their share of the total Federal tax burden would drop by $1.6 billion, to about $46.4 billion a year in 1993 dollars.
By comparison, households with expanded incomes of more than $200,000 would suffer a sharp rise in their tax burden, to nearly $199 billion from the current $168 billion a year. Those in between would experience comparatively modest increases.
The portion of the package that appeared to win universal praise today was a stiff increase in the earned income tax credit, a tax break aimed solely at working families with incomes beneath the poverty level.
The House had passed an even more generous version of the tax credit benefiting families with and without children. The Senate finance panel excluded childless wage earners, but it sharply raised the amount of the credit -- to $2,098 from the current maximum of $1,434 for families with one child, and to $3,500 from $1,511 for families with two or more children.
The credit would be phased out as a household's income approaches a threshold of $23,470 for one-child families and $27,000 for two-child families. At its maximum, Mr. Moynihan noted, "we now have the equivalent of a family allowance of $75 a week for low-income families."
Other provisions were not greeted with such open arms.
 
Increases in Tax Rates
 Republicans generally argued that the bill's major tax provisions -- lifting the corporate tax rate one point to 35 percent, and the personal income-tax rate to a maximum of 39.6 percent from 31 percent -- were a bill of false goods, advertised as deficit-reducers but destined to finance Mr. Clinton's social agenda.
"The American people don't want us to raise taxes unless we're also going to cut spending," Mr. Dole said early in the session. Nor did he stop there: Mr. Clinton's plan to tax 85 percent of the Social Security benefits of wealthier people, rather than the current 50 percent, was "a rifle shot aimed at senior citizens," Mr. Dole said.
That provision would raise $26.3 billion through 1998. "If he didn't spend all that money for so-called investment programs nobody really cares about, he wouldn't have to do this," Mr. Dole said of the President.
But when a Republican proposal to delete the tax increase -- the only amendment considered today -- came to a vote, three of the finance panel's most moderate Republicans bolted to join the Democrats. They were John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, Mr. Danforth of Missouri and Dave Durenberger of Minnesota.
Later, they and other Republicans sounded ferocious objections to the Democrats' Medicare proposals, which add $17 billion in new cuts to the $50 billion that Mr. Clinton had already proposed. The Democratic cuts reduce or freeze payments to providers of ambulances, outpatient surgery, home health care, community health centers and other services.
Republicans argued that the Democrats should have raised insurance premiums for wealthier older citizens to finance some cuts.
"I've never seen a community health center wallowing in money," Mr. Chafee said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S NEWS CONFERENCE;
Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference at the White House

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference tonight at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Ladies and gentlemen, first I want to speak with you about a situation that all of us have followed very closely in the last week. And that is the United Nations action in Somalia. General Powell reported to me this afternoon that this operation is over and that it was a success. The United Nations, acting with the United States and other nations, has crippled the forces in Mogadishu of warlord Aidid and remains on guard against further provocation. Aidid's forces were responsible for the worst attack on U.N. peacekeepers in three decades. We could not let it go unpunished. Our objectives were clear. The U.N. sought to preserve the credibility of peacekeeping in Somalia and around the world to get the food moving again and to restore security. 
 I want to congratulate the American and the United Nations forces who took part in this operation. In this battle heroism knew no flag. And in this era our nation must and will continue to exert global leadership as we have done this week in Somalia.
Here at home America is on the move. These past few days have been an impressive and important series of victories for the American people. Congress is taking major steps to limit the influence of special interests and their money in our lawmaking and in our campaigns. Congressional committees have also approved my plan for more college loans for the American people and to enable tens of thousands of them to pay their loans off by community service to their states and nation.
But the most important thing I want to discuss is the progress that is being made, the remarkable progress on the economic plan. Last month the House of Representatives passed a plan to reduce the deficit, the first step toward creating jobs and increasing incomes.
Yesterday, the Senate Finance Committee cleared the way for action by the full Senate. Make no mistake about it. This means that we are putting our economic house in order. Getting the economy back on track depends upon Congress passing this economic plan. It's necessary, it's fair and it will work.
I propose, indeed, I have insisted upon, $500 billion in deficit reduction to be locked away in a deficit-reduction trust fund. We will be making historic cuts in the deficit by making historic cuts first in Government spending. Then by making high-income Americans pay their fair share so middle-class Americans will be treated fairly in the tax burden, for a change. Seventy-five percent of the new taxes proposed fall on the top 6 percent of the American people, those with incomes above $100,000.
Now some of the critics of this plan in Congress prefer instead to cut Social Security or health care or tax benefits for elderly people just above the poverty line or working people just above the poverty line, so that the wealthy won't pay so much. I'm here tonight to say to you and to the American people that I have -- that I will draw the line. We have to reduce the deficit by reducing the unfairness of tax patterns of the 1980's, and once again, asking all Americans to do what is right and fair.
We can't simply balance the budget on the backs of the old, the sick, the veterans and those who work hard but are just barely making ends meet. It's not right.
Let's look at what's at stake here.
First of all, this chart shows that if we do nothing, the inherited deficit -- what we found when I came into office -- will go up by 1998 to about $400 billion a year. If this deficit reduction plan is passed, we will cut $500 billion out of the deficit. That's the difference in this line and that.
As all of you know, and as you've pointed out in various ways in the last few weeks, I just got here. And I may have a lot to learn, but I didn't create the red line. What I'm trying to do is to change the red line and bring the yellow line in. And let me say, to get the yellow line down here, we have to bring about an affordable health-care plan for every American. And that's the next big step. But look what this deficit reduction plan alone will do. I want to emphasize once again, because there's been so much about -- talk about taxes, that this is the most progressive tax plan this country has seen in decades. Two-thirds of the money will be paid by people with incomes above $200,000.
Seventy percent of the economic gains of the last decade went to the top 1 percent of the American people. They are in a position now to pay more to help make this economy move again and they will. This is the payment -- monthly payment -- if my full economic plan is passed, by people with incomes above $200,000. And you can see what happens here to the plan, with an actual modest break for people at the bottom end of the income scale. This is a very progressive and fair plan.
Now finally let me say there's been a lot of talk about spending cuts here. If you look at this plan for every $10 in deficit reduction $5, half of it, comes in spending cuts, $3.75 of the $10 comes in tax increases on the highest income Americans, the upper 6 percent and $1.25 comes in taxes from the middle class, people with incomes below $100,000 but roughly above $30,000. Families with incomes below $30,000 are held harmless in this program. Now that's the way this program works: $5 in spending cuts, $3.75 in taxes from the wealthiest Americans, $1.25 in taxes from the middle class. It's fair and it's balanced and I hope that the Congress will adopt it.
Let me say that, as I open the floor to questions, the real issue here is whether we will reverse the pattern of the last 12 years where Presidents send budgets to Congress that are never seriously considered and everybody is afraid to talk about taxes because they're afraid no matter what happens, that will dominate the agenda. Nobody will know about spending cuts. Nobody will know about deficit reduction. Nobody will know about fairness.
I've tried to tell the truth to the American people and if this plan passes, you will see a continuation of what's happened already in the last five months: low interest rates, increased housing sales, more jobs coming into the economy. In the first four months of this economy alone, we had a bigger growth in construction employment -- 130,000 people -- than we have had in nine years. Why? Because we're serious about bringing the deficit down. That's what this last week means. It means continued victory for the American people if we can stay on this road.
Helen.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. If Vance-Owen is dead, will the United States approve of a partition of Bosnia, if the three factions meeting in Geneva actually approve it? And also isn't NATO really obsolescence now? I mean, hasn't it outlived -- it can't stop the slaughter in Europe. It won't be the policeman in Europe.
PRESIDENT CLINTON That's two separate questions. First of all, as you know, my preference was for a multi-ethnic state in Bosnia. But if the parties themselves, including the Bosnian Government, agree -- genuinely and honestly agree to a different solution, then the United States would have to look at it very seriously. Secondly, I do not agree that NATO is dead. NATO was limited in what it could do in this instance because there was no agreement among the NATO partners first of all, and because any organization of states was limited by the rules that the United Nations imposed in the former Yugoslavia on the arms embargo, for example.
The clearest example I know to give you that NATO is not dead was provided by the leaders of the all the Eastern European countries that used to be Communist that aren't any more. When they came here a few weeks ago for the Holocaust dedication, everyone of those present said that their number one priority was to get into NATO. They know it will provide a security umbrella for the people who are members, and I think we need to continue to be involved in it.
Q. Who's the enemy?
A. Well, there will be different enemies. The enemy will be anybody that threatens the security and the peace of the member nations and the values that -- that we hold important. There are all kinds of possible problems in the years ahead from terrorism, from the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, from yet unforeseen developments in countries around NATO. So I don't think it's time to dismantle NATO, I think it's very, very important.
Terry.
Q. Mr. President, doesn't this plan for carving up Bosnia send a dangerous message to separatists around the world, particularly in the former Soviet Union that military aggression pays?
A. I think that this plan shows that a civil war which has roots going back centuries, literally centuries, based on ethnic and religious differences has not been resolved in the way that I certainly would have hoped. I think Serbian aggression has been rewarded to the extent that the United Nations resolution permitted the Serbs to send arms to the Bosnian Serbs and permitted the Croats, that were next door to Croatia, to have access to more weapons than the Bosnian Government, predominantly Muslim, had. And I think that was a mistake. But I don't think that anybody should overlearn that lesson. Everyone who looks at this can see that this is perhaps our most difficult foreign policy problem.
Andrea?
Q. Mr. President, getting back to your pie chart. You said that a dollar and a quarter from that tax increase will hurt the middle class. During the campaign --
A. I don't think it will hurt the middle class. I think that it will help the middle class because it'll be a way of bringing the deficit down.
Q. But a dollar and a quarter out of that tax bite will hit the middle class. In the PBS debate during the campaign, you said, "The only thing Paul Tsongas has recommended that I haven't is a 3- to 5-cent a year gas tax increase. And I'll be darned if I understand why we should do that without giving some offsetting tax relief. Then in "Putting People First," which was your campaign manifesto you said, you oppose a Federal excise gas tax. I quote, "Instead of a backbreaking Federal gas tax we should try conservation." Why are you now willing to go along with the Senate plan at least to keep it moving through the Senate for a gasoline tax. Do you think you can defeat in conference and if you do, will you try to restore the B.T.U. tax as your budget director suggested today? If so, won't you then lose Senators Boren and Breaux and all the other opponents when it gets back to the Senate? Isn't it a no-win situation?
A. First of all, I think it is a win-win situation if the Senate passes a budget that has $500 billion in deficit reduction, locks the spending cuts away in a trust fund and asks the highest-income Americans to pay their fair share. I think that's a win-win situation because I think we'll go to conference and we'll get a plan that will meet those criteria and will also be fairer to the middle class people and to the working poor. There's also a lot of important provisions in there that I care about that will help to encourage people to move from welfare to work.
The Senate bill is very different. It does have a 4.3 percent fuel tax in it. That is very different from 3 cents a year, which is 12 cents or 15 cents over five years, or 5 cents a year which is 25 cents over five years, a 4.3 percent tax flat is not nearly as onerous as that.
I wish we didn't have to do that, but I would remind you that after the election and before I took office, the aggregate deficit over the next five years was written up by $165 billion. I'm doing the best I can to use very conservative hard-headed revenue estimates to get the deficit down and keep interest rates down, so that people in the middle class can save more money than they'll pay if they refinance a car loan or a home loan or take out a business loan with lower interest rates.
And tonight there will be millions of people who will either watch us or hear about this tomorrow who have refinanced their homes just since November with interest rates dropping they'll save more money in one year than they'll pay in five years under this program. So I still think, on balance, it is the right thing to do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. You say this Somalia operation has been a success. Does that mean that the United States and U.N. forces have captured the Somali warlord Gen. Mohammed Feher Aidid and his associates including Col. Omar Jess and if you haven't captured them, what are you planning on doing with them if you do capture them? Are they going to be put on war crimes tribunal or anything like that?
A. The purpose -- no, they have not been arrested -- the purpose of the operation was to undermine the capacity of Aidid to wreak military havoc in Mogadishu. He murdered 23 U.N. peacekeepers and I would remind you that before the United States and the United Nations showed up he was responsible for the deaths of countless Somalis from starvation, from disease and from killing. The back -- the military back of Aidid has been broken. A warrant has been issued for his arrest. If he is in fact arrested then the United Nations will have to determine what appropriate action to take. That is the decision the United States is leaving to the United Nations and one I believe we should. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Economic Problems
 Q. Mr. President, I'm surprised that for the first four months you came into office you were saying how bad the economy was and how important it was for your program to be enacted to grow the economy. Now, we hear you in the last week or so talking up the economy, saying how well things are going and yet, your program hasn't passed. What are we to make of this? Why have you changed your mind about the economy.
A. First of all, I think the economy is still bad for most Americans. But the trends are good, and the trends are plainly tied to the determination of this Administration to bring the deficit down. We began to see a substantial drop in long-term interest rates after the election, when Secretary of the Treasury Bentsen announced that we were going to have a serious deficit reduction plan that would include entitlement cuts, other budget cuts, tax increases on the wealthy and an energy tax. We saw that. And every student of this, starting with the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who has testified before Congress to this effect, has said that if we continue and pass this we will get interest rates down.
So those things have been coming down. That's why the Home Builders Association of America -- not a Democratic group, presumably, largely a Republican group -- came from all over the country to Maryland a few days ago to endorse the economic program, because it is already beginning to bring interest rates down. So are most people affected by the economic recovery? No. But is it a good thing that you have 755,000 private sector jobs in the first five months, that you have 130,000 jobs in the construction industry -- the biggest gain over a four-month period in nine years? Yes, it is.
So the point I'm trying to make is we're taking the right direction but we've still got a lot of changes to make.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, as you pointed out, your economic plan would reduce the budget deficit by $500 billion over five years, which is a significant improvement over what we've seen in the past. But your critics would point out that the budget deficit would continue to mount by hundreds of billions of dollars a year and that your attack on the deficit is limited to lowering projected spending increases rather than taking the much harder tack of making real cutbacks in the budget. Can't you do more to deal with the problem of this deficit and runaway spending?
A. Let me have the chart again.
The answer to that question -- first of all, let me answer -- you asked two questions, not one. Let -- It is absolutely true that if this whole thing is adopted, or any other deficit reduction plan that has been presented today is adopted, by the fifth year the deficit starts to inch up again and you don't get down to zero. Now that is true. But why is that? That is because primarily of the projected exploding costs in medical care through Medicare and Medicaid. And because we have programs like Social Security and other retirement programs where people are given cost of living increases year in and year out, something that most Americans support. But the prime culprit here is Social Security -- I mean is medical costs, not Social Security. The prime culprit is medical costs. They've been going up way faster than inflation.
Now, I want to make two points: Why did we reduce the deficit only $500 billion over five years, even though that's a huge amount? Because it was the considered judgment of the economic team -- Secretary Bentsen, Mr. Panetta, Mr. Rubin -- that in a recession there was a limit to how fast you could contract the deficit. And that this would be a very rapid reduction of the deficit in a time when there is very slow economic growth around the globe. We think it will actually lead to some expansion of the economic activity. Why? Because there's so much debt built into our system at high interest rates that if people just go refinance all their homes and their business loans it will give them a lot of cash in their pocket and that will stimulate the economy to grow.
Secondly, it is our considered judgment that we cannot get the deficit down to zero, which is where it ought to be, until we do something about health-care costs which is why the next big piece of this Administration's work is to provide a comprehensive health-care plan that will bring health costs in line with inflation. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, many African-American writers have expressed their anger, or extreme disappointment, over the way you handled the Lani Guinair nomination, and with the way you handled the Haiti situation. In addition, the Congressional Black Caucus has said it's very angry with the fact that they voted for your budget package, and cast some very politically difficult votes only to have you negotiate a watered down package in the Senate. What would you assess your relationship right now with blacks, and what are you doing to mend fences with the Congressional Black Caucus so they will not vote against the conference report on the budget package?
A. I did not negotiate that bill that the Senate passed. That is just inaccurate. I did not do that. And I think you know what I liked about the House bill, and you know where I have been on the issue, and you know what the principles are; I have enunciated. I think Senator Moynihan did a remarkable job to get a bill out that does have $500 billion in deficit reduction, more spending cuts and tax increases, and taxes falling primarily on upper income people. I think to that extent we ought to give him credit. But there has been no negotiations. Secondly, and quite to the contrary, when members of the Black Caucus came to see me and asked me to pursue sanctions in the United Nations against Haiti that included oil, I examined it and I agreed to do it. They were the first people to ask me to do it and very shortly after the meeting I agreed to go forward. But the know, the ones who follow the Haitian developments, that even before that I offered to have the United States participate in a multi-national peacekeeping force to restore democracy and restore President Aristide and that he rejected that. They know that's the fact. Thirdly, I don't think my commitment to civil rights is very much open to question. And I think my actions as President, the appointments I've made and things I've stood for, document that, and I believe that over the long run the Black Caucus and the Clinton Administration will continue to be very close, and I've talked to any number of them personally, recently. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. President, will you support the Senate's 10 percent increase in the capital gains tax?
A. Well, they imposed a 10 percent surcharge because there's now a difference between the capital gains rate and the income rate. And as you know, the theory of the Tax Reform Act of '86 was to level them. Let's see what comes out of the conference report. What I want is a tax system where 75 percent of the burden falls on the top 6 percent of the American people -- at least that progressive. And if it is that progressive, then I'm open on the details. But i want to see what the final bill is. That's the key thing: will the wealthy pay their fare share, will it all be in a trust fund to reduce the deficit and will the ratio be at least as good as the one I showed. Five dollars of every 10 in spending cuts, 375 in tax increases on upper income people, $1.25 on the middle class.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plans to Ask Congress to Approve Smaller, Cheaper Space Station

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Saying that in even tight budgetary times the nation "cannot retreat from our obligations to invest in our future," President Clinton said today that he would ask Congress to support a smaller, less-expensive version of the space station.
Mr. Clinton said a space station was crucial to the country's long-term technical leadership and a focal point for international cooperation in the post-cold war era. "At a time when our long-term economic strength depends on our technological leadership and our ability to reduce the deficit, we must invest in technology but invest wisely, making the best possible use of every dollar," he said.
Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore strongly supported the concept of a space station in last year's Presidential campaign. But that support was called into question last spring when the President, under pressure to reduce the Federal deficit and Government spending, ordered the space agency to redesign the orbiting laboratory to cut its costs significantly.
 
$16.5 Billion by 2001
 The Administration said it would propose spending $10.5 billion on the space station over the next five years, asking for $2.1 billion a year starting in the fiscal year 1994. In order to construct a permanently staffed orbital laboratory, spending could reach $16.5 billion by the year 2001, it said.
Compared with spending estimates for the original Space Station Freedom, which would have taken $14.4 billion in the next five years and $25.6 billion to complete, the new proposal could save up to $9 billion in construction costs and $18 billion in operating costs over the projected 10-year life of the station, the White House estimated.
Senior Administration officials said Mr. Clinton was pleased with the proposals for cutting costs, and would make the space station a "high priority" in future budgets. "You can and should assume that the President will support this, and that he will get involved personally," said a White House official who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
In addition to redesigning the station and streamlining the program's management, Mr. Clinton called for reducing bureaucracy and personnel at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to improve efficiency.
Noting that Mr. Gore's National Performance Review team would work with the agency on proposed management changes, Mr. Clinton said, "We are going to redesign NASA as we redesign the space station."
 
Cutbacks in Personnel
 NASA has spent almost $9 billion on the space station project over the last decade and continues to spend about $150 million a month on the program. An independent panel that reviewed the latest NASA redesign effort said most of the savings of the new design would come from major changes in the management and organization of the project, including a 30 percent reduction in the 17,000 NASA and contractor personnel working on the program.
Mr. Clinton reviewed three options for a scaled-down station and chose a combination of the two that most resembled the existing design of the space station Freedom. That design calls for pressurized modules and solar power units attached to a girder-like truss or backbone. Mr. Clinton's plan incorporates most of the elements of what was called Option A, a simplified version of Freedom with scaled-down modules and less complex electrical and data systems, but includes elements of the more expensive Option B.
The President rejected the least expensive alternative, Option C, which called for orbiting the core of a station, a pressurized cylinder with solar panels attached, launched in a single space flight. Option C, criticized as less advanced technically than the other two, would not easily have accommodated modules being developed by international partners to the project.
The White House said the Administration would spend the next 90 days working with Congress, NASA and the project's international partners in Japan, Canada and Europe to work out the details of a new, simplified design of the station. A major goal of the effort, it said, would be to expand international participation in the project, which some observers took to mean a greater role for Russia.
"I will also seek to enhance and expand the opportunities for international participation in the space station project so that the space station can serve as a model of nations coming together in peaceful cooperation," Mr. Clinton said.
Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University in Washington, said the President's action could make the station a truly international project. "I read the President's statement as leaving the door wide open for enhanced Russian participation," he said.
Major supporters in Congress said the President's decision to stay with many aspects of the design now in development would help the project retain political support, particularly among Congress members with space station work in their districts.
 
Clinton Backs Supercollider
 On another technological matter, Mr. Clinton today reaffirmed his support for the Energy Department's Superconducting Supercollider in a letter to Congress, a week before the House is to debate how it would finance the project.
"These are tough economic times, yet our Administration supports this project as part of its broad investment package in science and technology," he wrote in a letter to the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, William H. Natcher, Democrat of Kentucky.
Mr. Clinton sent the letter to Congress to counter speculation that the Administration planned to trim the $8.25 billion particle-accelerator project under construction in Texas, a White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press.
