HEADLINE: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Base Closings;
Aspin Asks Base-Closing Panel Not to Add to List

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Les Aspin today told a Presidential commission studying base closings that shutting down more than he recommended could hurt military readiness and overwhelm Pentagon efforts to help communities find new uses for closed sites.
Mr. Aspin's cautionary tone was in striking contrast to his first appearance before the commission on March 15, when he acknowledged that his list was based on outdated assumptions of the military's future size, and all but invited the panel to close several more installations. 
 Since then, however, senior Pentagon policy makers have been grappling with ways to shrink the military and do not want the commission to pre-empt any of their options on the use of bases before their review is completed this summer. In addition, the Defense Department now realizes the deficiencies of existing Federal efforts to assist communities in developing new uses for closed installations.
"Closing the wrong bases could impair our future readiness and military capability," Mr. Aspin said. "Closing too many bases could overload the system and undermine our ability to pick the right bases."
Mr. Aspin's plea to commissioners to hold back from closing more bases than he recommended sounded less like a defense of those bases than a testimonial to Pentagon incompetence.
"Closing bases has been cumbersome and slow," Mr. Aspin said, adding that only 13 of the 42 large bases identified for closing in 1988 and 1991 have actually closed.
"Grants were too meager," he said. "The property disposal process was far too slow. Interaction with communities was fragmented. Folks didn't know who to talk to. And finally, Federal assistance itself was uncoordinated."
 
Decision Expected Soon
 Mr. Aspin said he had ordered a major effort to correct these problems.
The chairman of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, James A. Courter, a former Republican Representative from New Jersey, said the seven-member panel would probably start making its final recommendations Wednesday.
The commission is studying the 43 large bases and 122 smaller sites that Mr. Aspin recommended for closing or reduction, as well as 47 other large bases and 26 smaller installations the commission added because they were comparable to the sites on Mr. Aspin's list. Commissioners have said they may substitute one or two bases from Mr. Aspin's list, or close a few more, but are not likely to alter the Secretary's list significantly.
The panel, set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents, can add or subtract bases from the Pentagon's list. The panel must submit its final recommendations to President Clinton by July 1. Mr. Clinton, and then Congress, would have to approve or reject the entire package.
The hearing today was the last of 26 sessions the panel has held since March. The commissioners visited 80 installations and, reflecting the intense political interest in their work, heard testimony from 209 representatives and senators.
Mr. Aspin, flanked by Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the four military service chiefs, stood by his original recommendations, including sparing the Monterey Presidio and McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, because of the potential harm to that part of Northern California, which has been hit hard by the recession. The commission has since added the two installations for consideration.

Courter, chairman of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In April

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Confounding forecasters, the nation's trade deficit widened again in April, to $10.49 billion, as the imbalance with Japan climbed to its highest level in five and a half years and its third highest on record.
The Commerce Department report is likely to increase trade friction between the two countries as President Clinton prepares for the Tokyo economic summit meeting of top industrialized nations in less than three weeks. 
 The American deficit with Japan grew moderately to $5.5 billion, despite a slight reduction in imports of new cars. The drop in auto imports suggested that American car makers were at least holding their own, with the aid of a sharply rising yen.
Possibly adding to the trade tensions with Japan was a separate report that showed Tokyo had fallen slightly short of its commitment to import 20 percent of its semiconductors in the first quarter.
 
 
Most Analysts Surprised
 Although the widening of the overall merchandise deficit was not large -- only $35 million from a March level that was revised upward -- most analysts were surprised that the deficit did not narrow substantially following a huge jump that had carried it to a four-year high and was thought to have been temporary.
Exports and imports each declined about $500 million for the month, imports from a record $49.3 billion that Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary, had called "a one-month deviation."
Today, Mr. Brown called the trade results "disappointing," a reflection, he said, of the fact that economic recovery is taking shape in the United States while the economies of its main trading partners remain for the most part in the doldrums.
This disparity means that the United States can afford to buy large amounts of imported goods while other countries lack the money to buy as many of ours.
But surprised as they were, most analysts appeared to take today's report in stride, noting among other things that exports continued to be quite vigorous and that the weak dollar, which should eventually help shrink the deficit with Japan, had initially magnified it.
"The export pace is up 5.5 percent" over the first four months of this year, said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
Some analysts also pointed to customs data for May indicating that the next report on merchandise trade, due July 16, will show a markedly smaller deficit. Michael Englund of MMS International, an analytical firm, calculated that customs receipts for imported goods fell 18 percent last month.
And Paula Stern, a consultant and one-time head of the International Trade Commission, found no new worrisome elements in the trade data even though the deficit with Japan was the largest since one of $5.54 billion in October 1987.
"What we've got," she said, "is a chronic problem that's been in the making for several years," one mainly the result of the bursting of Japan's economic bubble and not of faltering competitiveness here.
"We've been growing," Ms. Stern added, noting that American automobile companies, for example, have been using the rising yen to take back market share from the Japanese instead of using it as cover to raise their own prices.
The falling dollar, however, does cause uneasiness among economists in that it makes foreign goods more expensive and thereby aggravates inflation, which so far remains under control in the area of 3 percent, heading for perhaps 3.5 percent.
One of the main factors keeping the deficit high in April was the bill for imported crude oil, which climbed to $3.7 billion, from $3.4 billion in March. The United States bought 14 million more barrels in May at a price averaging $16.71, up 24 cents.
The biggest change in exports was a $400 million decline in capital goods while the biggest nonpetroleum change in imports was a decline in consumer goods, the report also showed.
 The American surplus with the European Community withered in April to $47 million from $860 million as deterioration with Britain and France far exceeded a narrowing of the deficit with Italy.
But a small deficit with South and Central America became a $240 million surplus and the deficit also narrowed with South Korea and Singapore while holding steady with Hong Kong and Taiwan.
The surplus with Mexico, with which the United States is trying to conclude a free-trade agreement, eased to $264 million; over the first four months of the year, it ran at only 54 percent of the comparable 1992 pace.
The deficit with Canada, the largest trading partner of the United States, widened in April to $934 million from $661 million as imports of new cars exceeded exports by $1 billion.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Tokyo Misses Goal
 WASHINGTON, June 16 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- Japan imported 19.6 percent of its semiconductors in the first quarter, just shy of its commitment of at least 20 percent, the United States and Japanese Governments said today.
In the last three months of 1992, foreign semiconductor makers held 20.2 percent of the Japanese market.
In March, Japan warded off what might have been the beginning of a trade war with the United States by announcing that it crossed the 20 percent level agreed to in a 1991 accord.
"Any decline in foreign market share is cause for concern," Andrew A. Procassini, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said. "However, having just returned from productive meetings with electronics company executives in Japan, we are encouraged by their commitment to continue working with the U.S. industry to achieve the goals of the semiconductor trade pact."
Hidehiko Yoshida, senior executive vice president of the Toshiba Corporation, said the decline should not be used to justify demands that Japan commit to at least a 20 percent foreign share of its chip market in 1993.

HEADLINE: Technology Fund Is a First for China

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
China took another step down the capitalist road yesterday with the creation of its first international venture capital fund, the Shanghai Pacific Technology Venture Fund.
The $20 million fund plans to invest in 30 to 40 technology companies in Shanghai, a city of 12 million people. The start-up companies -- some already formed, others still to be created -- will be in selected high-technology fields like computer software, telecommunications, cable television and pharmaceuticals. The fund will make its first investments later this year. 
 Half of the financial backing for the fund will come from nine state-owned Chinese banks and companies, while the other half will be invested by an American partner, Pacific Technology Venture Fund Inc. of Boston.
For the Chinese, the Shanghai fund is an effort to spur development of an entrepreneurial high-technology sector, tapping American money and business expertise. "The Shanghai government wants to reform the structure of its industry," said Liu Zhenyuan, the chairman of the fund, who stepped down earlier this year after a decade as the vice mayor in charge of economic development in Shanghai.
"We need the know-how much more than we need the money," Mr. Liu said yesterday in a telephone interview from Boston.
 
Big Money for China
 There has been a flood of foreign investment in China recently -- in the booming Shanghai Stock Exchange, in factories and in joint ventures. Another Chinese venture firm, the Guandong Science and Technology Venture Capital Company, was set up earlier this year, backed by several Government agencies. But the Shanghai fund is believed to be the first venture capital fund with a foreign partner to be authorized by China.
The American partner, Pacific Technology, is also discussing similar joint investments with the Chinese authorities in Guandong, the province near Hong Kong, and in Beijing. Pacific Technology was founded more than a decade ago by Patrick J. McGovern, the chairman of the International Data Group, a leading publisher of computer magazines like PC World and Computerworld.
 
New Public Companies

The Shanghai fund plans to work with the companies it backs in much the same way as an American venture capitalist works with start-ups in Silicon Valley. There will be plenty of hands-on coaching at the beginning, said Hugo Hsiung, managing director of the Shanghai fund.
"After a few years, we want to take them public," said Mr. Hsiung, a former Chinese official who was educated in the United States. The flourishing Shanghai Stock Exchange, he added, should prove an eager market for the initial stock offerings of the new companies.
For his part, Mr. Liu, 59, reflected briefly on how much times have changed in China. The new venture capitalist received his doctorate in electrical engineering from the Academy of Sciences of the former Soviet Union in 1960, when China favored Marx over markets.
In the next couple of weeks, Mr. Liu will visit American high-tech centers like Cambridge, Mass., and Silicon Valley. "We want to bring small American businesses with technology and marketing expertise to China to work with our entrepreneurs," he said.

HEADLINE: Productivity for Quarter Off, First Drop in 2 Years

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
After two years of impressive gains, the productivity of American workers plunged in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The new numbers suggest that perhaps the workplace is not becoming as efficient as many experts have suggested.
Productivity -- essentially, the amount produced by workers in a given period -- fell at an annual rate of 1.6 percent in the quarter, the Labor Department said. While some economists insisted that the setback was only a temporary interruption for a work force becoming steadily more efficient, others predicted that productivity might be falling back to the weak rate of growth that hampered the nation in the 70's and 80's. 
 Whatever the view, nearly everyone agreed yesterday that one quarter's poor figures, after months of improvement, did not provide a conclusive answer. "There is no way to say the trend line is definitely up until one has seen a few years of data," said Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist.
 
More Overtime and Temporaries
 The latest report concluded that while the nation's nonfarm output -- the total production of goods and services -- rose only eight-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, the number of hours worked by Americans increased 2.5 percent. Employees, rather than cutting the time needed to type a letter or manufacture a shirt, as they had in the eight previous quarters, took longer to carry out such tasks.
Recoveries from previous recessions have followed a similar pattern. There were many months in which companies found ways to squeeze greater production from the work force, only to give up the effort and once again hire, add overtime or bring in temporary workers. All three tendencies showed up in the first quarter.
 
A Qualitative Difference?
 Some economists, like Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Company, argue that the current upturn is different. They say that American companies, beset by competition and weak demand, have achieved permanent efficiencies that allow them to produce more without raising labor costs. Automation and computers have helped to achieve this.
"What happened in the first quarter is only a brief interruption in this long-term trend," Mr. Roach said. "Over the last two years, it looks as if the cumulative gain in productivity is just over 2 percent" annually.
But Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, hailed yesterday's numbers as the beginning of a return to the lower productivity gains characteristic of the 1970's and 1980's, when efficiency improved at an average annual rate of only 1.3 percent. "My bottom line is that all the improvements in 1992 were simply correcting the inefficiencies of the late 1980's," Professor Gordon said.
The first-quarter numbers -- revising an earlier estimate of a decline of only five-tenths of 1 percent -- showed great variation. Manufacturing productivity, for example, rose by a healthy 4.8 percent. But while makers of durable goods like cars and machinery shot ahead 8.6 percent, efficiency among manufacturers of nondurable items like clothing and toys fell by four-tenths of a percent.
The Labor Department does not provide separate breakdowns for service companies, public employees, construction and the like.

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Medicare;
Cutting Health Dollars to Heal Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
The two houses of Congress are preparing for a fight over how deeply to cut the growth of Medicare, a fight that has major implications for the nation's elderly, for doctors and hospitals, and for the success of President Clinton's plan to overhaul the nation's health-care system.
Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee said today that they were seeking much deeper cuts in the growth of Medicare, the Federal health-insurance program for the elderly and disabled, than President Clinton proposed or the House of Representatives endorsed. The extra savings would reduce the need for the Senate to vote to raise taxes as much as the House did. 
 Mr. Clinton sought Medicare savings that would total $42.9 billion over five years. The budget bill passed by the House would generate savings of $50.4 billion. Senate Democrats would shave $67.3 billion from Medicare. Most of the additional cutbacks envisioned by Democratic senators would come from hospitals and, to a lesser degree, from doctors.
Medicare is expected to cost slightly more than $1 trillion over the next five years. Mr. Clinton would trim total outlays about 4 percent, while the House would save nearly 5 percent and the Senate 6.4 percent.
 
Different Approaches
 The Senate bill would make selective cuts in Medicare over five years, whereas the House bill would simply freeze most payment rates, eliminating inflation allowances for the next two years.
The changes would be the starting point for future efforts to revamp the nation's health-care system. The Medicare cutbacks will complicate Mr. Clinton's task of financing the health-care overhaul. Many people had hoped that Medicare savings would be available to help finance health care for the uninsured, but now that money will be used to help reduce the Federal budget deficit.
While many economists agree that the deficit should be reduced, the specific measures proposed by the Senate Democrats have drawn a chorus of criticism from spokesmen for elderly people, doctors and hospitals.
Dr. Daniel Thursz, chairman of the Leadership Council of Aging Organizations, a coalition of groups that lobby for the elderly, called the Senate's proposals for further Medicare savings "a pointed attack against older Americans."
"Most of the Medicare cuts will initially be placed on doctors and other service providers, but their impact will eventually be felt by consumers," Dr. Thursz said.
 
Impact on Hospitals
 In speech after speech, President Clinton has pointed out that Medicare cutbacks do little or nothing to control overall health costs because hospitals and doctors simply raise their charges to privately insured patients, a process known as cost shifting.
Thomas A. Scully, a top budget official in the Bush Administration, observed that most of the cutbacks now sought by Senate Democrats had been proposed unsuccessfully by Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, asserted that the new cutbacks would have "a devastating effect" on the city's hospitals, which depend heavily on Medicare. In particular, he lamented cutbacks in Medicare payments to teaching hospitals; he noted that 15 percent of all doctors were trained in New York City.
"If the program is chopped up like this, it will have a terrible impact on our ability to deliver care," Mr. Raske said. "It will force New York hospitals to make cuts in work force and services."
The Senate bill would take several novel steps to favor "primary care" doctors -- those who practice family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics and preventive care -- at the expense of surgeons and other specialists. Surgeons are predictably angry.
 
Favoring Some Doctors
 Dr. W. Gerald Austen, chief of surgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital and president of the American College of Surgeons, said: "We are outraged by recent actions of the Senate Finance Committee that disproportionately and unfairly penalize surgeons. The committee's decision to achieve budget savings by placing additional, unwarranted burdens on surgeons shows total disregard for the physician-payment system that Congress designed just a few years ago."
Under that system, Congress established a fee schedule for doctors serving Medicare patients. To make sure that doctors do not perform unnecessary services, the Government set annual goals for Medicare payments to doctors. Payments for surgical services decreased last year by 3.3 percent, partly because of surgeons' efforts to control the volume of such services, while payments for other doctors' services rose 7 percent.
Charles G. Huntington, director of the Washington office of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said: "The Finance Committee saw fit to protect and promote the delivery of primary-care services. That's consistent with most proposals for health-care reform, which seek to make such services more available by providing incentives for doctors to go into primary care."
Medicare pays teaching hospitals for some costs of medical education, including a portion of salaries for residents in training. Under the Finance Committee's bill, the payment would be increased 10 percent for each resident in a primary-care program. Payments would be reduced 30 percent for other residents.
Despite the cutbacks, the total outlays for Medicare would continue to increase at a robust pace, to more than $220 billion in 1998 from the $129 billion in 1992. But, at the current rate, the costs in 1998 would grow to $258 billion.
Howard B. Shapiro, director of public policy at the American College of Physicians, said that many doctors were now reluctant to take new Medicare patients because Medicare payments were inadequate to cover their costs.
Administration officials are preoccupied with the budget bill and have little time to work on Mr. Clinton's ambitious plan to guarantee health care for all Americans, a delay that has caused consternation for some groups that have pushed for such changes.
Ellen L. Goldstein, director of health policy at the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group composed mainly of Fortune 500 companies, said: "Health-care reform is an existential exercise right now. Will there be reform? Will it be bold and comprehensive, as President Clinton promised? This was the moment for such reform, but people worry that maybe it will slip away again."

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Campaign Finance;
Senate Passes Measure to Curb Aid From PAC's

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
The Senate today passed campaign finance legislation that would create voluntary spending limits and reduce the amounts that political action committees can give candidates.
The Senate bill actually proposes to ban PAC contributions absolutely, but it adds that if that is found to be unconstitutional, as many senators believe, the contributions must be reduced to $1,000. 
 The vote was 60 to 38, with 7 Republicans joining 53 Democrats in support, and 3 Democrats voting with 35 Republicans in opposition.
The Republican votes in favor came only after Democrats agreed to drop most public financing from the bill, retaining only a provision under which a candidate who abides by spending limits can get Federal money if his opponent exceeds them.
But this and other compromises did not dim the enthusiasm of Senate sponsors or of President Clinton. Mr. Clinton issued a statement saying, "Today's vote is a victory for the American people and a setback for the special interests," and adding, "The Senate has answered the call for change."
 
Republican Unity Fades
 This bill, whatever happens to it in the House or in a House-Senate conference, is also an important token of the warning that leaders of both parties issued earlier in the session, when Republicans united to kill Mr. Clinton's economic-stimulus program. On many issues, they said, Republicans will not be able to muster that sort of unity.
Mr. Clinton, while winning no help from Republicans on any issue involving taxes or the deficit, can attract their support on domestic issues like student loans or national service, and even on the more partisan question of campaign-finance legislation.
And his technique of claiming victory and emphasizing the successes his Administration achieves in compromises is one that Capitol Hill welcomes. Lawmakers compare his reactions favorably to those of President Jimmy Carter, who they thought spent more energy complaining about what he did not get than boasting of what he achieved.
Today's passage was an anticlimax after Wednesday's 62-to-37 vote to end a Republican filibuster, which had gone on for nearly three weeks.
But when the bill was passed, at least one major question was left unsettled by the Senate, and that was how to make the Federal Election Commission more decisive. The six-member commission that enforces the campaign laws is one of the slowest-acting agencies in Washington and frequently does nothing at all because of tie votes.
A provision in Mr. Clinton's version of the bill, giving the commission's general counsel, in effect, a tie-breaking vote, was attacked at the last moment by Republicans, who thought it would make the agency partisan, and probably pro-Democratic.
To insure that the filibuster would be broken, the bill's managers agreed to drop that section Wednesday, and today they agreed to try to resolve the matter in a House-Senate conference.
But before a conference can be held, some form of the bill has to be passed in the House.
The bill passed today fundamentally deals with only Senate elections, leaving the House to write rules for its own elections. The only provisions that apply to the House as well as the Senate are the one that would reduce the maximum contributions by political action committees to $1,000 from $5,000, and another prohibiting franked mass mailings in an election year.
House leaders today professed optimism that they could pass a bill, although one that would differ sharply from the Senate bill. "We will retain part of the campaign finance role of political action committees," said Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington.
 
Public Financing Imperiled
 And while some spokesman for outside interest groups, like the League of Women Voters, said today they would press for the House to restore the public financing that the Senate dropped, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, indicated that was unlikely.
In the bill passed today, the incentives for Senate candidates to adhere to the spending limits, which vary by state according to population, are that if they do, television stations would have to sell them advertising time at half price, they could get low-cost mailings and they would not be subject to a newly imposed 35 percent tax on the money their campaign committees receive.

HEADLINE: Assembly Tax-Cut Plan Fans Political Flames in Trenton

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 17

 BODY:
It will be at least weeks before the tax-cut proposal that the Assembly Speaker introduced today comes to a vote, but the political impact of his move was immediate.
It set off a heated exchange between Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, while sending both Gov. Jim Florio and his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, scrambling for safe political ground. 
 On Monday, the Republican legislators released a version of the budget that called for an anticipated $150 million surplus to go into a "taxpayer relief fund" to soften an anticipated increase in the Federal gasoline tax by the Clinton Administration.
 
A Blustery Meeting
 But Mr. Haytaian said 54 Assemblymen, including three Democrats, had signed on as co-sponsors of his bill, enough to assure its passage. That would force Senate Republicans to go along, or accept the consequences of voting down a tax cut in an election year.
Legislative aides said a meeting today between Republican leadership from both chambers to discuss the tax cut ended quickly with the blustery Mr. Haytaian and the normally reserved Mr. DiFrancesco yelling at each other.
"I categorize it as some disagreements, which I expected," Mr. Haytaian said later at a news conference. "My job is to get bills through the Assembly. We'll worry about the passage through the Senate when we get it through the Assembly."
He said he expected an Assembly vote in July or August.
Mr. DiFrancesco issued a statement that said the Senate would consider Mr. Haytaian's plan.
"It may be premature, however, for the Legislature to finalize a taxpayer relief program before it has a clearer view of the direction of Federal fiscal policies and the health of our state's economy," Mr. DiFrancesco said.
 
A Rift Between Chambers
 Last year the Republicans, who control both chambers of the Legislature with a two-thirds majority, overrode Mr. Florio's veto to roll back the sales tax by one percentage point. But since then, Mr. DiFrancesco and the other Senate Republicans have become more cautious and Mr. Haytaian more aggressive.
"We are carrying on the mandate of the people, people that voted us in and agreed with us when we said we would repeal the sales tax, cut the size of government and, as monies come in, we would look at the other taxes that Jim Florio enacted," Mr. Haytaian said. "I have been consistent in what I have been saying and this is just consistency extended."
A senior Republican aide in the Senate said that Mr. DiFrancesco felt he had been "ambushed" by Mr. Haytaian. Many Senate Republicans and some Assemblymen believe any surplus should be used to reduce the state debt, not taxes.
Governor Florio, in a letter to Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco, said that he favored "a responsible, fiscally prudent tax cut." "But I believe we should not wait until the fall for whatever tax relief we believe we can responsibly and prudently provide," the Governor said. "People have a right to expect certainty in the process, and they are rightly skeptical about promises made in June about a tax cut that might come in September or October."
 
Middle-Income Benefit
 Mr. Haytaian said later that Mr. Florio had no say in the process.
"Governor Florio is not moving this train," the Assembly Speaker said. "Chuck Haytaian and the Senate President are moving this train by virtue of a veto-proof majority."
Meanwhile, Carl Golden, chief spokesman for the Whitman campaign, said his candidate's position had been consistent.
"If the money is available to support this kind of tax cut, then we should move ahead and do it," he said. "If the money isn't there, we shouldn't do it."
The tax cut, intended to benefit New Jerseyans with middle incomes, would average $250 a year. The Haytaian plan would cut half a percentage point from the tax burden on income between $20,000 and $70,000 for married couples and between $20,000 and $35,000 for single taxpayers. The tax rate on income below $20,000 would stay the same.
If approved, the tax cut would take effect on Jan. 1, 1994, and would cost between $108 million and $117 million in the first six months, Mr. Haytaian said, and between $240 million and $260 million in the following years.

HEADLINE: Newcomers Find Success Despite the Barriers

SERIES: Hidden Economy: Immigrants Underground -- Last of six articles.

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRICK, N.J.

 BODY:
After following their dreams to the United States, Yolanda Vasquez and her husband found themselves in a dark, three-room tenement in North Bergen with a mattress on the floor, wondering what had possessed them to leave Panama.
They had no working papers, no job connections and few prospects -- at a time when immigration laws were about to become stricter and halfway decent jobs hard to come by, even for Americans. 
 But now, like many thousands of other immigrants who make their way against great odds, they are on the verge of success. After nearly nine years in the United States, they already own a three-bedroom ranch on a cul-de-sac, spend most weekends chauffeuring their three children to soccer matches and hold two individual retirement accounts. Any day now, they will also be legal residents.
The journey this couple made -- starting out in the region's underground economy -- does not always end in success. The underground economy -- a world that is off the books and unregulated -- has virtually enslaved thousands of vulnerable immigrants, exploiting their desperation by forcing them into the worst jobs for the worst pay.
But it has also served to sustain and nurture many thousands more who eventually surface to pay taxes, gain legal status and achieve their goals.
Experts say that those most likely to succeed are much like Ms. Vasquez and her husband, who were both well educated when they got here and had the advantage of a relative already living legally in this country.
But theirs was not a journey without hardship. For this couple, it has involved one route for the husband and one for the wife. He worked 12-hour days, seven days a week, for years. She had to work as a live-in maid, hostage to a job she hated, because she knew that maids, sponsored by their employers, are almost guaranteed they will be granted legal status. The children, two boys, 14 and 12, and a daughter, 13, suffered too. Often lonely in a strange land, they spent long hours with babysitters, and many hours by themselves, as their parents worked to establish themselves.
Sitting on a rose chintz sofa in their living room on a Sunday afternoon, the couple talked of how far they had come even without a green card. They love the security and convenience of their Brick Township neighborhood, a sleepy block of identical houses on quarter-acre lots bordering several large roadside malls and plazas. Both have become fluent in English; Ms. Vasquez barely has an accent. Together, they make $55,000 a year, with $45,000 coming from wages and overtime earned by Ms. Vasquez's husband.
"Now, getting all the papers means we have arrived," said Ms. Vasquez, who is 41 years old. "But, whew!" She pretended to wipe sweat from her brow. "It has been very hard."
 
Entry
A Simple Plan Derailed by Reality
Ms. Vasquez's husband, who is 39 and came to New York on a tourist visa in 1984, one year before the rest of the family, expects his green card, or permanent visa, within the next few weeks. Because he is not a legal resident yet, he spoke only on the condition that he not be identified in order to protect his job as a manager in a parking garage in northern New Jersey. Ms. Vasquez, who usually uses her husband's last name, would only allow her given surname to be used. She and the children received permanent visas last year, after applying when Ms. Vasquez began working as a maid eight years ago.
When Ms. Vasquez's husband came to New York, the plan was so simple: Get a high-paying job, save money, and send for the family. He believed that a job -- any job -- was the ticket to becoming a permanent resident of the United States.
He had decided to come after constant prodding from his brother-in-law, a native Colombian who is a naturalized American citizen, and his sister.
 
Limited English in New Land
 The couple lived in David, the capitol of Chiriqui, on Panama's west coast, where they both had good jobs. He headed the human resources department of a major company. She was a social worker. But they came to believe that their children, who were still preschoolers, would never have the same educational opportunities as their American counterparts.
"Panama doesn't have the technology," Ms. Vasquez's husband explained.
When he arrived in New York, in 1984, Ms. Vasquez's husband stayed with his sister and brother-in-law in Astoria while he began looking for work by scouring the want ads in the Sunday papers. But he knew little English beyond "How are you?" "I am fine, thank you?" No job fit the bill for a manager/accountant who couldn't speak the language.
 
Rough Times at Work
 Meanwhile, his sister and brother-in-law told him to apply for a New York State driver's license. All it took, he said, was a written test at the Department of Motor Vehicles and proof from the Panamanian consulate that he had been a licensed driver in Panama.
By his second month here, his brother-in-law also got him a Social Security number and card -- sold by its owner -- from an acquaintance in Astoria with connections in the underground economy.
"I didn't know that it belonged to somebody," Ms. Vasquez's husband said of the card. "I didn't know what an illegal alien was. All I knew was that I was told I needed the card to work."
Actually, at first he didn't need the card. His first three jobs, brokered by an employment agency he found in the classifieds of Noticias Del Mundo, a Spanish-language newspaper, were in places employing illegal immigrants. He was dismissed from the first, a midtown croissant shop, after two hours for failing to understand a sandwich order. He quit the second, as a deliveryman for a Times Square diner, after getting paid $60 for a 60-hour week. (He had been promised $130.) At the third, a Greek diner in Queens, he dropped a tray in the dining room, sending plates and glasses crashing "with tremendous noise." The owner paid him $80 for four days of work and said he would get a call if the diner needed him.
 
Employment
Making a Living Despite Obstacles
It took close to six months to find a steady job, at a parking garage under a midtown hotel. When the employers asked him for a driver's license and Social Security card, he was able to show both.
By this time, his visa had expired. He and his brother-in-law went to an immigration lawyer in Queens for help and were told that to get a visa he needed the kind of job that would lead an employer to sponsor his application. Live-in domestic work qualified. Parking cars did not.
But the garage paid relatively well -- $4 an hour when the minimum wage was $3.35, and he decided to stay there. He set aside the issue of his residency and began taking English classes twice a week for $60 a week at a midtown language center.
He also opened a savings account at a Queens bank. And he received his first credit card, by applying for a $500 credit limit, the minimum the bank offered.
Two months after he started working at the garage, he was ready to bring the family over.
 
Moving to New Jersey
 Ms. Vasquez and the children arrived in New York on tourist visas to find their new home was a two-story clapboard building on North Bergen's busiest commercial strip. On the advice of a co-worker, Ms. Vasquez's husband had crossed the Hudson to find an affordable apartment. The rent: $500 a month.
"It was not a very nice apartment," he said.
But they could save money. A month later, they bought their first car, a 1978 Ford Fairlane, for $1,300.
They planned to have Ms. Vasquez's college transcripts transferred here so that she could get a job as a social worker and apply for a green card. Meanwhile, she enrolled in Hudson County Community College where she took six credits in English and social service. "We considered it an investment," Ms. Vasquez said.
"It was a happy time," her husband said. "We started to travel around. One of the first places we took them to was Washington, D.C. I learned how to use a map. We went to Vermont. We went to Great Adventure."
Ms. Vasquez began applying for county social-service jobs but was told she needed to learn more English.
"The plan wasn't really working out," she said.
 
Assimilation
Buying a Home And Settling Down
Not long after she and the children moved here, the 1986 immigration bill imposing sanctions on employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens was passed. It was then that she decided to become a maid. A friend in North Bergen told her that a family in Deal, a half hour from where they now live, needed help. "We went together to the couple," Ms. Vasquez said. "We said we wanted visas. That's the only reason I will do this." The couple, who had two sons in elementary school, agreed.
Ms. Vasquez and her husband saw few other options. They could have divorced each other, married citizens for $2,000 to $3,000 each, then divorced the citizens and married each other again. (He knew of people who were doing it.) Or they could have bought false documents stating they lived in the United States before 1982 so that they could apply for amnesty under the new law. (He knew of people doing that as well.)
"It wasn't the right way," he said. "I didn't want to go through that situation."
They concede they have resorted to a few illegal methods to move forward here. Ms. Vasquez's husband's Social Security card not only helped him get the garage job; he also used it to open bank accounts and apply for credit cards. And Ms. Vasquez bought a New York driver's license, paying a Panamanian official $50 and a Department of Motor Vehicles worker $40 to get it.
But they have made their money in honest jobs, they say. And they have sacrificed. For the first 18 months of her job, until the family moved from their apartment in Hudson County to Ocean County, Ms. Vasquez lived with her employers and saw the family only on weekends. She spent close to $80 of her $100-a-week cash salary on taxis. Her husband, who worked an overnight shift, had to hire a babysitter to care for the children. The eldest began having problems in school. The whole family was miserable.
"I cried every night," Ms. Vasquez said. "I lost 40 pounds. I wanted to go back to Panama."
The family then moved to a beach apartment in Deal, and having saved about $10,000, started looking for a house. And because Ms. Vasquez had a work permit and proof that she was in the process of obtaining a visa, they could apply for a mortgage.
When they bought their $110,000 house in Brick Township in November 1989, it took every penny they could save -- their combined income was about $40,000 -- and a small loan from the employers of Ms. Vasquez's husband.
It took nearly seven years for Ms. Vasquez and the children to receive their visas. The applications, like thousands of other visa applications that flood the Immigration and Naturalization Service each year, became mired in bureaucracy.
Her husband had not applied for a visa with the rest of the family because if his request had been denied, he would have had to leave the country, he said. Ms. Vasquez applied for her husband's visa after she received hers because the family's lawyer advised them that visa applications sponsored by a spouse are usually quickly approved. In April, immigration officials requested a copy of their marriage certificate -- a good sign, according to their lawyer. Eventually, they hope to become full United States citizens.
 
Progress on Job Front
 As much as she loathes it, Ms. Vasquez still works as a maid. For a while, she kept the job because she thought she had to if her husband was to get a visa. But a couple of months ago, she found out that that wasn't so.
"The lawyers said I just need to be employed," she said. She applied for a job as a social worker for a nonprofit organization; last week, she found out she got the job, which starts later this month.
Ms. Vasquez keeps a file of their children's school records on a kitchen counter, with all their report cards, teacher's notes and awards. Recently, when their report cards didn't meet her standards, Ms. Vasquez and her husband canceled their cable television.
"We tell the children keep your first language and then work hard to achieve," she said. "That's the two pieces of advice."
Her husband is researching schools offering business courses for the import-export business he wants to start. He firmly believes he will succeed.
"One of the things that has always prompted me," he said, "is the idea that if someone else could do it, what can't you?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Trump Jumps the Gun a Bit On Success of His Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
True to his promoter's instincts, Donald J. Trump announced yesterday the "tremendous success" of the sale of his $385 million in junk bonds, even though they have not been officially sold.
"They were all saying they wanted to buy Trump bonds," he said in a midafternoon call he initiated about the sale of $325 million in eight-year mortgage notes and $60 million in 10-year payment-in-kind notes.
 
 
'A Good Year'
 The coupon rate on the mortgage bonds, he said with some obvious pride, was below 11 percent -- at 10.875 percent. And the deal "was oversubscribed." 
 So, he was asked, "Is Trump back?"
"I'm doing great," he replied. "It has been a good year."
What's good? He listed the rebound of his three Atlantic City casinos, one of which, the Trump Plaza, is backing the two junk-bond issues he was touting. There was the New York City Council's approval of his $3 billion residential development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. And there was the approval to convert his 140-room, Palm Beach, Fla., home, Mar-a-Lago, into a beach club and spa.
Then, in the way that he can get personal, he confided, "I had to get back to work, in all fairness."
But a subsequent call to Merrill Lynch & Company, the lead underwriter on the deal, disclosed that the new bonds had not been officially sold yesterday and there could be no comment on the details of yields and prices or who bought what.
The reason the sale could not be completed was that some small changes had been made in the plan that required it to be refiled with the Securities and Exchange Commission. "We cannot go effective on the transaction until tomorrow, when we anticipate on being cleared by the S.E.C.," an official at Merrill Lynch said yesterday.
Still, that was no obstacle to Mr. Trump. Calling later yesterday from near the 17th green at the Baltusrol Glof Club in Springfield, N.J., he said, "Believe it or not, I am at the U.S. Open." And, he added, "I guess it will be effective tomorrow morning," referring to the bond sale.
Regardless of the finality of the deal, the junk-bond sale did appear to be going very well, even though it was just three years ago that Mr. Trump's real estate and casino empire nearly toppled.
One of the signs of strong demand was that all of the $60 million of payment-in-kind notes were sold to the public. In the May 24 prospectus, $25 million of them were to be taken by Mr. Trump's bank creditors.
The rumor in the credit market was that high-yield mutual funds run by Fidelity and Putnam would buy many of the Trump junk-bond issues. This could not be confirmed. But if such high-yield funds do buy the Trump notes, it will be millions of small investors who are taking on the risks as portfolio managers try to keep their returns attractive.
"Some people may buy them but not want it to be up in lights because of the drubbing that people took on Trump," said one portfolio manager, who like others was reluctant to comment for the record on the Trump deal.
 
 
Risks Cited
 The payment-in-kind notes will allow interest to be paid with new notes rather than cash for eight years. A number of portfolio managers said they would not touch the Trump notes because of the risks. One manager said he figured that the equity value of Trump Plaza would have to increase at a rate that exceeded the yield on the bonds over the next eight years.
That yield, according to Mr. Trump, will be around 12.5 percent. He said the yield would be 137 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the yield on the mortgage notes, which is 11.125 percent. The fact that the notes are being sold at a price below their face value raises the yield value of the 10.875 percent coupon to the investor.
Another sign of strong demand was the fact that the spread between the yield on the mortgage notes and the payment-in-kind bonds was lower than the 150 basis points that was being predicted as Merrill Lynch began shopping the bonds this week.
The actual return on the payment-in-kind bonds will be higher because they come with warrants that give a buyer $1,000 in additional notes for each original $5,000 note that was purchased. This brings the effective yield to around 15 percent, analysts said.
 
 
Better Buy
 The mortgage notes, according to portfolio managers, seemed to be a much better buy, in part because they are a mortgage on the Trump Plaza casino. Several analysts said the casino had the assets to back up the mortgage.
But still, there are those who wonder about buying from Mr. Trump again.
"It's like Brazil coming back to the market," said Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. "From an outsiders point of view I am always amazed how quickly people forget. But when you are managing other people's money you do that."
Mr. Trump dismissed such thoughts. Asked about Brazil, he said, "I've never been like that."
"The reason they stuck with me," he added, referring to bondholders, "is that they know what kind of job we do."
 
 
Treasury Market
 Prices in the Treasury market were little changed yesterday, even as traders and investors were greeted with the news that Senate Democrats had reached a compromise on a new version of President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan.
The price of the 30-year bond due in February 2023 was up 1/32 point, to 104, and the yield was unchanged at 6.81 percent. The prices of short-term Treasury notes were down slightly as the yields, which move in the opposite direction, inched up a few basis points.
The shape of the final deficit-reduction plan depends on what compromise the House and Senate can finally work out if the full Senate approves the version put together by the Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee. So any real response in the bond market, if there is any, will have to wait until then.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Steady

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
New claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged last week, the Labor Department reported today. The department said that 344,000 people applied for first-time benefits, the same as in the week that ended on June 5 and in line with forecasts.
The four-week moving average of new claims, regarded as a more accurate measure of the jobless situation than the more volatile weekly figures, showed a slight increase to 343,250 last week, compared with 342,500 a week earlier. 
 "The four-week moving average has not dramatically changed for some time," said Michael Niemira, an economist with Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. "What we're seeing is more of the same."
Initial claims for the June 5 week were revised down slightly, from 345,000. A total of 2,769,000 people were receiving state unemployment benefits in that week, the latest period for which the figure is available.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nomination Expected for Labor Post

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to nominate Katherine G. Abraham, a labor economist at the University of Maryland, as the new commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, Administration officials and colleagues of Professor Abraham said yesterday.
If nominated and confirmed by Congress, Professor Abraham, 38, who has spent most of her career in academia, will head the agency that produces several of the most important statistics for measuring the economic health of the nation and for gauging the success of any Administration. These include the monthly unemployment rate and the inflation rate, as measured by the Consumer Price Index. 
 "She is really quite good; a major researcher who has done important work on the nature of the labor force today," said Richard Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University, where Professor Abraham received a doctorate in economics in 1982. "She would be on any short list of candidates for the job."
 
Fitting the Mold
 The bureau commissioner has traditionally been a professional economist with considerable experience in survey work and statistical analysis. Professor Abraham fits this mold, having done considerable research on unemployment data, and on temporary and contract workers, a growing work place issue. In a survey of 442 companies that used temporary workers, for example, she found that 23 percent brought in the workers with the goal of finding good candidates for permanent jobs.
Another study, of which she was a co-author, found that older workers with 30 years or more of service were 3.6 times as likely to be laid off or dismissed as employees with eight to 10 years' service -- perhaps because the companies found the younger workers were more productive for their salaries than the higher-paid older workers.
Reached by telephone, Professor Abraham declined to comment on the reports that she was President Clinton's choice for commissioner. She would replace Janet Norwood, who resigned on Dec. 31, 1991, after more than a decade in the job, and became a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a research group in Washington.
 
Bush Nominee Not Confirmed
 To replace Ms. Norwood, President George Bush had nominated Marvin Kosters, the director of Economic Policy at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington, but Congress did not act on the nomination last year.
Before Professor Abraham was chosen, the Clinton Administration had offered the position to Rebecca Blank, an associate professor and labor economist at Northwestern University, various economists reported, but Ms. Blank decided not to move to the Washington area.
Professor Abraham, a native of Ames, Iowa, who lives near Washington, holds a Bachelor of Science degree from Iowa State University. She taught at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and in the mid-1980's was a research associate at the Brookings Institution, a research organization in Washington. She joined the University of Maryland faculty in 1988. She and her husband, Graham N. Horkeley, who works in computer software, have two sons.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed; Gold Continues to Edge Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday as several reports of economic weakness gave traders an excuse to cash in their profits following the currency's recent run-up.
Gold continued to edge up. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery rose 70 cents an ounce, up $372.20. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for spot gold of $370.85 an ounce, up 85 cents. 
 Traders initially sold dollars in early New York trading after the Commerce Department reported that the April trade deficit jumped to $10.49 billion. Many analysts had expected the deficit to narrow substantially.
In theory, a larger trade deficit signals weakness in the economy and diminishes prospects for higher interest rates. Lower rates would make investments denominated in dollars less attractive to investors.
In addition, currency market participants believe that the Clinton Administration favors a strong Japanese yen as a way to help pare the American trade deficit.
Another sign of economic weakness came in a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, which said its June indexes of business conditions and employment fell sharply in comparison with May.
But the dollar quickly recovered as sentiment crept back that Europe's economy was in worse shape than the United States'. "The market is still anticipating lower interest rates in Europe and eventual higher rates in the U.S.," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
In addition, political uncertainties in Japan continued to undermine the yen. Opposition parties filed a no-confidence motion against Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa for failing to enact political reforms in the current session of Parliament, which is due to end tomorrow.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 107.00 yen, up 0.65 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a lower rate of 106.60 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 107.30 yen, up from 106.45 yen late Wednesday.
The dollar posted only slight gains against the German mark following its three-pfennig rally early this week.
In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6545 German marks, from 1.6590 marks late Wednesday. But in New York, the dollar rose to 1.6585 German marks from 1.6570 marks.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.5145, up from $1.5035 late Wednesday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the pound fetched $1.5165, more than late Wednesday's $1.5050.
Other late dollar quotes in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.4810 Swiss francs, down from 1.4850; 5.5760 French francs, up from 5.5710; 1,507.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.2766 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2787.

HEADLINE: Business Confidence Wanes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Business executives' confidence in the economy plunged in June, the United States Chamber of Commerce said today.
The business confidence index fell to 47.7 percent in June from 59.3 percent in April and 62.4 percent in both February and December 1992. It was the lowest level since 39.3 percent in December 1991, when the economy had only recently emerged from the recession. 
 This month's decrease in confidence was the steepest drop recorded in the two years that the business lobby group has been conducting a bimonthly survey of its members.
The decline reflected, the group said, "a growing disenchantment with the economic uncertainty caused by the prospects of higher taxes for deficit reduction and health- care reform."
An index reading of 50 or more indicates moderate economic growth. A reading of 70 or more indicates strong growth.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Shades of a Rebirth for Painting

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
After a year dominated by everything but painting -- sculpture, installation art, late-Conceptual political art and so on -- the 1992-93 art season is winding down with a flurry of group painting exhibitions, almost all of them in SoHo. It would be stretching things to say that the medium is making a comeback, although it's about time: like the Democrats, painting has been out of office for so long that, in theory, it ought to be able to do some good. But it does seem that painting has a higher priority among young entry-level artists than it has had in recent seasons. With several galleries mounting painting shows concentrating on younger painters, re-election could be just around the corner.
Although these shows hardly represent the full range of painting being done at the moment, even by the younger generation, they do provide some interesting signals about the medium's direction. Cartoons, usually mixed with abstract elements, are especially hot, as are high-key fluorescent colors, which give some of these shows an undeniable visual bounce. Variations on the all-over composition, whose roots go back to Jackson Pollock's abstract drip paintings, continue to proliferate, often made of tiny semi-legible images. 
 As always, artists are experimenting with different ways to make paintings, an activity that seems essential to its vitality. Sometimes this involves using unfamiliar materials (a glass-smooth resin surface is rather popular right now) or unusual tools, like a felt-tip marker. In addition, the urge to appropriate found imagery and to bring the camera into the painting-making process, basic to so much art since the early 1980's, is yielding new twists and turns.
These shows of current work are all the more interesting because they're bracketed by two group shows of paintings from opposing styles of the recent past. At the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, "Singular Dimensions in Painting" presents nearly 40 Minimalist works by such artists as Ellsworth Kelly, Frank Stella, Brice Marden, Robert Ryman and Robert Mangold dating mostly from the 1960's and 70's. The show pays tribute to a sensibility in which logic, rigor and reduction ruled; it is characterized by an austere, crystalline beauty and the certain faith that less is more.
In marked contrast, the Tony Shafrazi Gallery (which recently relocated to 119 Wooster Street, SoHo) has mounted a timely, if not always first-rate tribute to the painting of the early 1980's, when the less-is-more faith crumbled and precocious talents like Kenny Scharf, Keith Haring, Donald Baechler, Francesco Clemente and Jean-Michel Basquiat were on the loose. (The Clemente -- a double-decker interior titled "My House" -- has never been shown in New York City and is especially good.) The painting of this period has been so roundly bashed of late that it may almost be time to start revising its somewhat sagging reputation, a process that might benefit the medium's current condition.
 
Postmasters Gallery
 The group show that has the most visual bang is "What's Wrong With This Picture?," at Postmasters Gallery, although its title never quite makes sense. The presiding spirit here is Carroll Dunham, who has operated in the gap between abstraction and cartooning for more than a decade and is represented by a new abstraction, radiant of color, loquacious of form and bursting its pictorial seams with mounds of little balls dipped in paint. Mr. Dunham's influence is visible in new paintings by Matthew Weinstein and Bill Komoski.
Steve Di Bennedetto, known for cool-handed reprises of Op Art, has turned to more heavily worked and layered compositions, which have a new emotional heat, while Michael Scott's painting of black-and-white stripes continues to build quite effectively on the Op vocabulary. The show's newest name is Christian Schumann, whose taut collagelike mixture of words, cartoonish images and abstract shapes exudes so much precocious pictorial talent that he seems like an early 80's throwback.
 
Jay Gorney
 The optical punch of the Postmasters show has a slightly softer echo at Jay Gorney Modern Art, where a show of six painters includes works by Mr. Komoski and Mr. Di Bennedetto, who provide some of its better moments. Here the inclination toward the all-over compositions, preferably achieved through eccentric painting methods, is especially evident.
Scott Grodesky has made an unexceptional painting by covering a canvas with shattered glass and spraying it with black paint. Lari Pittman's small paintings reveal that this talented painter needs a big surface to build up pictorial steam. Peter Nagy's ornate yet somewhat sinister black-on-white patterns suggest origins in the vicinity of the Xerox machine.
Lisa Ruyter, a young artist who is making her debut in several galleries at the moment, covers her canvases with a fine-lined web of interconnecting images drawn with a felt-tip marker and intermittently filled in with one or two shades of Day-Glo color. Ms. Ruyter's images, which repeat motifs that seem to come from various popular sources, are engaging in the way they shift in and out of legibility, like linear Rorschach blots, but ultimately they are thin and a little gimmicky, and steer too close to some kind of crazed commercial illustration.
 
Jack Tilton Gallery
 Down the street at the Jack Tilton Gallery, the Cartoons "R" Us energy prevails in the group show "Pure Pop for Now People" (the title is lifted from an album by the English pop star Nick Lowe), but here the imagery tends more toward the figurative.
The best-known and most accomplished of these six artists, several of whom are showing their work in New York City for the first time, is Chuck Agro, a veteran of several recent group efforts, who has yet to have a solo show. With the help of clear resin applied to paint on plaster, Mr. Agro has come to specialize in endearingly wry, physically smooth images of rough characters, fat blobby guys with 5 o'clock shadows and bad haircuts, when they have any hair at all. The clear frescolike colors add to the air of innocence, as does the plaster, which curls around the edges of the paintings like cake icing, or shaving lotion.
Katie Merz and Dan McCarthy also specialize in cartoon images and share Mr. Agro's sense of ease and economy, while the complex, more conventionally rendered images of Jane Fine and Jory Felice show promise, but also try too hard.
 
Salvatore Ala
 "Paintings," the group show at Salvatore Ala, seems intent upon avoiding a unifying theme or style. Cary Smith's blocky thick-surfaced paintings and Stephen Westfall's inimitably airy ones make the case for hard-edged geometry. (Although the best Westfall on view in SoHo right now is a relatively small painting in an otherwise mediocre group show at the Stephen Rosenberg Gallery.)
Making the case for gesture are Craig Fisher's big, confident abstractions, in which large spots of paint in different colors and densities drift across bare canvas. They provide more evidence that the legacy of Color Field painting, crossed with a little Cy Twombly, lives on.
The Dutch artist Jan Frank, whose work used to be more geometric, contributes three swirling black-and-white abstractions, big spongy thickets of line, whose main attraction is that they are painted on big squares of raw plywood boxed out to a thickness of six inches, so that they resemble packing crates.
The cartoon sensibility finds especially delicate expression in the paintings of Amy Sillman, which contrast thin stains of rich color with lacelike patterns of line that effortlessly flow between the decorative and the imagistic, often intimating feminist tales as they go.
 
Collins & Millazzo
 In Chelsea, on West 23d Street, the independent curators Collins & Millazzo have organized an exhibition of American and European artists that is rather ambiguously titled "Elvis Has Left the Building (A Painting Show)." Although large and uneven and often relentlessly derivative, it offers several works of interest.
Among these are a small, adept, if rather Polke-like abstraction by Lino Fiorito, an Italian painter who helped organize the show; a painting of a giant blue-on-white plant form by Alessandro Twombly (son of Cy Twombly), and two small, rather Surrealist interiors, beautiful in their color and detail, by Robin Tewes, whose work has not been so visible in recent years. Also of interest are works by Joo Chung, Marc Maz, Gian Carlo Pagliasso and Charles Clough.
 
Solo Shows
 In addition to these group shows, several painters are having one-person exhibitions that are worth a visit. Mr. Clough, for example, has mounted a show of his roiling gestural abstractions, which contrast passionate brushwork with glaring Pop colors, at the Grand Salon, a gallery Collins & Millazzo recently opened in SoHo.
At Wooster Gardens, additional works by Lisa Ruyter are on view, along with the paintings of Margaret Curtis, which seek a new fusion of pure paint, narrative and feminism with the help of cake-decorating tools. The results are quite impressive.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 13; Column 5; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 861 words

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Racing Report Is In, And Jockeying Begins

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Sweeping changes in operating, taxing and betting on horse racing in New York State were proposed to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday when his special commission released its report on how to revive an industry that it said was "in decline in New York State and throughout the nation."
The report sprang no surprises after nine months of hearings and two months of briefings. But it did concede that "the reform process will be long, difficult and at times frustrating," especially since its main provisions would have to be approved by the Legislature. And the Governor took the occasion to renew his attack on the New York Racing Association for "having blown the whole racing industry." 
 The heart of the report calls for a merger of the two principal organizations in racing in the state: the New York Racing Association, which operates the Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga race tracks, and the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, one of the six regional offtrack betting companies, which handles 60 percent of the money wagered in the state.
 
100 Pages in the Report
 The two organizations, which operate as competitors for the betting dollar and almost as natural enemies, would join under a new state agency that would regulate the entire business. However, their precise relationship to each other would have to be decided through joint negotiations, which seemed likely to trigger a political fight for survival.
The tone of the 100-page report, titled "Racing Into the 21st Century," was diplomatic but firm and at times doomsaying. But it was received by the Governor with renewed anger directed at the executives of N.Y.R.A., which was enfranchised in 1955 to run the race tracks and to turn over any profits to the state. The franchise expires in the year 2000, but as the profit has dwindled, the Governor's anger has grown.
At an impromptu news conference at the state Capitol in Albany, he said with heat:
"What did the people at N.Y.R.A. get paid for having blown the whole racing industry? For not being able to pay the taxes? Well, they got Jaguars. They got Porsches. And they gave themselves bonuses this year."
"You're begging for jobs in western New York," he went on. "Your unemployment rate is out of sight. You can't find work for the people on welfare. You can't increase the unemployment insurance because you can't afford it. You're cutting Medicaid benefits. People in education are all crying. You had to increase the tuition of hard-working middle-class people.
"But they're giving themselves raises at N.Y.R.A."
He was asked if the Legislature could act during its current session, which ends on June 25, and he replied: "I don't know." And he said that he would talk with his advisers "to see what the next steps are."
 
Less Winter Racing
 The commission, headed by the state's director of economic development, Vincent Tese, made these key proposals:
*The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation and N.Y.R.A. should enter into a "joint venture" to eliminate duplicate costs, "increase the total amount bet, return more revenues to the industry and to government and maintain an option for privatization." They would somehow be merged under a new state superagency within the Public Service Commission.
*The state tax on parimutuel bets would be reduced by approximately 2 percentage points to return money to "the betting churn" to stimulate wagering. Under current law, 17 percent is subtracted from every winning bet (and up to 25 percent on exotic, or multiple, bets). The money is split this way: 8.5 percent to N.Y.R.A., 4.5 percent to the state, 3.5 percent to purses and one-half of 1 percent to breeders. The commission recommended that the takeout be lowered by 2 percentage points for two years to see if it actually put more money back into the betting system.
*In a one-year experiment, winter racing in New York would be replaced by a combination of live racing and simulcast racing from other tracks. New York's tracks are now limited to importing 50 races on television each year. But some live racing would be held to accommodate horsemen who spend the winter in New York, despite the fact that seven racing days were canceled by severe weather last winter.
*The 12 percent state withholding tax on payoffs of $1,000 or more would be deferred. The bettor would still be expected to pay taxes on winnings at the end of the year. But, the commission said, the withholding practice "has been a severe burden to horseplayers, who are being taxed not on their profits, but on their gross receipts."
 
Cautious Reactions
 The industry reactions to the report were guarded. Allan Dragone, the chairman of N.Y.R.A. who was in California on business, said in a statement: "N.Y.R.A. is anxious to effectuate change after careful deliberation of the impact of the commission's proposal."
Hazel Dukes, president of the city OTB, said: "We have many questions as to the nature of a joint venture. But we are looking forward to a realistic dialogue that leaves the past behind."
And Vincent Tese said for the commission: "Unless there's change, this industry is in for a long, deep slide."
