The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 18, 1993

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2979 words

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Books That Make a Case for Shades of Gray

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
HUMAN beings have always had a fondness for black and white distinctions, for easy ways of categorizing experience, values and taste, as though life were just one great big athletic showdown. People are foxes (who know many things) or hedgehogs (who know one big thing); Apollonians (advocates of order and classical discipline) or Dionysians (revelers in the romantic and the extreme). Writers are palefaces (genteel surveyors of sensibility, like Henry James) or redskins (raucous explorers of the outer limits, like Melville). One is "in" or "out"; in Nancy Mitford's words, "U" or "Non-U." Or, as Ken Kesey once put it, you're either on the bus or off the bus.
Recently, however, such amusing distinctions have given way to more serious efforts to pigeonhole the world, efforts that underscore our tendency to see everything in terms of either-or, all-or-nothing, left-or-right. Teen-agers used to ask each other, "Are you a fan of the Stones or the Beatles?" John or Paul? Those innocuous questions, used to categorize one as a human being, have been replaced by similarly reductive -- but considerably more loaded -- litmus tests: Are you "pro life" or "pro choice"? Are you for unemployed loggers or endangered spotted owls? Do you believe Anita Hill or Clarence Thomas? Is Bosnia another Holocaust or another Vietnam? 
 Television, newspaper and magazine polls almost daily tell us whether President Clinton is up or down, whether people give a thumbs up or a thumbs down to the world, the country, their own lives. Newsweek's Conventional Wisdom Watch evaluates everything from politics to sports to the fortunes of Socks the cat with an arrow up or an arrow down (or a horizontal arrow to indicate no change). Time magazine's new column Winners & Losers gives the reader an illustrated list of that week's personalities who have scored a success or suffered a defeat, while its Health Report categorizes developments in medicine as "good news" or "bad news."
Mr. Clinton's campaign talk of creating a new politics of consensus has devolved into factional fights between liberals and moderates within his own Administration, and attacks from the right and left without. The Administration's struggle to find an acceptable Supreme Court nominee, its waffling over the issue of homosexuals in the military, the appointment of David Gergen as a White House consultant, all have been marked by a heightened awareness of reactions from the left and the right.
Indeed, shrill denunciations, absolutist language and extremist assertions have become a commonplace in debates about politics, race, abortion and sexism. Dr. Leonard Jeffries preaches the superiority of blacks (or "sun people" as he calls them), while David Duke has declared "there's only one country anymore that's all white, and that's Iceland, and Iceland is not enough." Feminists blame men for sexism, while members of the men's movement blame women for making them victims. Traditionalists assail multiculturalists as "Visigoths in Tweed," while radical reformers complain about the hegemony of DWEM's (that is, dead white European males).
This rising tide of rhetoric, along with our current penchant for either-or constructions, is both a symptom of -- and a catalyst for -- the growing polarization of American society, a polarization, as authors of several recent books point out, that has begun to affect how we think about everything from politics to the arts. "Polarization is addictive," writes the critic Robert Hughes in his eloquent new book, "Culture of Complaint." "It is the crack of politics -- a short intense rush that the system craves again and again, until it begins to collapse."
Cornel West -- the director of Afro-American studies at Princeton University and the author of a new book called "Race Matters" -- argues that in the area of race, too, "the predictable pitting of liberals against conservatives, Great Society Democrats against self-help Republicans, reinforces intellectual parochialism and political paralysis."
As Mr. West sees it, "these two camps have nearly suffocated the crucial debate that should be taking place about the prospects for black America." By focusing on government aid and the economic dimension, he says, the liberal approach overlooks the crucial role of culture and values; by focusing on the moral behavior of poor city blacks, he adds, the conservative approach "tends to deny the lingering effect of black history -- a history inseparable from though not reducible to victimization."
Another scholar, James Davison Hunter of the University of Virginia, defines the polarization taking root in America in somewhat different terms. In his book "Culture Wars: The Struggle to Define America," he suggests that orthodox elements from the Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant traditions are forming a coalition against progressive forces from those same traditions and secular interests. Given most political and social issues, he suggests, it's fairly easy to predict the stand of many major organizations: on the progressive side, one can usually find mainline Protestant denominations, as well as such groups as the National Council of Churches and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations; on the orthodox side can usually be found such groups as the National Right to Life Committee, the American Council of Christian Churches, the American Association of Christian Schools and Agudath Israel of America.
 
Mirror, Mirror
 Just what accounts for this growing polarization? In part, the development is a reflection of realities in American society: the growing disparity between rich and poor, and the growing racial tensions that have been exacerbated by unemployment, shifting immigration patterns and a troubled economy.
Yet at the same time, the polarization is also the result of ideologues on either end of the political spectrum imposing their paint-by-the-numbers formulations on the national debate; and a function of a time-pressed, fashion-obsessed society in which people have opinions about books they've never read and movies they've never seen. After all, it's easier and more amusing to dispense a quick pro or con witticism about a subject -- be it Somalia, the budget or the latest Springsteen album -- than to embark upon a considered discussion. Cut to the chase, as they say: what people want to know is, is it good or bad? What's the bottom line?
No doubt the "us versus them" view of the world also has roots in the Manichaeism of the cold war decades, which pitted a virtuous, democratic America against the evil empire of the Soviet Union; and in the counter-culture struggles of the 60's, which encouraged opponents of the Vietnam War to see themselves in an adversarial relationship with the Establishment. Conservatives remember the 60's, when they saw liberals as obscenity-shouting radicals; liberals remember the 80's, when they saw conservatives as greedy capitalist pigs.
As the world order has fragmented, as economic and social problems have proliferated at home, these old habits of bipolarism die hard. Japan and Iraq have been floated as possible successors for the role once filled by America's old nemesis, the Soviet Union, while an assortment of domestic bogeymen have been proposed by ideologues on both the left and right.
Of course, the us-versus-them formula has long been used by politicians, eager to focus their agendas by playing up distinctions between themselves and their opponents. It's an inclination that has been galvanized by television: not only do the nightly news programs zero in on the most colorful sound bites, but talk shows (from "The McLaughlin Group" to "Crossfire" to "Meet the Press") like to pit conservatives against liberals, Republicans against Democrats.
In his compelling new book "Strange Bedfellows," the Los Angeles Times reporter Tom Rosenstiel argues that television has concentrated increasingly on the horse-race aspect of politics, and that politicians have learned to exploit this situation. Of the Clinton adviser Paul Begala, Mr. Rosenstiel writes that he "believed the teachings of Republican strategist Roger Ailes that the press was mostly interested only in conflict, scandal, polls, process and gaffes." Mr. Rosenstiel adds: "So to get coverage of a speech, he usually included attack lines, making his speeches more malicious than they would otherwise be."
 
Corralling Scapegoats
 In the escalating war of words, hyperbole flourishes, as both sides play to the public's fears, searching for easy scapegoats and convenient straw men. Extremes consequently begin to dominate the debate: while the left tries to equate conservatives with Senator Jesse Helms, the right tries to equate liberals with the Rev. Jesse Jackson. As Mr. Hughes observes in "Culture of Complaint," "one side needs the other, so that each can inflate its agenda into a chiliastic battle for the soul of America."
This process of polarization began decades ago, say Thomas Byrne Edsall and Mary D. Edsall in their book "Chain Reaction: The Impact of Race, Rights and Taxes on American Politics." As the Edsalls see it, the reform wing of the Democratic party, which gained control of the nominating process in 1972, alienated working-class and middle-class whites by pushing the party toward an identification with minority rights. During the 80's, the Edsalls say, the Republicans learned to exploit this development, portraying the Democrats as the party of special interests and welfare recipients; this Republican tactic -- which culminated in the use of Willie Horton in television ads during the 1988 campaign -- effectively used racial politics as a wedge to break up the old Democratic coalition.
Though the Democrats have regained the Presidency, the polarization nourished by years of divided government (since 1951, the White House and Senate have been controlled by different parties more than half the time) has remained in place. Voters have become accustomed to a familiar dialectic: the private sector versus the public sector, taxpayers versus welfare recipients, defenders of responsiblity versus advocates of rights.
 
Political Art
 In much the same way that the liberal-conservative dialectic has politicized the workings of government (from the selection of Supreme Court Justices to the passing of budget proposals), it has also infected the worlds of art and academia.
Some artists have willfully decided to use their work as a means of making political statements: rap music frequently purveys a hostile, divisive message, using ethnic slurs and violent antipolice demagoguery to try to shock audiences into an awareness of social problems. Much of the art on view at this year's Whitney Biennial is also overtly ideological, banging home messages about racism, sexism and ecology with the subtlety of a jackhammer.
At its best, such art has the ability to educate the public at large and provoke intelligent discussion; one thinks, say, of "Angels in America," Tony Kushner's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about AIDS and the spiritual malaise of America. More often, however, overtly political art, like that on display at the Biennial, tends to preach to the converted, thereby accelerating the Balkanization of the arts in this country and the loss of common ground.
"A dazzling array of different radio stations, music recordings, and films," says the history professor Paul Jerome Croce, in an essay in the magazine The Public Perspective, "are now available to individual customers, without their having to defer to the selective choices of media moguls. With polarized politics and technological variety, people can get their news and find entertainment -- things that used to be the province of mass culture -- all within the segregated clusters of their own subculture."
To complicate matters further, the politicized Zeitgeist that has encouraged overtly ideological works of art also ratifies the tendency to look at all art -- both past and present -- through an ideological lens. On one hand, reactionaries label everything from "Murphy Brown" to the photos of Robert Mapplethorpe as subversive work that threatens to undermine family values and corrupt the youth of the nation. On the other hand, advocates of political correctness denounce the likes of Conrad and Melville as outdated avatars of a sexist and racist power structure that needs to be overturned.
The loudest voices raised on both sides of this debate are shrill, admitting little room for rational discussion or common sense. Columbus is either the heroic explorer who opened the gates of the New World or the barbaric imperialist who initiated the rape of Eden. The literary canon taught at colleges is condemned either as a motley assortment of obscure third-world writers, or as an obsolete collection of DWEM's. To put it another way, you're either on the bus or off the bus.
The problem with this either-or approach is that it reduces art to its message, and erases the subtle grays of ambiguity and chance. Characters become stick figures in a morality drama, and just to make sure that the identity of the heroes and the villains is perfectly clear, the audience is given lots of little signposts. In "Indecent Proposal," we know Demi Moore is supposed to be sympathetic because she takes a job teaching citizenship; in "Jurassic Park," we know the Brachiosaurus is a good dinosaur because it's a vegetarian; the Velociraptor is a bad one because it's got an unhealthy appetite for meat.
As politically correct attitudes permeate esthetics, the story an artist wants to tell or the way it is told becomes less important than the issues it supposedly addresses. "It revives the illusion that works of art carry social meaning the way trucks carry coal," writes Mr. Hughes. "It divides the sprawling republic of literature neatly into goodies and baddies, and relieves the student of the burden of imaginative empathy, the difficulties of esthetic discrimination."
 
No Nuances, Please
 The consequences of society's overall polarization are similarly insidious. Hyperbolic rhetoric about any issue obscures the emotional and political nuances of the actual situation. Symbolism and metaphor -- comparing Bosnia, say, to Vietnam or the Holocaust -- begin to color reality; generalizations take the place of specifics; snap judgments replace thoughtful debate.
To give Mr. Clinton or any public figure a simple thumbs up or thumbs down flattens out the ambiguities of politics and history, turning the chiaroscuro of real life into a comic book's primary colors. "We tend to deal with our past Presidents," writes Meg Greenfield in a recent Newsweek column, "either by suppressing and ignoring their faults so we can count them saintly, or uncovering those faults and deciding they obliterate all the good the benighted fellow ever did. Which is to say that, just as it is with our contemporary Presidents, so we seem always to insist that their long-gone predecessors were either heroes or villains, successes or failures -- never, say, a little of each and a lot in between."
Equally problematic is the effect that an either-or, all-or-nothing mentality has on the collective dialogue. When opinions calcify into hard-line stands, when extremists on the right and left define the agenda, the middle ground is lost, and along with it, the possibility of consensus.
 
Beyond Dogma: Jazz
 Are there any solutions to this situation? In his book "Beyond the Culture Wars," Gerald Graff, a professor of English at the University of Chicago, proposes teaching the conflict between, say, multiculturalists and their traditionalist opponents as a way of forcing students to grapple directly with both sides of the debate.
Mr. West uses the metaphor of jazz to describe a mode of critical exchange that would move beyond dogmatic pronoucements and supremacist ideologies. "The interplay of individuality and unity is not one of uniformity and unanimity imposed from above," he writes, "but rather of conflict among diverse groupings that reach a dynamic consensus subject to questioning and criticism. As with a soloist in a jazz quartet, quintet or band, individuality is promoted in order to sustain and increase the creative tension with the group -- a tension that yields higher levels of performance to achieve the aim of the collective project."
Such an approach is predicated not upon mutually exclusive alternatives but upon the inclusive belief that individuals can understand, even sympathize with the disparate beliefs and values of others. Its result is not polarization but pluralism, the idea, as Isaiah Berlin wrote in "The Crooked Timber of Humanity," that "there are many different ends that men may seek and still be fully rational, fully men, capable of understanding each other and sympathizing and deriving light from each other, as we derive it from reading Plato or the novels of medieval Japan -- worlds, outlooks, very remote from our own."
 
The Books
"BEYOND THE CULTURE WARS: How Teaching the Conflicts Can Revitalize American Education." By Gerald Graff. W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

HEADLINE: Brazil Prolongs Haiti's Agony

 BODY:
U.S. Navy and Coast Guard vessels ring its coasts. It has barely six weeks' oil supply on hand. The worldwide oil embargo voted by the U.N. Security Council on Wednesday should have marked the beginning of the end for Haiti's military regime.
But at the last minute Brazil got squeamish. The Council flinched from authorizing those vessels to enforce the embargo. The likely results: more unnecessary weeks of suffering for the Haitian people, and a weakening of Brazil's own claim to a permanent Security Council seat. 
 Even in its diluted form, the Security Council resolution, which takes effect next Wednesday, is important and welcome. Until now, the only economic pressure behind diplomatic efforts to restore Haitian democracy was a highly porous Western Hemisphere embargo.
That only made life harder for Haiti's destitute peasants and slum dwellers, but failed to stop luxury imports to the wealthy supporters of the military regime. And it had no effect at all on the tanker traffic between Europe and Haiti.
If it can stop the flow of oil, the Council resolution will immobilize the army's trucks, planes and tanks, along with the cars and boats of the elite. The resolution also usefully bans arms shipments and freezes Haitian assets abroad. But the removal of the naval enforcement provision invites evasions, even though countries violating it now face punishment themselves.
Brazil's action, supported by Venezuela, reflects a longstanding Latin American concern about outsiders, particularly the U.S., intervening in domestic political issues. But in this case the intervener is the United Nations and the domestic political issue is the destruction of democracy by military force.
What of Latin America's own commitment at Santiago, Chile, two years ago to defend the hemisphere's democratic regimes? And what of Brazil's claim to be a serious world power deserving a permanent seat on the Security Council? The Council is often asked to authorize the use of international force, sometimes over such internal political questions as starvation and banditry in Somalia or potential genocide in Iraq. Should Brazil be expected to water down all such resolutions?
Bad enough that Brazil embarrasses its own diplomacy. Far worse that it prolongs the agony of Haitians who have already suffered far too long.

HEADLINE: Budget Bill: Make It Better

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget plan got roughed up by Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee. But the bill that is emerging would still cut the deficit by about $500 billion over five years, primarily with lower defense spending and higher taxes on families with taxable income over $100,000. The committee bill, like the President's plan, would be a step toward fiscal prudence.
Nevertheless, the bill would come at a steep price to poor workers and makes health-care reform needlessly more difficult. Senate Democrats cut $45 billion from the energy tax passed by the House. More than $35 billion of the gaping hole was filled by whacking Medicare, food stamps and tax credits for low-paid workers -- cuts that House-Senate conferees should fully restore. 
 The loss of a single Democratic vote would have buried the President's budget plan in committee. Senate Democratic leaders were therefore forced to appease each committee member who opposed higher energy taxes. That required substituting a sales tax on transportation fuels, mostly gasoline, for the President's broad-based B.T.U. tax and scaling back the tax increase from $70 billion in the House bill to $25 billion.
The committee would pay for these changes, in part, by cutting back programs for the poor. Gone is Mr. Clinton's plan to increase food stamps for needy families. Also gone is his innovative plan to extend tax credits to workers without children who are currently ineligible for the credits and who, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, have been hit hardest by Federal tax hikes over the past 15 years.
Indeed, because as higher gas taxes work their way into consumer prices and thereby hit all poor families, the Senate plan will tax some poor families into poverty. This threatens the centerpiece of the President's anti-poverty strategy: to lift every full-time worker out of poverty.
The committee would pile on $20 billion in Medicare cuts on top of the $50 billion already proposed by the House. Supposedly this cut would come at the expense of doctors and hospitals. But they will charge their private patients more.
And by taking a $20 billion cut out of Medicare now, the committee plan would leave that much less for the President's task force to take from Medicare when it issues its health care reform. That will force it either to scale back its program or pay for it by raising taxes by an additional $20 billion.
That said, the committee made changes worth preserving. At the urging of Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, it trimmed some $12 billion in unwarranted corporate loopholes and other tax giveaways proposed by the President. They include wasteful subsidies for investors in small business and the restoration of deductions for so-called passive losses by real estate investors. The last thing the economy needs is more investment in real estate.
The committee bill is expected to be passed by the full Senate next week. Exactly how the House and Senate will resolve their differences isn't clear. The important task for the conferees is to reinstate about $10 billion in tax credits for poor workers, $7.5 billion in food stamps and $20 billion for Medicare. One place to look for the extra money is a broader sales tax on energy -- one that extends beyond gasoline to electricity and other sources. For the sake of the environment, the poor and health reform, the country can afford more than $25 billion in new energy taxes.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Change Is Hard

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Bill Clinton ran as the candidate of change. So, in his way, did Ross Perot. A large majority of Americans voted for them and for change. But since Jan. 20 we have been relearning -- we and President Clinton -- how hard change is in the American system.
In the campaign Mr. Clinton blamed "gridlock" in Washington, the tension between a Republican President and a Democratic Congress, for inaction on national problems. By now he knows that the difficulty is far more profound. 
 This week the President made some satisfying gains in Congress. His budget plan moved another step, the Senate Republican filibuster against campaign finance reform was broken after compromise, and committees approved his proposal for national service.
Those victories did a lot for Presidential morale after a string of bad weeks for Mr. Clinton. But the price of victory was giving up a good deal of substance, and who knows what the bills will contain by the time of final passage?
Political deadlock is more than a passing Washington phenomenon. The men who created our constitutional system 200 years ago deliberately made change difficult, dividing authority and building in conflict. They reasoned, wisely, that efficiency in government was less important than protecting the people from the dangers of concentrated power.
But something has happened to the constitutional theory in recent years. Dealing with urgent national necessities has become not just difficult but, we often feel, impossible.
The budget deficit is a compelling example. Just about everyone agrees that it has to come down, and President Clinton is making the first serious effort in years. But his proposal is being nibbled to death by ducks. Its fate illustrates what has gone wrong with the system.
The Clinton plan relied heavily on a new energy tax. Lobbyists for big energy users savaged that proposal, and senators from oil states killed it. Instead the Senate Finance Committee put in a derisorily small gasoline tax increase and, to save money, called for massive cuts in Medicare. Does anyone really think that those cuts will survive the certain onslaught by the elderly lobby?
In other words, it is hard to change because important interests want to keep the advantages they have. We live in a world of mutual vetoes. Most of the time, inertia wins.
Loss of the energy tax is particularly painful. American energy prices are the lowest in the industrial world. In real terms, taking account of inflation, they are 30 percent lower than they were 10 years ago. The result is to make us profligate users of energy, damning the environment and making us dangerously dependent on Middle East oil.
"The neutering of Bill Clinton's energy tax would be a huge opportunity missed," The Economist of London said last week. Since then it has effectively been neutered.
Why has the resistance to change that the Framers built into the Constitution become so much greater, and more serious?
First, the Federal Government is far more important than James Madison & Co. ever imagined, with huge powers over the national economy and individuals' share. It follows that interest groups will fight more tenaciously over its policy.
Second, modern communications have inflated the egos of members of Congress, and their independence. They are less likely to cooperate with their leadership or the President when they can go on television and take a stance as protectors of local interests.
Third, the President nowadays has no respite from the press. The age of deference is past. Reporters are all over him all the time.
In those circumstances we are dated romantics if we think a President can just use his bully pulpit to see that the nation's problems are solved. Bill Clinton has made mistakes. But the problems are deep, and any President who is serious about addressing them would find it desperately hard to make things change.
I erred in a recent column when I said that President Clinton had asked Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago to be Secretary of Transportation and then withdrawn the offer. The offer, made and withdrawn, was to the Mayor's brother, William M. Daley, a banker and lawyer.

HEADLINE: Simple Categories Just Don't Explain the World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Coming Clash of Civilizations or, The West Against the Rest" (Op-Ed, June 6) by Samuel P. Huntington, director of Harvard's Olin Institute for Strategic Studies, is fraught with dangerous assertions. While the article illustrates the declining importance of the nation-state, it offers a hollow paradigm of a new world order rife with competing civilizations.
To categorize the world into Western, Confucian, Japanese, Islamic, Hindu, Slavic-Orthodox, Latin American and "possibly African" civilizations is arbitrary and ahistorical at best, racist at worst. Mr. Huntington's depiction of civilizations as "the highest cultural grouping of people and the broadest level of cultural identity" follows the logic that leads to the justification of "ethnic cleansing," for he implicitly asserts that authentic, pure civilizations exist. 
 Moreover, he explicitly downplays the importance of political and economic conflicts. In Mr. Huntington's formulation differences between civilizations will be the source of tensions. Thus the presence of "Latin Americans" in the United States, "Africans" in Britain and "Muslims" in Germany will inevitably lead to conflict, as seen in the Western context. Consequently, according to this logic, to avoid conflict these outsiders should become Western or leave.
Civilizations are not homogeneous entities; they are composed of and divided by overlapping groups based on gender, class, religious sect, region, language and ethnicity. Moreover, there are strong links between groups across civilizational categories. Although Mr. Huntington acknowledges that civilizations blend and overlap, he still maintains that the "clash of civilizations will dominate politics."
For Mr. Huntington, "differences among civilizations are basic, involving history, language, culture, tradition and, most importantly, religion." If one were to take Islamic civilization as an example (which along with Confucian civilization he labels as potentially hostile to Western civilization), one would see that the more than 1 billion adherents of Islam do not share a single history, language, culture or tradition.
Islam is a complex religion that has, over 1,400 years, taken on many political, philosophical, theological and mystical forms in a number of countries; and Muslims are a diverse grouping of people that differ in gender, class, ethnicity and experience. Simply to place all Muslims under the rubric Islamic civilization is to iron out diversity and support the ideologies of fundamentalist groups, which wish to eliminate differences within the Muslim world.
Moreover, it ignores ties between groups who are members of different civilizations. This is not to deny the importance of civilizational identities, but to argue that these divided and dynamic identities are only one of the multiple identities all individuals possess.
To divide the inhabitants of the world into seven or eight simple categories of civilization and conclude that in future major conflicts will occur along these lines is a simplistic political analysis that reflects the rhetoric of racist-fundamentalist-nationalist leaders, rather than the reality of the diverse groups of individuals that make up this world. Global conflicts will occur, but they will emerge from a combination of the political, economic and cultural tensions pervading the world, not simply from divisions between seven or eight categories dreamed up by Samuel Huntington.
 
FARHAD KARIM
New York, June 10, 1993

HEADLINE: Simple Categories Just Don't Explain the World;
Attached to Big Guns

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Samuel Huntington's June 6 Op-Ed article seems to me fictional and xenophobic. He uses religious labels to separate "civilizations," which are in a great state of flux and increasingly interdependent. Having just returned from nine months as a visiting scholar at the Central Institute of Fine Arts in Beijing, I question what he means by "Confucian civilization." Is he referring to China and Korea?
Having visited an entirely deserted Confucian temple in Suzhou (all the Government money flows to tourist sites like the gardens), I can hardly be convinced that Confucianism in its institutional, religious sense is predominant in China; making money in Western capitalist fashion is more of a current value. If any religion is making headway in China, it is Christianity, again contradicting Mr. Huntington's thesis of separately evolving religious "civilizations," sealed off and pitted against each other. 
 Mr. Huntington posits, in new cold war fashion, a "connection between Confucian and Islamic states." This is pure fiction, promulgated to resist arms reduction. Mr. Huntington is linking his fears of Islam and "Red" China into a mythical beast.
If, as he appears to fear, the East, and particularly China, is rising up as an economic force, isn't it in our best interest to understand the past and present of the region? Is it necessary to regard the Chinese or the Muslims as America's new enemy? Ought we not recognize that America itself is becoming a racially mixed nation, which must respect various races in daily interaction to prosper?
Mr. Huntington's argument is based on outmoded cliches and attachment to big guns, and would benefit from more direct cross-cultural experience.
 
TAMARA HEIMARCK
Leonia, N.J., June 9, 1993

HEADLINE: For Best Revenue, Tax Cigarettes $1.26

 BODY:
To the Editor:
According to Jeffrey E. Harris, a $2 increase in the Federal excise tax on cigarettes from 24 cents a pack to $2.24 a pack would increase tax revenue from $5 billion to $33 billion (Op-Ed, June 4). Professor Harris underestimates the reduction in smoking rates that would accompany the excise tax hike and thus substantially overestimates the additional tax revenue that would be generated. 
 My research with Gary S. Becker, winner of the 1992 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, Frank J. Chaloupka and Kevin M. Murphy demonstrates that cigarette consumption is responsive to price. Given the addictive nature of smoking, consumption of cigarettes is positively related to past consumption. This means that price response grows over time. For example, a price hike in 1993 would reduce consumption in 1993, which would cause consumption in 1994 and all future years to fall. Moreover, since teen-age smoking rates are particularly sensitive to price, the number of new smokers would fall dramatically.
My colleagues and I estimate that eventually each 10 percent increase in price causes per capita cigarette consumption to decline by about 8 percent. Based on our studies, I estimate that a tax rate of $1.26 a pack would maximize Federal revenue from the excise tax at $16 billion. Higher tax rates, such as the $2.24 suggested by Professor Harris, would yield less revenue than $16 billion.
Indeed, if the tax rate were sufficiently high, it might produce even less revenue than the $5 billion yielded by the tax of 24 cents.
The harm done to others by smokers (for example, that done to fetuses by pregnant women who smoke) may justify Federal excise tax rates of more than $1.26 a pack. But a rate of $2.24 would not yield nearly enough to pay for the health care of one-fourth of the 37 million uninsured Americans, for which Professor Harris argues.
 
MICHAEL GROSSMAN
New York, June 11, 1993
 
The writer is professor of economics, CUNY Graduate School.

HEADLINE: Gains Tax Turnabout

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
A capital gains tax increase?
Tax analysts are buzzing over a seemingly minor provision in the Senate Finance Committee's hastily cobbled budget proposal presented on Wednesday. For wedged in among the big-ticket items -- ranging from the 4.3 cent gasoline tax to the Medicare reimbursement cuts -- is an effective increase in the maximum tax rate on capital gains to 30.8 percent from 28 percent for those who pay most of the capital gains. 
 Ironically, the political fallout is likely to be large and the revenues small from this higher tax on gains for households with incomes over $250,000. "It's like waving a red flag at conservatives," remarked one senior Congressional staff member, who questioned the logic of rekindling the fiery debate over capital gains taxes at a moment when Democrats loyal to President Clinton need every vote they can muster.
But to the Finance Committee majority, an increase in the capital gains tax is a nod to good public policy and equity.
Under current law, the maximum capital gains tax for most Americans is 28 percent, although high-income taxpayers who claim large itemized deductions do pay a slightly higher effective rate. But that maximum rate represents only a modest break for upper-income families, who are now subject to a 31 percent rate on wages, interest and dividends in excess of $89,150.
And for years, economists who lean to the right have been arguing that a deeper cut in the capital gains rate would spur productivity with little or no sacrifice in revenue.
"Encouraging risk-taking is important," insists John Taylor, a researcher at Stanford University who was a member of President George Bush's Council of Economic Advisers.
Indeed, this argument for helping small business has made more than a little headway among centrist Democrats: The House version of the budget bill would allow taxpayers to exclude from taxable income 50 percent of their long-term capital gains on sales of stock in small businesses.
But in a surprise move, Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, managed to eliminate the break for small businesses from the Senate Finance Committee bill. More important, at least in symbolic terms, the committee voted to extend the House's 10 percent tax surcharge on ordinary income for wealthy taxpayers to include capital gains. Thus, the maximum effective rate on capital gains would rise from 28 percent to 1.10 times 28 percent, or 30.8 percent.
 
No Pressing Need Seen
 This reversal of fortunes clearly was not driven by the pressing need to recoup revenues lost in the rubble of the abandoned B.T.U. tax. For while the preponderance of evidence on capital gains suggests that somewhat higher rates would increase revenue over the very long term, the impact over the five-year horizon of the Congressional budget makers is probably too small to measure with any accuracy.
On the one hand, the stiffer tax rate would mean more taxes from those who chose to sell appreciated property. On the other, the higher rate would aggravate the "lock-in effect," reducing the incentive to realize capital gains. "It could raise or lose revenue," concluded Eric Toder, an economist at the Congressional Budget Office.
A more realistic concern to some is that the expanded tax rate differential in the House bill would serve as a catalyst for mischief. In the House's version, the difference between the tax rates on ordinary income and capital gains would widen to more than 11 percentage points, from only 3 percentage points now, making it more profitable for tax alchemists to transform dividends into gains from the sale of stock and other business property. "You are laying the foundation for new tax shelters," Senator Bradley said.
But perhaps the most pressing reason behind the push for a higher capital gains rate is the perception of fairness. The House bill hardly touched the incomes of middle-class families and actually increased the take-home pay of the working poor: As President Clinton correctly claims, the only big losers would be the wealthy who did very, very well indeed in the 1980's.
 
Keeping Rich on Hook
 The Senate Finance Committee bill, by contrast, limits the energy tax to gasoline and diesel fuel, stripping the burden from corporate stockholders. It delays the full impact of higher income tax rates on the wealthy until next year. And while the Medicare cuts are supposed to be borne by physicians and other well-off providers of health care, it is widely believed that the squeeze on Medicare will raise private medical insurance rates paid by the middle class.
Hence the Senate Finance Committee's concern that the wealthy not be let off the hook. And since 27 percent of the income from the sale of capital assets in 1991 was realized by taxpayers with more than $1 million in adjusted gross income, capital gains became an irresistible target.
It is far from clear whether the Senate Finance Committee's capital gains provisions will survive a floor vote, and then emerge intact from a reconciliation conference with the House. The higher gains rate will undoubtedly be cheered by House liberals, who have never been enthusiastic about President Clinton's focus on deficit reduction. But it will alienate the substantial numbers of Congressional Democrats who have no particular affection or loyalty for the President. And it is already becoming a rallying point for conservatives, who are bitter about the Democrats' turn toward populism.
"I think this whole thing is class warfare and very shortsighted," said Eugene Freedman, the chairman of Coopers & Lybrand.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 19, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an economic analysis article about proposed changes in the capital-gains tax misstated the number of returns declaring capital gains in 1991. It was 8,054,000.

HEADLINE: Japan's Government Falls; Party in Peril

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, June 19

 BODY:
In a revolt that could end nearly four decades of one-party rule in Japan, rebel legislators in the party of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa joined forces with the opposition Friday night to pass a vote of no confidence in Mr. Miyazawa's Government. The Prime Minister then dissolved Parliament and called for elections next month.
The organizers of the rebellion, which turned on the question of how to reform Japan's scandal-plagued Government, appeared to be preparing to split off from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Their moves raised the prospect of a fundamental reorganization of the political order that has ruled Japan since the Liberal Democratic Party was founded in 1955. 
 Mr. Miyazawa, who will serve as a caretaker through the elections, seemed almost certain to step down as Prime Minister even if his party wins. His precarious position casts the Government into embarrassing turmoil three weeks before President Clinton and the other leaders of the major industrialized countries arrive here for their annual summit meeting.
 
Meeting Going Forward
 Kyodo news service reported that the Cabinet decided this morning to hold the election on July 18, meaning that the street campaigning will begin on July 4, three days before the summit meeting begins.
Japanese leaders insisted that the Group of Seven summit meeting and the simultaneous visit of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia would go forward without a hitch, even in the midst of what promises to be one of the most critical and hard-fought parliamentary campaigns of postwar Japanese history.
But the battling seems certain to leave the Government virtually paralyzed, dashing any hope that Japan would use its role as chairman of the annual gathering to provide leadership on a host of critical issues, from stimulating the global economy to bringing global trade-liberalization talks to a quick conclusion.
Analysts and officials said the political upheaval in Japan could jeopardize the trade talks with the United States and the meeting in Tokyo. [Page 35.]
 
A Crushing Blow
 Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Yeltsin are also scheduled to meet in their first face-to-face discussion of the territorial dispute that has frozen relations between the two countries and now seems even less likely to be resolved soon.
For the courtly, 73-year-old Mr. Miyazawa -- a man who has been involved in Japanese politics for so long that he attended the signing of the treaty of San Francisco formally ending World War II -- Friday's events were a humiliating and crushing blow.
Though a brilliant analyst of international events, he never mastered the party's vicious factional infighting and never seemed at the center of the money politics that command influence.
In the end, he was outmaneuvered by far craftier forces. As members of Parliament walked up to the podium at 8 Friday evening to turn in their paper ballots, he looked stricken, his eyes downcast.
The vote was, in many ways, the culmination of five years of endless corruption scandals that carried different names -- Recruit, Kyowa, Sagawa Kyubin -- but the same message. They revealed a political system festering with corruption, in which companies regularly paid tens of millions of dollars to assure favorable treatment, win contracts or keep investigations at bay. Those investigations claimed the party's most powerful players, ultimately destroying the huge faction led by former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita that once ran the country. Its collapse led to a power vacuum.
Despite the turmoil, few in Japan expect major changes in policy. The battling that careened out of control Friday is part of a long-simmering feud among leaders of Japan's conservative establishment, none of whom seek fundamental changes in the policies pursued by Japan for decades.
Nonetheless, American officials said Friday night that they expected negotiations with the United States over the Administration's new framework for closing Japan's ballooning trade surplusses, and other talks requiring major political decisions, to probably grind to a halt for several months.
 
Lament on Trade Talks
 "The President might as well leave his trade files at home," a senior American official lamented, "because it is not even clear who he should be talking to." On television Friday night a leading member of the ruling party's executive council, Rokuro Kato, said that "there is no question this will affect the summit as well as trade talks with the United States."
Indeed, for a generation, Japan's allies and trading partners have geared their strategies to the assumption that the party that has held a grip on power for 38 years would be the only political force that mattered in Japan.
Now that assumption seems shattered, and diplomats scrambled Friday night to cable their capitals with speculation about how the prospect of a coalition government in Japan, even one with many of the same principal characters, could ripple through their own economies.
Opposition politicians celebrated the moment with cheers of "Banzai!" on the floor of the Parliament.
"It's like the Berlin Wall coming down for Japan," said Morihiro Hosokawa, who last year created a reform group called the Japan New Party that is widely expected to seize 30 or more seats in the coming election.
 
A Rare Event
 Before Friday night's vote, no-confidence resolutions had passed only three times since the end of World War II and only once in the 38 years that the Government has been controlled by the Liberal Democratic Party. That was in 1980, when Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira was forced to dissolve Parliament after a bitter dispute with two other former Prime Ministers. But Mr. Ohira died in the midst of the campaign, and a sympathy vote once again swept the party to power.
But sympathy for the Liberal Democrats is in far shorter supply now, and history seems of little use in predicting how the political landscape may be rearranged. The Liberal Democrats hold 274 seats in the lower house, or 53.5 percent of the 512 members. Its chances of retaining that majority seem slim.
The no-confidence vote capped years of perpetual scandals and days of wild maneuverings that ostensibly centered on the question of who would take responsibility for the Parliament's failure to agree on a long-promised package of political reforms. But it quickly became clear that the real battle was over who would control the party, a battle in which Mr. Miyazawa, never known for his skill at intraparty politics, was quickly outflanked.
The stage was set for the confrontation several days ago when Mr. Miyazawa abandoned any hope of getting a reform package through this session of Parliament, effectively reneging on a pledge.
A group of younger Liberal Democrats, seeing their chance and contending that they were tired of the party's image of corruption, insisted that the party strike a compromise with the opposition to get the reform package through, even in imperfect form.
The party's leadership would not budge, though, from its own more-sweeping plan, which argued that the way to reduce the amount of money sloshing through the political system is to change Japan's voting system to a series of single-seat constituencies, rather than constituencies that now contain three to five seats.
But the leadership's proposal also would have had the effect of practically guaranteeing the ruling party's virtual monopoly on power. To many, Mr. Miyazawa and the party leadership seemed to be advocating an extreme form of reform in order to kill it.
By 6:30 Friday evening, when the normally smiling Mr. Miyazawa took his seat in Parliament, a glance at his exhausted, dour face made it clear that hours of desperate negotiations to keep the party together had finally failed.
The end came quickly, with no pretense of Japanese politeness or indirection. Sadao Yamahana, the chairman of the Japan Socialist Party, the largest opposition group, presented the no-confidence resolution, declaring that "in the world after the cold war, Japan will be trusted and respected only when it has a healthy democracy."
"When we have a Prime Minister who is a liar," he said, "we simply will buy only sneers."
When the ballots were cast, 255 members of the lower house voted in favor of the no-confidence resolution, with 220 against it and 21 absent. A number of seats are vacant.
But most important, those who voted against Mr. Miyazawa included 39 members of his own party, most of them followers of two ambitious power brokers who once seemed in line for taking over the party leadership: Tsutomu Hata, a former Finance Minister, and Ichiro Ozawa, the protege of the man who ran Japanese politics with a cloaked hand for more than a decade, Shin Kanemaru.
Mr. Kanemaru has since been arrested for tax evasion, after investigators found tens of millions of dollars in his office -- a hoard that many speculate was being collected to propel Mr. Ozawa to the Prime Minister's office. But so far, Mr. Ozawa has not been implicated.
Many party elders, including the secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party, Seiroku Kajiyama, have now vowed to oust Mr. Hata, Mr. Ozawa and their 40 or so followers. That would cut them off from the support and patronage that have made the ruling party one of the world's best-oiled political machines.
 
Talk of Alliances
 The rebels, in turn, seem likely to jump before they are pushed: they have been hinting for months that they might form a new party.
There is considerable speculation that Mr. Hata and Mr. Ozawa will form an alliance with the Japan New Party and perhaps with the right wing of the Socialist Party and with a number of minor parties.
"What we are seeing is the emerging of two centrist parties, instead of Japan's usual competition between the conservatives and the leftists," said Takashi Inokuchi, a professor at the University of Tokyo. "The kind of vigorous leadership you once saw, when a few faction heads controlled the party, will become much more scarce. And for a long time, the government will seem weak and indecisive."
Eventually, he predicted, "they may all merge once again."
While it has often appeared monolithic from afar, the Liberal Democratic Party always has suffered from factional infighting, making the party seem like a coalition government at times. But in the end, the members have usually followed the command of their leaders. How much that could change if the political structure changes is one of the questions no one in Tokyo seems able to answer yet.
The bolting from the party seemed a particularly heavy blow to Mr. Miyazawa.
His faction is small, and Mr. Miyazawa has a reputation for being driven by events. He is widely described as ineffective, and his popularity rating in one televison poll Thursday night dropped below 10 percent.
In the end, many of his colleagues say, it was his passivity that finished his government. He watched the political reform debates more as a bystander than as a participant. "This matter is very difficult for many to solve because it is related to their own districts," Mr. Miyazwa said Friday night.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa acknowledged the no-confidence vote that brought down his Government and could end his party's long rule. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Chart: "The Politicians: Who's Who"
 Kiichi Miyazawa -- As Prime Minister since 1991, Mr. Miyazawa, 73, is known as an internationalist. But he is considered a poor intraparty politician, and the no-confidence vote he lost yesterday came after he was unable to fulfill his pledge to pass a political reform package.
 
 Ichiro Ozawa -- Once a lieutenant of two of Japan's disgraced politicians, Mr. Ozawa, 51, is known as a master fixer. Despite his past links, he has cast himself as a reformer and as the moving force behind the renegade politicians from the governing Liberal Democratic Party who brought down Parliament.
 
 Tsutomu Hata -- A former Finance Minister, Mr. Hata is the public face of the renegade faction that Mr. Ozawa largely controls. Mr. Hata, 57, refused in recent days to back down and ultimately led 39 governing party members to vote against their own party leaders.
 
 Seiroku Kajiyama -- The secretary general of the governing party, he has advocated a hard line against Mr. Ozawa and Mr. Hata, saying they should be expelled from the party. Mr. Kajiyama, 67, seems determined to wage an election campaign to crush the dissidents, and he apparently believes he can retain a party majority.
 
Sadao Yamahana -- Head of the Socialist Party, he has moved it back toward the mainstream of Japanese politics, avoiding the hard-line polemics of his predecessors. Mr. Yamahana, 57, offered the no-confidence motion, saying, "Miyazawa can no longer be trusted to run this country."
 
 Morihiro Hosokawa. Scion of one of Japan's oldest families of feudal lords, Mr. Hosokawa, 55, is the head of the Japan New Party, a reform group that has scored highly in the polls and is expected to win many seats that once seemed safe for the Liberal Democrats. (pg. 5)

HEADLINE: Airlines' Passengers Waging Guerrilla War to Trim Fares

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Call it the do-it-yourself fare war.
Trying to duplicate the low fares that were readily available last summer, growing ranks of passengers are using every means in the air fare book, and a few that are not, to take advantage of the airline industry's complex pricing system and drive down their ticket costs. The methods may not be new, but the consumers' fervor is, airline executives and travel agents say. 
 In response, some airlines are confiscating tickets and using their computer systems to track abuses as well as trying to convince customers that many of their moves are unethical.
Many passengers look for what are known as "hidden city fares." For example, Delta Air Lines, which charges $540 for a direct flight to New York from Dallas, charges $346.50 from Dallas to Montreal with a stop in New York. Thus, a passenger who books to Montreal and checks no baggage, might get off in New York, the hidden city, paying $193.50 less than the person who booked to New York. Such anomalies are created by the industry's hub-and-spoke route system and by the airlines' habit of matching competitors' prices.
Another popular tactic among passengers who fly frequently between two cities is back-to-back ticketing. A passenger, for example, can buy two round-trip tickets between Seattle and Kansas City, Mo., for $200 each, which require a Saturday-night stay. By using alternate halves of each set of tickets, a passenger can avoid a Saturday night layover and still pay less than the fare for a midweek round trip, which costs $1,000 on several airlines.
"It's like income tax," said Tom Parsons of Arlington, Tex., who publishes Best Fares, a monthly compilation of air fare discounts and ticketing tips. "If a loophole is there for the taking, then why not take it?"
His views are shared by frequent travelers like Herb Comrov, president of a Chicago company that makes security tags for retail merchandise. Mr. Comrov said he regularly bought hidden-city and back-to-back tickets. "The business passenger pays through the nose, and we have to do whatever we can to even the score," he said.
In a recent survey of 200 companies, Corporate Travel magazine found that almost 40 percent saw nothing wrong with using discount business fares for conferences for regular travel. And nearly half of those surveyed said they thought travel agents should do "whatever it takes" to get low fares.
Airline executives say that such gamesmanship is difficult to measure, but they contend it has added tens of millions of dollars to their recent annual losses. And travel agents agree that the flying public is hunting for deals with more determination than ever.
"Consumers always wanted to get the lowest possible fare," said Donald J. Carty, American Airlines' executive vice president for finance and planning. "But more and more people are looking for it."
The trend is partly fed by the legions of business travelers who are trying to squeeze more flights from their travel budgets, said Severin Borenstein, a professor of economics at the University of California at Davis who studies the airline industry.
In their search for fare bargains, Mr. Borenstein added, many travelers comb magazines and newsletters that serve frequent travelers and scroll through home-computer networks like Prodigy and Compuserve that allow consumers to check fares.
The big carriers say they are fighting back, trying to tighten up the loopholes in their fare structure. Their sophisticated computer systems enable them to improve their monitoring, they say, and employees at airports are checking tickets more carefully. Some airlines, like USAir, confiscate tickets if they catch a passenger using hidden-city or back-to-back fares. But others, including Delta and Continental Airlines, say they tolerate back-to-back ticketing because the practice technically breaks no rules.
 
Pressure on Travel Agents
 Many airlines exhort travel agents not to write hidden-city or back-to-back tickets. But travel agents say customers will simply take their business elsewhere if their request for such service is rebuffed.
"It puts us in a very difficult position," said Estelle Lessack, president of Travel Trends in Fort Lee, N.J. "The whole structure is ridiculous."
The airlines argue that consumers enter a type of contract with the airlines to be flown to a certain destination, and the fact that their flight stops briefly at a hub city is immaterial to their agreement. By beating the system, they add, passengers hurt those who play and pay by the rules. "It is clear to me that the customers are misrepresenting themselves," said Bill Brunger, vice president of revenue management at Continental Airlines.
But many passengers reject that argument. They see an airline ticket not as a contract but more like a ticket to a baseball game. If ticket holders want to leave the game in the seventh inning, they have every right to do so, and similarly, they say, passengers can leave a flight at an interim stop.
Thomas W. Dunfee, a professor of legal studies at the Wharton School who has researched ethics in the travel agency business, said that if there is a clear misrepresentation by the consumer, as he believes there is with hidden-city ticketing, "that bothers me." And while he believes an airline ticket is a type of contract, the airlines do not always make completely clear, in advance, such practices as overbooking. "It's a truly interesting area for an application of ethics," he said.
Some other methods used to beat the system include reserving a first-class seat with a fictional name, but buying a coach ticket. After the payment deadline, the first-class reservation will not be honored, but the airline may not be able to sell it at the last minute. So the passenger who made the initial reservation simply sits in the first-class seat as the cabin crew closes the door, and says hello when he is addressed by his fictional name. Frequent fliers say that flight crews rarely ask to see tickets, especially in first class.
 
Promotion Opportunities
 Very frequent travelers who hold so-called gold cards offered by many airlines are entitled to free upgrades to first class if there are any such seats available when the plane departs. So some people make several fictitious reservations in first class to better their chances.
Such duplicitous methods, however, represent a small part of a broader, low-profile fare war driven by the proliferation of discount travel coupons offered by the airlines.
Such promotions are seen by the industry as a slightly more effective marketing tool than all-out fare wars, which typically give an airline only a brief competitive advantage before its deal is matched.
Industry experts say the airlines, which have too many seats chasing too few passengers, are likely, if anything, to complicate matters further with more new marketing strategies.
They also point to American Airlines' failed attempt last year to overhaul the fare structure. Its so-called value pricing was intended to eliminate much of the discounting and complexities of the pricing system, but the rest of the industry balked.
Recently, however, USAir has taken a small step by introducing a new fare structure in the Northeast that is intended in part to reduce the need for manipulating fares.
For example, it created a tier of fares that require seven-day advance purchase but no Saturday night stay and are $50 lower than the highest last-minute coach fare.

HEADLINE: In Peace Plan for Northwest Timber Dispute, Options May Anger Both Sides

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
In a crucial test of a promise to square environmental goals with economic ones, the Clinton Administration has prepared an array of suggested solutions to end a fractious battle over timber and endangered species in the Pacific Northwest, including one that would slash the amount of cutting on Federal lands in the region by half or more, an Administration official said yesterday.
According to officials in the Administration and staff members in Congress, the options also include a proposal for legislation to bypass or waive some provisions of three important environmental laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act, to hasten the pace for putting the President's timber plan into effect. 
 These options are part of a package of proposals that officials in five Federal agencies and the White House are close to finishing and that may be sent to President Clinton early next week, according to Administration officials.
Marla Romash, the spokeswoman for Vice President Al Gore, said that no final decisions had been made and that the President would not make any for at least another week and perhaps longer.
"The President made clear at the forest conference, and believes strongly today, that the long-term economic and environmental health of the region must be what drives the Administration's policy," Ms. Romash said. "We are facing a difficult decision that has been created by years of bad management and policy making."
 
Longstanding Problem
 The package of proposals was ordered by Mr. Clinton in early April, when he, Mr. Gore, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and several other Cabinet officers traveled to Portland, Ore., to hold a public hearing on ways to resolve the conflict between logging interests, who are concerned about jobs, and environmentalists, who want to preserve the old-growth forests, the home of the northern spotted owl.
Mr. Clinton said during the campaign last year that he would study the issue and propose solutions. But almost anything Mr. Clinton calls for is bound to anger important political constituencies in the region, say leaders of the environmental movement and the timber industry.
In addition, some influential Democrats on Capitol Hill hail from the region, among them House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon. Both lawmakers represent timber districts and have made it known to the White House that they would like to see logging on public lands in the two states kept at levels sufficient to sustain logging jobs and mills. Congressional staff members say Mr. Clinton needsthe support of the Speaker and Mr. DeFazio if he hopes to enact his budget, a new health-care plan or any other important legislation.
In an interview, Mr. DeFazio said he wanted environmentalists and other critics to hold their fire until the President concludes his review and makes a decision. "It's a bit premature to be jumping all over the President when they really don't know what the President will do," Mr. DeFazio said. "This is not Ronald Reagan. This is not George Bush. This is not James Watt. This is a plan produced by Bill Clinton, Al Gore and Bruce Babbitt."
 
Limit on Logging
 Aspects of the Administration's plan were reported yesterday in The Washington Post, including one option that would limit logging on public lands in the Pacific Northwest to an average of 1.2 billion to 1.5 billion board feet annually over the next decade. In the late 1980's, at the peak of production, loggers produced more than 5 billion board feet annually in the region, according to Federal figures.
That level of production has fallen to roughly 3 billion board feet annually, largely because of Federal court action in the early 1990's that has severely limited the amount of Federal timber that the Government can sell to logging companies. Unless the President acts, timber cutting on Federal lands in the Pacific Northwest would come almost to a halt by 1995 because all of the timber under contract would have been cut and no new sales have been conducted for several years.
Environmental groups attacked the proposal yesterday, not only because it would open forests now off-limits to logging because of court orders and other legal action but also because the plan under consideration would not establish forest reserves where no logging could occur.
The environmentalists, who were among the strongest supporters of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore during the campaign, also criticized the proposal as an effort to waive environmental law and perhaps limit public involvement in some aspects of the plan.
"After decades of illegal abuse and logging of nearly 50 million acres of public forest, this Administration endorses politics as usual," said Timothy Hermach, executive director of the Native Forest Council, an environmental group in Eugene, Ore. "Most Americans would demand an immediate halt to further sales."
Timber-industry employees and executives also attacked the recently disclosed option to limit logging to 1.2 billion to 1.5 billion board feet. They said such a low level of cutting would close more mills and put thousands more people out of work. "At that level, it's unacceptable -- it means a 75 percent or 80 percent loss for our industry," said Cary Jones, the executive director of Douglas Timber Operators, a group in Roseburg, Ore., that represents the timber industry.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

International
Political upheaval in Japan could jeopardize U.S. trade talks and next month's Group of Seven summit meeting in Tokyo. It could also delay measures to stimulate Japan's economy, which is showing signs of recovery. [Page 35.] The dollar ended higher against the yen, raising hopes that the string of recent postwar lows had ended. The dollar also rose against the mark. [35.] 
 The vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa raised the prospect of a fundamental reorganization of the political order that has ruled Japan since 1955. [1.]
 
The Economy
Airline passengers are using ingenious methods to take advantage of the industry's complex fare-pricing system and drive down their ticket costs. But the carriers are retaliating. [1.]
The Senate Finance Committee approved the main elements of a five-year budget package, the last step before a Senate debate next week that promises to be one of the sharpest in years. [7.]
 
Companies
Apple's chairman, John Sculley, will relinquish his role as chief executive to pursue alliances involving new technologies. There was speculation that he was looking for a graceful way out after reporting last week that the company's earnings were being hurt by the price war in the personal computer industry. [35.]
Prudential Securities is said to be negotiating to pay as much as $100 million in Federal and state settlements relating to selling limited partnerships during the 1980's. A Federal criminal inquiry has also begun into the partnership sales and the activities of the firm's north Dallas branch. [35.]
Litton Industries will split into two companies, one focusing on lucrative commercial business and the other on the declining market for military weapons. [35.]
Digital agreed to sell its U.S. leasing business to GE Capital, continuing the computer maker's efforts to pare costs. [37.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Currencies and Diplomacy Get Jolt From Tokyo

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In a move that could not be better timed for American tourists, the dollar rallied sharply yesterday against the German mark and other European currencies and, suddenly, against the Japanese yen.
In a hectic day of global trading, the dollar ended 2.3 percent higher against the yen after a political revolt in Japan apparently doomed the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and threatened to end four decades of rule by his Liberal Democratic Party. 
 In New York, the dollar reversed its five-month plunge and surged to 109.75 yen, from 107.30 the day before.This was the dollar's highest close in a month and came just days after the dollar touched a record low close in New York of 105.08 yen.
 
Impact on Bonds
 The dollar also soared to its highest close against the mark since October 1991. It finished in New York at 1.6805 marks, up from 1.6598 marks and 3.2 percent higher for the week.
The dollar's rally could be felt immediately in the American bond market. Given low inflation and continued progress on deficit reduction in Washington, a currency rally may be the extra spark to push Treasury yields lower soon.
Several traders and economists said that they expected the rally against the mark and other European currencies to continue because the underlying economic fundamentals, including a continuing decline in interest rates in Europe, favor the dollar. This means the dollar could move toward 1.80 marks or higher.
But they were less certain about the dollar versus the yen, because the economic fundamentals, like the huge Japanese trade surplus, still favor the Japanese currency.
Given the new political uncertainity, it appears that the dollar may not fall now to new record lows against the yen. But it will not rally all that much either, especially if the Japanese leadership crisis is resolved faster than expected. This means that the dollar, which had fallen 16 percent against the yen since the end of last year, is likely to remain about 110 to 115 yen, which is still a hefty slump of 10 percent for the year.
"The dollar will hold better against the mark than the yen," said Robert A. White, a senior vice president at Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles. But, he said, if the Clinton Administration has stopped talking the dollar down against the yen, then the dollar has probably reached bottom.
It was such jawboning in February that began the dollar's precipitous slide against the yen. The Administration's apparent hope was that a weaker dollar would help shrink Japan's trade surplus by making Japanese goods sold here much more expensive. Intervention in the currency markets by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan had not been able to stem the slide.
 
Forces Favoring Yen
 John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the positive economic forces still favoring the yen were the trade surplus, the lack of a Japanese appetite now for foreign assets, the decline in oil and other commodity prices, which helps the Japanese economy, and the fact that the overall prospects for the Japanese economy are improving.
But he argued that even if the political uncertainty was cleared up quickly, the dollar would not fall to new lows. He expects the Bank of Japan to cut Japanese interest rates to prevent the American currency from falling to near 100 yen to the dollar. He also said there might be some signs that Japan's trade surplus was beginning to shrink.
The rise of the dollar against the German mark, in comparison, is not much of a surprise, except that the rally to this level has taken longer than many forecasters expected. That is because the American economy in the first quarter was much weaker than expected, meaning the flow of foreign money to invest here was lighter than expected.
In addition, the German central bank has moved more stubbornly than expected in cutting interest rates.
The dollar has been forecast to rise against the mark because the German economy is in a recession that many analysts argue is more severe than German officials are saying.
If this is the case, the Bundesbank will have to cut interest rates much further. In addition, the European slowdown will make the Continent a less attractive place for investors while the American economy appears, finally, to be on a steady, if moderate, path of growth.
And because currency traders and speculators like to be as far ahead of the next dollar move as possible, these expectations could push the rally forward quickly.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Gold in Slight Rise
 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- A stronger dollar helped limit a rise in gold yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery climbed for the third consecutive session, gaining 30 cents to $372.50 an ounce. The August contract gained $5 this week amid perceptions that strong demand is overcoming signs of dormant inflation.
