HEADLINE: President Chooses an Expert To Halt Smuggling of Aliens

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
President Clinton moved today to put his stamp on immigration policy, appointing an expert to head the Immigration and Naturalization Service and announcing new initiatives intended to end the smuggling of illegal aliens.
Mr. Clinton nominated Doris M. Meissner, who was a Deputy Associate Attorney General under President Jimmy Carter and an Acting Commissioner of Immigration under President Ronald Reagan, to head the agency. The 51-year-old Ms. Meissner has most recently been director of immigration policy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. 
 In announcing her selection, Mr. Clinton said a chief goal for Ms. Meissner would be to insure that the United States does not "lose control of our borders."
The Administration also announced a streamlined policy aimed at reducing the number of illegal aliens who are smuggled into the United States. The practice drew international attention last week when a tramp steamer carrying about 300 illegal Chinese immigrants ran aground off the coast of Queens, stranding many and resulting in the drowning death of six passengers who had attempted to swim to shore.
Such schemes are "a shameful practice of unspeakable degradation and unspeakable exploitation," Mr. Clinton said. He pledged to speed up the processing of illegal aliens who are caught while being smuggled into the country and to strengthen efforts to catch the organizers of smuggling rings.
Administration officials said legislation to meet these goals was expected to be introduced in two weeks, after Ms. Meissner has had an opportunity to review the recommendations, made by the White House, the I.N.S., the National Security Council and other agencies.
Immigration policy experts praised Ms. Meissner's knowledge of the subject and said her appointment represented a departure from the previous practice of treating the commissioner's job as a political appointment.
"She's solid," said Rick Swartz, an immigration-policy expert in Washington. "Doris is probably the most experienced choice that Clinton could have made."
Arthur Helton, an immigration expert for the Lawyers International Committee for Human Rights, said: "There were many inside the agency who were worried that a strong antagonist to their interests would be appointed. There were others outside who were concerned that it would be someone whose principal qualification was as a good fund-raiser in the course of an election. None of these worries panned out with the choice of Doris Meissner."
The Administration has only recently begun to integrate its foreign policy operation with immigration issues. Tim Wirth, the former Colorado Senator, was recently appointed to a new position as an undersecretary of state in charge of a grab bag of global issues, including drugs and immigration.
The Clinton Administration's new immigration policy, officials said, is expected to include proposals to toughen penalties for smuggling to as much as 20 years in prison, to allow racketeering laws to be applied to smuggling syndicates, to expand the ability of the Government to seize the assets of immigration smugglers and to expedite the admission or deportation of aliens seeking entry into the United States.
 
Streamlining the Process
 If such legislation is passed, officials said, the amount of time it takes for aliens to have their cases considered will shrink from as long as 18 months to as little as 30 days.
"With this plan, the United States signals its abhorrence of the trafficking in human beings for profit and its determination to combat this illegal activity," Mr. Clinton said. "At the same time, we reaffirm our commitment to protect bona fide refugees."
But Mr. Clinton would not specify the price tag for such a strategy, which would require, at a minimum, a significant increase in immigration workers.
Mr. Clinton stressed today that the Administration review had begun some time ago, when Government agencies had first become aware of a pattern of organized smuggling that brought illegal aliens from China, El Salvador, Guatemala and Haiti.
But it was clearly the most recent episodes of alien smuggling -- especially the grounding of the Golden Venture steamer off Queens -- that prompted today's announcement.
"Events in recent weeks have brought into focus the tremendous economic, human and social impact immigration has on our country," said Attorney General Janet Reno, who oversees the immigration agency. "We have much work to do in this area to insure that those who truly deserve political asylum are granted it, but those who break the laws of this country are given the strictest possible penalties."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
House in Queens Is Raided
 Immigration agents found 22 illegal Chinese aliens being held in Bayside, Queens, in an early morning raid yesterday, and eight members of an Asian gang were charged with smuggling them into the United States, law-enforcement officials said.
The illegal aliens were part of a larger group that had traveled by ship from Asia and landed near San Francisco on June 2. They had flown to Kennedy International Airport from Los Angeles and were being held at 230-36 57th Road in Bayside when they were apprehended, the officials said.
William S. Slattery, the district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York, said the timing of the raid, on the same day as President Clinton's announcement of a crackdown on the smuggling of illegal aliens, was a coincidence.
The 22 illegal immigrants, 14 men and 8 women, were apparently being held by gang members until they could pay the $30,000 each had agreed to pay for passage. They will be held by the I.N.S. or released to family members until deportation proceedings begin.
The illegal aliens make up the third such group to be found in the New York area in a month. On May 24, 57 undocumented immigrants were found in a Jersey City warehouse; on June 8, 13 more were found in the basement of a house in Sunset Park in Brooklyn.
The eight people arrrested yesterday were charged with smuggling illegal aliens.

HEADLINE: Currencies and Diplomacy Get Jolt From Tokyo;
Turmoil Amid Crucial Economic Talks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 18

 BODY:
The stunning political upheaval in Japan could jeopardize important trade talks with the United States as well as next month's Group of Seven summit meeting in Tokyo, analysts and officials said today.
Political paralysis resulting from the turmoil could also delay additional measures to stimulate Japan's limp economy. According to new figures released today, the Japanese economy is showing the first signs, albeit feeble ones, of recovering from its worst slump in two decades. 
 Indeed, from an economic point of view, the no-confidence vote tonight against Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, which is likely to topple his Government, could not have come at a more delicate time.
 
 
Fear of Paralysis
 Kenneth S. Courtis, strategist for Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, said, "Political paralysis is the big risk we run at this critical juncture, where we need political leadership from Japan."
The political uncertainty seems to have halted, at least temporarily, the relentless rise of the Japanese yen, which has been occurring since February. The yen weakened sharply against the dollar today in New York trading, which took place after the no-confidence vote in the lower house of Parliament. After losing the vote, Mr. Miyazawa dissolved the lower chamber and set the stage for elections.
 The Tokyo stock market has also been jittery this week as the political crisis mounted, with the Nikkei average closing today at 19,804.54, down 120.97 for the day and off about 700 points for the week.
Analysts expect the yen and Japanese stocks to continue to fall next week, but perhaps not for long. "In the past, political uncertainty has had only a temporary effect" on the markets, said Tomoko Fujii, an economist with Salomon Brothers in Tokyo.
One longer-term economic question is what will happen if the current turmoil finally leads to a loss of power by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which has controlled the Government continuously for four decades. There is a widespread feeling here that one-party rule has provided political stability and allowed the nation to concentrate on its rapid industrial development.
 
Much Is on the Plate
 But a more immediate concern is that with Mr. Miyazawa effectively a lame duck, it will be difficult for Japan to make decisions on crucial economic matters. And there is no shortage of important matters that will need attention in coming weeks.
Chief among them is the meeting of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, which will start on July 7 in Tokyo. The agenda will include issues like aid to Russia, revival of the world economy and liberalization of world trade.
A pre-summit meeting aimed at forging an agreement on market-opening measures under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will take place in Tokyo next week.
A political vacuum may also make it more difficult for Japan to make the hard decisions that may be needed to forge a new trade framework with the United States, which is also expected in time for the summit meeting. "No one's in a position to produce a deal," said Dr. Courtis of Deutsche Bank.
 
Bureaucrats Keep Humming
 Some Japanese officials played down talk that the summit meeting or the trade negotiations would be affected. They say the groundwork for both matters is being handled by Japan's powerful bureaucracies, which tend to go on running the country despite changes in administrations.
"We have spent a lot of time making preparations for the series of international meetings," Mamoru Ozaki, the Vice Minister of Finance, was quoted by the Kyodo News Service as saying today. He said the meetings would go on "without a hitch."
After losing the no-confidence vote, Mr. Miyazawa chose to dissolve the lower house of Parliament and hold new elections in late July. The other option would have been for him and his Cabinet to resign. That, officials said, would have truly disrupted the Group of Seven conference.
Still, having election campaigns begin in early July could divert attention from the summit meeting. "There is no doubt that this will affect the summit as well as trade talks with the United States," Rokuro Kato, a member of the ruling party's executive council, was quoted by Reuters as saying.
The political paralysis also makes it unlikely that there will be new efforts to stimulate the economy anytime soon. "The political development will mean no additional policy in the next two to three months," said Noboru Kawai, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo.
 Some business and political leaders have been pushing for an income tax cut to spur consumer spending. But the powerful Ministry of Finance has been opposed to this, because it does not want a national budget deficit.
The Liberal Democratic Party has been instrumental in overcoming Finance Ministry resistance to two other economic stimulus packages that were enacted in the last year. But now the party is in disarray, leaving the Finance Ministry with a freer hand to determine economic policy.
Still, Japan is not expected to consider new stimulus measures until fall, and by then the turmoil may be over.
There is still pressure on the Bank of Japan to cut interest rates, but at 2.5 percent, the discount rate is already so low that little stimulus could be obtained by further reductions, some economists say.
Although the economy is still weak, some experts say it has hit the bottom. The Government reported today that in the first three months of 1993 the gross national product grew six-tenths of a percent over the previous quarter, or at an annualized rate of 2.3 percent. That followed three quarters in which economic output had either shrunk or remained flat.
 
A Disappointing Year
 But that slightly positive showing could not erase a bad year. For all of the 1992 fiscal year, which also ended on March 31, Japan's economy grew only eight-tenths of a percent, the worst showing since a decline of two-tenths of a percent in the 1974 fiscal year, after the first oil crisis.
The eight-tenths of a percent growth for the year was a fraction of the Government's initial target for the year of 3.5 percent growth. It was even well below the revised target of 1.6 percent, an indication of how badly the Government misread economic signals as the slump deepened.
Much of the growth in the March quarter came from Government spending as a stimulus package announced in August finally began to take effect.
There were some other positive signs in the data. Personal spending rose 1.2 percent in the quarter after declining six-tenths of a percent in the previous quarter. Even corporate investment, which has declined for six consecutive quarters, fell only two-tenths of a percent in the most recent period, compared with 3.6 percent in the December quarter.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Kantor Is Hopeful
 WASHINGTON, June 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today that he saw no indication that the political crisis in Tokyo was causing Japan to reduce its efforts on trade issues.
Mr. Kantor said he hoped that the momentum of negotiations "is not hampered in any way" by Mr. Miyazawa's action to dissolve Parliament after losing a no-confidence motion.
Japan is involved in talks to remove trade barriers under the Uruguay Round of GATT talks and is also engaged in separate talks between Tokyo and Washington in which the United States is pressing for greater access to the Japanese market.
"We have no indication at this point that the Japanese Government is backing away" from its effort to move forward, Mr. Kantor said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Kantor said he was scheduled to hold talks in Tokyo on Tuesday and Wednesday that aim to reduce Japan's trade surplus and increase American companies' sales to Japan.
 Trade experts said they saw several ways the changes could affect trade negotiations. Japanese bureaucrats already dominate the talks, the experts noted, and the weakening of the politicians in power could strengthen the bureaucrats' hands, allowing the talks to continue as before, or perhaps even more smoothly.

HEADLINE: Theme Schools Face Hurdles In Opening

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
As they race to open more than 30 small experimental public schools in the fall, New York City educators say they are grappling with an array of difficulties -- from hiring directors to finding buildings to signing up students.
Four of the 37 small new schools will not open in September as originally planned, school officials said yesterday. All four will instead open in the fall of 1994. 
 Despite the setbacks, however, several senior education officials, including the state Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, and the president of the New York City Board of Education, Carol A. Gresser, said yesterday that they believed the movement to create smaller, theme-based schools was still gaining momentum.
 
Smaller High Schools
 The comments were made at a news conference held at Central Park East Secondary School at Madison Avenue and 106th Street. The news conference was held to draw attention to efforts to open six small high schools at various locations in Manhattan this fall as part of a plan to phase out Julia Richman High School, where only about one student in three now graduates.
"These schools are part of a broader initiative by the New York City public schools to create smaller and personalized new high schools," Mrs. Gresser said. "They will provide safe and caring environments in which all students can be known well. They set a direction for effective school reform in New York City for years to come."
Ms. Gresser and another school board member, Ninfa Segarra, also announced their support for plans to replicate the Julia Richman experiment, by creating six small high schools in the Bronx in the fall of 1994 as part of an effort to replace one of the borough's failing high schools. The high school has not yet been designated.
For more than two decades, isolated pioneers have been experimenting with small schools as alternatives to the hundreds of colossal, factory-like elementary and high schools operated by New York City. Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez gave crucial support to their efforts, and earlier this year the Board of Education approved plans to open 37 of the new schools this fall.
 
Resembling a Corporate Office
 The 37 schools, like the High School for Economics and Finance with its site planned to resemble a corporate office, were all designed with curriculums centered on separate themes. Most were developed in partnerships between the board and unions, colleges, neighborhood groups and even some churches.
As a group, the new schools represent one of the largest expansions of the city's public school system in decades. Not surprisingly, some of them have run into problems.
"There's a lot that goes into starting a new school, from finding people and space and equipment to developing a curriculum, and it all has to be done in a relatively short period," said Beth Lief, executive director of the Fund for New York City Public Education, an education organization that is raising money and working to get 14 of the new schools started.
"This is the most exciting project I've ever been involved in, but it takes a tremendous amount of hard work." Organizers of the Health Opportunities Collaborative High School, which was to immerse students in a health-related curriculum with projects in hospitals and clinics, were forced to postpone the school's opening for a year because the proposed site, a converted gymnasium at Lehman College, was unavailable, and the director hired to run the school backed out.
The director originally picked to run the Museum School in Manhattan also backed out, forcing postponement of the opening of that school, which was to make use of the resources of the Museum of Natural History and several other museums.
Organizers of the Brooklyn School for Global Citizenship, who planned to turn Brooklyn into an urban laboratory this fall with a curriculum centered on the borough's immigrant communities, postponed their plans after protests from parents at a junior high school whose vacant classrooms they had hoped to use.
 
School Within a School
 The inauguration of the Andrew Jackson High School Magnet School, which was to open this fall as a new high school within a high school in Queens, has also been postponed a year. "That one never really got off the ground," said James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for the Board of Education.
Because the board only approved plans for the new schools in March, a catalog explaining to parents and students how to sign up was issued late, complicating enrollment, Mr. Vlasto said. But more than 4,400 students have now applied for the 3,300 seats that will be available in the new schools this fall, he said.
Though organizers of all the new schools have been racing against a tight schedule, most have hired project directors and teachers, found classroom space, and are well along in the development of their curriculums, Stanley S. Litow, the deputy chancellor for operations, said at the news conference.
Deborah Meier, a prize-winning principal who pioneered several of the city's first small alternative public schools in the 1970's, is a coordinator of the effort to phase out Julia Richman High School. She said it has not been easy to find buildings, hire teachers and make all the other arrangements for the six new schools. But she said she was sure all the toil would pay off this fall.
"I'm confident that these schools will provide a superb educational environment," Ms. Meier said.

HEADLINE: Planned Parenthood of New York Begins Abortion Training

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Planned Parenthood of New York began training doctors yesterday to perform abortions, a role that teaching hospitals have abandoned in recent years in response to social, legal and economic pressures.
Over the last decade the number of medical residency programs that require abortion training in the United States has dropped by half, and that drop is one reason most of the nation's counties do not have a single doctor who will perform the procedure. 
 "Most teaching hospitals find it easier to leave abortion training to someone else," Alexander C. Sanger, president and chief executive of New York's Planned Parenthood chapter, said in announcing the program. "We have decided to become that someone else."
While some individual abortion clinics have occasionally trained doctors to work for them, the Planned Parenthood program is the first large-scale effort to increase the availability of doctors nationwide.
The graduates of the Planned Parenthood classes will not gain any additional legal standing: under current licensing rules, gynecologists and several other specialists are already certified to perform abortions even if they have never done one. But they will gain increased knowledge about the technicalities of the medical procedure as well as the counseling that usually accompanies it.
One doctor who signed up for the Planned Parenthood course said he did so because he felt his lack of training in abortions left him unprepared to be a good obstetrician. Dr. Jeffrey Meneges is a third-year resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, which he said does not perform abortions.
"I was surprised when I started my residency program to realize that abortion was something I would have to learn on my own," Dr. Meneges said. "It is an important part of an OB/GYN practice. It's something I should know how to do."
The program drew criticism from opponents of abortion, who have long seen the decline in the number of abortion practitioners as a sign that their message was gaining favor.
Jeanne Head, president of the Right to Life Committee of Manhattan, predicted that the Planned Parenthood program would fail. "I don't think that any amount of training can encourage doctors to destroy babies," she said.
Mr. Sanger, whose grandmother, Margaret Sanger, founded the American birth control movement, said the training program was a response to the growing nationwide shortage of doctors willing and able to perform abortions. According to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, an independent, nonprofit research and policy institute on the subject of reproductive health, 83 percent of counties in the United States had no abortion providers in 1988, the last year for which it had statistics.
The shortage is worst in rural areas, but even in New York, Planned Parenthood is having a difficult time finding doctors, said Dr. E. Hakim Elahi, medical director of Planned Parenthood here. A catalyst for the program, in fact, was when a doctor in the group's Brooklyn office took an emergency three-week leave in 1992 and no replacement could be found.
Behind the shortage, experts say, is a confluence of trends and events. First, a generation of doctors who trained during the late 1960's and were struck by the often tragic complications of illegal abortions are retiring. Younger doctors were shaped by a different world, in which those who perform abortions are often harassed by protesters and threatened with violence, as evidenced by the murder of Dr. David Gunn earlier this year outside the Florida abortion clinic where he worked.
 
Fewer Training Programs
 While young doctors are having their doubts, the hospitals that train them are, too. Across the country, the number of hospital training programs that routinely include abortion training fell by 50 percent since 1985. Currently, 38 percent of all obstetrics/gynecology residencies do not offer any abortion training, according to a study by the National Abortion Federation. Only 12 percent of residencies require such training, and the other 50 percent make it optional.
Even at hospitals that teach the procedure, Dr. Elahi said, residents are limited by the number of abortions performed there. Because most abortions are done in clinics, he said, hospital residents receive insufficient exposure for proper training.
And when abortion training is optional, he said, young doctors often focus their energies elsewhere. Obstetrics and gynecology is increasingly subspecialized, he said, with doctors choosing to train in fields like infertility. "They put family planning at the bottom of the list," he said.
To counteract these trends, clinics have been recruiting their own doctors and offering to train them -- with varying degrees of success.
 
3,000 Letters, No Reply
 In Atlanta, the Feminist Women's Health Center sent 3,000 letters to imminent graduates of the nation's obstetrics/gynecology residencies without finding one person willing to train to work at that abortion clinic.
In Ohio one family planning clinic almost closed for lack of a doctor, and was saved only when an out-of-state physician offered to fly in periodically to train two recent graduates.
At the Vermont Women's Health Center in Burlington, physician's assistants train interested residents, who then work at the clinic.
The New York plan, however, is the most ambitious in scope. Mr. Sanger said his organization hoped to train 35 doctors a year over each of the next three years. He said $1.5 million had already been raised for that purpose.
 
'Regional Training Center'
 Eventually, he said, he expects New York to become a "regional training center," attracting doctors from along the East Coast.
The group that began classes yesterday consists of eight residents, three women and five men; three more women were trained during a test late last year. They are training to be specialists in the fields of obstetrics/gynecology, family practice and adolescent medicine.
Over the next three months they will spend 40 hours learning abortion procedures -- added to their hospital schedules of 80 hours a week. Some of that will be classroom time, covering subjects like the history of abortion, pregnancy diagnosis, preoperative preparations, surgical procedure, follow-up care and patient counseling.
Much of the time will be spent in hands-on surgical training in first-trimester abortions. Those procedures will be done in Planned Parenthood clinics under the supervision of a staff doctor. Doctors who complete the program will receive a certificate to that effect but will have no obligation to work at Planned Parenthood clinics.

HEADLINE: Inflation Warnings Weigh on Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Warnings by two Federal Reserve governors about inflationary trends weighed on what was otherwise a dull session in the bond market yesterday. Still, Treasury issues ended the day mixed.
The Fed governors, Lawrence B. Lindsey and Wayne D. Angell, issued separate warnings about inflation, several days after the Government issued reports showing consumer and producer prices remained in check in May. 
 The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond initially fell on the reports, but it later rebounded in technical trading. In the end, the 30-year bond gained 2/32 point, while its yield dipped to 6.80 percent, from 6.81 percent on Thursday.
Mr. Lindsey, in a television interview, said he planned to increase his inflation estimate to an annualized rate of 4 percent, from 2.7 percent. Mr. Angell, speaking at a luncheon in Switzerland, also said inflation was still too high for his tastes and added that he did not believe the Fed's inflation projection of 2.75 percent for 1993 would be met.
 
Hawks on Inflation
 Analysts said both men were considered inflation hawks, meaning their overriding goal in monetary policy was to achieve price stability. Inflation erodes the value of bonds and other fixed-income investments.
"These guys are the biggest hawks," said Susan Hering, an economist with Salomon Brothers. "They don't want people to give up on the issue."
Kevin Flanagan, a money-market economist at Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said the Fed governors' comments "put some pressure on the fixed-income arena."
The effect of their comments and a preliminary University of Michigan survey that showed rising consumer confidence in June were exaggerated in a lightly traded market, Mr. Flanagan said.
The two-year Treasury note fell 3/32 point, with its yield rising to 4.12 percent from 4.07 percent. And the five-year Treasury note fell 5/32 point, while the yield rose to 5.20 percent from 5.17 percent.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.86, to 1,296.73.
 
Three-Month Bills
 The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.04 percent from 3.02 percent, while the discount rate on six-month bills rose to 3.16 percent from 3.14 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 2 7/8 percent, down from 3 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10122/32, up 1/32 point. The average yield to maturity was 5.82 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
In a Glut of Information, Some Items to Ignore

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
THE United States Supreme Court has issued credentials for this session to 34 reporters, virtually all who asked. The Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund trade group, issued credentials for its convention this year to exactly 100 reporters, plus cameramen.
Let nobody complain that they lack information about investing. Newspapers, radio, television and magazines are all expanding their coverage. Readers and viewers might say they want even more, but some indigestion is evident. 
 "Ten years ago the question was 'How do you get reliable information?' " said Don Phillips, publisher of the Morningstar Mutual Funds newsletter. "Today the question is 'How do you avoid overload?' "
The overload is especially severe because the job of most networks and publications is to cover what's new and different, much more than repeating some standard, unvarying advice. Market coverage concentrates on the big winners or losers of the day or week, and a staple of mutual fund coverage is the quarterly performance ranking.
This info glut can reinforce investors' worst habits. . Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard economist who joined the Clinton Treasury Department, has written about "the tendency for people to do today what they wish they had done yesterday."
Each quarter, the best-performing mutual funds attract huge amounts of money. No matter that these funds tend to be narrow and risky, like the gold funds that did so well in this year's first quarter. Some coverage emphasized that the long-term returns from gold and gold funds remained dismal, but the mere reporting of gold's gains inflamed investor passion.
One quarter's express trains can become the next quarter's derailments. Say, as an experiment, you had taken the five best-performing stock funds at the end of each quarter and held them through the next quarter. Asked to calculate the results, apart from any sales charges, Morningstar found that in only 9 of 25 quarters would you have beaten the average stock fund.
Following the hottest stocks and sectors can be even more dizzying. Consider the market's course since last October. First stocks of small technology companies soared on hopes that Bill Clinton would subsidize their research and development. Meanwhile, drug stocks collapsed under his pledge to control medical costs. By year-end, early cyclical stocks, like machinery makers, which do well in the beginning of a recovery, ran up on signs of economic strength.
This year, consumer growth stocks staggered as consumers and investors became less willing to pay up for brand names. Now, just six months after recommending those early cyclicals, many analysts are fast-forwarding to late cyclical stocks, like auto makers. And drug stocks have started to recover on hopes that Mr. Clinton will have trouble getting much of his health plan through.
Even if a small investor caught all these waves, the transaction costs could still practically wipe out his gains. As for getting in early when sentiment about a stock shifts, the little guy hasn't a chance. The first to learn of a stock analyst's change of mind are usually his firm's clients. Often, by the time news hits the press, investors have factored it into the stock price. When news reports do trigger a market response, the professional traders and big institutions are invariably the first to fire.
Many investors, including the professionals, respond by playing momentum, making the stock market one of the few where customers buy more when prices are raised, less when cut. Few researchers have found significant correlation between a stock's past and future performance, however.
In some respects, small investors are becoming more temperate in responding to the news. Instead of panicking and dumping stocks after market routs, they have often bought, damping the market's volatility.
The challenge is learning how to use the news and advice to your best advantage, making decisions that stand up over the longer term. For individual securities, distinguishing between the ephemeral and the lasting can stump the best professionals. As much as earnings surprises send stocks spinning, some research suggests that analysts under-respond, failing to adjust their earnings estimates sufficiently.
As for mutual funds, the publicity given to short-term performance can drown out other news that investors should know. Changes in management, which the Securities and Exchange Commission now requires mutual funds to disclose, should cause investors to ask whether they will continue to receive the same investment performance and style.
A manager's efforts to reverse a slump by shifting styles likewise can raise questions. After years of riding small technology stocks to attractive gains, the Robertson Stephens Emerging Growth Fund is now trying to overcome recent declines by looking at gold and energy stocks. "That is always kind of a red flag," said Kurt Brouwer, president of Brouwer & Janachowski investment advisers in San Francisco.
Some of the best picks among mutual funds, he said, come not among hot funds cheered by the news media but those whose sound, consistent investment practices are temporarily going unrewarded. He mentions the widely reported reversals at John Neff's Windsor Fund and Michael Price's Mutual Shares Fund, and their more recent turnarounds. "If you're looking at someone with a very strong record who is out of favor," he said, "you're probably going to buy in at a good time."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Pacific Rim Investments for the Long Haul

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The Van Eck Asia Dynasty fund is part of a flurry of new funds that are investing in the Pacific Rim countries to benefit from economic growth rates greater than those of the United States and other developed nations. The fund invests mainly in Hong Kong, with smaller investments in Taiwan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. While investments in emerging markets can be profitable, they are also risky.
Mutual fund investors can bet on the natural gas industry with Fidelity's Select Natural Gas Portfolio, which invests in companies that produce and distribute natural gas or that provide services or equipment to the industry. The fund's narrower focus may make it more volatile than Fidelity's Select Energy Portfolio. A 0.75 percent redemption fee applies to shares sold before 30 days; after that, the fee is 0.75 percent or $7.50, whichever is less. 
 The Janus Mercury Fund is an aggressive growth fund run by Warren Lammert, a protege of James Craig and Tom Marsico, who run Janus's successful Venture and Twenty Funds, among others. Like them, Mr. Lammert uses a bottom-up, fundamental approach to stock picking instead of betting on sectors that look promising. The fund is nondiversified, meaning it can own a big chunk of one issue. That means potentially bigger returns, but more risk.

HEADLINE: Consumer Index Is Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for June rose to 82.8, from 80.3 in May, suggesting more moderate economic growth in the months ahead, analysts said yesterday.
Even with the increase, the index remains below the post-election high of 91 set in December. 
 "We're not seeing any major improvement" in consumer confidence, said Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "We're still below the first-quarter" average of 87.3 for the Michigan index. That reading suggests economic growth of 2 to 3 percent pace in the months ahead.
The record high for the index, which the university releases to clients, is 97.9, set in January 1989. The record low is 63.9, in October 1990.

LENGTH: 477 words

HEADLINE: Campaign Finance Reform: Alive

 BODY:
The Senate's campaign finance reform bill isn't nearly as strong as the package recommended by President Clinton and Senate Democratic leaders. It leaves big holes that will need filling when the measure gets to conference with the House. That it passed at all, however, is a victory worth savoring. There was ferocious Republican opposition and stratospheric nervousness about campaign reform on both sides of the aisle.
Ignoring scandals and public disgust at corrupt and distracting campaign fund raising, Republicans have blocked meaningful change since 1974. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, deserves credit for breaking this gridlock with a difficult victory that keeps reform alive. Seven Republicans -- James Jeffords of Vermont, William Cohen of Maine, John Chafee of Rhode Island, Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Dave Durenberger of Minnesota and John McCain of Arizona -- provided the crucial votes needed to break the Republican filibuster. 
 But to win this support, Mr. Mitchell and the bill's chief Senate sponsor, David Boren of Oklahoma, had to agree to a devilish bargain, striking the bill's publicly financed communication vouchers. Vouchers to pay for media and mail will now be made available only as a "backup" when an opponent exceeds the spending limit. The seven swing Republicans thereby hurt underfunded challengers of both parties and preserved the power of fat-cat donors. They were also hypocritical; all but Senator Kassebaum had supported similar public-financing legislation in the past.
There's still much in the bill to like. Its spending limits and curbs on political action committees would greatly reduce the financial advantage that incumbents now enjoy over challengers, and eliminate millions in favor-seeking dollars from the system. Reduced-rate television time and mailings can only enhance campaign debate by making it easier for challengers to get their messages across. The bill also preserves the integrity of contribution limits, prohibits incumbents' free mass mailings in an election year and shuts down the soft-money loophole that left both parties' Presidential candidates beholden to a long list of $100,000 donors.
The fight now moves to the House, where there's a danger the Senate's retreat on public financing will give House members the excuse they crave to do the same. The House bill, with its lenient approach to PAC's and generous spending limits, is already too protective of incumbents and the corruptive status quo.
House Speaker Thomas Foley says he remains an "enthusiastic" supporter of public financing and even calls it "the royal road to fairness." He can show real leadership and do a real service by challenging the Senate and waging the same aggressive fight for public financing that he waged for the President's economic plan.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Family Preservation and Its Victims

BYLINE: By Patrick Murphy; Patrick Murphy is the Cook County Public Guardian. His office represents abused children and the disabled elderly.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Take any floor of a typical low-income housing project. In one apartment, there might be a single woman in her mid-20's with two kids, struggling on a meager welfare check to keep the kids dressed, clean and in school. Down the hall is a family of six. Despite months of looking, Mom works as a maid and Dad, unemployed, does a few odd jobs. At the end of the hall, there is a woman with three kids. She is a heavy crack cocaine user. Her present boyfriend is also her drug supplier, and when he gets angry he hits the kids. Sometimes they lock the kids in the apartment and go off for hours of partying.
The state decides to make life easier for one of these families. Which one? Under welfare laws in Illinois and other states, the mother doing drugs and allowing her boyfriend to belt the kids is the only one entitled to a free housekeeper up to five days a week. She can also receive up to $2,000 for a security deposit and the first month's rent on a new apartment, as well as furniture and up to $500 in cash. 
 So-called family preservation programs like this are in place in more than 30 states and receive more than $295 million in Federal funds a year. The Clinton Administration is seeking $1.4 billion for family preservation over the next five years. In Illinois, the Department of Children and Family Services spends $20 million a year on such programs.
Proponents of family preservation argue that it is cheaper for taxpayers and better for abused and neglected children to remain at home rather than be thrown into the often cruel foster care system. In some cases, this is true. But in most cases, giving services and money to parents who have abused their children does nothing but reward irresponsible and even criminal behavior.
How does it work in real life? In December 1991, the aunt of a 3-year-old girl told the family services department that her sister and her sister's lover had physically abused the child. State investigators confirmed the abuse: the child had bruises and rope burns on her body. Instead of bringing the case to court, the department provided a housekeeper and a social worker who between them went to the home a total of 37 times over the next 90 days. The housekeeper helped the mother clean up and make dinner. The social worker took her out for meals and shopping.
On March 7, 1992, the aunt telephoned the family services agency again, pleading that the child was still being abused. The agency ignored her. On March 17, the agency closed the case with a glowing report on how well the family was doing. Several hours later, the girl was dead. An autopsy revealed that boiling water had been poured on her genitals and that she had been struck on the head with a blunt instrument. Her body was covered with 43 scars, bruises and rope burns, most of which had been made in the previous few weeks. She weighed 17 pounds.
This is not an isolated incident. This spring, a drug abusing mother, who had been charged with criminal battery of her 2-year-old daughter, was given family preservation services after authorities found the girl and her 8-month-old brother eating out of dishes encrusted with rotten food and swarming with flies. Five days after the services began, the young boy was dead. Apparently the 2-year-old girl had tried to give him a bath while her mother slept into the afternoon, leaving them unattended.
In 1989, the Illinois Legislature commissioned a three-year study of the family preservation program by the University of Chicago. Last year, the researchers concluded that families receiving preservation funds were just as likely to have their children eventually placed in foster care as were families that received no funds. The report showed that the state was spending $20 million a year in an effort to save $2 million in foster-care expenses. Still, in the best tradition of bureaucracy, after the study was released the Department of Children and Family Services asked that the state expand the program.
The family preservation system is a continuation of sloppy thinking of the 1960's and 1970's that holds, as an unquestionable truth, that society should never blame a victim. Of course, the children are not considered the victims here. Rather the abusive parents are considered victims of poverty and addiction. This attitude is not only patronizing, it endangers children. The vast majority of poor parents do a decent job of raising their children under adverse conditions. In effect, the state is saying: Beat up or rape the kid next door and the government locks you up; beat up or rape your own kid and the government rushes in a housekeeper. What kind of message does this send?
Before more Federal money is turned over for these programs, the Government should demand that states prove they are effectively monitoring neglectful parents and can guarantee the safety of the children. Most importantly, we should insist that preservation services not be used to keep children with parents who have physically or sexually abused them.
There are alternatives. Many abused children have grandparents, aunts and uncles who can and do act as excellent foster parents. We should make it easier for these relatives to get public assistance if they take on the extra burden.
If there is no relative to care for the children, they should be placed in foster homes. If the parents straighten out their lives, they can reclaim the children. Indeed, the goal of reuniting their families should be an excellent incentive for parents to kick drug habits. Bribing abusive parents with housekeepers, cash and new apartments will only make them worse.

HEADLINE: Coup in Guatemala Nothing Like Peru's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Guatemala: Democracy Recouped?" (editorial, June 3), you presuppose an automatic similarity between the political process in Guatemala and Peru without attempting at least a cursory evaluation of the specific conditions in each country.
The outcome of events in Guatemala has already proved that the parallelism drawn was clearly wrong. President Alberto Fujimori of Peru has stated that the circumstances of the two countries are different, that the concrete situation of Peru does not lend itself to a facile comparison with any other country and that it should not serve as a model. He also stated that the destiny of Guatemala was, as it ought to be, in the hands of the Guatemalan people. 
 The depth and complexity of the crisis in Peru is unique in its magnitude and in the diversity of its manifestations. The response to this historic crisis since the election of the Peruvian President in 1990 has also been unique and, on the whole, successful. But the events that challenged Peru's capacity for sustained governance and led to a temporary adjustment in its political institutions last year have been overcome by newly elected democratic institutions, which have wide acceptance and clear legitimacy in Peru society and the international community.
It is in this context of democratic renewal that the modernization of the Peruvian economy and the growing success against the terrorist onslaught should be seriously assessed.
The assertion "that a white elite dominates an Indian and mixed-race majority" in a May 27 editorial also comparing Guatemala and Peru is simply a caricature to add to other groundless and negative references.
The so-called elite in Peru is, like the overwhelming majority of its society, the product of a fusion of races that began 500 years ago. Both white and Indian populations are relative minorities in relation to the "mestizo," the real protagonist of the political and social changes that have inverted the demographic topography of urban and rural Peru in less than a generation.
 
RICARDO V. LUNA
Ambassador of Peru
Washington, June 8, 1993

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber

 BODY:

BECOMING A MAN: Half a Life Story
By Paul Monette. HarperSanFrancisco, $12.
Winner of the 1992 National Book Award for nonfiction, this autobiography chronicles Paul Monette's struggle to accept his homosexuality after years spent hiding it. "His fine memoir is affirmative and ultimately celebratory," Wendy Martin said here last year.
A GOOD SCENT FROM A STRANGE MOUNTAIN
By Robert Olen Butler. Penguin, $10.
Robert Olen Butler was an Army linguist in Vietnam and his experience infuses his first collection of short fiction, which won the 1993 Pulitzer Prize. All 15 stories are told from the point of view of a Vietnamese emigrant to the American Gulf Coast, where his or her sense of loss is less a result of the war than of cultural displacement. Last year our reviewer, George Packer, praised the stories' originality, calling them "the work of a writer who is intoxicated by Vietnam and the Vietnamese, who loves what has alienated so many other Americans." 
 AFTER HENRY
By Joan Didion. Vintage International, $12.
These essays cover wide terrain, from Presidential politics to urban violence to the author's feelings regarding the death of her editor, Henry Robbins. "Joan Didion writes well," Hendrik Hertzberg said here last year. "More often than not, she writes beautifully."
COLLABORATORS
By Janet Kauffman. Graywolf, $11.
This novel concerns a young woman's almost suffocatingly close relationship with her mother. Writing in the Book Review in 1986, Ursula Hegi praised Janet Kauffman's "extraordinary gift for language and character development. . . . She brings a poet's sensitivity to her prose."
IN MORTAL COMBAT: Korea, 1950-1953
By John Toland. Quill/Morrow, $13.
The Korean War was, in its own time, as unpopular as the one in Vietnam years later. But, argues the military historian John Toland, it may prove to have been the deciding element in the chain of events that eventually unraveled Communism. "Mr. Toland's rendition is panoramic, gripping and, to a remarkable degree, original in its insights," Nicholas Eberstadt said here in 1991. In KOREA: The First War We Lost, by Bevin Alexander (Hippocrene, $16.95), the author takes a different view, asserting that the United States triumphed over North Korea but failed to curb Chinese strength. In 1986 our reviewer, Richard Halloran, found the book "well researched and readable." For an in-depth look at China's role, there is THE DAY THE CHINESE ATTACKED: Korea, 1950, by Edwin P. Hoyt (Athena/Paragon House, $12.95), which also evaluates the state of Chinese-American relations through the 1980's.
LET THE DEAD BURY THEIR DEAD: And Other Stories
By Randall Kenan. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $10.95.
In these interrelated short stories, Randall Kenan continues the saga of the residents of Tims Creek, the tiny, mostly black North Carolina hamlet he brought to life in his first novel, "A Visitation of Spirits." Last year our reviewer, Howard Frank Mosher, called the collection "nothing short of a wonder-book."
THE REAL THING: Stories and Sketches
By Doris Lessing. Harper Perennial, $11.
The pieces in this collection include keenly observed glimpses of contemporary London life as well as short stories that illuminate its emotional underside. Last year our reviewer, Eils Lotozo, said that the author continues to write with the "freshness and wonder of one newly arrived on the planet."
THE PATRON SAINT OF LIARS
By Ann Patchett. Ivy, $5.99.
In Ann Patchett's first novel, a pregnant young woman enters a Catholic home for unwed mothers not because she lacks a husband, but because she lacks a meaningful life. Last year our reviewer, Alice McDermott, called the book a "made-up story of an enchanted place. A fairy tale. A delight."
AMERICAN PLACES: A Writer's Pilgrimage to 15 of This Country's Most Visited and Cherished Sites
By William Zinsser. Harper Perennial, $10.
William Zinsser's itinerary included Disneyland and Rockefeller Center, along with less frequently celebrated locales like Abilene, Kan. (Dwight Eisenhower's hometown). "Mr. Zinsser personalizes each place, giving its history and adding his own keen observations," Herbert Mitgang said in The New York Times last year.
DAUGHTERS OF ALBION
By A. N. Wilson. Penguin, $10.
This is the third in A. N. Wilson's "Lampitt Papers" novels, a saga that revolves around, among other things, the possible murder of a famous historian by his biographer. Last year our reviewer, Joel Conarroe, found the book "an odd hybrid, revealing characteristics not only of the academic detective tale but also of the comedy of manners . . . and the novel of ideas."
HEAD TO HEAD: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe, and America
By Lester Thurow. Warner, $12.99.
The United States will probably lose this war, warns Lester Thurow, an economist, unless it is prepared to make radical changes. Last year our reviewer, Adam Smith, found the author's solutions debatable but described him as "a cogent analyst and an excellent interpreter of economic doctrine."
BOOTLEGGER'S DAUGHTER
By Margaret Maron. Mysterious Press/Warner, $4.99.
The daughter is Deborah Knott, the attorney heroine of Margaret Maron's latest mystery series, who is asked to investigate an 18-year-old murder case. "The country air encourages plot as well as plant growth," Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: Small-Town Smart Alecks

BYLINE: By Francine Prose; Francine Prose's new collection of stories, "The Peaceable Kingdom," will be published in the fall.

 BODY:

NOBODY'S FOOL
By Richard Russo.
549 pp. New York:
Random House. $23. 
 YEARS ago, when I felt that the world weighed too heavily on my shoulders and believed (as only the young do) that the world would not willingly let me go, I used to dream of disappearing to some remote upstate New York town and checking in, a permanent guest, at its crumbling bleak hotel. Such towns, which I imagined to be off the edge of the map, are very much at the center of Richard Russo's fictional geography. His ambitious new novel, "Nobody's Fool," is set in North Bath, N.Y., a fractionally less blighted version of the blue-collar dead end where his earlier novels, "Mohawk" and "The Risk Pool," take place.
North Bath is the sort of community we might drive through without pausing, except to fantasize roomier lives for ourselves in its "aging clapboard Victorians and sprawling Greek Revivals that would have been worth some money if they were across the border in Vermont." But Mr. Russo encourages us to stop and look around; he shows us that what seems static is churning, underneath. And one soon realizes that no sensible person would go to North Bath to disappear, since life there, as Balzac wrote of the provinces, is lived entirely in public.
Perhaps that's the reason that small towns, like seagoing vessels, have always suited fiction: manageable little pressure cookers with a fixed cast of characters, whose lack of privacy and enforced proximity may cause the plot to boil over. What's turned up the heat in North Bath is the possibility that a theme park, to be called the Ultimate Escape, may be built there, and may breathe some economic life into the moribund former spa. Once a thriving resort, the town has declined steadily since 1868, "when the unthinkable began to happen and the various mineral springs, one by one, without warning or apparent reason, began, like luck, to dry up, and with them the town's wealth and future."
It's autumn 1984 and North Bath is "still waiting for its luck to change," but one senses its luck would need a fairly dramatic reversal to much affect the fortunes of Sully, Donald Sullivan, the novel's incorrigible and engaging hero: "Throughout his life a case study underachiever, Sully -- people still remarked -- was nobody's fool, a phrase that Sully no doubt appreciated without ever sensing its literal application -- that at 60, he was divorced from his own wife, carrying on halfheartedly with another man's, estranged from his son, devoid of self-knowledge, badly crippled and virtually unemployable -- all of which he stubbornly confused with independence."
Sixty years have knocked Sully from one part of North Bath to another, from his violent father's house to the rooms he rents now from the elderly Miss Beryl Peoples, his former teacher. A painful knee injury has him working odd jobs, off the books.
Sully is a partly domesticated, slightly maddened bear, feinting and jabbing at the center of the book's many subplots and hard-luck characters. His estranged lover, Ruth, has a husband she despises and a daughter whose own husband is trying to kill her. Sully's son, Peter, has serious marital troubles, two difficult children, a crazily possessive mother, a sick stepfather -- and he's been denied tenure at the small college where he teaches. Miss Beryl has been getting lost on her excursions around town, and she is compelled to fend off the grabby, selfish meddling of her banker son, Clive Jr. -- one of the main boosters of the Ultimate Escape. Even Sully's best friend, Rub (he's too dim to find trouble to get into), is undone by his wife's late-blooming kleptomania.
One wants to congratulate Mr. Russo for what he avoids. "Nobody's Fool" never slides into the corn-pone hokiness so often found in novels of small-town life, fiction in which the rural setting is either a Walker Evans photo or Dogpatch. In these books, the characters talk as if they were auditioning for the Henry Fonda part in "The Grapes of Wrath." But dialogue is what Mr. Russo does best, and the fun of this novel is in hearing these guys (and women) talk, giving one another a hard time -- they're funny, quick and inventive. (The novel's tone has the same low-key, smart-alecky intelligence as its characters.)
THESE people all have inner lives (you'd have to, in North Bath) and a range of expertise. They're capable of combining hard labor with metaphysical speculation: "Maybe sheetrocking wasn't one of Sully's favorite jobs, but like most physical labor, there was a rhythm to it that you could find if you cared to look. . . . Rhythm was what Sully had counted on over the long years -- that and the wisdom to understand that no job, no matter how thankless or stupid or backbreaking, could not be gotten through. The clock moved if you let it."
Like his characters, Mr. Russo deals with interesting themes (he'd have to, in all these pages): change and stasis, free will and obligation, luck, responsibility, forgiveness -- the bonds of community, friendship and family. He offers us apt observations of human types, human behavior. Here, for example, Sully's grandson reminds Sully of the boy's father: "Peter had been the same way, an almost comatose kid, it had seemed to Sully. If you didn't tell him to open a door, he'd just stand in front of it. At the time it had not occurred to Sully that the reason might be fear. The fear of doing the wrong thing. It seemed obvious now."
Having praised the novel, one has to say that it's not a consistent pleasure. Some characters are simply mistakes -- Peter's grad-student nympho girlfriend, for example. Near the ending, we feel Mr. Russo snipping and lining up the plot threads; we know where, and how neatly, the right knots will be tied. The Ultimate Escape park is built elsewhere because folks in North Bath are "funny-looking . . . like some failed genetic experiment." But, except for Clive Jr., no one minds very much. There's a sentimental pulling back from the exigencies of these lives as bittersweet music swells behind a warming vision of father-son reunion. A final grace note extends this beneficent spirit even to a semi-paralyzed Doberman pinscher, "its nub of a tail twitching in what -- who could know? -- just might be contentment."
More problematic is the novel's length. It's never exactly unreadable, and a lot does happen: punches are thrown, trucks and marriages wrecked, there's litigation, death. But at times it's maddening; you want to stick a pin in the novel and watch the subplots leak out. The observed asides and set pieces are among the best sections in the book, which requires a pace that's loose enough to accommodate the slow spots. Still, there's too much of a good thing -- too many mini-biographies of walk-on characters, too many points of view, too many idle hours at the OTB parlor and the diner. You wish Mr. Russo had been tougher in editing his book.
It makes the experience of reading "Nobody's Fool" a little like spending time in North Bath. Mostly you're curious and pleased, glad for a chance to eavesdrop and see into these lives, these souls. Then, after a while, you begin to fear that you'll never get out of this place alive. But as the end of your stay approaches, you feel a premature nostalgia -- you'll miss the town, especially Sully -- and you look around fondly, regretfully, as you speed up and drive on through.

HEADLINE: America Out of Reach

BYLINE: By Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:

DECLINING FORTUNES
The Withering of the American Dream.
By Katherine S. Newman.
257 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $23. 
 THE great strategic insight of the Clinton campaign was the recognition that America's middle class was in turmoil, terrified that the ordered suburban existence it considered its birthright was slipping away. The principal political flaw of the Clinton Administration so far may be its failure to maintain that focus in day-to-day policy making.
It is easy for elites, liberal and otherwise, to move on to other things in nonelection years, to issues less prosaic than homeownership, job security and educational opportunity. But Katherine S. Newman, in "Declining Fortunes," makes a persuasive case that middle-class anger and middle-class fear will run deep in American politics for some time to come. In a New Jersey suburb that she gives the pseudonym Pleasanton, Ms. Newman goes beneath the poll numbers and glib generalities that color so much political discussion, and gives a poignant portrait of how broad economic trends affect individual lives.
That the 72 million Americans born between 1946 and 1964 -- the so-called baby boomers -- represent "the first generation since the Great Depression that can expect to have a lower standard of living than its parents" is not a new insight. But Ms. Newman, whose previous books include "Falling From Grace: The Experience of Downward Mobility in the American Middle Class," does not make the mistake of treating the boomers as a monolithic victim class. In fact, she argues that the sharp differences among them are what keep them from becoming the potent political force that their parents became -- and remain. The older boomers view the younger as "hopelessly materialistic . . . utterly lacking in commitment," she writes. Younger boomers "often look over their shoulders at the flower-power generation as . . . people whose attitudes were fine for their own time but out of step with today's realities." The clash of culture and values obscures shared economic interests.
Based on interviews with about 60 families who were promised confidentiality to protect their privacy, "Declining Fortunes" tells the story of a community that was wide open to the World War II generation of upwardly mobile urban emigrants, but that, in an era of wage stagnation and enormous increases in real-estate values, is out of reach for their children. The fact that many of these children have educations and professional credentials that surpass their parents' only makes their troubles more perplexing to them.
Ms. Newman, an anthropologist who teaches at Columbia University, is particularly good on the boomers' dispossession. The men and women who moved to Pleasanton after World War II sit tight, amazed at the value their homes have acquired, but yearning for the children and grandchildren driven out into a kind of suburban diaspora, unable to afford to live where they grew up. She also shows how some of the basic beliefs of the postwar era -- that all things come to those who work hard and "wait their turn," for example -- obscure the fact that Government actions, from low-interest home mortgages to the G.I. Bill of Rights, helped create the vast middle class of the 1950's.
Such beliefs, of course, have important political ramifications for an Administration trying to make the case (however intermittently) that there is a role for Government in helping this new generation of middle-class Americans. Do Pleasanton's baby boomers want too much, too soon, as many of their parents seem to think? Or do they deserve a hand, like national service programs to help pay for their children's educations?
MS. NEWMAN gives a far more sympathetic portrayal of the baby boomers than they usually get. Yes, they had privileged childhoods, but many spend their adulthoods trying to duplicate -- with two careers -- the style of life their parents enjoyed on one.
They put off having children, sometimes with much regret, or have fewer children than they want. And the women "worry -- a lot -- about the consequences for their children of their absence from the home," Ms. Newman writes. The women who came of age with the feminist movement find staying at home with their children a luxury that is out of reach. "Isn't that ironic?" one boomer says. "The deal was going to be that you didn't have to stay home. Now it's like you can't stay home if you wanted to."
It is such voices, and the voices of the boomers' parents, that give "Declining Fortunes" much of its power. In fact, the reader is left hungry for more texture, more detail on the residents of Pleasanton, particularly how this generation's turmoil affects its views on the issues percolating through politics today. One wants to hear more, for example, about how boomers who feel their own childbearing choices are limited react to "the new paternalism" that attempts to regulate the behavior of mothers on welfare; one suspects they are not appalled.

HEADLINE: Airborne Spirits Lose Altitude

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES; WILLIAM GRIMES, a culture reporter for The Times, is the author of "Straight Up or on the Rocks" (Simon & Schuster).

 BODY:
WAVE farewell to the three-martini flight. The days of the airplane as a flying cocktail lounge are pretty much over, as health-conscious passengers and business travelers on tight schedules forgo cocktails and cognacs in favor of a little wine or water.
Overall consumption of alcohol on planes is down, with a decline of about 10 to 15 percent a year for the last several years at most airlines, according to food and beverage managers at major domestic and foreign carriers. Passengers who do drink spirits tend to drink vodka, but most others are ordering beer or wine or water. 
 Back in the good old days, recalled Peter Nixon, manager of wine and beverage development at British Airways, in the late 1970's when he started working in cabin service for the airline, the 20 passengers in first class would go through four bottles of whisky on a typical trans-Atlantic flight. "Now you have one," he said, "and that's still half-full when you land."
The airlines do not make it easy to put the drinks picture in focus. In fact, it's as murky as a Pernod and water. Some, like British Airways and Trans World Airlines, can provide fairly detailed information on beverage purchases and drinking trends. Others supply only anecdotal information. And caterers at Air France claim they don't have any information on beverage consumption at all.
Even with good record-keeping, assessing the trend is difficult, since consumer behavior depends on such factors as the length and time of the flight, the destination and the nationality of the traveler.
The airlines themselves find it all a bit confusing. T.W.A., facing a 15 percent decline in drinks sales in each of the last six years (with consumption holding steady in first class and business class, where the drinks are free), ran a test on selected flights for a week three months ago, reducing by $1 the price of its drinks from the industry-standard $4 for spirits and $3 for beer.
"Average sales per passenger did not decline," said Stan Henderson, the airline's director of in-flight services operations. While this test proved that the lower price halted the general decline, another one showed that a price change reversed the trend. "We ran a test on another set of flights in which we charged a flat $2 for all drinks," he added, "and consumption of soft drinks went down 5 percent, while beer and liquor sales per passenger went up 10 percent."
Encouraged, T.W.A. adopted the $2 policy system-wide. But so far this year, the airline is still down 15 percent in sales, according to Mr. Henderson, who speculated that the ban on smoking may have something to do with the results. "A lot of people have to have a cigarette if they drink," he said. "Also, there are more hub flights on T.W.A. now, and so there are more short flights, and more flights that start before 2 P.M."
Vodka, which mixes easily with fruit juice and soda, has come on strong in the past 10 years and now accounts for about half the airborne spirits market on domestic flights, said food and beverage managers at several airlines. Scotch accounts for about a third, and the rest of the pie is made up of very slim slices of rum, gin, bourbon, brandy and assorted liqueurs, such as Amaretto and Kahlua, with Bailey's Irish Cream, a whisky-based liqueur, a strong up-and-comer in recent years. "With Bailey's," said Gary Franson, director of food services for Northwest Airlines, "the volume is so high we almost don't think of it as belonging to the liqueur category."
Like his counterparts at other airlines, Mr. Franson theorized that increasing numbers of businesswomen account for the Bailey's boom.
On international flights, national drinking preferences can skew the totals. The British still prefer gin to vodka. On Alitalia, vodka and Scotch dominate the spirits, but passengers order a fair amount of Punt e Mes, a bitter aperitif, Peroni beer and Vecchia Romagna brandy. Rum sells well on flights to the Caribbean, but when Delta Airlines test-marketed margaritas on its Mexico City flights, response was weak. The strongly international clientele did not share the American love for cactus juice.
According to Mr. Nixon of British Airways, his airline uses more vodka and bourbon on North American routes than on others. "In Europe, where we have more British passengers, we use more gin," he explained, "and we use more whisky and cognac on the Far Eastern routes."
Brand preference is difficult to gauge, since airline pasengers are a captive audience, and space limits mean that only a couple of brands can be stocked in any category. Beverage managers have decided that it's better to be deep than to be broad when stocking spirits.
The big news, however, is not in spirits but in wine, which is on the upswing, even as overall consumption of wine in the United States declined by 10 percent between 1980 and 1990. "One of the most significant trends is the increased popularity of red wines, because of that '60 Minutes' program," said Bob Sobczewski, manager of food and beverage planning at United Airlines. The TV program, broadcast in November 1991 and repeated in July 1992, presented recent findings by medical researchers that a glass or two of red wine each day reduces the risk of heart attack by lowering cholesterol levels. Overnight, wine store owners and the airlines registered a sharp increase in the demand for red wine.
"We recently increased the red wine we carry in coach, and we can't seem to stock enough," said Mr. Henderson of T.W.A. "At the moment we serve all wine from splits in coach, but we're seriously considering going to fifths." (A split is a single-serving 187-milliliter bottle.) In the three years that Alitalia has been serving wine free in the back as well as the front of the plane, consumption has tripled.
The airlines have become more innovative in drawing up wine lists for their first-class and business customers, and in a classic case of trickle-down economics, coach passengers, now limited to mass-produced screw-cap chardonnays and cabernets, may soon reap the benefits enjoyed by their more fortunate fellow passengers.
Delta recently hired the wine writer Anthony Dias Blue as a consultant. Instead of purchasing wine for the entire system, Delta has divided the United States into four regions, each with a different wine list, a practice that allows the airline to buy wines from smaller producers.
"We've looked for wines with assertive varietal character," said Mr. Blue. "Not airline-type wines, but restaurant wines." Recent purchases include a sauvignon blanc by Hanna, a California winery that produces only 15,000 cases yearly. For the first time in five years, wine consumption on Delta is up, although Denise Poole, the system manager for food and beverages at the airlines, said she did not know by how much. "We expected to have the wines on for three to four months," said Mr. Blue, "but we ran through them in a month."
British Airways relies on a powerhouse tasting team for its wine list: Colin Anderson, who holds the title of Master of Wine, conferred by the Institute of Masters of Wine in London; Hugh Johnson, the British wine writer, and Michael Broadbent, head of the wine department at Christie's in London.
The airline's policy of stocking wines native to the country of destination is in force on flights to the United States, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa and will soon be extended to South American flights, which will carry Chilean wines, and short-haul trips to Spain and Germany.
"About four years ago we were using 250,000 cases of wine a year," said Mr. Nixon. "Now we go through 340,000 cases. There have been more passengers, but not enough to account for that kind of increase."
THE problem for beverage managers is that boutique wineries cannot afford to supply wine in the splits that airlines serve in coach, so imagination runs up against an economic wall. One solution is to pour from full-size bottles, as T.W.A. is considering doing. That's messier and more time-consuming. At Delta, Mr. Blue has begun approaching mid-sized wineries, like Wente Brothers in California, to supply splits with a bit more character than the usual airplane wines. Whether passengers will recognize the difference, and reach for their wallets, remains to be seen.
The wine boom on planes presents another problem. Unfortunately for the airlines, when passengers give up spirits, they drink bigger. The tiny mini of bourbon takes up a fraction of the space required by a single-serving bottle of wine, beer or designer water. So the crunch is on.
"We're getting more and more requests for nonalcoholic beer, so we're running a test to see what kind of demand is out there," said Ms. Poole of Delta. "But we're cautious about committing because of space limits."
Shall there be no more cakes and ale? There certainly shall. That's why they invented Las Vegas. With the same trend-resistance that made Wayne Newton king, the city attracts a different kind of flier, the kind that still cannot believe that anyone would pay money to drink water. "We have to put twice as many liquor kits on board for that group," said Ms. Poole of the airline's Las Vegas flights.
It's somehow reassuring to know that somewhere up there, at 30,000 feet, at least someone is having a high old time.
