HEADLINE: FILM;
Seen the One Where Arnold Sells Noodles?

BYLINE: By LAUREN DAVID PEDEN; Lauren David Peden writes about entertainment for Us magazine and the Ladies' Home Journal.

 BODY:
Americans abroad will not have to wait for the foreign release of "Last Action Hero" or "Sliver" to see Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sharon Stone this summer. All they'll have to do is turn on the television and wait for an ad.
Along with earning millions from summer blockbusters, stars reap additional benefits from commercials shown in foreign countries. Not surprisingly, American celebrities who reluctantly endorse products at home are only too happy to appear in ads abroad. 
 In Italy, Kim Basinger models hosiery, while Woody Allen has written and directed a series of commercials for the country's largest grocery chain, Co-op Italia. Ms. Stone stars in one racy ad for Pirelli Tires and another for Freixenet champagne in Europe.
Nowhere are celebrity ads more prevalent than in Japan. Mr. Schwarzenegger can be seen pitching Nissin Cup Noodle and Chi Chin vitamin drink. Turn on a television or flip through a magazine and you're likely to spot Harrison Ford hawking Hondas, Bruce Willis selling Subarus, Demi Moore pushing cosmetics, Tom Berenger smoking Larks and Sylvester Stallone eating baked ham.
Why do stars endorse such products on foreign shores but not at home? "There are still those film stars who you're just not going to see doing a product endorsement here in the States," says Noreen Jenney, president of Celebrity Endorsement Network, a California company that represents advertisers seeking stars. "They think it's selling out. But when you make the kind of money they make doing it, and nobody knows you do it, that's a different story."
Ms. Stone, for instance, received between $1 million and $2 million for her Pirelli endorsement, and Mr. Allen was reportedly paid from $1.5 million to $5 million for the Co-op Italia ads.
Before the Japanese economy took a nosedive, American actors routinely made millions there: Gene Hackman and Kevin Costner each received $1 million to represent Kirin beer. Today's foreign ads typically pay from $250,000 to $600,000 for a couple of days work in New York or Los Angeles.
As for what Mr. Schwarzenegger earns, all lips are sealed. But he's obviously being paid enough to look silly. In his Chi Chin vitamin drink series, he's seen carrying an ancient Asian woman on his back; then the shot changes and she's seen carrying him (presumably after downing some Chi Chin). In another ad, Mr. Schwarzenegger -- done up in a too-tight suit, slicked-down hair and horn rims -- is harassed in the subway by an angry mob. He drinks some Chi Chin and -- presto! -- the walls of the subway fall away to reveal a pumped-up Arnold, dressed in black and ready for action.
For Takeda Pharmaceutical, he's seen straddling a rocket that blasts off and shoots him out of the frame; in a Cup Noodle ad, he's dressed in a kimono, with a dish of noodles on a table in front of him: He just stands there, smiling and making weird, mimelike hand motions.
"The Japanese do very unique commercials," says Stephen Carbone, an executive vice president at International Creative Management. "They're ofttimes very oblique, and the actor or actress has fun with them."
It is Mr. Schwarzenegger's willingness to entertain that has made him the leader of the ad pack, according to Hal Lifson, a consultant at Dentsu Advertising in Los Angeles, the agency responsible for many of the Japanese celebrity ads. "Certain actors are unwilling to do certain things," he explains. "They're just not willing to bend their own rules. Schwarzenegger, because of 'Twins,' has a softer image in Japan than Stallone, and he became the hot ticket. Stallone was always viewed as the prototypical American 'Hawk' character -- Hercules. And Hercules is not really comedic and self-deprecating."
On Japanese television, Bruce Willis spoofs his action-movie image by crashing through a plate-glass window, rolling on the floor and swinging from a chandelier and onto a food-laden table before quenching his thirst with a bottle of Post Water, a mineral water.
Japan Airlines has featured Richard Gere singing Bob Marley's "No Woman, No Cry." Jodie Foster, in a Honda ad, flirts with a group of men to the tune of the Fine Young Cannibals' "She Drives Me Crazy."
While Japanese ads may lose something in translation, European ads have more universal (read: American) appeal. In Ms. Stone's Pirelli ad, the star steps off an airplane and into a waiting car. The handsome young driver watches in the rear-view mirror as she removes her sunglasses, then her scarf, earrings and jacket. When she tells him to pull over (or so we imagine, since there's no dialogue), he stops the car and nervously loosens his tie. Then he gets into the back seat, and she climbs behind the wheel. The tagline ("If you're going to drive, drive") flashes as they exchange a look in the mirror.
"Pirelli's brand image is very Italian, quite sexy," says Tim Lindsay of Young & Rubicam in London, the agency that did the ad. "We chose Sharon Stone because of who she is -- very sexy, grown up, in control."
The stars commonly have nondisclosure clauses in their contracts, specifying that the ads cannot be shown -- or sometimes even discussed -- outside the country for which they were intended. ("Entertainment Tonight" has, nonetheless, broadcast some clips from the commercials.) Actors "believe that knowledge of that endorsement should stay within that country," says Rick Hersh, worldwide head of commercials at the William Morris agency.
Mr. Lifson concurs: "Generally, big stars are not interested in being positioned as a spokesperson, because it's not viewed as a creative endeavor. It's viewed as a cash-in, cash-out capitalistic maneuver. And, to the performer, that's not an acceptable way to make money, because they're not acting in these commercials, they're endorsing."
Ah, yes, but they're acting on the inside.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
For Car Renters, The News Is Bad

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
AUTO renters who have been saving the cost of a collision damage waiver because a credit card or charge card provided this protection will need to take a close look at any new rules coming from their credit card company or bank. The protection may be disappearing.
American Express and the Visa card and Mastercard issued by Chase Manhattan Bank are cutting back. American Express is limiting the number of companies in the United States where its card will provide a C.D.W. alternative, and has eliminated coverage in Italy and New Zealand. The Chase Bank's standard Visa and Mastercards will no longer provide a C.D.W. alternative at all. 
 "Cost-effectiveness" and "redirection of enhancement efforts" were cited by the card issuing companies; still more reductions may be ahead.
The new changes on the Chase-issued cards do not affect the gold cards, only the standard or "classic" Visa or Mastercards issued by Chase. As of June 30, these cards will no longer provide repayment plans equivalent to the collision damage waiver in the event the rental car is stolen or damaged. Visa and Mastercard have always left it to the issuing bank to decide whether to provide this benefit, and Citicorp, the biggest issuer of these cards, with 20 million standard cards estimated in use, never provided it. Chase, the second-largest issuer, will not disclose its numbers, but Kevin T. Higgins, editor of Card Industry Directory in Chicago, puts the number of standard Chase Visa cards and Mastercards at 11.5 million.
At the same time, Chase is dropping free card insurance that provided a benefit of $50,000 in the event a card holder was accidentally killed or dismembered when traveling on a bus, train, ship or scheduled airline. Card "enhancements" like these were heavily promoted by credit and charge cards in the 80's when high interest rates would pay the premium. American Express estimated the C.D.W. cost at $1.25 for each card-holder annually.
 
15 Rental Companies
 American Express took action to restrict the rental-car coverage provided on standard, gold and Optima cards other than those provided to employees of big corporations. Bill Moss, an American Express spokesman, estimated that 21 million cards would be affected. The changes are effective Aug. 1.
The major change limited the domestic use of American Express Car Rental Loss and Damage Insurance to rentals from 15 major companies in the United States and its territories. The 15 companies are:
Advantage, Agency, Alamo, Avis, Budget, Dollar, Enterprise, Hertz, Inter American, National, Payless, Rent-a-Wreck, Snappy, Thrifty and Value.
Mr. Moss said 95 percent of all rentals charged to American Express were through these agencies. The rub is that in smaller places, where a local auto sales lot or a leasing company may be the only game in town, the American Express card-holder is in the same fix as someone without the card. Jan M. Armstrong, executive vice president of the American Car Rental Association, said smaller companies would be hard hit, and that the group would have preferred that American Express simply eliminate the coverage. Gary Rubin, editor of Auto Rental News, affiliated with the association, said the 15 companies represented 33 percent of the 26,291 rental locations in the United States.
Those who own a car and maintain collision and theft coverage on it are usually covered at the same level when they rent a car in the United States. The card typically covers the deductible and any difference in value between the new rental car and the renter's own car. This is known as secondary coverage. For those who do not own cars, and therefore have no car insurance, the card coverage is primary, meaning it reimburses the renter for any money paid for damage or loss of the auto.
As before, to activate the card coverage, the renter must charge the rental on the card and decline the rental company's collision damage waiver, under whatever name it is offered.
American Express also added while taking away, improving its domestic C.D.W. coverage providing, of course, that the rental is at one of the listed agencies. Formerly, the coverage was limited to 15 consecutive days; this has been extended to 31 days. Four-wheel-drive sports-utility vehicles were formerly excluded. Now, American Express says, the insurance will cover "four-wheel drive vehicles, including but not limited to Jeep Renegade, Jeep Cherokee, Chevrolet Blazer, Ford Bronco and Suzuki Samurai," but only when driven on paved roads.
 
Overseas Cuts
 American Express has also cut back on its protections for certain auto-renters overseas: As of Aug. 1, it will provide no coverage for travelers who rent in Italy or New Zealand. The rental companies in Italy, according to Avis, Hertz and National, have been suffering rising losses through auto theft, and the credit card companies were sharing in these losses. The losses were apparently outstripping the car rental companies' yield through the sale of waivers, so what amounts to a surcharge on a surcharge was devised. In January 1993, auto rental companies operating in Italy agreed to require that renters buy a separate theft-protection policy, which costs 16,500 lire a day, or $11, for a car in the middle range, and 22,500 lire a day, or $15, for a bigger car.
The credit card coverage could still be used for the collision part of the coverage in Italy, but when this was done, the rental agency often put a "hold" on the card, effectively freezing $5,000 to $14,000 in available credit, depending on the value of the car. For people operating with one card, it often seemed easier to pay for the C.D.W., since it did not tie up their cards' credit.
Summarizing this from the standpoint of American Express, Mr. Moss said the common practice in Italy of requiring the customer to buy the C.D.W. or put down a huge cash deposit meant "we were offering something useless."
The New Zealand situation is different, and American Express said that regulations there made its coverage moot, so customers are being notified accordingly. According to Kim Wong of the New Zealand Tourism Office in Santa Monica, Calif., New Zealand car rental agencies have never accepted card coverage in lieu of the C.D.W. All car renters are required to buy insurance costing the equivalent of $7 to $8 a day, depending on the company, she said. In addition, they must present a deposit, known as a "damage excess," of $325 to $400 in cash, traveler's checks or credit-card charge, refundable upon the safe return of the car, or must pay a further daily fee of $2.75 to $3.25. Car renters with the American Express card clearly assumed that waiver of the damage excess was to be refused, but if they were in an accident, sought a repayment of the deposit. Mr. Moss said that actually the purchase of the insurance invalidated the card coverage, but the situation was creating great confusion.
The gold card C.D.W. coverage by Visa, Mastercard and Diners Club had not changed as of June 14. In a time of apparent flux, however, anyone planning to refuse a waiver and use credit card coverage should call the information number given in the card literature.

HEADLINE: Town-House Sales Pick Up as Their Prices Fall Off

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
LIKE those of much of the New York residential real estate market, the sale prices of one-family town houses in Greenwich Village, the Upper East Side and other prime Manhattan neighborhoods have been, for the most part, falling for the last five years.
The decline, however, has now left prices at what some real estate brokers believe are bargain levels and, according to several recently released reports, has prompted a small resurgence in sales in some parts of the city, particularly on the Upper East Side. 
 There were, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, 55 one-family town houses sold in Manhattan in 1992, compared with 54 in 1991 and 42 in 1990.
Sotheby's International Realty, which tracks town-house sales in Manhattan south of 96th Street, recorded an 11.1 percent increase in the sale of one- and two-family houses, to 70 in 1992 from 63 in 1991.
Sales volume in dollars, according to the Sotheby's report, increased 2.7 percent,to $111 million from from $108 million.
The average sale price, though, declined 7 percent, to $1.59 million from $1.71 million.
Kathryn A. Korte, a vice president at Sotheby's, attributed the increase in sales more to realistic pricing than to a surge of interest from foreign buyers, who are often unable to buy co-op apartments, commercial users, such as physicians, or foreign missions and consulates.
"A lot of these properties have been on the market for some time," she said. "Over the past few years they have gone for 75 to 80 percent of the asking prices."
Ms. Korte said that the sales volume was particularly strong among town houses priced under $1 million. She said that sales of these homes made up almost 50 percent of the total sales in 1992, compared to 38 percent for 1991.
She also said that the number of town homes sold this year was likely to surpass last year's total. "The number of sales we have achieved so far this year is more than we had at this time last year," she said.
"The average are in the $2 million or so range," she added.
Ms. Korte also said that most of the activity was on the Upper East Side and the least in the East 30's and 40's -- Murray Hill and Turtle Bay.
"In general, we are pleased," she said. "We have a lot of buyers looking for the right place and the right price."
CLARK HALSTEAD, president of the Halstead Property Company, noted that on the Upper East Side, where most of the city's one-family town houses are, there were 10 sales in the first five months of 1993 compared to five in the same period in 1992.
He said there were 32 town-housesales for all of 1992 on the Upper East Side, attributing this to a belief by buyers that prices had bottomed out and that there were many good buys on the market.
He also said that, apart from the more favorable economy, particularly the lower mortgage interest rates, the rising number of sales was evidence that, despite the growing popularity of lofts -- which are configured horizontally -- multi-level town-house living continued to have strong appeal in a city where buyers paid a premium for space.
Most of the town houses sold on the Upper East Side this year are about 3,500 square feet.
"It seems to be much stronger in terms of the number of deals," he said.
The largest sale in 1992 was of a town house at 44 East 71st Street for $10.8 million. The 11,900-square-foot home, which has a swimming pool and garage, was sold to the Korean Mission for use by the Korean ambassador.
Mr. Halstead added that the median sale price of town houses on the Upper East Side fell 4.6 percent, to $1.42 million, for the first five months of 1993 from $1.49 million for all of 1992. He also said that the median price per square foot was $354 in 1993, as opposed to $450 in 1992.
The most expensive town house in square footage was 17 East 92d Street, which sold this year for $536 a square foot or $2.8 million, according to Mr. Halstead. In 1992, the most expensive town house, 178 East 64th Street, sold for $1,000 a square foot or $3 million.
Sales prices have been especially weak for the few new buildings that have been built.
For example, a new town house at 16 East 85th Street, on the Upper East Side, was sold this year for $3.2 million, the highest price paid for a town house this year.
The owner, however, had originally asked for $6 million.
The home, which is one of two new town-homes that were built side by side, was designed by Gwathmey Siegel and Associates, an architectural firm best known for its vacation homes in the Hamptons.
ANOTHER new development, Greenwich Mews, at Greenwich Street between Christopher and West 10th Streets, consists of seven town houses that have been on the market since 1990 for $1 million each. So far, two have been sold.
The overall town house market, however, has not plummeted, as it has for many co-ops and condominiums. The unusual size and luxuriousness of town homes are primary reasons, as is location. Most town homes are in historic districts or in gentrified areas.
Moreover, town houses are rare. According to the city's Department of Finance, there are only 967 one-family mansions or town houses in the city. By comparison, there are, according to the Real Estate Board, about 120,000 co-ops and condominiums.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Looking for the Right Space;
Why Mastercard Stayed in Manhattan

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
AS it turns out, Mastercard International isn't leaving Manhattan after all. Instead, the fast-growing interbank organization, which has been bursting out of its headquarters space at 888 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street, will spread out across some 350,000 square feet at 1345 Avenue of the Americas, the old Burlington House at 55th Street.
New York City gets to keep 450 jobs now and a promise of more than double that number before the decade is out. Mastercard gets as much space as it needs at an excellent price, gets its name on the door of a Class A building in central Manhattan and doesn't have to put any employees through the enervating process of relocating. 
 Staying in New York should have been a clear-cut choice, right?
Wrong.
In fact, Burlington House didn't enter the picture until the 11th hour of what had been a three-year corporate odyssey to find exactly the right state, then the right city, and then the right space. And until Burlington House showed up, whether Mastercard would stay in New York or move to Westchester remained hotly disputed.
"To the last minute it was a 50-50 race and a roller-coaster ride," said F. David Brangaccio, the Mastercard senior vice president who headed the search for a new headquarters.
Mastercard's decision to stay in Manhattan represents the culmination of a process that involved consultants, architects, brokers, Mastercard employees at every staff level and local officials -- not to mention landlords and leasing agents who wanted to snare the high-profile tenant for persistently vacant spaces in their buildings.
The way Mastercard went about eliminating various locations and buildings makes a good case study of how intricate a space search can be and how its result can be as much a matter of serendipity as it is of economic calculations.
Perhaps even more important, it illustrates how much a company's corporate strategies are reflected in its real estate decisions.
"Corporate decisions on where to locate are no longer only real-estate-driven," said Les J. Cranmer, a principal of PHH Fantus Consulting, a management consulting firm in Florham Park, N.J. that Mastercard hired to help it evaluate the repercussions of moving. "Maybe an expiring lease is the catalyst, but corporate strategy is the driving force behind a move."
IN the beginning, only one thing was clear: Mastercard could no longer abide the cramped existence it had been living. This was a company that outgrew its quarters as quickly as toddlers outgrow clothes.
Over the last decade or so, it had supplemented its basic credit card business with a gold card, travelers' checks, corporate accounts, affinity cards, travel insurance, all kinds of accoutrements that required more and more people to market and administer.
In 1978, when it first moved into 34,000 square feet at 888 Seventh Avenue, it had about 150 employees in New York. By the mid-80's that number had doubled. The company kept taking more space -- and outgrowing it. By 1990 it had nearly 400 employees crammed into 154,000 square feet, sprawled across nine noncontiguous floors.
Meanwhile, the company's data-processing center in St. Louis had 581 people in 117,000 square feet.
By late 1990, although it had five years more to go on its New York lease and 12 years in St. Louis, it had had enough of this catch-as-catch-can approach to space. It asked itself the obvious question: Should it consolidate its St. Louis and New York facilities? If so, where should the newly combined company be set up?
If Mastercard had opted for consolidation, Manhattan would never have had a chance. Midtown rents may have dropped sharply from those of four or five years ago, but they are still high enough to effectively rule out siting any kind of data center or other back-office operation in Manhattan.
Economically, suburban Chicago, suburban Washington, even suburban New York seemed to make sense. And St. Louis, where so many people could stay put, made the most sense of all. By moving everyone there, the company would benefit not only from lower occupancy costs, but also from easier communications between its technical staff and its headquarters folks.
But strategically, consolidation just didn't seem to work. It was unlikely that, wherever Mastercard landed, all its people would move with it. And, with the competition against Visa, American Express and other credit-card companies getting fiercer, the turmoil caused by disrupting the staff could easily make any talk of long-run benefits academic.
"The attrition costs of consolidation would have just been too much for us to bear," Mr. Brangaccio said.
Deciding to keep the company's two halves separate was easy; figuring what to do with the New York contingent was not.
By the fall of 1991, Mastercard had narrowed its sphere to midtown Manhattan or close-in Westchester, the two areas that were most accessible to the highest number of Mastercard's employees.
WITH PHH Fantus's help, it put together a preliminary space plan that laid out its needs. And it hired as architects Gensler & Associates, as brokers Cushman & Wakefield and Douglas A. Edwards and as construction consultant Robert Bennis to help it investigate sites and buildings and to serve as checks and balances on one another.
With the space plan done by Fantus, the brokers wouldn't be tempted to skew it to favor buildings their firm manages or that pay better commissions; with Mr. Bennis checking the architect's preliminary designs, anything that would cost too much to build would get caught at the outset.
"It's always a good idea to have team members who will challenge each other," said Mr. Cranmer of Fantus.
According to Mitchell Barnett, a Cushman & Wakefield director, Mastercard and its brokers and consultants looked at about 15 buildings and proposed buildings in Westchester and 30 in Manhattan. By the middle of 1992 it had narrowed its search to four sites in Westchester and eight in New York.
In Westchester there was 100 Manhattanville Road, the old Nestle building in Purchase; 400 Summit Lake Drive in Valhalla; One Gateway Plaza in White Plains and 10 Main Street, a not-yet-built office complex, also in White Plains.
IN New York there was the Mobil Building, at 150 East 42d Street; 335 Madison Avenue, near 42d Street; the McGraw-Hill building, at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street; the CBS building, at 51 West 52d Street; 277 Park Avenue, near 48th Street; 666 Fifth Avenue, near 53d Street; the Citicorp Building, at 153 East 53d Street; and 1585 Broadway, at 47th Street. All of these Manhattan buildings had large blocks of space available and their occupancy costs were within 10 percent of one another's.
Mastercard executives and representatives of employees at all levels visited each of the buildings and reported back on their gut feelings. The brokers, architects and other assorted consultants visited, too, and came back with more technical evaluations.
"Certainly not every vote counts the same, no company is a complete democracy, but we did try to do this in a participative way," said Alex W. Hart, Mastercard's president, who is universally known as Pete. Just as important, the employee representatives would serve as management's conduit to the staff, who could both explain to the employees how decisions were made and give management early warnings of disgruntlement that any prospective move might cause.
When employees reported that the small, dark floors available at the CBS building made them feel hemmed in, for example, or that they didn't like walking through a lot of retail space to get into 666 Fifth Avenue, those comments were all factored heavily into the building's rankings.
In November, Mastercard's executive committee met with the brokers and consultants for a detailed presentation of every one of the short-listed buildings. Bob Bennis discussed each building's technical aspects. Mitch Barnett and other Cushman brokers discussed the occupancy costs and other financial parameters. The architects kicked in with talks about potential layouts.
By the end of that meeting, it looked as though White Plains would be the winner. Yes, the company liked the idea of being in a global city like New York, but even Mr. Brangaccio, who was in the stay-in-Manhattan contingent, conceded that the city's sometimes-difficult life style, with its crowds and high living costs and crime problems, and the "questionable future" of the Times Square redevelopment project and other proposals to make the city more pleasant, couldn't be ignored. The main problem, said Vito A. Fragala, Mastercard's vice president, administrative services, was that "nothing we saw in New York really excited us."
Indeed, each building on the short list had its own deal-killer drawback. 666 Fifth Avenue dropped out because it was too old and had too much retail space to go through to get in. The floors available in the CBS building, at 335 Madison Avenue and the McGraw-Hill building were too low and too dark.
The Citicorp building was just too closely associated with Citicorp, something that a membership organization of banks did not feel appropriate. And 277 Park was also an old building; but more importantly, Mr. Brangaccio says it got thrown out of the running when Mastercard executives decided that a Park Avenue address seemed a bit "uppity" for a not-for-profit membership organization.
Westchester was seen, by contrast, as a backwater, but it was easy to reach and it had several campus-like sites that were approved for office complexes and that developers would build to suit for Mastercard.
"In a company that's trying to put its stamp on the business worldwide, we needed a signature building," said Mr. Hart. Although the company's internal guesstimates were that it would lose about a third of its people if it moved to White Plains, it figured it could handle that amount of attrition.
Moreover, a delegation of Westchester officials, including Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio of White Plains, had come down in September to tout their quality of life and fiscal soundness . Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and assorted city officials countered with talks about cultural and business vibrancy and plans to revitalize Times Square and otherwise enhance safety and quality of life.
At that point, Westchester sounded better.
Not only that, but the New York contenders were dropping out rapidly. By late 1992, the process of elimination had narrowed Mastercard's search to four buildings. There was state-of-the-art 1585 Broadway, with a gleaming facade, no other tenants to usurp Mastercard's limelight and a layout perfectly suited to its space needs. But it was in the hands of its banks, the banks were squabbling and negotiations were impossible.
The McGraw-Hill building came back into the running when some tower floors with more light and better space became available. The building's management agreed to prominently display Mastercard's name in the Avenue of the Americas plaza and in the lobby, but in the end Mastercard still balked at being just another tenant in someone else's signature building.
"The building was too big, it was identified with another company and we just felt we'd get lost in there," Mr. Brangaccio recalled.
Yet no one was really excited about anything they had seen in Westchester.
"Since the company was clearly leaning in that direction, we went back to look again at the Westchester marketplace," Mr. Barnett recalls. The brokers came back with an added contender: Kings Wood Corporate Center, a yet-to-be-built four-building complex in Armonk that had originally not been considered because it was more than 15 minutes from the White Plains train station. But it was close to highways and near the North White Plains and Valhalla train stations and the landlords were happy to build to Mastercard's specifications.
KINGS WOOD came very close to snagging Mastercard. But then word came out from 1345 Avenue of the Americas: Smith Barney, Harris Upham, which occupied floors 44 through 50, would probably be moving out. That, combined with other vacant space in the building, was enough to accomodate Mastercard's present and future needs.
"Here we were, all in hiatus while the Mastercard executives are evaluating all the reports, and then the Burlington building just popped up," recalled Robin Klehr Avia, Gensler's vice president.
The Burlington space was about as close to Mastercard's optimum space plan as an existing structure could come. Mastercard had decided it wanted floors that were between 35,000 and 40,000 square feet; Burlington House's floors were 40,000 feet. The cafeteria was available, as was mailroom space in the basement. And the Fisher Brothers, the building's owners, were happy to rename the building Mastercard World Plaza.
Suddenly Mastercard began to rethink leaving the city. It took a closer look at possible attrition, even printing out a list of people it thought would leave. Many were key to the company. "We'd save a few dollars in White Plains, but it wasn't worth losing a few steps in our competitive march," Mr. Brangaccio said.
Mastercard made its final decision in early February and signed the lease this month. It is leasing seven floors, about 270,000 feet, now, and has committed to take two more floors in five years, for a total of 350,000 square feet. The 20-year lease includes flexible expansion and contraction options that kick in every five years. The deal specifies a rent in the high $30's per square foot, along with a contribution of close to $60 a foot to the cost of building the offices, plus more than a year's free rent.
Even in this depressed market, that represents a good deal.
Surprisingly, both New York City and Westchester waited until the last minute to offer any financial incentives. In fact, neither White Plains nor Armonk had a chance to make a concrete offer: By the time New York came through with what was a fairly small incentive package -- $2 million in tax breaks over the next 20 years if Mastercard maintained its employment level of 450 people, four times that if it doubled its workforce -- Mastercard had already sold itself on staying in Manhattan.
"People like to say they feel trapped here, but the fact is most people are living and working in New York by choice," said Mr. Hart. "And the roar from the staff when we announced our decision made me realize we were doing the right thing by everyone."
New York couldn't be more delighted.
According to the city's estimates, the retention of Mastercard with a staff of 450 would yield some $81 million to city coffers from corporate taxes, personal income and sales taxes and related business travel. With a staff of 900, the boon is estimated at $176 million. Mastercard projects that its New York workforce will grow to 1,200 by 2005.
"Now that the recession has bottomed out, we can focus on companies that will grow," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "And the bulk of benefits from Mastercard are in its growth."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: 110-118 Riverside Drive;
A Mixed Window Dressing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
IT'S just the kind of thing that drives preservationists nuts: Over the last 20 years the 1929 apartment house at 110-118 Riverside Drive has gone window-wild.
With no master plan for replacements, tenants in the nonlandmark co-op have installed windows in a wild variety of colors and the place looks like a test lab for a fenestration institute. 
 This wacky heterogeneity is against every tenet of historic preservation, which prizes the uniform in such situations. But now the co-op board of directors is implementing a master plan governing replacement windows, in a search for energy savings and uniformity in the 3,000-window building.
The orange brick building, designed by Gronenberg & Leuchtag, who were active in apartment design for speculative builders, was built along the gentle, inward curve of the block between 83d and 84th Streets.
The original architectural drawings show four-, six- and eight-over-one windows: that is, upper sashes divided into multiple panes over a lower sashes of larger, single panes.
There is not much writing on window choice of that period, but critics generally thought that apartment house design got far too little study. In 1930 the Architectural Forum editorialized that typical apartment houses on the major avenues were "dry, monotonous and uninspiring."
In the early 19th century most windows had small panes for purely economic reasons. When the manufacture of large plates of glass became feasible at mid-century, one-over-one windows became common in brownstones, tenements and commercial buildings. There was a mild reaction to this in the 1880's, when Queen Anne-style buildings adopted widely varying window sizes, glazing and shapes. But one-over-one was still the standard until the turn of the century.
The Art Nouveau and Arts and Crafts styles revived a certain amount of variety in window patterns, but the big shift was the Colonial revival, which brought back multipane windows to both private and apartment houses. Even today, an 1870's brownstone with six-over-six windows is a telltale sign that it was altered in the 1920's or later.
There were many apartment houses with multiple panes in the top and bottom sashes, but a common variant was multiple panes in the top and one in the bottom. With little else to go on, the modern observer presumes the upper multilight pane broke up the glare and the lower single pane provided a view. But to judge from historic interior photographs, the idea of "view" was not very important -- typical apartment windows are heavily draped, with additional glass curtains or blinds. The "picture window" as we know it today did not exist in the 20's.
Because of the influence of historic preservation, the prevailing wisdom now is that apartment house windows should be uniform; a building with a scattering of different windows seems like an esthetic affront, even if, like 110-118 Riverside Drive, it's not a landmark.
But this building's window alterations have been left mostly up to the tenants. There are all manner of window frames in seven different colors. In some cases the brick panels separating paired windows have been knocked out for picture windows. Any critic calling it lovely in its comic orneriness would be considered a subversive crank, but even the most orthodox preservationist should make an inspection trip, if only to confirm dearly held opinions.
A MASTER window plan passed in the mid-80's has been casually enforced. But now the board is serious about performance and appearance standards for new windows. "Uniformity is much more esthetically pleasing" says Ewen R. Gillies, co-chairman of the operations committee, who has been most involved in the project. But he also looks forward to the day when the building won't be wrangling with repairs to 15 to 20 different makes of windows and the time when all the windows are up to the same level of energy savings.
"We'll have control of the whole skin," Mr. Gillies says.
The co-op's standard requires any new windows to be the ubiquitous bronze in color, but they can be single pane or one-over-one, from selected contractors, at a cost of about $650-$850 each. About 100 to 200 of the modern replacement windows are so terrible that they will have to come out this fall, Mr. Gillies says, but all later replacements can remain until they begin to fail.
Although done in the name of uniformity, in fact the last bit of uniformity in the building will vanish: Another priority this year is to replace the remaining original wooden windows, about 1,600, to avoid continued painting and other costs. Is some sentimentalist claiming the right to keep the wooden windows?
"Not in this building they don't," says Mr. Gillies.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Window styles vary widely at 110-118 Riverside Drive. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2748 words

HEADLINE: Race and the American Workplace

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
THERE are nights Harold Thomas lies in bed, kept awake by the words that still scream through his head, words he heard for years over the paging system at the Miller Brewing Company plant in Fulton, N.Y.
A production supervisor in the packaging department, Mr. Thomas has no idea whose voice it was, calling him: "Harold, the . . . ape, Thomas." But by early 1991, he had grown so distraught that a psychiatrist advised him to take a leave. Upon his return almost a year later, a voice rang out over the paging system, "Welcome back, Harold, but you're still a nigger." 
 For almost a decade, through last year, many black and female employees at the plant in Fulton, a small industrial town north of Syracuse in central New York, say they were targets of racial epithets or sexual comments over the speaker system or were harassed by other means, such as messages written on restroom walls, obscene drawings and prominently placed items, like a noose, that spoke of overt hostility.
While these kinds of incidents are not necessarily characteristic of Miller plants, they are remarkably common in the American workplace -- and may even be on the rise. Efforts by companies to hire more minorities and women, often at the expense of white males, coupled with the wave of corporate downsizings that has further threatened job security, have led to a backlash against minority workers, Federal authorities and management experts say.
Since 1990, complaints of racial harassment filed through local and regional offices of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and state human rights agencies increased nearly 17 percent, to 6,038 filings last year. Among the recent cases is a class action suit against the Ford Motor Company charging racial discrimination and harassment.
"It's not just limited to blue-collar workers," said Mildred Saunders, a New York-based consultant on equal employment matters. "In academia, in government, among professionals, wherever people are different and fewer jobs are available because of the economy, these kinds of issues are commonplace."
One reason the problem persists is that companies often deny it exists or fail to eradicate it at its base levels, forcing victims to turn for action to the courts, as Mr. Thomas has. Lawrence Kunin, general counsel to the New York State Division of Human Rights, said that sometimes a company "has established a culture, without realizing that it's discriminatory."
 
The View From Milwaukee
 While perhaps extreme, the Miller case in Fulton provides a compelling study of how bigotry endures in the workplace, even after victims complain repeatedly and managers experienced in diversity are brought in to help.
At Miller's headquarters in Milwaukee, officials maintain that their efforts to catch the Fulton perpetrators were adequate, if unsuccessful. Michael Brophy, a Miller spokesman, said that through the years in question senior managers in Fulton had taken "corrective action" in the form of a tape monitoring system and surveillance by security personnel.
"Were we concerned? Of course," he said. "Do we believe the problem was rampant? Of course not. We're talking about a plant where there are 1,200 to 1,400 pages a day, about 550,000 a year, more than 5 million over 10 years. How many offensive pages are we talking about? Maybe 12 or 14." Largely for that reason, he said, the paging system, the principal means of abuse, was retained until last year.
A Miller lawyer in Milwaukee, Bert Butler, insisted Miller has always complied with state and Federal antidiscrimination laws. He said that over a 16-year period no "formal complaint" of racial harassment reached the office of the Fulton plant manager. He said Miller officials in Milwaukee would not have known about complaints from people like Mr. Thomas to their superiors or how the superiors handled them.
Mr. Thomas and others -- managers as well as union workers -- said complaints were largely ignored.
How much harassment might be considered too much? Speaking in general terms, Mr. Kunin said, "After 35 years of civil rights laws, I have to question a response of 'I didn't know,' or 'It happened at such a low level,' or 'It was too subtle.' I have to question even one statement over a loudspeaker."
Several employees have filed complaints against Miller for discrimination. Mr. Thomas and Waverly Faison, a former Miller employee who was laid off in 1984, presented enough evidence to the United States Attorney in Syracuse last year to have the Federal Bureau of Investigation investigate whether Federal criminal civil rights laws had been violated. To prevail in a criminal action, a prosecutor must show that racial harassment included physical harm or a threat of physical harm.
In addition, Mr. Thomas and two other black ex-employees filed separate civil claims against Miller with the New York State Division of Human Rights, in which a plaintiff must show by a preponderance of the evidence that discrimination occurred. Mr. Faison has challenged Miller in New York State Supreme Court under the same civil rights laws.
 
The Lure of Fulton
 A vast complex about 10 miles south of Lake Ontario, Miller's Fulton plant opened in 1975 and quickly became a magnet for college graduates of all races seeking management careers. In an economically depressed town of fewer than 13,000 residents, 98 percent of them white, it was an oasis of diversity.
Mr. Faison was a typical recruit, part of an initial work force of more than 2,000. Now 43, the former Marine with a degree in history and education from North Carolina Central University was hired in 1976 as a packaging supervisor. Within three years, he said, he became the first black at the plant to be promoted to middle management. As a packaging superintendent, he managed nearly 75 people, "about 90 percent of whom were Caucasian," he said. "That's when the trouble started."
Easily accessed through hundreds of telephones around the plant, the paging system became a vehicle for foul language and abusive comments. "Nigger," black employees say, was a common term.
At his supervisors' suggestion, Mr. Faison began a written log of derogatory remarks in September 1982, keeping it at a desk a floor above the packaging area. "It was a feeble attempt to do something," Mr. Faison said. In the first three months, at least two dozen racial or sexual references to him and other employees were logged.
"It was humiliating," Mr. Faison said. "They talked about my mother, my mother's sexual preferences, whatever they wanted. And the log shows only part of it. You couldn't always stop working to run up the stairs to write in the log."
The log was discontinued in 1983. Testifying in a 1984 sexual harassment case against Miller, Bruce Olm, a supervisor and custodian of the log, said the abusive messages on the paging system had ended by then. However, nearly a dozen current and former Miller employees -- black and white, management and union -- dispute that.
"What bothered me so much," said Michael Oldenburgh, a white manager who worked at the plant until 1984, "was that this was a company using its commercials to portray itself as the All-American company. But guess what? They failed miserably in Fulton."
Mr. Butler, the Miller lawyer, said the corporate office first became aware of a problem with the paging system in 1983, when Mr. Faison "said he had been subjected to two abusive pages." Mr. Butler said that plant officials attempted to learn the identify of the abusers, to no avail.
But Mr. Faison, who said his complaints were far more numerous, pointed out, "If that's all I complained about, why did the F.B.I. agree to look at the case?"
Meanwhile, other objectionable behavior persisted.
George Clarke, a black who retired as superintendent of maintenance in 1988, recalled several incidents. "Chicken bones kept appearing in my desk," he said. "They also erected a tombstone in the courtyard with a sign that said, 'George Clarke, rest in peace,' and there were chicken bones sprinkled over the grave. These people went to great lengths."
He said he informed his superiors of each incident, but never discovered who was responsible.
Cynthia Brewer, a black who resigned last September, has a claim against Miller in the state human rights division, charging that plant officials discriminated against her after she spoke to the F.B.I., in her role as head of security and safety manager, as part of its investigation of Mr. Faison's charges.
Mr. Faison, now the human resources director for the municipal bus company in Syracuse, said he once encountered a noose hanging from a gate and said that people periodically left racially offensive messages on his beeper number.
Black union workers say they suffered similar indignities. J.D. Smith, a 38-year-old machinist who has worked in the plant since 1976, said that in addition to harassment, black union workers were often assigned to "less responsible jobs" than whites. He said he complained to union representatives, Miller officials and state authorities. None, he said, took action.
Frank Carelli, business manager for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, local 2587, and a former Miller employee, said that "in an industrial complex that large, sure they have racial incidents. Nobody is immune to that and I truly believe that the Miller Brewery is no different than General Motors or anybody else. You just have to adjust and deal with it."
But a union representative (who, like Mr. Carelli, is white) who spoke on the condition of anonymity said black workers in the plant suffered "unmerciful and unrelenting" abuse and that "until recently," Miller officials "never dealt with it."
Jerry Church, manager of the plant for 10 years until his retirement in 1990, said the paging system caused "sporadic problems," but that he never heard any objectionable remarks himself. He also said "never was anything formally" brought to his attention. "But in hindsight," he added, "the company should have dealt with it."
Miller apparently recognized a need to address racial tension at the plant. To replace Mr. Church, it brought in David Green, who had spent 11 years at Miller's brewery in Albany, Ga. Mr. Green, who is white, said his success in harmonizing a racially mixed work force in Georgia earned him the transfer. (At Miller, neither Mr. Butler nor Mr. Brophy would discuss Mr. Green's selection. "That's personnel stuff," Mr. Brophy said. "If we discussed any aspect of it, we'd be in trouble.")
As Mr. Green recalled it: "When I got there, it was obvious what the problem was. Miller wasn't focusing on the harassment. They were chasing people rather than heading off what was at the heart of the issue, and it wasn't getting any better."
Mr. Green formed a multicultural steering committee and instituted "consulting pairs," in which one black employee discussed issues with one white, or one man with one woman. He also met with managers to stress the need for attitudinal change and got agreements from union officials and other plant leaders that any objectionable behavior would stop.
But incidents continued. In two, during the fall of 1990, security officers found messages in restrooms saying to "kill" black people.
Harold Thomas, now 43, was a graduate of Morris Brown College in Atlanta with a degree in biology and psychology when was hired by Miller in 1977. He was promoted a year later to production supervisor, a position he still holds.
He said he felt so threatened by the verbal abuse, vandalism (a tampered air valve on a front tire, a smashed patio window at home) and overall atmosphere at Miller that "sometimes I couldn't do my job effectively." Those feelings led to his medical leave of absence, beginning in February 1991, at partial pay.
Mr. Thomas said he never filed a formal complaint at the plant because he "had always been told to follow the chain of command. . . . I'm not a boisterous person. If I started shouting and jumping on tables, they would have thought I was out of control."
But in a sworn affidavit filed with his state case in June 1991, Mr. Thomas listed 21 instances in the seven months leading to his leave in which he was paged in the plant or on his beeper in an offensive context. He said he notified a superior each time.
The personnel administration manager for the plant at the time, Michael C. Sigona, who has since left the company, argued in response that the complaint should be dismissed because the brewery had "done everything it could be expected" to do to learn the identity of those responsible for the pages.
The offensive pages subsided when Mr. Thomas began his leave, according to Mr. Green, but resumed when Mr. Thomas returned 11 months later. Mr. Green decided to remove the paging system. A month later, he was asked to resign.
Mr. Green said that subordinates had complained to the corporate office, a view shared by several former Miller employees. Sam Crumpton, a black who is a retired Miller supervisor, said people in Milwaukee were told by his colleagues that Mr. Green was engaged in "white-male bashing." Mr. Butler and Mr. Brophy again declined to discuss any aspect of Mr. Green's employment.
By late last year, Mr. Thomas began wondering if these episodes had violated his civil rights. His lawyer recommended he meet Anita Roberts, whose client, Mr. Faison, was proceeding along the same path. Mrs. Roberts suggested the two combine efforts, in taking their case before the United States Attorney in Syracuse.
 
Enter the F.B.I.
 The F.B.I. "largely substantiated" some of the allegations, according to a letter to Miller's lawyers in Syracuse from Paula Ryan Conan, an Assistant United States Attorney. But without evidence to identify the perpetrators, she wrote, neither her office nor the Justice Department could take any action against Miller.
But she chastised the company for what "may be a deep-rooted problem at the plant" and for the "appearance of endorsement-by-inaction" that allowed the alleged acts to continue.
Unsatisfied, Mr. Faison presented the F.B.I. a list of additional witnesses, some of whom, he said, "have direct knowledge" of who was responsible for various of the incidents. Mrs. Roberts said that the F.B.I. is still interviewing witnesses.
Mr. Thomas, meanwhile, reports to work each day. "I still look over my shoulder," he said. "They have threatened my life. But I'm not leaving. If I walk out, I'm gone, and Miller will never address the issue."

 
 
THE CASE AGAINST FORD

CLARENCE A. HOLCOMB, a 44-year-old manager for the Ford Motor Company in St. Louis, claims he has suffered racial discrimination and harassment as a Ford employee since 1977. He says he was passed over for promotions and pay increases, made the butt of racial slurs, and, after he filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, subjected to false claims of bad performance, threatening his employment.
Mr. Holcomb's charges are included in a class action suit filed earlier this month against Ford in Federal district court for Minnesota. He is one of 12 plaintiffs -- black managers at Ford facilities around the country -- with at least one common complaint: that they suffered as a result of unfair performance evaluations.
Judith Muhlberg, a Ford spokeswoman, said the company has a "very well-developed and disciplined program for considering the performance of all employees," but charges of discrimination of this kind are hardly unusual in America. Last year, the E.E.O.C. compiled 125,217 complaints of racially motivated discrimination or harassment nationwide, up 8.5 percent from 1991.
"We probably get 200 queries a week," said Paul C. Sprenger, whose Minneapolis firm, Sprenger & Lang, specializes in employment litigation. The growing number of complaints is a result, he added, of relaxed labor-law enforcement under the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
In the case against Ford, the plaintiffs charge that the company has "engaged in a general practice of discriminating against black persons and denying them equal opportunities." Ford is also charged with failing to hire and recruit blacks on an equal basis with whites.
This, Mr. Sprenger said, is a "second generation" suit. The first generation meant getting minorities hired. "Now," he said, "we have to make sure they are treated fairly."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 13-18

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Budget Plan, or What's Left of It, Is Off and Running 

"We are putting our economic house in order," President Clinton said, pointing proudly to the progress of "his" budget plan. But it's no longer his plan, of course. Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee did some wrenching fine-tuning before agreeing to a compromise they could all live with -- like scrapping a broad fuel tax for a more modest tax on transportation fuel, and making deep Medicare cuts. Still, the committee did manage to agree on a bill -- which the chairman, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, called "the most progressive change in taxes since World War II" -- and that gets the process through a tight bottleneck. So suddenly it seems very possible that a good part of Mr. Clinton's vision will become law later this summer. As for the rest, the horse-trading still angers the President. "We can't simply balance the budget," he said, "on the backs of the old, the sick," and the poor.
 
Space Trek, the Next Generation
 
For the moment, the space station is not dead -- just a little smaller. President Clinton, saying we "cannot retreat from our obligation" to the future, asked Congress for a $10.5 billion model, with spending spread over five years. In keeping with what has quickly become the Age of Compromise, that's at least $1.5 billion more than Mr. Clinton had sought, but a lot less than the $17.6 billion the original would have cost taxpayers. To make more drastic cuts could have got Mr. Clinton into a global mess, since Canada, Japan and Europe are already big investors. But that's not to say the station will survive; many lawmakers have no home-district suppliers to protect and thus no reason to vote for it.
 
So Where Are the New Houses?
 
Everything looked good for home building. Sales boomed in early spring, construction jobs were up, mortgage rates were at 20-year lows, lumber prices had eased. And if housing was strong, it's a good bet the broader economy would be, too. But when the numbers on May housing starts came in last week, they showed a disappointing 2.4 percent rise -- so housing is likely to do little to help the economy this quarter.
 
Mortgage rates should stay low for a while, as there was more evidence that earlier rumblings of inflation were fading. Consumer prices showed only an 0.1 percent rise for May, reinforcing the recent message that producer prices were flat.
 
I.B.M., Springboard to the Sky
 
Many corporate jobs are rungs in a ladder, orderly steps upward. But where do you go after running I.B.M.? For John F. Akers, the answer was this: something "different from what I've done in the past." He's certainly found that. Last week Mr. Akers, who left I.B.M. this spring, joined forces with Frank Lorenzo, former head of Texas Air, in his venture to run a low-cost East Coast airline. "This is about as different as I can imagine," Mr. Akers said. But "it's a lot easier to start with a clean sheet of paper" than to change an established organization. And this is not, he said, alien territory -- he did spend four years as a Navy pilot. Mr. Akers will own 5 percent of the new carrier and will do whatever Mr. Lorenzo thinks "could be useful."
 
Silent Summer Runways
 
This may not be the time to get into the airline business. Vacationers, spoiled by fare wars past, are balking at this summer's higher fares, and businesses, nibbling costs right and left, are trimming travel budgets. What this is adding up to, American Airlines said last week, is disappointing earnings. Investors seemed primed for such tidings: shares in AMR, its parent company, fell sharply, and other airline stocks quickly followed.
 
Surgery at Empire Blue Cross
 
Empire Blue Cross is probably wishing it had better health coverage for itself; it's displaying more and more symptoms of a pretty nasty illness. Its chairman was forced out recently, after directors learned that he had kept crucial facts from them. Now it turns out that data the insurer sent to New York State regulators and to legislators had only a passing link to the truth. Empire must get state approval to raise rates for small groups and individuals, so it's been tinkering with the numbers to make its losses in that area look bigger -- thus bolstering its case for rate rises. It also used the false data in a push to change insurance laws. Last week the correct numbers surfaced -- and the company came clean. It suspended its top financial officer and rescinded bonuses just granted to 68 executives.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
This Is Clear: It Was No Genie
 
No surprises, please. When people shell out extra pennies for a familiar brand, they're buying the cozy glow of absolute predictability. For the products' makers, this is normally fine: loyalty equals sales. But let a crack appear, and a mass market becomes a mass public-relations nightmare. For Pepsi last week, it was a tiny crack indeed -- scattered reports (many proven false) of odd objects in soda cans. But it was enough, Pepsi feared, to make shoppers hesitate as they reached for the Pepsi shelf -- and (Horrors!) go for the Coke instead. So Pepsi pulled out all stops to reassure the soda public, with its chief executive, Craig Weatherup, turning up so often -- on late news, early news, on "Nightline" and "Larry King Live" -- that he seemed to be running for President.
 
Kodak Starts Its Shrinking Act
 
Yes, Eastman Kodak can change -- but at its own pace, thank you. Investors have urged Kodak to cut its debt -- and cheered the arrival this year of an aggressive finance officer, Christopher Steffen. But when Mr. Steffen made a quick exit, pressure mounted on Kodak's more deliberative chairman, Kay R. Whitmore -- and the stock slid back into the pre-Steffen dumps. Mr. Whitmore vowed to sell a big piece of the company, and last week he did so, saying Kodak would spin off its chemical business to shareholders. This is a big belt-tightening: Eastman Chemical will be the nation's No. 10 chemical company. And the stock ended the week at $53.25, up from $47.25 at Mr. Steffen's departure.
 
Once Sculley Saw Greenwich . . .
 
John Sculley already seemed to be looking beyond Apple Computer. He'd bought a house in Greenwich, Conn. -- on the coast his family prefers. He'd been mentioned for some political role. Some described him as detached from the daily Apple -- one analyst referred to "Sculley's view from 10,000 feet rather than down and dirty." And Apple seemed to be looking beyond him, too. With PC profits pinched and the stock slumping, the board was said to be pressuring him to step aside. So it was no shock last week when Mr. Sculley, 54, who came to Apple 10 years ago, handed the chief executive's title to Michael Spindler, now president. This frees Mr. Sculley, still chairman, to think bigger thoughts -- and to spend more time in the East.
 
A Warehouse-Sized Merger
 
The big are getting bigger. The nation's No. 2 and No. 3 warehouse clubs, Price and Costco, joined forces last week, saying they planned to merge in a $2 billion-plus stock swap. With $16 billion in annual sales, Price/Costco will vault past Sam's Club to head the field of mammoth discount retailers. Maybe there's some cosmic cycle here. Stores grow ever bigger, mergers create huge companies to run the huge stores, and pretty soon they put a roof over the whole country and create a single, giant store. Then, in some forgotten corner, hundreds of miles from the checkout counter, a mom-and-pop grocery store is born. And it all starts again.
 
Litton's Guns, Litton's Butter
 
The post-military landscape is taking shape. Companies are facing the fact that guns are giving way to butter, and one has decided that the side that's buttered must be given its due. Last week Litton Industries said it would split in two, with one company focusing on its commercial businesses and the other on the declining weapons market. The commercial business -- which includes oil-field services -- is growing fast and now accounts for 40 percent of revenues, up from 15 percent six years ago. The stock market approved heartily, as Litton shares soared $8.125, to $65.125.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
G.M. Doesn't Frighten Lopez
 
Ignacio Lopez made his own declaration of independence last week. "We are a free continent," he said, when asked if any threats by General Motors would stop his new employer, Volkswagen, from building a plant in Spain. The deciding factor is what "is best for our customers," he insisted. He stopped short of saying the plant would be built, saying negotiations were under way, but he did not seem worried by G.M.'s warning that it would sue if it appeared that a plant was based on ideas Mr. Lopez developed in Detroit. A radically low-cost plant has been dear to Mr. Lopez since his days as G.M.'s shining star, and he does not plan to be sidetracked now.
 
Trade Gap Refuses to Shrink
 
The April trade deficit was supposed to shrink after a huge jump in March to a four-year high. But instead it rose even more, as the imbalance with Japan hit a five-year high. That will certainly give President Clinton something to talk about -- if he feels like taking on this touchy topic -- when he goes to Tokyo in a few weeks for an economic summit meeting. But perhaps Americans seeking culprits should look to their own gas tanks: the United States bought $3.7 billion worth of imported oil in April, up from $3.4 billion.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 20, 1993

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2000 words

HEADLINE: Technology;
Through TV-Tinted Glasses

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND

 BODY:
STROLLING through a shopping center in Phoenix one recent Friday evening, Roberta Trengrove attracted quite a few stares with her oversized, shiny black wraparound visor. She barely noticed.
"Oh look," she said to no one in particular. "It's Miss Finland. Wow, look at that red dress." For an instant, Mrs. Trengrove forgot that only she could see the televised beauty pageant. 
 Pulling off the visor, a test model of a new product called Virtual Vision Sport, she laughed. "It's hard to remember that you're the only one watching," she said. "It could be totally antisocial. It really tugs at your eye."
Watching television while cruising the mall, sitting on a bus or basking in the stadium bleachers has been possible for years with miniature battery-operated sets. But now a start-up company near Seattle, using technology first developed for Air Force flight simulators, is selling a television system fit into a pair of tinted glasses.
Slip them on, hit the switch and a broadcast appears before your eyes. In a technique akin to reading with bifocal glasses, you can focus on the screen, or look through the glasses to see the world around you.
Introduced in May, the Virtual Vision system is currently available in New York, Miami, Montreal, Chicago, Los Angeles and Seattle and through the Sharper Image catalogue. By August, Virtual Vision Inc., of Redmond, Wash., plans to have the product in stores across the country.
At $900, it's hardly an impulse buy. But sociologists take note: Virtual Vision will let consumers, who in the United States already have their television sets on an average of 7 hours a day, watch television virtually anywhere at any time.
There may be limits, of course. Robert Sights, who runs an independent film production company, was impressed when he tried Virtual Vision recently. But he wasn't sure the glasses would be useful in Los Angeles, where he lives.
"In other places, people read the newspaper or get ready for work on the subway," he said. "But in L.A. we do that while driving. I can just see getting arrested for driving while watching TV"
Mr. Sights also balked at the gadget's price. "But if the price gets to be $395," he allowed, "I might buy one."
Virtual Vision uses a technology the company calls virtual imaging, meaning it creates pictures that seem to float in space, appearing about the size of an ordinary television screen about a dozen feet away.
The actual image is produced by a postage-stamp sized liquid crystal display imbedded in the bridge of the glasses and reflected into a wearer's field of vision with a mirror.
The display is on only one side of the glasses, so it projects into the wearer's dominant eye -- something that the salesperson can help the buyer easily determine before selecting a "right-eyed" or "left-eyed" version. Because the system exploits the natural tendency for the dominant eye to share images with the weaker one, the picture seems to be visible to both eyes -- without undue strain.
The broadcast is picked up by the antenna on a 3-pound belt-pack tuner and sent to the screen through a thin electrical cable. The sound is heard through earphones attached to the visor's frame, and the whole apparatus is powered by a rechargeable nickel-cadmium battery on the belt pack. Unlike virtual reality, the futuristic technology that seems to immerse a viewer in a completely artificial world by blocking out all other sights and sounds, the Virtual Vision picture is restricted to the bottom of the wearer's vision field.
When industry experts look at Virtual Vision, they see applications beyond television, such as using the technology to replace computer screens in the workplace.
"It is the future of display," said George Gilder, an economist who frequently writes about telecommunications and is author of the book "Life After Television." "It gets rid of the cathode ray tube, the scanning display with tremendously high wattage. All the residual mechanics of computers are overcome."
But for now, Virtual Vision is purely an entertainment device. The system can be plugged into a cable-ready VCR, allowing the wearer to watch either cable programming or videotapes, although the obvious lack of mobility would seem to defeat the whole point of the product unless the user is toting a portable VCR.
Nevertheless, the company plans to introduce a wireless adaptor by this fall, which would allow a viewer to watch cable or videos in another room, while washing the dishes, say.
And the Virtual Vision visor can be used in place of the viewfinder on any video camcorder, by plugging the cable into the camera. An amateur cameraman can tape a child's birthday party, for example, by watching the whole scene on the glasses' screen while aiming his camera anywhere, even over his shoulder.
The system does have its drawbacks, however. The reception isn't perfect, because the TV set relies on a small antenna, and the small liquid-crystal display screen tends to produce a grainy image. And like any television, the picture is worst outdoors where bright light makes the image difficult to see.
THAT'S unfortunate for people who want to watch television at the beach -- despite the company's ads, which depict a televised football game seen clearly against the backdrop of a tropical shore.
But many people who have tried the device seem willing to look beyond its limitations. "The resolution was good, it was usable resolution," said Nolan Murdock, research and development project director for Panavision, the maker of movie cameras for films.
"A lot of directors rely on video now to get an immediate replay of what they're filming," Mr. Murdock said. "I could see them wearing these glasses to see the picture as it's being filmed." And yet, as with many who have tried the glasses, Mr. Murdock wondered whether looking back and forth between the image and the real world a lot would strain the eyes.
Not to worry, says Dr. Barbara Arnold, an ophthalmologist and professor at the University of California at Davis, who has no ties to the company. "I wouldn't anticipate any problem whatsoever."
The focusing muscles in eyes of people over 45 years old might tire sooner than in younger people using Virtual Vision, Dr. Arnold said, but that would be about the extent of the danger. "Its like aerobics," she said. "You use a muscle, go home, rest up and are fine."
The television visor is the first product of Virtual Vision Inc., a privately held company that was formed in early 1992 and now has about 60 employees.
THE company is tight-lipped about sales so far of the visor, which is based on military research done by Tom Furness, a professor at the University of Washington in Seattle and director of the university's Human Interface Technology Lab.
Professor Furness, who in addition to helping to develop flight simulators and heads-up display helmets that let airplane pilots see gauges and flight data without having to look down at the instrument panel, holds the patents to the Virtual Vision technology, which he licensed to the company.
Rusty Bennett, Virtual Vision's vice president of sales, said that the product incorporates some of Professor Furness's earlier research. "We use parts of heads-up technology from fighter planes," he said, "including the parts that allow you to see an image that is not actually there."
The company is not entirely alone in developing glasses-style viewers. The Sony Corporation has been working on a headset called Visotron for watching videos, and a British inventor holds a patent for a television visor he calls Goggle Vox. But both devices block a wearer's vision. neither one is yet being manufactured.
"I look at Virtual Vision and devices like it towards their future applications," said Andrew Kessler, an interactive media analyst with Unterberg Harris, a financial firm in New York.
"It will take software and titles developed specifically for that device, but I don't think it's five to 10 years away," Mr. Kessler said. "I think its probably two years away."
Already, Virtual Vision executives are exploring new avenues for their product. The company says, for example, that it is talking with physicians about applying the technology to microsurgery. Rather than stopping to check the surgery's progress on a video monitor, as doctors do now, surgeons could glance down at the glasses' monitor as they operate.
THE company also hopes it may be able to capitalize on the fact that movie theaters, in order to comply with Federal regulations for the handicapped, will soon have to supply subtitles for deaf customers. Virtual Vision proposes a solution: let those customers rent the video visors in the lobby and the subtitles could be electronically transmitted to only those whose need to read them.
Airlines could be another possibility, renting Virtual Vision glasses instead of headphones. Passengers would be able to watch the movie without worrying that someone in the next row was blocking the screen.
And the company says it plans to create glasses that plug in to laptop computers, so that a passenger could work on his computer without the bored person in the adjacent seat reading the screen over his shoulder.
Fine. But what about the here and now, which in the case of Virtual Vision seems to be plain old TV. Do couch potatoes and their tater tots really need to do their viewing on the move?
Virtual Vision executives say the glasses, like VCR's and portable audio cassette players, simply offer people more of the flexibility they want in their lives.
"I don't see this changing most people into TV addicts if they weren't already," said Mr. Bennett, the Virtual Vision vice president. "People do sit inside and watch TV when they know they should be doing something else," he said. "Maybe with this product they'll do both. So maybe that will be an improvement."
 
MORE THAT MEETS THE EYE
 Someday, watching TV on Virtual Vision may seem as quaint as viewing nature scenes on great-grandmother's stereoscope.
Researchers at the University of Washington, where Virtual Vision technology was born, believe they may have found a way to step sprightly into whole virtual worlds. Their hope is to do away with the cumbersome headsets and bulky cables currently required for experiencing 3-D, computer-generated virtual reality.
At the university's Human Interface Technology Lab in Seattle, a team of engineers led by Joel Kollin have developed a technique that dispenses with miniature television screens or liquid crystal display panels.
Instead, Mr. Kollin's group is at work on a system that projects 3-D images directly onto the retinas of a person's eyeballs. The technology is meant to offer a realistically clear, depth-of-field view into lifelike worlds that exist only as computer data.
Although the Virtual Retina Display, as it is called, is still a workbench model several feet long, the researchers hope within a few years to have developed a full-color, high-resolution, panoramic version that would be small and lightweight enough to mount onto a pair of eyeglasses and would cost only a few hundred dollars. The images might be piped in through fiber-optic strands attached to a portable computer.
The current benchtop model uses a series of laser scanners, lenses and mirrors to project a video signal onto the retina that the brain perceives as a 3-D image. Though the field of vision currently is fairly narrow, Mr. Kollin says the goal is a wide field of view approaching 140 degrees for each eye.
The Virtual Retina Display is bright enoughthat Mr. Kollin is confident that computer-generated images could someday be superimposed on the real world -- allowing such trompe l'oeil effects as placing a television character right in the viewer's living room.
Anyone who watched such virtual-reality capabilities depicted on the recent television mini-series "Wild Palms," can begin to image the possibilities . . . PATRICK COTTER
