HEADLINE: Hospitals Begin Streamlining For a New World in Health Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The Genesys Health System plans to close its four hospitals in Genesee County, Mich., and replace them with a single streamlined hospital with 439 patient beds, half as many as the old hospitals. Genesys, based in Flint, is shrinking to get ready for the new world of managed competition in health care under which hospitals and doctors may have to bid against one another for insured groups of patients. And it is struggling to make health care more affordable so that the county's dominant employer, the General Motors Corporation, will not close any additional local factories, further reducing the hospital's potential pool of patients.
Under an avalanche of economic and political pressures, hospitals nationwide are reinventing themselves. In addition to cutting costs and delivering care more efficiently, they are providing services unheard of in the past like making house calls and competing with insurers in processing claims. 
 At stake is their survival. As cost-conscious employers and insurance companies pushed for shorter hospital stays, occupancy in the nation's hospitals dropped to 66 percent by 1991 from 76 percent a decade earlier, according to the American Hospital Association's latest survey. Since 1980, about 1,000 hospitals have closed or merged as a result.
In the latest large merger, Galen Health Care agreed earlier this month to a $4.1 billion deal to merge its 73 hospitals with the Columbia Hospital Corporation, based in Fort Worth, which has 26 hospitals. After previous acquisitions, Columbia closed a number of hospitals in cities where it wound up with more than one. Galen, based in Louisville, Ky., was created in March to take over Humana's for-profit hospitals.
And industry executives say hundreds more hospitals will disappear in the next few years because of continuing pressure from big payers and now, from the Government. The shrinkage will accelerate, hospital executives say, if the Clinton Administration succeeds in putting Government limits on health-care spending.
"The hospitals' worry beads are well worn," said Gary Ahlquist, a managing vice president at Booz-Allen Health Care Inc., a consulting firm.
According to Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a trade association in Washington, "In a four-hospital town, No. 4 is gone unless it can change." He said the survivors will also be smaller because increasingly patients are seeking less expensive care in doctor's offices and walk-in clinics.
So how are hospitals preparing for the new world? Perhaps the most sweeping change is that a growing number of them are allying with networks of primary-care physicians, giving these family practitioners, internists and pediatricians greater influence in the health maintenance organizations and other medical networks that predominate under managed care.
Formerly these doctors had taken a back seat to surgeons and specialists in most cities. But now, they are typically deciding which hospital to use for routine treatments. And their authorization is often required before a patient consults a specialist.
As a result, MacNeal Hospital in Berwyn, Ill., a blue-collar suburb of Chicago, actively woos family physicians to help keep its 427 beds occupied. MacNeal will pay the doctors a salary or, if they prefer, provide an office and assistants in a neighborhood where doctors are scarce, said Luke McGuinness, MacNeal's president.
Many doctors look forward to warmer ties with hospitals, instead of the "sometimes hostile relations" of the past, said Dr. Nancy Dickey, a family physician in Richmond, Tex., a small city 35 miles from Houston. Doctors and hospitals will probably "share much more closely in the risks and benefits," she said.
Insurance companies also see the changes. "Hospitals used to be the center of the universe," said David Willis, who is in charge of policy and programs for more than 200 physician and hospital networks for the Aetna Life and Casualty Company. "In the new world, we start with the physicians and talk to them about their hospitals."
Hospital profits (or surpluses in nonprofit hospitals) have been rising, on average, since 1988, as managements have tightened up, introduced operating efficiencies and even begun to charge for things that were not previously separate charges. Operating profits jumped 28 percent, on average, at 167 large hospital groups surveyed by Modern Healthcare, a weekly trade magazine.
And a few hospitals with international reputations, including several in New York City, are still spending heavily for new buildings and equipment that is often duplicated at other institutions just a few blocks away.
But the golden era may end for many hospitals. Many are already being forced by employers and insurers to give up the lucrative practice of submitting jumbo bills listing hundreds of difficult-to-monitor services. Now, rather than charging for each pill, injection and service, "well over 80 percent of hospitals" are paid either a fixed daily fee or a preset amount for each illness treated, Mr. Willis of Aetna said.
THIS cuts down on overhead and helps reduce the number of errors. At least 92 percent of hospital bills are riddled with errors, said Bob Dubester, a vice president of American Claims Evaluation Inc., based in Jericho, L.I., which audits large hospital bills for employers.
"An American hospital bill is a joke," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton University health economist.
Also forcing medical efficiencies is the increasing practice of health maintenance organizations, including some owned by hospitals, to pay a uniform annual or monthly sum, or capitation, for each H.M.O. member.
"Capitation is the coming thing," said Dick Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association. He predicted 80 percent of health coverage would be financed by per capita payments by the year 2000, in contrast to only 10 percent now.
At the Henry Ford Health System, an eight-hospital group in Detroit that is often cited as a model of things to come, about 45 percent of the patients are under capitation. "Capitation is the single most important factor in changing the system," said Gail L. Warden, president of the group, which also has several H.M.O.'s, with 1,000 salaried physicians. With capitation, he said, doctors and hospitals have a financial interest in avoiding unnecessary tests and procedures.
"WE don't consider ourselves as being in the hospital business," Mr. Warden said. "We view hospitals as a cost center, not a revenue center as in the past."
The system seems to have curtailed costs at Henry Ford. Mr. Warden said that overall costs had risen 7.7 percent annually in recent years, compared with 10.5 percent nationally.
Per capita payments offer strong incentives to keep all but the sickest people out of hospitals. When hospitalization is necessary, low-cost community hospitals are used increasingly for routine cases like appendicitis and many children's diseases, instead of leading teaching hospitals.
The prestigious teaching hospitals may have a hard time maintaining their expensive mix of teaching, specialized medicine and research as the drive to cut costs intensifies, said Dr. David Blumenthal, head of health policy research at Massachusetts General Hospital, a Harvard Medical School teaching affiliate in Boston. The teaching hospitals will have fewer beds and fewer residents in clinical specialties, he added.
At the same time, they will develop a greater commitment to the community around them, typically in the inner city, Dr. Blumenthal said. "We will be much more involved with training people to be community-based practitioners," he said. "There will be researchers who study and define primary care." That field has been neglected, he said, because it "was not fashionable or technology intensive or profitable for drug companies to support."
In another change from past practice, because patients are being quickly discharged from hospitals -- on average staying fewer than eight days -- many hospitals are providing follow-up care in the patient's home or a nursing home, which costs less than keeping them in the hospital.
"The winning hospitals are transforming themselves into integrated delivery systems," said David Rey, a managing partner in San Francisco with the Arthur Andersen consulting firm. "They can offer a complete package of services at a capitated rate."
Some hospital groups may end up bypassing the insurance companies and dealing directly with employers and other groups. "The typical insurer go-between role has been lessened," said Bernie Ferrari, a partner who heads health care consulting at McKinsey & Company.
Jack McNamara, president of Sentara Health System in Norfolk, Va., vehemently agrees. "Folks like Cigna and Aetna and Blue Cross really add no value for the purchaser of health care," he contended. Sentara, which has hospitals, H.M.O.'s and nursing homes, is learning to perform insurer services -- actuarial science, claims processing, marketing and member services -- so that it can eventually deal directly with large purchasers of health care, Mr. McNamara said.
It is too early to know whether the Clinton Administration's proposed changes in the health-care system will allow room for companies like Sentara to short-circuit the insurance industry's role.
Genesys in Flint also includes home-care service, a nursing home and hospice care, so patients are placed in the most appropriate -- often the least expensive -- setting, said Young Suh, Genesys's president. The new hospital will be "so efficient that G.M. can really benefit," Mr. Suh said. "We want to assist G.M. by saving money, so they will have a reason to stay in Genesee County."

HEADLINE: THE NIGHT;
Peace, Love And Chompers

BYLINE: By Bob Morris

 BODY:
THE roster of superwaifs, vegetarian grunge actors and musicians in Birkenstocks and beads continues to grow like late-summer squash in the garden of some California commune. That's why the New York Shakespeare Festival's black-tie fund-raising event under a tent at Tavern on the Green on Wednesday, which celebrated the 25th anniversary of the tribal love musical "Hair," carried more cultural weight than it would have two years ago.
It was nice, a relief even, that some of the performers singing about the Age of Aquarius, peace, love, harmony and understanding -- they included Kevin Kline, Ben Vereen and Betty Buckley -- were actually old enough to have lived through the hippie era. And if the event was yet another revival in a season of revivalism, at least it was inspired by a breakthrough moment of political and spiritual intention in musical-theater history. 
 "It was a time of caring for one another," said Mr. Vereen, who was in the original cast of "Hair." He sang "I Got Life" wearing kente cloth over his black tie.
George C. Wolfe, the new producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, who grew up in the segregated town of Frankfort, Ky., said: "I had an Afro and a pair of jeans with patches all over them. The patch on my butt said, 'Kiss me, I'm black.' You couldn't live through a year like 1968 and not feel the dynamics of it. Everything you wore was an expression of defiance. When you're 13 or 14, that's all you have. You can't control the universe, but you can control what you look like."
As happens at a society party in a society on image overload, things got a little confusing. There was the designer Randolph Duke, for instance, who remarked that the soft recycled look now gripping New York and Los Angeles would be in for the rest of the decade. "It takes the rest of America a long time to catch up," he said. There was Gabe Doppelt, the editor in chief of Mademoiselle magazine, who wore a peasant-style hippie dress and said she had never even seen "Hair" but was considering renting the movie this weekend in the Hamptons. And there were the gift bags stuffed with the June issue of Allure magazine (a sponsor of the party), which featured an article called "A User's Guide to Bell-Bottoms."
And then, alas, there were two young women in oversized white T-shirts, red spandex bicycle shorts and air-pumped running shoes. They had slipped away from the crowds at the Corporate Challenge that had brought 10,000 runners into the park that evening. The two women stood in the tent holding the drinks they'd sweet-talked from the bartender and ogled the 600 bold-faced names who had paid at least $500 to support the festival and revel, momentarily, in an era when tribal culture didn't suggest gatherings around a Stairmaster or at a finish line.
 
Too Multicultural to be True
 Many ethnomusicologists, sociologists, urban anthropologists, community organizers and multiculturalists would like to make Don Byron into some kind of a politically meaningful, bridge-building symbol. But he doesn't want to be a symbol. All the 34-year-old, classically trained musician wants to do is to keep developing his music.
Of course, you can't blame people for getting a little politically expectant when they first hear him play. There's something so ripe about a young black jazz clarinetist who grew up in the Bronx and who is so deeply into klezmer music (he refers to it as Jewish hip-hop) that he's recorded an entire album of it. "It's the kind of story a lot of cats can sell," Mr. Byron said with his downbeat cool between sets at the Village Vanguard on a recent Thursday.
"You're so full of humor and surprises," a fan told Mr. Byron, whose dreadlocks were hanging down over his wire-rimmed glasses.
"I work on it," he said.
Mr. Byron's lavish repertory also includes ragtime and postmodern experimental music. One night he can be found at the Knitting Factory playing songs from his klezmer album, "Don Byron Plays the Music of Mickey Katz," with Joel Grey singing solo (Mickey Katz, the clarinetist and klezmer band leader was Mr. Grey's father). On another night he can be found on the "Tonight" show playing hypnotically delicate jazz compositions from his album "Tuskegee Experiments." Once in a while, when he's in town from his home in Boston, he can also be found playing the recorder in the birdhouses of the Bronx zoo. "Stravinsky liked birdy things and Messiaen actually transcribed bird calls and wrote them down," he said.
Mostly, he tries to keep his music and politics in separate cages. Not long after the Crown Heights disturbances in August of 1991, for example, Mr. Byron was asked to give a concert in Brooklyn. He refused. "I'm not going to be an instrument to placate people," he said while cleaning his clarinet with a rag. "If people want to talk about economic issues and access and school boards and community centers, I'm down with that. But if it's just a matter of my getting up there to get people to chill out, I don't think so. I want people to talk about what's bugging them, not to shut up."
Mr. Byron, who is to perform at Central Park's Summerstage on July 4, has been downwind of some pretty strange comments over the years. Once someone came up to him and told him that it was nice to see a black person making money from Jewish music after seeing so many Jewish people making money from black music. At another gig, someone asked him if he was a falafel.
"He meant a Falasha, which is an Ethiopian Jew," Mr. Bryon said. "But I didn't say anything."
 
Scenes From a Screeningsaurus
 New York is in a Jurassic state of mind. The city is in the monstrous and all-consuming jaws of a juvenile action movie deemed by many parents to be too frightening for their children. On Tuesday, at a showing of "Jurassic Park" at the Worldwide Cinemas on Eighth Avenue, Christine and Austin Hearst were sitting with their friends Courtney and Bob Arnott and the two couples' 5-year-old children.
Megan Hearst and Bobby Arnott Jr. were squirming, switching from one parent's lap to the other's with each threatening thud of each approaching dinosaur footstep. Right before each of the scariest scenes, Austin Hearst, who had prescreened the film for the sake of the children, would push firmly downward on their heads, and they'd sink below the seats. That way, they could only hear the movie and the screams of the adults.
Afterward, in the Rotunda of the Museum of Natural History, at the postshow supper party (to benefit the museum and Ronald McDonald House), Susan Crile, a girl who likes to say she is 8 but is still only 7, was sitting between her parents beneath a massive cast of a barosaurus skeleton. "Wasn't it too scary for you?" her father, George Crile, a "60 Minutes" producer, asked her.
"No," she said, as she fingered her "Raptor Attack" coloring book and "Jurassic Park" souvenir lunchbox.
Like most children, she had already seen so many movies that a few animatronic reptiles alive with teeth as large as fists eating people alive just didn't faze her.
"The movies that really disturb her are the ones in which kids are abandoned or badly treated," said her mother, Susan Lyne, the editor of Premiere magazine. "Also, the good things about this movie is that there aren't any dinosaurs, so there's not going to be any dinosaur under the bed at night. 'Jaws' was terrifying because you had to go back into the ocean. For her, a scary movie like this one is just an emotional release."

HEADLINE: RUNWAYS;
Turns of Fashion's Wheel

BYLINE: By Suzy Menkes; Suzy Menkes is fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune.

 BODY:
THE store is so crowded that customers fight to hand over their money. The atrium is a seething, swirling mass of humanity clutching shopping totes. Women with glossy hair and sleek suits rub padded shoulders at the beauty counter. Outside on the sidewalk, yuppie couples juggle attache cases and ice cream.
A shopping mall in America? A rerun of a 1980's movie? An ad man's fantasy? No. Just an ordinary shopping day in Shanghai. 
 The People's Republic of China is where shopping is still happening. Where a passion for fashion has only just been ignited. It is farewell to Mao suits and welcome to power suits. It is also the place to see the postwar cycle of dress and excess starting over.
The Western world is mostly bored with fashion, its consumers faced with bursting closets and its designers determined to tear up -- literally or metaphorically -- the established wardrobe. By contrast, China represents fashion's glad, confident dawning.
In Shanghai, in the peacock parade in front of the Garden Hotel, in the old French quarter of the city, 22-year-old Li Chiu is wearing a passable imitation of a Chanel blouse in cream silk, black pants and gold jewelry that is a hot seller in the stores. Her companion, describing himself as a "salary man," meaning office worker, is playing Michael Douglas in "Wall Street": double-breasted pearl-gray suit, custom-made shirt and flashy gilded watch. Only his sturdy bicycle is not in keeping with the image.
"Everybody in Shanghai likes fashion because you can choose the clothes you wear," said Ms. Li, who is a member of the last generation brought up in the Mao suit, the severe uniform that faded from the urban scene a decade ago.
The shock of Shanghai is overwhelming for those who still think of China as drab and monolithic. On Nanjing Lu, the main shopping thoroughfare, and on Huaihai Lu, women hit the streets in pastel silk suits and matching pumps. The shops sell bright, colorful mass-produced clothes that are made in China and rarely cost more than $60 for an outfit. The First Department Store in Shanghai, with a thronged bridge that spans the street, had a turnover of about $237 million in 1992 and a record 300,000 shoppers during the Chinese New Year period in January.
Beijing is a fashion notch behind Shanghai. Typically, the department stores are cheap and cheerless and look like pictures of stores in postwar Europe. An appetite for clothes is filled by substantial stock without any fancy presentation. But capitalist fortunes are already being made, and with new money comes status dressing. The Palace Hotel in Beijing has a mall with glittering fountains and stores for Louis Vuitton and Ermenegildo Zegna.
So great is the urge to dress for success that in May, the Hong Kong luxury-goods entrepreneur Dickson Poon opened a store to sell women's suits that had Charles Jourdan labels sewn on the sleeves. He is also selling fancy watches, the most overt signs of success. In Guangzhou, tailors make shirts with the left sleeves a little more than an inch shorter than the right ones, the better to show off your Rolex, fake or real.
Why the label craze in China?
"Luxury products offer an individual identity," Mr. Poon said, adding that a sudden increase in disposable income has made people look for ways of defining their success and has inevitably led them to be status conscious.
Mary Wong, the assistant director of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council in Hong Kong and an expert on the Chinese market, said that in 10 years the consumer cycle had gone from bicycle, watch and sewing machine, through refrigerator, washing machine and television, to the current craze for fashion.
"The consumer market is pretty green." she said, to explain why clothes with labels at fancy prices are the new benchmarks.
To see the state of fashion and consumerism after another turn of the wheel, you have only to go from mainland China to Hong Kong. The Hong Kong public is still "aspirational" (no shredded bluejeans or tattered-and-torn clothes here) but they have already seen it all. Giorgio Armani, Chanel, Donna Karan and Calvin Klein all have shops there, and business at most of them seems as slow as at their New York equivalents. The shopping action in Hong Kong is now in medium-priced stores, filled with some shoppers who have graduated from factory outlets and street markets, and others who are trading down.
"I would like to buy designer clothes, but I can't afford them," said a customer at one of the Episode shops in the Central district, who identified herself only as Amy. She was trying on a suit that sold for around $200. Significantly, one of the glossy air-conditioned malls that seems to be doing best is Pacific Place, on Hong Kong Island; it specializes in medium-priced clothes and designers' secondary lines.
And so to Tokyo, which has been the Asian fashion mecca for 15 years, a place where newly rich consumers in droves bought designer-label clothes and where international designers have sometimes done 30 or 40 percent of their overall annual business. Now the stores in the Ginza neighborhood are deathly quiet, visible proof of Japan's gloomy economic statistics.
But down in Shibuya, Tokyo's hip shopping area, there is plenty of action. A new generation is voting with its feet and striding out in clompy shoes under long, loose layered clothes that are oceans away from European status-label dressing.
"I made it myself," said Maiko Maeda, 18, of her apron-dress, for which she recycled a pair of denim overalls by attaching it to the bottom of a man's shirt. Other young women were wearing baggy shorts with hefty boots, long skirts with high-top running shoes and clattering clogs.
In the Harajuku district, fashion has already started to deconstruct: torn jeans, shredded T-shirts, bondage leather and punk hair are worn by rock fans as Tokyo's fashion politics of protest.
Now that the new generation in Japan has started to reject the status clothes their parents craved, will the rest of Asia inevitably follow the same cycle -- fashion boom to fashion bust over 25 years?
Countries that have given up their own traditional costumes turn to the West for a fashion identity, whether defined by American sportswear or by European status labels. It is not surprising that China, its cultural roots brutally severed by revolution, should be such fertile fashion ground.
Nor is it surprising that the world's luxury-goods companies see the emergence of China as the ultimate opportunity for the next millenium. In September, Donna Karan will open a DKNY store in Shenzhen, the special economic zone near Hong Kong; Estee Lauder is China-bound in the new Isetan department store in Shanghai. The mantra chanted by all hopeful China traders is that if you get just 1 percent of the 1.3 billion potential customers, you sell more than 10 million items.
Shanghai's nouveau clothes horses can be seen as proof of fashion's resilience and of its abiding hold on hearts and minds.
In a Beijing market last month, two Russian-speaking women were seen beating down a Chinese vendor to reach their own bilateral agreement. At stake were track pants in flimsy fabrics and screeching colors that were selling for $15 for a pack of 12. Few people in the West would give the items closet room, even at those prices. Yet for these and other similar treasures, the women had traveled for days by train from the former Soviet Union and were about to start the long trek back.
Thousands more from the former-Soviet republics are thronging China's northern cities, sometimes bargaining for clothes so cheap that the Chinese even export them to India.
How awesome to us, with our jaded fashion palettes and sated appetites, that fashion still has so many hungry fans asking for more.

TOKYO: The Asian fashion mecca for 15 years is now moving away from its infatuation with European labels. Fashion is deconstructing here: large, clompy shoes appear under long, loose layered dresses. The truly hip take part in the fashion politics of protest. THE WAY IT WAS: The severe Mao suit, seen far left in a 1974 political drama performance on a commune, was once de rigueur. It has now faded from the urban scene. A sexier style, left, was the snug-fitting traditional cheongsam, like the one worn by Nancy Kwan in the 1960 film "The World of Suzie Wong." HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Ukraine's Not A Kid Brother Anymore

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
RELATIONS between Russia and Ukraine were bound for trouble from the moment the old Soviet Union broke up 18 months ago. Even now, most Russians find it difficult to adjust to the loss of territory that for centuries they considered their own, while Ukrainians are learning that independence requires something more than a flag, a quasi-currency and a foreign policy that has been mostly about proving to the world, and to Russia, that theirs is a serious country, worthy of respect.
But as they try to forge a new relationship, these two Slav neighbors, the two most populous former Soviet republics, have received little help. Their shared history has proved more of a burden than a guide. Both governments, mired in internal crises, have had to fend off nationalist oppositions, while the outside world has taken a laissez-faire attitude that has left both Russians and Ukrainians feeling a bit put out. 
 It has only been recently that the West, its attention riveted on the significant nuclear arsenal that remained on Ukrainian territory after the collapse of the Soviet Union, has taken serious notice of the inherent problems in the Russian-Ukrainian relationship. The United States took the first step with visits first by its special envoy to the former Soviet Union, Strobe Talbott, and later by Defense Secretary Les Aspin, who came from Washington bearing messages of understanding, if not sympathy, for Kiev's security concerns.
Just as Ukraine had expected all along, nuclear weapons were the key to this turnaround. The more politicians in Kiev began to talk about "temporary" nuclear status, the more the West began to think hard about the consequences of two large and potentially unstable nuclear powers living together in uneasy proximity. Even discounting alarmist theories about Ukraine's secret hopes of taking control of the disputed weapons, just the lingering presence of almost 2,000 nuclear warheads on Ukrainian soil is enough to conjure a mini-cold war on Europe's easternmost edge.
In retrospect, many diplomats now agree that it was perhaps a little naive to expect, as the West did a year ago, that Ukraine would simply hand over the strategic nuclear weapons it had inherited to Russia, as it promised to do in the heady days after the Soviet Union's collapse.
 
'Unpleasant Feeling'
 "It is not difficult to understand the unpleasant feeling of sitting on this territory, next to a neighbor they see no reason to trust," said a diplomat in Kiev. "Both the Russians and Americans have to understand just how touchy they are here."
After a meeting last week between Presidents Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine and Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, there are signs that the two countries may be ready to accept a face-saving solution, floated by the Americans, to create an international commission charged with taking control of the disputed weapons, pending their final elimination.
The two Presidents also took steps toward speeding the division of the Black Sea Fleet, another issue that has assumed proportions far greater than the strategic value of the fleet itself. The agreement would also give the Russian navy leasing rights at the Crimean port city of Sevastopol.
 
'Little Brother'A Strike, a Flurry of Flags
 This was not the first time the two Presidents have reached around a crisis to produce an agreement. In the past cases, however, problems arose later as the agreements got thrashed over by recalcitrant bureaucracies and political opponents. This time, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk stipulated that their proposed solution for the Black Sea Fleet be ratified by their respective parliaments, no sure thing in either case.
The problem is that in neither country has the leadership been able so far to put together a consensus on their new relationship. As the larger, richer and militarily more powerful of the two, Russia continues to treat its neighbor as a "little brother," a role that Ukraine is determined to reject.
From Kiev, there is an even more ominous view, shared not only by the nationalist opposition but by many diplomats, that Russia has been carrying out a policy designed to weaken Ukraine and bring it back under Moscow's sway.
They point to an outbreak of strikes in the mainly Russian-populated Donbass region of the Ukraine; to the most recent incident in the Black Sea Fleet dispute, in which more than 200 supply ships simultaneously hoisted the Russian Navy flag; to recent hikes in Russian fuel prices, and to provocative visits by Russian politicians to the Crimea, the Black Sea peninsula that is to Russian nationalists what Alsace-Lorraine was to France before World War I.
"I don't think these are uncoordinated Russian tactics," said a Western diplomat in Kiev. "Russia does not seem to hesitate to make their life more difficult whenever the opportunity arises."
Back in Moscow, diplomats and other observers tend to attribute conspiracy theories to over-developed sensitivities. They note that the Russian Government these days is hard-pressed to carry out its stated policies, let alone covert ones.
Furthermore, Russian Government experts here note that Ukraine is now considerably in arrears on payments to Russia for oil and gas supplies, at prices set directly by oil-producing regions that are still at 30 to 50 percent below world market prices. According to one recent published report, Ukraine now owes Russia 572 billion rubles, or $523 million.
Given their intertwined economies, and their even more intertwined populations (11 million ethnic Russians in Ukraine and 4.5 million ethnic Ukrainians in Russia), the chances of a Yugoslav-type conflict breaking out between the two former Soviet republics is considered highly unlikely. But that does not mean the road to normalized relations will be easy.
In an interview with a Moscow newspaper, the Ukrainian Prime Minister, Leonid Kuchma, said cooperation between the two countries was essential if both were to pull out of economic crises. "Earlier in the country that was once called the U.S.S.R., the life of all republics was regulated by very close interrelations," he said. "But then we began erecting a new building, pulling everything down. Now when the stones of the old foundation are scattered around, we are looking back to see what has happened to us. I think it is time to gather those stones."

HEADLINE: The Enemy Within;
Mexico's Drug Habit Is Giving It Shivers

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
AFTER the first car bombs exploded last year in one of the dusty capitals of Mexico's drug trade, and after traffickers started attacking one another in resort towns like Puerto Vallarta and Cancun, a strange word began to gain currency here. People spoke of "colombianizacion." Then the gunmen of drug gangs shot a Roman Catholic Cardinal 14 times in a battle outside a busy airport last month, and the fear was no longer so abstract: Were the traffickers not starting to menace Mexican society, people asked, the way the cocaine suppliers in Colombia menace theirs?
The investigation into the killings of Juan Jesus Cardinal Posadas Ocampo, his driver and five other people in Guadalajara has again exposed a significant difference between the two countries. The greater threat to Mexico, it would seem, is not a war against the state waged by drug lords, Colombian style. It is that collusion with traffickers by elements of the state may run so deep, much deeper even than in Colombia, as to be beyond the Government's reach. 
 To outraged countrymen, the Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari vowed that neither the killings nor the wider corruption they exposed would go unpunished. The intended target of the Guadalajara attack, Joaquin (El Chapo, or Shorty) Guzman Loera, probably the most powerful trafficker in Mexico, was seized in Guatemala on June 9. Last week the Attorney General dismissed 67 federal agents, waiving his usual insistence on proof of criminal involvement and thereby giving new weight to mere suspicion. A new anti-drug force was ordered formed.
Despite the flurry of new effort, however, Mr. Salinas may continue to be haunted by an official ambivalence toward the drug trade that has lasted long after he promised to make the lives of Mexico's traffickers miserable. Barely a year before the next presidential election, the credibility of his long-ruling party has plummeted again. Mexico may not be sliding toward Colombia, but its rising violence may threaten Mr. Salinas's dream of pulling Mexico up from Latin America, of signing a free-trade agreement with Canada and the United States, of eventually finding it a way from the third world to the first.
The White House has offered little more than praise for Mexico's efforts, in contrast with criticism vented the last time Mexican traffickers claimed such a prominent victim -- the 1985 slaying of Enrique Camarena Salazar, an American drug agent.
On Capitol Hill, however, Mexico's rising violence and concerns that its traffickers might exploit freer trade between the two countries have stoked an old mistrust. And it is in Congress where the fate of the still-unratified North American Free Trade Agreement will be decided this fall.
Two aides to Mr. Salinas described him as "furious" that the Cardinal had been killed, and at such a bad time. In private, such officials often argue that their governance is in part a matter of containing a dark, corrupt and violent old order that they hope to eventually bleed of power. But until recently, they have been freer about stating their lack of control over, say, the political bosses who try to rig elections. They have tended to play down a threat to law, order and foreign investment from the rogue police who kidnap executives and conspire with traffickers.
The sensitivity of the drug issue in Mexico's relationship with the United States sometimes gets lost in the warm spirit of cooperation that has obtained in recent years. A commitment to fight drugs was central to Mr. Salinas's strategy for closer economic and political ties with the United States. It meant new programs to share drug intelligence, a sharp rise in seizures and eradication, and the capture in 1989 of Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, then the country's leading cocaine trafficker, who has been linked to Mr. Camarena's killing.
In recent years, cocaine seizures and the destruction of marijuana and opium poppy fields have continued apace. But there have also been indications that while the Government struck at trafficking with one hand, it held the other behind its back. Mr. Salinas chose as his first Attorney General the man who governed Jalisco state when Mr. Camarena was slain there; at the time, the state was described by American officials as a cesspool of corruption. In addition, one drug-control chief appointed under Mr. Salinas is now a fugitive, and officials say he was the traffickers' most important ally on the force.
Until last month, Mexico had seemed to suffer its drug business relatively lightly by South American standards. Its innocents have died in small handfuls, not by the score. Its judges and prosecutors were targeted for retribution relatively infrequently. Because the Mexican traffickers are primarily in the cocaine-smuggling business, they generally have less territory to protect than do their suppliers, and less need to buy off politicians along with the police.
Traffickers like Mr. Felix Gallardo also seemed to play by rules. Though he is said by drug agents to have bought the protection of scores of police officers and politicians, he has kept such information to himself even after his jailing. And drug-related violence has generally been a private, almost discreet affair -- that is, until the recent escalation of a war pitting Mr. Felix Gallardo's group and that of his Tijuana-based allies, the four Arrellano Felix brothers, against the mafia headed by Mr. Guzman.
Until last fall, no other top traffickers followed Mr. Felix Gallardo into jail. And before his recent transfer to more secure quarters, Mr. Felix Gallardo continued to administer his vast empire from a prison office equipped with a fax machine and cellular telephones. Mr. Guzman's capture this month only revived the question of why Mexican officials are sometimes so smashingly able to strike at traffickers, and most of the time not.
To rebut such questions, Mr. Salinas's second Attorney General, Ignacio Morales Lechuga, kept a running list of the hundreds of agents and prosecutors he dismissed. He liked to replace the old cops with bright young lawyers like Rodrigo Esparza Cristerna, a star of the force who rose quickly to become its chief officer in Sinaloa state, the unofficial headquarters of Mr. Guzman's cartel.
In January, Mr. Morales Lechuga was sent off to Paris as the Mexican Ambassador for reasons yet to be made clear. Mr. Cristerna was fired last week on suspicion of involvement with traffickers, just a few months after he had given reporters an impassioned speech on the new breed in the Attorney General's office.
Of Mr. Morales Lechuga's contention that big drug seizures by his police officers were the proof of headway against corruption, one of the new senior officials said this: "They receive money from one group of traffickers and they cannot act against people from that group. But they have their hands free to arrest people from other groups."
The new Attorney General, Jorge Carpizo MacGregor, has yet to fully answer many questions about the shooting of the Cardinal, including why authorities so vigorusly hunted down Mr. Guzman but have yet to locate his would-be attackers, the Arrellano Felix brothers. But mindful of the Government's credibility problem, he seems to have been candid about the challenges before him. After the Cardinal's death, he conceded he was "surrounded by traitors."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mexican drug trafficker Joaquin Guzman Loera after his arrest this month. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
In a 90's War On Poverty, Who Hands Out Money?

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
FOR more than a quarter century, the broad outlines of the debate over how to provide social services to poor neighborhoods has been set in stone: Liberals have touted the work of community organizations financed with government and foundation money. The Clinton Administration shows every indication of trying to use them extensively, with Henry Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, testifying last week before a House subcommittee in support of a new $50 million program to be funneled through neighborhood groups called community development corporations.
"I believe in community-based solutions," he said. "I'm convinced that it is imperative for us to build, nurture and maintain community-based capacities such as community development corporations."
Conservatives, from the early days of the war on poverty in the mid-1960's, have rolled their eyes over this arrangement, citing inefficiencies and questioning the very premise. 
 But as the once-fledgling community organizations have become entrenched in the politics of cities across the country, the debate has opened up in unusual ways. David Stoesz, a sociology professor at San Diego State University and the former social services commissioner in two East Coast counties, frequently finds himself the odd liberal at conservative gatherings at which the community organizations are lambasted. But after many years, he said he has concluded that they are "the postmodern Tammany Hall."
Michael Gecan, a board member of the Industrial Areas Foundation, a community assistance group, said any group that accepts government grant money is virtually doomed: "The minute you take government money whether you have good or bad intentions, you become very seriously affected by that funding and your relationship with government figures. The people controlling the money will work to keep those getting the money on a leash."
The disillusionment for many is the result of the most egregious irregularities that have beset many community organizations in large cities -- financial scams, cronyism and sheer ineptitude. Scandals have touched major community-based not-for-profit organizations in Chicago, Philadelphia, Atlanta and Washington, among many other cities. Perhaps no "povertician" is more notorious than the South Bronx's Ramon S. Velez, who has drawn more than a million dollars in salaries and consulting fees from a network of community groups that have frequently been cited for poor service, questionable finances and thuggish behavior toward adversaries.
But beyond the flamboyant excesses, and in marked contrast to the quality organizations which exist in almost every city as well, are the drab agencies that, particularly in older Eastern cities with entrenched political machines, run uninspired programs while pursuing what seems to be their main goal: electing their political benefactors and operating patronage mills.
These developments are "a logical outgrowth of the negative aspects of the Great Society," said John Mollenkopf, a political scientist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, particularly in old-line Democratic cities with political machines that can co-opt the neighborhood groups. "It's a very telling feature of New York political culture in contrast to cities like San Francisco, Minneapolis, or Seattle, where there are stronger examples of community organizations."
In New York, where political power bases have evolved from government-financed groups in many neighborhoods, the city's social service agencies last year handed out 4,000 contracts to not-for-profit groups that were worth $2.8 billion. Nationally, because the money flows from so many agencies at so many levels of government, there seems to be no reliable figure for how much money finds its way to neighborhood groups .
The money in New York, while not going exclusively to neighborhood-based groups, has established what amounts to a fourth level of government, one that operates in many ways like government did a hundred years ago, without civil service tests, employee or vendor background checks, or ethics or bidding regulations anywhere as complete as those for government agencies.
 
'Patronage Empires'
 Susan E. Shepard, commissioner of the city's Department of Investigation, said: "The flow of billions of dollars to not-for-profits, operating in the poorest parts of the city, shifts political power to those who control their operations. The money translates into jobs and contracts that can support patronage empires comparable to those historically controlled by political clubhouses."
John Parr, president of the National Civic League, an urban reform group based in Denver, said that when money is distributed, far more emphasis should be placed on how well groups perform than on whether they purport to represent the community. Gladys Carrion, New York's community development commissioner, has spent a couple of years trying to change a grant selection process that for decades has been easily manipulated by neighborhood power brokers.
But others would go further.
"I would wipe all of the groups out," said Theresa Funiciello, a former welfare mother and organizer and the author of "Tyranny of Kindness." Ms. Funiciello argues that money for services should be distributed as much as possible directly to recipients, in the manner of Social Security checks.
Under the current setup, Mr. Gecan said, "you've got a lot of public money with very little accountability and with no real scrutiny. You can keep revealing how terrible some of these groups are, but they keep on rolling. They have no checks and balances."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Turkey, Still Climbing

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

 BODY:
AT first sight, the election last week of Tansu Ciller as Turkey's first woman Prime Minister seemed an anomaly in a society whose secular ideals are offset by a profound, Islamic conservatism.
In a way, though, the vote by the ruling True Path Party showed just how enduring the legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk has proven to be since the founder of modern Turkey launched the land on an often-frustrated Western trajectory in 1923. 
 Ataturk's commitment to women's rights was revolutionary for its time and place. He banned the Islamic veil, insisted on equal rights and gave women the vote in 1932, earlier than some of their European counterparts.
Although it has taken 61 years to move from the voting booth to the Prime Ministry, the process has been comparatively rapid: it took longer, from the suffragette movement of the early 20th century, for Margaret Thatcher to become Britain's first woman Prime Minister. And most other Western nations, the United States included, seem still intent on keeping the top job, formally at least, for men.
These days, though, Ataturk's legacy seems more ambiguous. True, many women have professional status as a result of educational and social policies dating from Ataturk's day: 40 percent of physicists and chemists are women; so are a sixth of the lawyers and doctors.
But a resurgence of Islamic sentiment has brought the veil back onto some streets. In the countryside, women still form the bulk of the menial labor force, and wife-beating is common enough to persuade some municipalities to set up "safe houses" for battered wives. Women, moreover, may not work without their husbands' permission. Nationally, there are fewer woman legislators than there were in Ataturk's time.
Those developments, however, may not rank among Mrs. Ciller's most pressing priorities. The 47-year-old economist has been in politics for only three years and thus has to establish authority over both a troubled and overwhelmingly male party and an uncertain coalition. And she has still to achieve what she failed to do as an economic adviser to her predecessor (and the current President), Suleyman Demirel: bring down Turkey's 60 percent inflation rate to manageable proportions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tansu Ciller, Turkey's new Prime Minister. (Sigli-H.H.A./Sipa)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Women Moved Up in Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
A BARRIER fell in North America last week when Canada's governing Progressive Conservative Party elevated Kim Campbell as its leader and the first woman to become Prime Minister.
But in Canada, obstacles to women in politics and society have been tumbling for years. When the Liberal Party leader, Jean Chretien, takes to the hustings for elections likely this fall, he'll be the only man of the three national party leaders. Four years ago, the New Democrats elected Audrey McLaughlin. Accentuating his isolation is Sheila Copps, chosen as the Liberals' first female deputy leader two years ago. 
 "Campbell is no accident," said Glenda Simms, president of the Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of Women. "This is part of the outcome of the struggle of our women over many years."
"In the political process," she added jubilantly, "we are now achieving a critical mass."
While Canadians are generally more culturally conservative than Americans, they are well ahead of the United States in the achievement of feminist goals, in part as a result of Canadian traditions of social welfare and a stronger union movement.
Canadian women incorporated an equal rights amendment into their constitution in 1982. The sort of vehement opposition from the religious right and other groups that killed the E.R.A. in the United States never materialized in Canada.
A Canadian maternity-leave statute has been on the books since 1972, allowing 17 weeks off, 15 of them paid through unemployment insurance. In the United States, it was only this year, under the new Democratic Administration, that Congress gave workers the right to take unpaid leaves of up to 12 weeks.
Women have 13.5 percent of the seats in the House of Commons, relatively low by the standards of northern Europe but well above the 8.5 percent of seats held by women in the United States Congress.
A strong and committed women's movement is leading the Canadian rights charge. There are rape-crisis centers, interval houses for battered women, immigrant women's working groups. All major universities finance women's studies programs. "I am not so sure the women's movement in the U.S. is as strong or united as in Canada," says Kay Armatage, professor of women's studies at the University of Toronto. "You don't have the political extremes here, or the fragmentation."
Not only is the religious right less active; there is less anti-feminist backlash. Lacking the individualistic bent of their southern neighbors, Canadians take more to quiet collective action.
The main women's organization, the National Action Committee on the Status of Women, has 500 member groups representing 3 million Canadian women. Canada's total population is only 27 million. Thirty percent of the committee's $1 million annual budget comes from the Government. In contrast, the National Organization of Women, the largest women's rights organization in the United States, gets no Federal money.
The Canadian organization has evolved dramatically over the past two decades. It used to be an exclusively white, middle-class network of professional women. Now a third of its members are from minorities or native groups. Native women seeking greater rights on reservations, strongholds of male domination, are among the more vocal members. The organization's new president is a 35-year-old single mother from Vancouver, Sunera Thobani, who reflects Canada's multicultural character. Born in Tanzania of a family that came from India, she is the first non-white to lead the organization.
In both English- and French-speaking Canada, the women's movement gained strength in the 1960's, as in the United States, with an influx of women in the work force, the formation of advocacy groups and wide availability of the pill.
A royal commission was set up in 1967 to look into women's needs. This led to the establishment four years later of a Cabinet minister responsible for the status of women. The involvement of senior levels of government differentiates the movement here from the United States.
Canada's feminists won the main tool of their struggle, the equal rights amendment, in the 1982 Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which says the human rights of the charter are "guaranteed equally to male and female persons." It makes specific allowance for affirmative action.
Marilou McPhedran, a lawyer who helped draft the amendment, said, "When a situation arises in any area of government policy or law and we are able to demonstrate an unequal result being borne by women because they are women, then we have the tool of our Constitution to challenge and have our law or policy either struck down or modified."
The Government has put up millions of dollars to help feminists finance court tests of discrimination. One result was a landmark 1988 decision by Canada's Supreme Court declaring unconstitutional criminal penalties against a Quebec doctor for performing abortions at his private clinic in Montreal rather than at a hospital (90 percent of abortions are performed in hospitals and paid for by national health insurance). The judgment left abortion a civil matter of personal choice.
Another defining moment was the massacre of 14 women by a gunman in Montreal on Dec. 6, 1989, which resulted in a public outcry and gun control legislation shepherded through Parliament last year by Ms. Campbell as Justice Minister. The killings put intense focus on the issue of violence against women.
While ahead of the United States on equal pay, maternity leave and representation, Canadian women lag behind northern Europe. French, Belgian, Italian and Scandinavian women get child care that "North American women would die for," says Doris Anderson, author of "The Unfinished Revolution: The Status of Women in Twelve Countries," which was published last year.
Still, hope is high for further change here. Feminist studies show that women in office, regardless of affiliation, tend to be more supportive than men of so-called women's issues like abortion and day care. Polls now even show that women have a better chance than men of winning elections, and in the coming elections Canada's parties are expected to field a record number of women.
Ms. Campbell, who describes herself as a feminist, was nevertheless criticized by many in the women's movement when as Justice Minister she walked a fine line between progressive policies and the conservatism of her Tories. Yet even one of the critics, Ms. Thobani of the National Action Committee, called her elevation "a historic moment for all the women of Canada."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kim Campbell, Canada's first female Prime Minister, after her party selected her last week. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Human Rights: The West Gets Some Tough Questions

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
IT is tempting to reduce the global human rights debate today to a clash of good guys against bad guys, of Western democracies against Asian dictatorships, of countries defending the principle of universal human rights against third world attempts to water down the concept with economic, cultural and religious arguments.
It is all the more tempting because the attack on traditional "Western" human rights is being led by the likes of China, Syria and Iran, countries not exactly renowned for their love of democracy. Further, with barely a blush, the Asian bloc seems to have assumed the Soviet bloc's old role of opposing international "meddling" on human rights. 
 Yet halfway through the World Conference on Human Rights, the first such gathering in 25 years, it is apparent that the debate is becoming more complicated: not only do some of the third world's economic arguments have validity, but lobbies in the West are now claiming special rights for, say, women, children, indigenous peoples, migrant workers and the handicapped.
As a result, the notions enshrined in the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights -- the right to life and security, along with a host of "negatives," such as the rights not to be tortured, raped, imprisoned without due cause or "disappeared" -- are in danger of becoming lost in a broader discussion about democracy, development, culture and religion.
Led by the United States, Western nations -- now backed by Moscow and its former satellites -- say they prefer to end the Vienna conference without agreement Friday if the alternative is a final document that threatens the principle of universal human rights. They are also determined to give the United Nations greater power to monitor and denounce human rights abuses.
In this, they are being strongly supported by delegates from over 1,000 non-governmental organizations, including many from Asia, who dismiss the third world's "relativist" arguments as nothing more than excuses for authoritarian regimes.
The meeting last week verged at times on the surreal. On the first floor, human rights groups busily denounced everything from attacks on Guatemalan Indians to trafficking in Thai women. One floor above, the diplomats could discuss only general principles.
Yet, by positioning itself as judge of the world's behavior, the West is also vulnerable to charges of upholding double standards. Today's worst atrocities are taking place in Bosnia, and the West has done little to stop them. Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, also had to recite a public mea culpa last week about the "xenophobic outrages" in his own country.
In addition, it is not forgotten here that the West was once happy to back anti-communist dictatorships and now protects despotic Arab monarchies out of fear of Islamic fundamentalism.
Yet perhaps the greatest weakness in the West's case is that it has traditionally emphasized political over economic rights. "It's hard for people who have never faced hunger or illiteracy to understand how crucial they are to a majority of mankind," Reed Brody of the International Human Rights Law Group said. "Ask an American about human rights and he'll say: freedom of speech. Ask an African woman about human rights and she'll say: the right to feed her children."
In a switch in American policy, the Clinton Administration has decided to recognize the "right to development." Last week, most Western countries also paid lip service to the "indivisibility" of human rights which means, as Pierre Sane, the head of Amnesty International, put it, that "you can't choose between torture and starvation." Yet the West's focus at this conference is still on civil and political rights.
As a result, while repressive regimes in say, China, Cuba, Iran, Burma, Vietnam and Syria may have little credibility when they claim that human rights are strictly internal matters, they and others -- among them, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia -- have won more sympathy for their argument that economic development is a more immediate priority than Western-style democracy.
Indeed, without bothering to point to democracy's dismal record in lifting third world countries out of poverty, many Asian one-party states can boast extraordinary economic growth of late. "The argument that human rights is the precondition for development is unfounded," said China's Deputy Foreign Minister, Liu Huaqiu.
In justifying his country's one-party system, Singapore's Foreign Minister, Wong Kan Seng, recalled that the United States, Britain and France took 200 years to consolidate democracy. And he argued that democracy can still be interpreted differently. "Singaporeans, for instance, do not agree that pornography is an acceptable manifestation of free expression or that homosexual relationships are just a matter of life style choice," he said.
He also said that "too much stress on individual rights over the rights of the community will retard progress." For example, he went on, Singaporean society protects itself by requiring anyone "who behaves in a suspicious manner" to be tested for drug use. Elsewhere, "the community's interests are sacrificed because of the human rights of drug consumers and traffickers."
Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, went further, arguing that, because human rights exist as a function of history, culture, value systems, geography and phases of development, they are "the competence and responsibility of each government." In other words: West keep out.
But this is not another North-South schism. Most Latin American and some African countries now agree that universal human rights exist. Last week, Nigeria, Gambia and Uganda endorsed the American proposal that a new United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights be appointed.
Indeed, in a sense, the conference can already claim success. If Asian countries are attacking universal human rights, it is because they are under closer scrutiny. And if non-governmental organizations are stronger, it is because peoples' awareness of their "right" to human rights is growing. "This movement is more important than the conference," one American official said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bosnian demonstrators at the World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: BILLIONS IN LOSSES SEEN IN MORTGAGES INSURED BY H.U.D.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
After what its own auditors call years of neglectful management, the Department of Housing and Urban Development expects to lose as much as $11.9 billion as hundreds of apartment building owners default on their Government-insured mortgages.
Most losses, which are expected to occur in the next few years, would be borne by taxpayers through Congressional appropriations. The troubled loans represent more than a quarter of the $43 billion in mortgages insured by the department under programs to encourage the construction of apartment buildings. 
 The expected losses could eventually bring hundreds of thousands of apartments under the ownership of the housing agency, which has a track record of allowing problem projects to deteriorate into slums. The buildings in question range from luxury apartments to tenements and are found all over the country, though there is a concentration in the troubled real-estate markets of the Northeast and Texas.
 
Potential for Huge Losses
 Under the loan programs, the Government sought to increase the nation's housing supply by encouraging banks to make loans on projects they might otherwise have passed up. Most of the loans were reviewed in advance by H.U.D., which promised to repay lenders in full if the developers defaulted on their mortgages. In reviewing the loans, H.U.D. was supposed to deny insurance on those deemed exceedingly risky.
Henry G. Cisneros, the Housing Secretary, acknowledged "the potential for massive losses" and in a written statement on Friday called the forecast "the single largest problem I have inherited" in a department rife with management problems. He pledged aggressive actions to mitigate the losses, including moving faster to resell buildings acquired through loan defaults.
 
Poor Management Cited
 Housing officials have known for years that they faced significant losses in the insurance program, under which the department paid the banks in full for any mortgages on which apartment owners defaulted. But the extent of the problem became clear only in April after a study by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, indicated that the amount of bad loans was more than double the department's earlier estimates.
A copy of the confidential report was obtained by The New York Times.
Much of the projected loss stems from the general downturn in the real-estate market, which has also brought large losses to private lenders. But reports by the agency's inspector general have also emphasized neglectful management practices by H.U.D., which may have added billions to the bailout's eventual costs. There is no way to determine how much of the loss could have been averted through more vigilant oversight.
The inspector general's office has been particularly critical of computer shortages and staffing cuts that have left the agency unable to keep track of its huge financial portfolios. In some instances, a single department official has been left to keep track of 100 projects, a workload six or seven times the industry average.
The $11.9 billion projection is the department's best guess, under current economic forecasts, of the amount the Government will lose by paying off the failed loans. Actual losses could be greater or lower, depending on the health of the economy, the steps Congress takes and the success of the department's management strategy.
 
Will Add to Deficit
 Mr. Cisneros said he was "working daily" with the White House to draft a bill that would give the department greater flexibility, and additional money, to manage distressed properties. Part of that strategy involves seeking additional money to renovate and sell the properties.
That notion has drawn early approval from Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, who said this week, "This a question of whether we're willing to spend a dime to save a dollar." Mr. Kerry is a member of the Senate subcommittee on housing and urban affairs, which will hold a hearing on Tuesday on the issue.
A small portion of the $11.9 billion would be covered by the insurance premiums paid by building owners. But the majority would come from Congressional appropriations, increasing the deficit, and squeezing the amount left over for housing assistance for the poor.
As of 1991, H.U.D. estimated that it was likely to lose $5.5 billion, with the bulk, $3.6 billion, coming from a troubled Reagan-era program. That program, co-insurance, gave lenders handsome fees for issuing loans without H.U.D.'s advance approval, but it left the Government with most of the risk.
But the Coopers & Lybrand audit prompted H.U.D. to raise the estimate of its losses in other insurance programs to $7.8 billion, up from $1.5 billion. That raised the total expected losses to $11.9 billion, with co-insurance accounting for about 30 percent.
The warning of multibillion-dollar losses comes four years after a series of scandals earned H.U.D. a reputation as one of the Government's most corrupt and inept agencies.
 
Vulnerable to Fraud
 Audits by the inspector general have credited the Bush Administration's Housing Secretary, Jack F. Kemp, with improving H.U.D.'s ethical culture. But the reports have also said that the department's management systems remain vulnerable to waste and fraud because of staff shortages, computer problems and lax accounting.
Among the unresolved questions about the losses is whether Mr. Kemp could have done more to prevent them. Mr. Kemp referred questions about the program to a spokesman.
"We took a horrendous situation and improved it," said the spokesman, Bill Dal Col, who served as Mr. Kemp's chief of staff at the department. He noted that it was Mr. Kemp who abolished the co-insurance program and commissioned the Coopers & Lybrand study to get reliable estimates of the fund's financial health.
But C. Austin Fitts, a former top aide to Mr. Kemp, painted a critical picture this week of his management of the program. She said an amount "in the billions" could have been saved through a more aggressive management strategy, including striking deals with business owners. The idea, common in commercial real estate, is to give borrowers small concessions, like reduced payments, to keep them from defaulting on their entire loan.
Ms. Fitts said Mr. Kemp opposed such arrangements, fearing he would be accused of giving developers the sort of sweetheart deals they had enjoyed under his predecessors. She characterized Mr. Kemp's attitude as "one could be done on a corrupt basis, and I could get a bad headline."
Ms. Fitts served as Federal Housing Commissioner for 18 months until 1990, when she was dismissed by Mr. Kemp, in part because of disagreements over this issue.
 
Single-Family Plan Solvent
 Mr. Dal Col said aggressive dealmaking would have been reckless, given a recent history of unscrupulous developers winning windfall Government concessions.
The insurance programs are run by the Federal Housing Administration, an arm of H.U.D., and they have existed for decades.
H.U.D.'s $43 billion worth of insurance covers approximately 15,000 projects with a total of 1.8 million apartments. The F.H.A. backs more than $353 billion in mortgages under a similar program for single-family homes. That fund, which is intended to sustain itself through insurance premiums paid by borrowers, is considered financially sound.
Investment in apartment buildings is considered inherently more risky, and it was always anticipated that Congressional appropriations would be needed beyond the premiums, though not of the magnitude now forecast.
If building owners are more than 30 days late with their mortgage payments, the lenders can invoke the insurance and have the Government repay the full value of the mortgage. In such cases, the housing department takes over as the lender, collecting the monthly payments from the apartment owners. That is now the case with 2,422 of its 15,000 projects, representing about 360,000 apartments.
But the owners of more than half of those projects are delinquent in their payments to the department. H.U.D. may then foreclose, take ownership of the properties and resell them to recoup its losses.
The growing defaults threaten to flood the department with apartment buildings it is unable to manage. As recently as 1990, H.U.D. owned only 10,000 apartments through insurance foreclosures. That figure will soon rise to 69,000 as a result of foreclosure proceedings now under way, according to the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress.
 
650,000 Units at Risk
 If H.U.D. forecloses on all troubled loans identified in the Coopers & Lybrand study, it will find itself owning as many as 650,000 apartments. Department officials say their management plan will avert such scenarios.
In the meantime, the department lacks the money and the skill to manage the buildings it now controls, most of which are being supervised by subcontractors and are deteriorating.
The department's problems are being aggravated by a 1987 law requiring H.U.D. to attach expensive new subsidies to all the foreclosed apartments before it resells them, to insure they are affordable to people with low incomes.
The General Accounting Office estimates that the department needs as much as $3 billion in new subsidy money before it can sell the 69,000 apartments in the process of being foreclosed. Last year, it received only $93 million.
 
A Decade of Problems
 H.U.D. took over Grant Manor, a 185-unit project in Boston's South End, in 1984, but local officials have still not sold it. "We needed subsidy dollars to sell it, and we didn't have them," said Ken Salk, the acting director of housing at the Boston regional office.
In the last 10 years, the department's staff has been cut to about 13,500, from 17,000, and reports from the inspector general have repeatedly warned it can no longer manage its programs.
Ms. Fitts complained that travel budget cuts had prevented the department's staff members from monitoring distressed projects. In a 1989 memorandum to Mr. Kemp, she wrote that while the reduced budget "saved $50,000 last year, we lost tens of millions of dollars in multifamily foreclosures."
In 1989, the department hired the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse to audit the insurance fund and prepare a statement on its financial health. But the accounting firm said the program's records were too disheveled for it to come to any conclusions.
As a result, H.U.D. hired Coopers & Lybrand, which wrote that it found the central office's database so flawed that it "failed to pass even minimal integrity tests." The auditors then traveled to field offices and reconstructed records on a sample that covered 13 percent of its loan portfolio.

Grant Manor residents used the housing complex's playground. (Evan Richman for The New York Times) (pg. 26)
