HEADLINE: Where Chinese Yearn for 'Beautiful' U.S.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: XIAMEN, China, June 19

 BODY:
As the hogs outside grunted their protests at the drizzle, R. T. Liang sipped cheap tea from one of his set of cracked cups and spoke of the Beautiful Country with a reverence that Americans might find both flattering and unsettling.
"The United States -- what a place!" Mr. Liang said wistfully, as family members clustered around him in his home, next to a porcelain God of Wealth apparently erected less in gratitude than in hope. "It's so rich! If there weren't restrictions, everybody would leave here. We would go to look for work in America, Hong Kong or Taiwan. If we could figure out how to get there, we would all go. The villages would become empty." 
 Mr. Liang is still searching for a way out, but tens of thousands of others from Fujian Province here in southeastern China have already found a path to Mei Guo, the "Beautiful Country," as the United States is known in Chinese.
Fujian Province, a lush green land of peasants, fishermen and -- perhaps more relevant -- smugglers, is the homeland of most of the 320 or so passengers on the Golden Venture, the ship that ran aground off New York this month. The incident spotlighted Fujian as the prime source of the deluge of Chinese boat people seeking a new life in the United States.
Three days of interviews here in southern Fujian, from the noodle stands of Xiamen to the tiny mud paths of the surrounding countryside, underscored how difficult it will be to control the migration. The provincial government has just begun a crackdown on the "snakeheads" who organize the human smuggling, but it seems that for every Fujianese who has made the journey so far, thousands more would like to join the line.
The reason for the migration is not exactly that the 32 million people who live in Fujian are poor, for in fact they are richer than they ever have been, and Fujian today is one of the more prosperous parts of China. Rather, the underlying factors seem to be the growth of the money culture, the rise of criminal gangs that arrange the smuggling, and the increasing boldness and mobility of peasants.
"Why do Fujianese want to go abroad, even though we're richer than other Chinese?" mused a history teacher in Xiamen as she munched on a 90-cent bowl of beef noodles in a street stall. "We're on the coast, and so we know more about what life is like abroad. So while we're better off, we also know more than people in other parts of China what we're missing."
In a larger sense, the problem appears to be that the Communist Party is relaxing its grip, in some respects perhaps losing its grip, on peasants and workers. Party slogans no longer motivate people -- money has taken over that role -- and the authorities seem as overwhelmed by the boat people as by corruption, prostitution, narcotics, smuggling and crime.
"The police don't interfere," said a young street tough, who goes to work each day outside a Xiamen hotel. "After all, this is the reform period, so they leave people alone."
Having resolved the theoretical issue, he then tried to persuade a visitor to change money on the black market ("there's a very good rate today") or to hire the services of a prostitute ("she's very cheap and convenient").
 
A Model Migrant Can't Get Out
 In a creek-side village 50 miles and a world away from the Holiday Inn, Y. H. Chen is the kind of clean-cut, hard-working, ambitious young man who causes American immigration officials to tear their hair out. Mr. Chen, 27, strong and sturdy, with a hint of a mustache, lives with his parents and some of his nine brothers and sisters in a grimy stone house decorated with pictures from a 1991 calendar.
Mr. Chen has only one-third of an acre to support himself and his wife, so he has roamed the region trying to improve his life. At times he found construction jobs paying about $30 a month, but they did not last long. For a while he sold chickens on the free market here, winning business by charging low prices. Then the other sellers beat him up and drove him away.
In recent years, Mr. Chen tried to sneak into Taiwan and Macao, but both times he was caught immediately and sent back. The "snakehead" who arranged his trip to Macao was a trickster, Mr. Chen complained.
"He promised he would have a good job for me, paying 3,000 yuan a month," Mr. Chen said, referring to the equivalent of about $535, a princely sum. "But it was all lies. He cheated me."
 
He Tried to Join A Migrant Boat
 A few months ago, Mr. Chen heard that people from a nearby village were arranging a ship to go to America, and he rushed over and pleaded to be allowed to join in. But they were wary of outsiders and refused to allow him on board. He has heard a rumor that they made it to the United States and now have good jobs, but he does not know if it is true. These rumors take on a life of their own, and they help feed the desperation to leave.
"I'd love to go to the U.S., but I don't know how," Mr. Chen said, sitting on a tiny chair next to a faded old tea table. "You need lots of money to take care of everything, and we're very poor here. So there's just no way."
It began to rain outside, so the villagers quickly took off their shoes and went barefoot to avoid splotching their shoes with mud from the footpaths. Mr. Chen's older brother, Y. C. Chen, entered the room and poured himself a cup of tea, explaining that he too would like to go abroad.
It is not that either man is particularly unhappy, for both readily acknowledge that life is getting better each year. Fujian is part of a belt of coastal China that is experiencing economic growth rates of more than 15 percent a year, probably the highest in the world. Prospects are bright, because economic ties are growing with Taiwan -- a bit more than 100 miles offshore -- and more and more Taiwan companies are moving their assembly lines to Fujian.
But for all the improvements in the standard of living -- the black-and-white televisions that most villagers now own, the bicycles and radios that are ubiquitous, the opportunities for women to give birth in a hospital instead of at home -- ambitions are spiraling at an even faster clip. People want to get ahead and to impress their neighbors, and the easiest way to impress people in the China of the 1990's is with a stack of cash.
 
'Everyone Thinks Only of Money'
 "These days everybody thinks only of money," the older brother mused as he sipped his tea. "That's why we want to go abroad."
"With money, you can do anything," he added. "You just give some presents to officials and police, and nothing is impossible."
Money even appears to have purchased a refuge in Fujian for a couple of leaders of international criminal gangs engaged in the smuggling of migrants. Two reputed gang leaders, Paul Jin-Fei Wong and Guo Liangqi, both wanted in the United States, are said to be hiding out with their bodyguards in northern Fujian Province.
For now, it is impossible to verify their whereabouts, partly because the Government bans journalists from northern Fujian. In any case, their presence would not necessarily indicate complicity on the part of the central Government. Local party or military officials could easily provide weapons and hideouts to gang leaders in exchange for a cut in the profits.
The national authorities are trying to crack down on the human smuggling operations, not least because the Government finds it embarrassing that so many people should want to flee. The leaders of Fujian held a conference on the topic a few days ago and announced a crackdown on the "snakeheads," as well as a propaganda campaign to warn peasants about the dangers.
The official newspapers have published accounts of the Golden Venture episode, in which at least six people died, but peasants rarely read newspapers. None of the villagers interviewed had ever heard of the case.
Nor did they seem particularly interested, perhaps because they were too busy asking a visitor all kinds of questions about the United States: Are there villages in America? How many children are Americans allowed to have? You're all rich, aren't you?
And the most common questions: Does America need Chinese workers? How can I get to the United States?
 
China Arrests 210 In Illegal Emigration
 The Government announced that in the first five months of this year it arrested 210 smugglers involved in 37 cases of illegal emigration. These were apparently only a small fraction of the number of shiploads of migrants to leave Fujian.
"Coastal areas will start by strengthening local Government powers and make great efforts to impose law and order," People's Daily declared a few days ago. "They will use every method to reveal the conspiracy of snakeheads and overseas gangs, while strengthening propaganda and education for the masses so as to prevent people from being cheated."
One headache for the authorities will be how to handle the boat people who are returned. Punishing them severely would discourage others from going, but it would also provoke charges of human right abuses and perhaps bolster the efforts of those already abroad to claim asylum.
According to nearly everyone interviewed, the procedure for boat people who are returned is to detain them for a few days to make sure that they are not wanted for some crime. Then they are normally fined, based on what the police think the market will bear: a wealthy entrepreneur may be fined thousands of dollars, while an impoverished peasant pays virtually nothing.
Some boat people are also sent to a labor camp for "re-education" for a few months, particularly if they are repeat offenders or seem to have a "bad attitude."
The peasants suggest that few of the boat people are politically active, although one of the first things most learn about the United States is that they should claim to be pro-democracy campaigners facing prison if returned to China. For good measure, they learn to say that they have already had their quota of one or two children and face forced sterilization if repatriated.
It is true that female peasants are often forcibly sterilized if they have had all the children they are allowed, but most boat people are men. Only in Sichuan Province is it quite common for men to face sterilization.
 
Smuggling of Goods Is Big Business
 While the crackdown on the snakeheads is just beginning, the Government has been trying for more than five years -- without any success -- to stop the smuggling of cigarettes, computers, video players, cars, pornographic videotapes and other products along the Fujian coast.
The authorities lose hundreds of millions of dollars each year in duties and taxes to the smugglers. Crooked police and customs officials play a central role in the smuggling operations, so perhaps it is not surprising that the police have been less than effective in eradicating the smuggling.
Any crackdown in Fujian also runs against a tradition going back to the 17th century of emigration to start a new life abroad. Most of Taiwan's inhabitants trace their roots to Fujian, and large numbers of Fujianese now live in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and other countries.
One of the first things any Fujianese learns is that the world abroad is full of opportunity, and that those who go abroad often become fabulously wealthy and successful. For most of the Communist era, tight police controls made it impossible to flee, but in the last decade the boom in contacts with Taiwan and the proliferation of private boats have allowed Fujian to resume its traditional role as an export base for workers.
"Lots of people from here have gone to Hong Kong or elsewhere, and they've gotten rich," said a worker in Xiamen whose older sister married a Chinese-American and is now living in Washington. "We see that. They come back and start factories and become big bosses."
He added: "We Fujianese think of the United States as a kind of heaven. We worship the United States. I would love to go and work there, if only I could find a way."

HEADLINE: Japan's Crisis: U.S. to Profit?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 19

 BODY:
For the better part of four decades America has held tight to the view that the unshakable dominance of a single, conservative party in Japan is essential to Washington's most critical alliance in the Pacific -- first as a bulwark against Communism, and second as a platform for one of the world's most remarkable economic success stories.
But as the party grew bloated with power, and the endless payoffs and influence-peddling became an international embarrassment for Japan, American officials increasingly found themselves forced to avert their eyes from the system's rotting core. 
 Though Washington was loath to criticize the decay of Japanese democracy publicly, the corrupt bonds between politicians and business became an integral part of the often invisible barriers that make it so frustrating for foreigners to break into the Japanese market.
 
For Better or Worse?
 So today, as the country's governing party continued to spin apart in the fractious generational battle that brought down the Government on Friday night, American and Japanese officials alike struggled with the question few are ready to answer: Will the uneasy relations between the two nations be better or worse off if the aging leaders who built Japan's postwar alliance with the United States finally lose power?
For years, critics of the one-party domination of Japan's political system have argued that only when a centrist alternative emerges will Japan begin to respond to the needs of consumers rather than manufacturers. That in turn could pry open the country's markets in ways that legions of trade negotiators could never accomplish.
But a more contentious political system may also be one that America has a more difficult time handling. For four decades Washington has been able to go to the governing party to solve its problems, and in every area except trade it has almost always obtained results. That era may be about to end.
 
Many Prepared to Bolt
 By this afternoon, it seemed that the end could come very soon. After the rebellion within the party that led to a vote of no confidence against the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, the Cabinet declared that an election would be held on July 18.
But by some counts, nearly a quarter of the members of Parliament who make up the Liberal Democratic Party's 38-year-old majority in the lower house are preparing to bolt from the party. Ten announced today that they were breaking away, and the leaders of the group that ousted Mr. Miyazawa are expected to announce the formation of a new, competing conservative party on Wednesday.
Today they received considerable encouragement. "Now is the time to make good use of ballots to put an end to the L.D.P.'s one-party rule," the Asahi Shimbun, a major daily, argued in an editorial.
In private, leaders of the old guard surrounding Mr. Miyazawa conceded that it would be virtually impossible to hold on to the majority it has commanded in the lower house of Parliament beginning in 1955. That was before 40 percent of Japan's population -- now 123 million people -- were born.
 
Coalition a Possibility
 "It is doubtful that there are enough votes for anyone to decisively take power away from the L.D.P.," Yasunori Sone, a professor of political science at Keio University, a leading training ground for politicians, said today. "But there certainly are enough to cripple it, forcing a coalition. It could take years before the new lines of power are really established."
The early date set for the election means that the paralyzed caretaker Government will be in the midst of a desperate campaign -- with candidates' sound trucks blaring through the streets of Tokyo -- by the time President Clinton and the leaders of fiveother major industrial nations arrive here in three weeks for their summit meeting.
But the leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party felt they had no choice but to hold the election as soon as possible. If they waited even a week more, election day would take place just after the start of a criminal trial against Shin Kanemaru, the power broker who until last year epitomized the party's awesome power, appointing and dismissing prime ministers at will, and receiving millions of dollars in illicit payments. Mr. Kanemaru is accused of evading taxes on tens of millions of dollars found in his home and offices this year, including several hundred pounds of gold bars kept in an aging safe.
Mr. Kanemaru's hoard of gold exemplifies America's dilemma in dealing with Japan's leaders. He often described himself as America's close friend and was treated that way: when he visited Washington last year, just before scandal erupted around him, President Bush invited him to the family quarters of the White House for coffee.
When the United States needed Japanese help -- a huge $13 billion contribution to the Persian Gulf war, or aid to Russia, or big contributions to America's space station, or the cost of stationing American troops in the Pacific -- it was Mr. Kanemaru and his circle of fellow septuagenarians who always came through. The huge faction that he and former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita headed could solve in a single phone call problems that American negotiators otherwise might take months or years arguing about with Japan's bureaucracy.
 
Help From the C.I.A.
 It is a relationship with nearly a half-century of history. "When the American occupation of Japan began, we purged the right wing," Robert Orr, a political scientist as Temple University's campus here, noted today. "Then in 1947 we reversed it all, put them back in politics to counter the Socialists and the Communists, and began to imprison the leftists."
For decades, many Japanese and American officials say privately, the Central Intelligence Agency even financed the Liberal Democratic Party to make sure it did not lose ground to its opposition. And Japanese voters came to associate the party with stability and anti-Communism: even when it was last threatened with a split, in 1980, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and other cold war tensions brought it to victory, to Washington's relief.
But by the 1980's the rampant corruption and arrogance that underpinned the faction's power -- and eventually set off its collapse and the party split that brought down the Government on Friday night -- often worked very much against American economic interests. No American construction company, for example, had a prayer of competing for huge Government contracts with Japanese companies that propped the faction up with millions of dollars in secret donations.
Thus, as the relationship of America with Japan has turned from security to trade, many have argued that its interests are changing.
"With the end of the cold war, I think you can argue that it is far better for our interests if there are two centrist parties, alternating power," said Michael Mochizuki, a professor at the University of Southern California who specializes in Japanese politics. "I'm one of those who always thought that the L.D.P. was more part of the problem than part of the solution."
The argument is simple: with two such parties actively contesting seats, one is bound to take up the interests of consumers -- and thus the interests of American business, whose goods here would make Japan's markets far more competitive. Until now, consumer interests have always been subjugated to the interests of Japan's manufacturers, who are also, of course, the money supply for the Liberal Democrats.
 
More of the Same Is Possible
 Many argue that their day is long gone. "Having accomplished what they set out to accomplish after the war, none of the parties today any longer serves Japan's needs," Kenichi Ohmae, a well-known management consultant, has said. He recently started a reform movement to change all of Japan's political parties.
The problem with the argument is that while it may make sense in American terms -- politics often turns on pitting the interests of producers against consumers -- no one knows whether it will have much appeal in Japan.
For decades Japanese voters have associated the growth of industry with the growth of their own wealth. Japan's consumer movements are tiny. Though some new political groups, like the Japan New Party, have begun to appeal to consumer interests, they have yet to pick up much steam.
Moreover, the rebels who downed Mr. Miyazawa are old wine in new bottles. Ichiro Ozawa, the "reformer" who masterminded the political coup this week, was trained by Mr. Kanemaru, and before that by Kakuei Tanaka, the Prime Minister most associated with the Lockheed scandal of the 1970's and a range of other shady deals.
In short, what could emerge from all of this turmoil is more of the same. Political chaos in Japan is an invitation for the most conservative force in Japan to step forward: the bureaucracy.
The weakness of political leaders plays into the hands of the Finance Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which traditionally have represented the interests of Japan Inc. In the short term, at least, that could mean a far more difficult time for American negotiators, at least until clear political leadership emerges that could be pressed to overrule the bureaucrats.
What could weaken them the most, of course, is open debate in Japanese politics about national policy. That has always been missing here, washed away by patronage and cash. "The biggest hope," said Professor Mochizuki, "is that what will emerge from all of this is some vision of a new Japan."

HEADLINE: As Hispanic Presence Grows, So Does Black Anger

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 19

 BODY:
When Cuban refugees began arriving here 30 years ago, Ruth Page was working as a seamstress in a tailoring and cleaning shop, and she says she had no strong feelings one way or another about the Spanish-speaking people. But when she lost her job to a Cuban, her attitude changed.
Now Mrs. Page remains resentful,and worried about the still-growing Hispanic presence in Miami. So when the Dade County Commission met last month to consider abandoning a requirement that all county business be conducted in English, she was one of several black Miami residents who attended the meeting to speak out. 
 "They are taking over, and I am a victim of that," Mrs. Page, who is now retired, complained after the commission voted unanimously to rescind the English-only rule.
Mrs. Page's attitude is shared by many other blacks as the city's Hispanic population has grown to dominate the economic and political life.
And although the language vote was among recent events that led some Hispanic and black officials to declare that "a new era" of tolerance and understanding was at hand, many of the deepest differences between the two groups remain unresolved.
The way those differences are settled, or not hold lessons not just for Miami but the entire country, prominent members of both groups say.
"The situation we are living in Miami today will be true of most major cities in America in the next 10 years," said Eduardo J. Padron, president of the Wolfson Campus of Miami-Dade Community College and a member of the executive committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
In Dade County, which includes Miami, the Hispanic population has grown, in a little more than 30 years, from 5 percent to a majority of the two million residents. In the same time, the population of non-Hispanic blacks has risen slightly, to about 20 percent from about 15 percent. These two trends have generated tensions over issues like jobs, government contracts, claims on public services and the distribution of political power.
Complicating the population shift is a clash of two very different concepts of race and ethnicity. English-speaking blacks are increasingly alienated from their Spanish-speaking counterparts, who identify themselves by their linguistic and cultural heritage, rather than their race, and associate mostly with other Spanish speakers, of whatever color.
 
New Responses Required
 In some important respects, though, Miami's situation diverges from that of New York, where Puerto Ricans are the main Hispanic group, and other cities. In New York City, for instance, Hispanics for the most part have not come as political refugees, and are on average poorer than blacks.
American blacks have long been accustomed to being the principal minority group in a given locale, with whites the majority. But situations in which Hispanic people outnumber blacks, or have replaced non-Hispanic whites as the dominant group, as is the case here, are new, requiring all three groups to find new responses and make new accommodations.
That demographic phenomenon is likely to occur with increasing frequency over the next decade in cities around the country because of continued immigration and high birth rates.
Hispanic people, who totaled 22.3 million nationally in the 1990 census, already outnumber blacks in Los Angeles and Houston, are rapidly pulling even in New York City and Dallas and are expected to overtake blacks as the nation's largest minority group between 1997 and 2005, according to various demographic projections.
"As a nation, we have pretty much developed our notion of minority policy based on the black population, and just stuck Latinos and Asians into that profile," said David Hayes-Bautista, a sociologist at the University of California at Los Angeles who has studied relations between minority groups. "The problem is that the profile doesn't fit. We're used to thinking of a unified minority agenda, but as the minority population becomes less black, the issues become different.
"Language and immigration, for instance, have never been part of the traditional black agenda, or are in conflict with it," Dr. Hayes-Bautista continued. "On the other hand, low levels of participation in the labor force, high levels of family disintegration and certain types of health problems are not Latino issues, frankly."
 
Minority Concept Challenged
 That conflict is already being played out here, where some prominent blacks maintain that Hispanic residents, especially Cubans, should not be regarded as a minority group because of their numbers and their economic success.
"In South Florida they are doing excellently," said Gary Siplin, a lawyer who is president of the New Miami Group, which seeks to encourage black leadership in government and business. "They own radio stations, TV stations, schools, banks, buildings, businesses. They have the jobs."
H. T. Smith, a black lawyer, said that as far as he is concerned, Cuban-Americans are simply "white people whose native language is Spanish."
Some black legislators here have argued that because Hispanic people now constitute the majority here, they should lose eligibility for certain minority benefits, like preferential treatment in government contracting or consideration under the Voting Rights Act.
But other blacks say there must be more effort in the black population to become bilingual and adapt to the city's changed character. "We can't move Miami," said Marvin Dunn, a professor of sociology at Florida International University who has written extensively on race relations here. "The reality is that Spanish is becoming the dominant language here. It's one thing to complain, but you can't hold back the tide."
Contributing to a recent mood of conciliation between black and Hispanic residents was an agreement last month that ended the boycott of tourism here by blacks. With Mr. Smith, the lawyer, among the leaders, the boycott was called after Miami's Cuban-dominated government snubbed Nelson Mandela when the South African anti-apartheid figure visited here.
The boycott is estimated to have cost Miami up to $50 million in revenue, and the agreement that black groups negotiated with business, civil and political leaders to end it, calls for increased loans and training programs for black businesses, as well as "fair hiring for African-Americans" in the hotel and tourism industries.
Black and Hispanic officials here acknowledge, however, that barriers between the groups are more than merely economic. Dr. Dunn said said English-speaking blacks are "being surrounded by this sea of brown, Spanish-speaking people, and becoming more entrenched in our own isolation."
Many American-born blacks here and in cities like New York and Chicago seem perplexed, for instance, by the tendency of black Cubans, Dominicans, Panamanians and Puerto Ricans to define themselves not by the color of their skin, but by their language and culture. "You can't tell if you just look at somebody," Mr. Smith said. "I can be walking down a street and I say, 'Hey, brother,' and they speak back to me in Spanish."
According to the 1990 census, the desegregation of housing is occurring more rapidly in Dade County than elsewhere in Florida or in the nation as a whole. But that is the result largely of the willingness of Hispanic whites and blacks to live together, or mixed with Haitians and other Caribbean blacks, in integrated neighborhoods that are largely free of racial tension.
For the most part, native-born, English-speaking blacks remain the most segregated group in Miami, and continue to reside in clearly identifiable pockets in the northwest section of the county. They also tend to be poorer as a group than white or Hispanic people, which both increases their frustration and limits their choices.
"A big chunk of the working-class Anglo community has simply left," because of growing Hispanic dominance here, Dr. Dunn said, referring to the estimated 250,000 whites who have moved out of Dade County since 1980, most of them to other parts of Florida. "But most of the blacks have no place to flee."
Not only here, but in cities as far-flung as Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Houston, competition between black and Hispanic citizens over the drawing of legislative districts and the allotment of seats is intensifying.
"There is a real tension across the board," said Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy in New York. "Generally, the black leadership has felt, 'We sacrificed all these years, we got the laws on the books, and now all these Latino interlopers are coming in.' The black population is stabilizing, while ours is growing, and there is a reaction on the part of blacks. You hear comments from blacks like, 'These Hispanics, they just got here, and they want to take over.' "
Though both black and Hispanic voters, with the exception of Cubans of both colors here, tend to vote for Democrats at the national level, their voting patterns are starting to diverge in local contests. In New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal challenger for mayor, has made overtures to Hispanic voters by picking a Puerto Rican, Herman Badillio, to run for comptroller on his ticket, and in Los Angeles last week, Richard Riordan, the Republican, received about 50 percent of the Hispanic vote in winning the mayoral contest.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rates Drive Up Unemployment Tax

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 19

 BODY:
High jobless rates in 1992 are likely to force employers to pay between $16 and $145 more a year in unemployment taxes for each employee starting in July.
"We're having the calculations reviewed, but it looks like there will be a slight increase in all employer tax rates," said George Krause of the state Labor Department. 
 The increase appears to be needed to build up the balance in the unemployment trust fund, from which benefits are paid. Mr. Krause said his figures indicated that the fund had $2.2 billion earlier this month, down from $2.4 billion a year ago.
Mr. Krause said a final decision was expected next week.
Under New Jersey's law, unemployment taxes on businesses are divided into about a dozen brackets. Companies that frequently lay people off pay the highest rates, which in the current system were as much as $869 a worker, said Joe Fogarty, an unemployment insurance consultant with the Frick Company in Mount Holly.
In addition to the claims-related brackets, the law requires the Labor Department to determine each year if enough money is being paid into the trust fund to cover anticipated claims.
Another increase could be in store next year as well, because the Legislature lowered the amount workers contribute to the fund. That could lower the balance in the fund to the point where further employer contributions would be required to keep it at a mandated level.

HEADLINE: A Teacher, Her Pupils And Lessons Learned

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
When school began last September, Patricia Cullen was as much a novice as the first-grade students assigned to her class at Public School 116 in Manhattan. It was her first teaching job, their first time in grade school. By the end of that first week, Mrs. Cullen looked pummelled, and the wiggling, giggling children had mastered only one lesson: standing in line.
But as the school year winds to an end, it is clear that much has changed inside Room 205. 
 Last fall, at least half of the children could not read or write more than a few basic words. One, when asked to write "dog," etched out "bkg." Now everyone, including the "bkg" child, can read and write scores of words. They can add and subtract two-digit numbers, count by fives and work word problems. And Mrs. Cullen, 29, has not just learned to keep order among her little minions. She has learned to teach.
"This has been the toughest year I have ever had," she said after a morning session last week. "I have learned so much. So much that I never learned in school."
 
The Secret: Stickers
 Indeed, Mrs. Cullen, who left a job at CBS Records to pursue a master's degree in education, found that the secret to teaching first graders has less to do with curriculum than with consistency, insistence and stickers. Students who spoke out of turn did not get called on. Ever. Those who spoke out two or three times had to sit alone for a brief "time out." And those who behaved well were rewarded with praise and colorful round stickers, placed, like badges of honor, on their tiny chests.
"They love these things," Mrs. Cullen said one morning as she stickered two children for sitting quietly. They smiled proudly. "In the end," she said later, "the most important thing to me is that they learn to respect each other and feel good about themselves."
It has been a long, hard year at P.S. 116, a five-story brick building on East 33d Street. But despite political and economic turmoil in the New York City school system, it has been a successful one for Mrs. Cullen and her students.
In addition to the academic strides, other changes came as well. During the first week of school, the class was packed with 34 children, several of whom spoke little English. Mrs. Cullen struggled to hold their attention for more than three minutes. Since then, the class size has dropped to 24, as the students with limited English and the more advanced readers have moved into other classes. The first graders have established clear routines, like working in learning centers or pushing in their little chairs whenever they get up from their work tables. They offer deliberate "excuse me's" when they accidentally elbow each other. And they raise their hands if they want to speak out in class. Most of the time.
 
Tired but Confident
 As for Mrs. Cullen, she moves through reading, writing and math lessons in an old room without air conditioning that has become a menagerie of student art work, number charts and children's books. The young teacher is clearly tired, but confident and effective with her students. Gaining that confidence, she said, has meant assembling an eclectic set of skills, some of which she learned through an array of teacher workshops offered by the local school district. Others came through trial and error.
Take, for example, the art of discipline. She began the year by having the class write out its own rules: "Raise your hand to speak" or "Stand quietly when in line."
But within just a few weeks it was clear that that was not enough. That's when the stickers came into play. "I've had a lot of support," Mrs. Cullen said. "But you never know if something is going to work unless you try it yourself."
She has also learned from her mistakes. She recalls one November afternoon when a first grader gave her a smothering hug and she sat on the carpet. Within seconds, the others piled on, burying the 98-pound teacher under a mound of little bodies. She couldn't move.
"There they were on top of me," she recalled. "And I realized I hadn't really established the lines between us well enough."
Another teaching trick came to her one fall day when she was trying to make homework seem more appealing. Suddenly, she remembered what another teacher had told her about trying reverse psychology on the children. "If you are good you get homework!" she announced enthusiastically. Suddenly, she said, the students straightened up in their chairs and acted as if homework were a prize, not a punishment.
 
Capturing Imaginations
 To capture the children's attention, she learned that she also had to capture their imaginations. Instead of always copying and illustrating the work of published poets, for example, they began writing their own poems, and copying and illustrating each others' work. They often make up their own work problems in math. And they are encouraged to think up different routes to solve equations.
But with the successes have also come challenges, both inside and outside the classroom. Mrs. Cullen, who defected from the corporate world to what she hoped would be more fulfilling work, has now joined the ranks of New York City's public-school teachers, who are still working without a contract because of stalled negotiations between the Teachers Union and the city.
Budget pressures, on both the local and national levels, have left the school with little money for extra supplies. Mrs. Cullen spent more than $500 of her own money this year on pens, paper and extra children's books. Next fall, cuts mean that P.S. 116 and other city schools will lose thousands of dollars in public money, including some of the financing they received as a Chapter One school, or one with a large number of children from low-income families.
Faced with the contested "Children of the Rainbow" curriculum, Mrs. Cullen, at the recommendation of her principal, Anna Marie Carrillo, used the curriculum as a general guideline. But she steered clear of material that dealt directly with AIDS or homosexuality.
"I just don't think some of the parents are ready for it," she said. If the topics had come up in class, she said, she would do her best to explain the issue, then talk about "how important it is to respect everyone."
 
Homeless Students
 In many ways, she has had her own rainbow to deal with. Some children come from nearby homeless shelters. Others from more affluent families, where both parents are professionals. Some are very sheltered. Some have already been exposed to violence on the street or at home.
But as she stood in the school yard at the end of the day last week, it was clear that Patricia Cullen had managed, as she had hoped, to make a difference with both parents and students.
Shirley Lee, who arrived early in the yard that afternoon, said the first-grade teacher had worked wonders with her daughter, Cathy, 7. "Her reading is very good," Mrs. Lee said. "She behaves more, too. And the teacher is very, very nice." Other parents have asked Mrs. Cullen if she planned to move to second grade, so she could teach the children again. And before heading out of the yard, Shante Sapp, 6, reached up and put a big round sticker on her teacher's blouse.
"Here's a sticker, Mrs. Cullen," the girl said with a smile. "You were good today."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "This has been the toughest year I have ever had," said Patricia Cullen of her first teaching job -- working with first graders at Public School 116 in lower Manhattan. HEADLINE: Move to Curb Incentives To Businesses

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Concerned that some cities and counties in New York have gone too far in their efforts to attract new jobs and to keep companies that are being wooed by other states, the State Legislature is seriously considering measures that would curtail some of the incentives that could be offered.
The proposals are intended to increase accountability and to limit some of the incentives, like sales-tax waivers, that local industrial development agencies have offered to companies, usually to keep them from leaving town. While such incentives have been used liberally by New York City to keep companies like Prudential Securities and the Morgan Stanley Group from moving to New Jersey or elsewhere, the legislators say their bills are aimed at abuses that have been reported around the state. 
 Still, because of the city's reliance on such incentives, Carl Weisbrod, New York City's top economic development official, says he fears the legislation will hurt the city's ability to compete for jobs.
 
'More Vigilant Than Ever'
 "With New Jersey sitting on a $200 million strike fund that is aimed like a dagger at New York City's economy, which they're using to induce New York City businesses to move there, and with Connecticut offering companies significant capital grants for even a small number of jobs, we have to be more vigilant than ever," said Mr. Weisbrod, head of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
While the Legislature has considered but failed to pass similar proposals in recent years, this year appears to be different, officials say. Negotiations between Senate and Assembly officials continued last week in an effort to reconcile the two bills, and legislative aides said it was likely that some development reform measure would be passed and sent to the Governor.
Assemblyman Francis J. Pordum, a Democrat from Erie County who is the primary sponsor of an Assembly bill and a strong proponent of development agency reform, said such a measure was needed to make industrial development agencies "accountable to the people and the governments that created them."
 
Agencies Created in 1969
 He added, "Many of the I.D.A.'s give away tax breaks, and very often the only one that benefits from the tax break is the corporation that locates there and the I.D.A. itself" through fees.
The Legislature created the development agencies in 1969 at a time when there was concern that not enough was being done to attract or keep companies in the state. Their mandate was to use various inducements, like bond issues, sales-tax and real estate-tax breaks, often in conjunction with state officials. But reports of possible abuses have led some legislators to conclude that the agencies have gone too far.
Mr. Pordum cited Roosevelt Raceway in Nassau County, purchased by a real-estate developer and horse breeder with the aid of $52 million in tax-free bonds provided by the Town of Hempstead Industrial Development Agency. He later sought to close the track and sell or develop the property despite charges that he had promised to keep the track open, and a state inquiry criticized the development agency for not fully investigating the raceway project before it granted the money.
Other development-agency activities cited by supporters of change include a decision in Troy, N.Y., to use development money to help local investors buy and operate a National Hockey League farm team, and to help the city with debt refinancing with development money. There have been other scattered reports that sales-tax breaks in development packages have been used to pay for custodial services, or that development money has been used to refurbish legal offices.
 
Trying to Reconcile Bills
 While Mr. Weisbrod said some abuses had occurred, he insisted that New York City's development efforts had never come under criticism, and expressed the hope that the Legislature would use "a scalpel, not an atom bomb" to correct problems.
Senate and Assembly officials are trying to reconcile the Pordum bill with another development reform bill, this one with joint sponsorship in both houses, in the Senate by William J. Larkin Jr. of Hudson Valley and in the Assembly by Robin Schimminger, Democrat of Erie County. The Pordum bill is much tougher.
Mr. Weisbrod said the city was particularly concerned about parts of the bills that would prohibit development agencies from using money to assist "professional services" that do not create substantial private-sector jobs. The sponsors of the bill say they are aiming to cut abuses, not to hurt efforts to keep and attract financial-services companies. But Mr. Weisbrod said a broad definition of "professional services" would not only restrict use of money for redecorating legal offices, but could also keep New York City from focusing on such financial-services companies as Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns and Prudential Securities.
Mr. Weisbrod's office worked out a $39.6 million package of incentives running 10 years to keep Morgan Stanley's headquarters in Manhattan and its back office in Brooklyn, a $106.2 million package over 20 years to keep the Prudential Securities headquarters and its 5,000 jobs in Manhattan, and a $17.6 million package to induce Bear Stearns to move 1,500 workers to Brooklyn rather than New Jersey. Last week, the city lost the Witco Corporation, a Manhattan-based manufacturer, and 200 jobs to Connecticut.
 
Limits on Sale-Tax Waivers
 Provisions in the two bills would also limit sales-tax waivers granted to businesses. Such waivers are used frequently "as a means of reducing the cost differential between New York and Connecticut and New Jersey," Mr. Weisbrod said. Both the Larkin-Schimminger and Pordum bills impose two-year limits on sales tax waivers; the Larkin-Schimminger bill exempts computer sales and service contracts, while the Pordum bill does not. Mr. Weisbrod noted that some New York City deals have included tax waivers that ran longer than two years or covered things like maintenance on mainframe computers, which could well be prohibited by the Pordum bill, thus restricting the city's ability to attract high-technology businesses.
Mr. Weisbrod also said city officials are worried about limits on the use of development money for retail projects, and about a provision that would give the State Comptroller's office control over such agencies.
"I don't think anyone intends for this to be an anti-New York City bill, but I think the consequences of it are anti-New York City," Mr. Weisbrod said, adding that the Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns and Prudential deals would all have been impossible under the current wording of the bills.
Mr. Pordum said he could not address Mr. Weisbrod's concerns on those issues because he was not familiar with the specific deals in question, but he said that when bad development packages are granted the taxpayer suffers. "I'm sure that there are many deals that were done before my legislation that couldn't have been done with it, but that wouldn't have been good for the community as a whole," he said.
 
How Far Is Too Far?
 Mr. Schimminger said he believes that Mr. Pordum's bill "goes further than I think appropriate" in restricting the development agencies' activities in several areas, including comptroller control and limits on retailing.
He also said his bill was not intended to hamstring the agencies, and added that he had no intention of limiting efforts to attract and keep financial-services jobs, because "to the extent that white-collar jobs in New York State can result in the importation of dollars and the exportation of services, they are an absolute benefit to New York State."
A spokeswoman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Juanita Scarlett, said Mr. Cuomo would not take a position on the bill until it has reached his desk for signing and he has had a chance to review it.

HEADLINE: Murder Trial in Beating by Detroit Officers Begins

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 19

 BODY:
A jury that took two painstaking weeks to assemble will have to decide whether the fatal beating of a black motorist was a wild exercise of raw power by the police or the action of committed officers confronted by a struggling man in a high-crime area.
As opening arguments began Friday in the trial of three white former officers, many people here wonder whether what happens inside the courtroom will ignite an explosion in the streets. The trial is expected to last six to eight weeks. 
 Live gavel-to-gavel television coverage is planned, and extra security has been added. The first witnesses are expected to testify Monday.
Two of the defendants are accused of second-degree murder in the beating death of the motorist, Malice Green, a 35-year-old unemployed steelworker. A third is charged with assault in the beating in a curb-side confrontation on a clear November night last year.
The incident has haunted Detroit for seven months and led to the country's third racially charged trial this year involving police officers accused of abusing a black motorist, after those in Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla.
 
Tense Relationship
 Like those trials, the Detroit case, known in local newspaper headlines as the Deadly Encounter or the Fatal Force Case, grows out of the often tense relationship between law-enforcement officials and black and other minority residents in the country's inner cities.
Two juries, one for former Officer Walter Budzyn and one for former Officer Larry Nevers, will hear testimony at the same time, seated a few feet apart in Courtroom 402. Originally, the men were to be tried by one jury, but Mr. Budzyn's lawyer, Michael Batchelor, asked for a separate trial, asserting that the defense of the former partners could be antagonistic, as each defendant tried to blame the other.
To save time and money, the judge in the case, George Crockett 3d, decided to try the men together with with a double jury, a fairly common practice in Michigan. The panels will hear prosecution witnesses together, but jurors will be taken out of the courtroom during proceedings that do not involve the defendant whose fate they will decide. Of the 32 jurors and alternates, 26 are black, as are about 70 percent of the people in Detroit.
The third defendant, former Officer Robert Lessnau, has requested a bench trial, and his fate will be decided by Judge Crockett.
 
Officials Moved Fast
 Seven months ago, as word of the fatal beating spread, Detroit officials moved quickly to calm the tension. The Mayor, Coleman A. Young, said he was shocked and sickened by what he called a murder by the police.
Eleven days after the beating, Mr. Budzyn, 47, and Mr. Nevers, 52, were charged with second-degree murder, and in mid-December they were dismissed by the Police Department. Mr. Lessnau, 33, was also dismissed and charged with assault with intent to do great bodily harm. Four other officers, including a black sergeant, were suspended.
The incident began shortly after 10 P.M. on Nov. 5, when Mr. Green was stopped by two plainclothes police officers, Mr. Budzyn and Mr. Nevers, in front of a suspected drug house on the city's west side.
The officers, on the lookout for an armed-robbery suspect driving a red car, ordered Mr. Green to show his driver's license. Halfway out of the car, he leaned over to the glove compartment and apparently had something in his hand. The officers told him to unclench his fist and then started to beat him with their fists and heavy metal flashlights.
Mr. Green was pulled out of the car, and the beating continued as two emergency medical service crews and several more police officers, including Mr. Lessnau, arrived on the scene.
 
Compared to Relay Team
 The prosecutor, Mr. Baker, said Mr. Green did not struggle, even as the two officers took turns beating him. Mr. Baker likened the beating to a relay team handing off a baton.
"At this point," he said, "Mr. Green is massively injured. Blood is literally streaming from his head, through his hair and down into the street, where literally a puddle is formed."
Mr. Baker said that Mr. Budzyn struck first and that when he was winded Mr. Nevers took over.
But the only people to see Mr. Budzyn hit Mr. Green were residents and customers of the drug house, and Mr. Batchelor told the jury that none of them have said they saw Mr. Budzyn strike Mr. Green in the head.
By the time Mr. Nevers began beating Mr. Green, an ambulance had arrived. One driver was so shaken by what he witnessed, Mr. Baker said, that he retreated to the back of his vehicle to compose himself.
Then Mr. Lessnau arrived and at one point kicked Mr. Green in the head while he was handcuffed on the street.
Within 15 minutes of the beating, Mr. Baker said, Mr. Green died from at least 14 blows to the head.
Mr. Nevers's lawyer, John Goldpaugh, hinted that he would challenge the cause of death because Mr. Green had cocaine in his system when he died.
While the death of Mr. Green has not caused any disturbances in Detroit, the Rev. Wendell Anthony, the president of the city's N.A.A.C.P. branch, said he believed that a lot of anger was just below the surface.
Marvetta Davis, who lived near where Mr. Green died and has now joined the Justice for Malice Green Coalition, sees the trial as a test of the justice system.
"Police violence happens every day in the black community," she said. "It's the normal thing. If these cops get convicted, it will be history because they always get away with everything."

HEADLINE: Woman in the News;
Immigration Expert Who Takes Broad Approach -- Doris Marie Meissner

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
4 A child of immigrants, Doris M. Meissner grew up in a German-speaking household in Milwaukee during World War II and suffered the anguish of ethnic discrimination early.
"I can clearly recall sitting on buses and streetcars and hearing my mother tell me not to talk, because it wasn't good to be heard speaking German," she said in a telephone interview from Milwaukee. 
 Ms. Meissner, 51, is now expected to become the custodian of the hopes of today's immigrants and those trying to gain entry. President Clinton nominated her on Friday to be Commissioner of Immigration, which requires Senate confirmation.
Ms. Meissner (pronounced MICE-ner) has specialized in immigration issues for nearly two decades, serving at the Justice Department in Democratic and Republican administrations. She served briefly as acting Commissioner in 1981.
Her family nurtured her longstanding interest in government and public issues, she said. "I think it probably came from my home and from my parents' strong feeling that you give back," she said. "They were always very grateful to have been here and to have built a life here."
 
Paying a Debt
 She has spent her life trying to give something back to her country, in two areas: women's rights and immigration policy. "I'm committed to the full participation of women in the life of our society," said Ms. Meissner, who for a time led the National Women's Political Caucus.
Ms. Meissner has won plaudits for bringing diverse groups together during 13 years at the Justice Department and during her present role as director of the Immigration Policy Project of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
"Immigration has traditionally been the province of advocacy groups only," she said. "We have created a dialogue that looks at these questions as serious policy questions, not just as questions for advocacy groups."
"We have to place the issues in an international context," she continued. "The movement of people is emerging as one of the critical global issues of our age. It is based on huge deficiencies in human rights and deep economic differentials."
When she takes over the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Ms. Meissner will be charged with, in President Clinton's words, insuring that the United States does not "lose control of our borders." Ms. Meissner indicated in the interview that she would take a broad approach to that mission.
 
Treating the Cause
 "Today, people have information and cheap transportation," she said. "They know what their circumstances are and can act on it. We can't deal with this only as an enforcement issue in the United States. We have to look at it worldwide and attack the conditions that create the desperation."
Her nomination won immediate praise from those involved with immigration issues.
Doris Marie Meissner was born in Milwaukee on Nov. 3, 1941. Her mother, Hertha Borst, was 10 when she came to this country from Berlin, Germany, and her father, Fred Borst, was 22 when he arrived from Stuttgart, Germany.
Her father was a tool and die maker and her mother a bookkeeper. "My parents were definitely the pivotal influences on my life," Ms. Meissner said. "They were both very hard-working and absolutely devoted to their kids. Our family life was very much devoted to our German heritage.
"Good parents make kids feel special and are proud of what they do. When you grow up in that kind of an environment, you're ready to meet the world when that time comes."
She attended public schools and met her husband, Charles Meissner, now an economist with the World Bank, when they were both undergraduates at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. She stayed to earn a master's degree in political science when he served in the Army during the Vietnam War.
 
Drawn to Politics
 While studying, she recalled, "I wanted to get involved in a campaign, some kind of political activity." She managed the campaign of Midge Miller, an opponent of the war who defeated a 20-year incumbent for a place in the state Legislature.
After the election, her husband returned from Vietnam and the couple moved to Washington. Ms. Miller provided the connection that enabled Ms. Meissner to become a founding member of the National Women's Political Caucus and its executive director in 1971.
In that post, she assailed both national political parties for not providing campaign financing for women. She devoted special effort to the successfulcampaign of Patricia Schroeder for a House seat.
Ms. Meissner won a White House fellowship in 1973 and went to work at the Justice Department, where she later specialized in immigration issues, becoming Acting Commissioner in 1981 and Executive Associate Commissioner from 1982 to 1985.
Ms. Meissner and her husband have two children: Christine, 28, a high school teacher, and Andrew, 24, a film student.
She inherited her parents' sense of family. "The most important thing is to be there for the people who are closest to you: family and close friends," she said. "And it's important to do work that is satisfying to you and useful to the world. If I can do those two things, I'm satisfied."

HEADLINE: Short of Money, U.N. Refugee Official Asks for Aid

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 18

 BODY:
Faced with a serious shortage of money, the United Nations official charged with caring for the world's 18.9 million refugees plans to summon representatives of the richest countries to a meeting here in July to ask them squarely whether they are willing to continue paying the bill.
"With this funding we can't continue," Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in an interview at her headquarters here this week. "For most operations I've only got money for another month or two." 
 In a poignant reflection of world disorder, the number of people fleeing war or persecution in their homelands has risen almost without interruption every year since the mid-1970's. But the total has soared by some 4 million since 1989, largely as a result of turmoil in former Yugoslav republics, some Central Asian republics of the former Soviet Union, Iraq, and African countries including Somalia, Ethiopia, Mozambique and Liberia.
 
Costs Doubled in Two Years
 The agency's costs in caring for refugees have doubled in the last two years alone, to almost $1.1 billion from $544 million in 1990. Mrs. Ogata, a Japanese citizen educated in the United States, says she will need $1.3 billion this year to feed and protect homeless victims of war and civil disorder across the globe and help a few return home.
But so far this year, the 22 governments on which Mrs. Ogata relies on for voluntary contributions have offered only $480 million, less than half of what she needs. "Last year I never thought we'd make $1.1 billion, but I'm far less optimistic today that we can get $1.3 billion this year," she said.
Ernest Chipman, chief of fund raising for the refugee agency, added: "The momentum runs out. The last dollar is always much harder to find than the first."
Money for the world's refugees is drying up mainly because the United Nations agency always had a narrow base of support, with the United States, Japan, the Scandinavian countries and the European Community providing the overwhelming bulk of its financing. Governments of those countries are now being forced to cut spending where possible because of an economic slump in which declining tax revenue and rising unemployment compensation costs have widened their budget deficits. .
"Our requests are increasing just when the donors are all going through difficult budgetary times," Mrs. Ogata said.
But there is also a feeling among agency officials that the public is beginning to tire of the issue as the number of refugees mounts year after year without even stabilizing, let alone recording a decline.
"Yugoslavia is a third of our budget, and people despair at its leaders' lack of will to make peace," Mr. Chipman said, in a reference to the three-way struggle between Serbs, Croats and Muslims in the region. He said the unending crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina had led to "aid fatigue."
 
Three Million Victims
 Many of the agency's biggest emergency programs are seriously underfinanced. Only $178 million has been raised for the most costly effort, the $420 million it plans to spend on feeding, clothing and caring for more than three million victims of fighting and "ethnic cleansing" in Croatia and Bosnia.
Nations and nongovernmental groups have provided only a third of the $475 million that the High Commissioner wants to spend helping refugees return home to Afghanistan, where 14 years of civil war and more recent fighting between rival Muslim factions in a new Government has driven millions from their homes.
The refugee agency's $55 million budget for repatriation of people in Mozambique, where a peace accord was signed last year, has attracted only $15 million in pledges so far. Yet the refugee agency's $28 million appeal to pay for the return of some 350,000 Cambodian refugees was oversubscribed by almost $1 million.
 
Big Political Stake
 The peacemaking effort in Cambodia was the biggest ever undertaken by the United Nations, and the United States, France and other major powers had a big political stake in its success. Thousands of Cambodian refugees had to be repatriated so they could vote last month in national elections, which were viewed as the culmination of the peace effort.
Mrs. Ogata is uncertain about what she can expect this year from the United States, which was her agency's biggest source of funding last year with a contribution of $240 million. The United States has contributed $97 million so far in 1993, only a third of the $280 million it must provide if it is to continue shouldering 22 percent of the refugee bill.
"Vice President Al Gore promised me full Administration support when I visited Washington last month," Mrs. Ogata said. "But when I went to Capitol Hill, they didn't say no, but they said it won't be easy."
Mr. Chipman is more pessimistic. "I expect a temporary dip in American funding this year," he said.
The 12-nation European Community, the second-biggest contributor at $226 million last year, has fallen seriously behind. "This time last year they had reached 76 percent of their target, but this year they are only at 12 percent," Mr. Chipman said.
Mrs. Ogata said she was particularly worried by shrinking international support for refugee aid in Bosnia.
 
Effect of Cold War's End
 From 2.7 million in 1976, the number of refugees worldwide had nearly quadrupled to 10.3 million in 1982 before reaching 18.9 million last year as visions of post-cold-war stability crumbled and one disaster after another forced people to flee their homes.
Next year Mrs. Ogata feels the total might really start to decline as sizeable numbers of refugees return home in Central America, Mozambique, Somalia and perhaps parts of the former Yugoslavia. She hopes the High Commisioner's budget will then slip back to the $1 billion mark.
"But that's always provided we don't have another disaster, another civil war somewhere else," she warned.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angolan refugees crowding onto a United Nations truck this year in the city of Huambo. About 300,000 Angolans were refugees as of the end of 1992. Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said that her agency was running out of money, adding, "For most operations I've only got money for another month or two." HEADLINE: Call for Moscow Aid Office Splits Wealthy Nations

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
The United States is pressing the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations to set up an office in Moscow to coordinate Western aid, but Britain and France oppose the idea, Western officials said this week.
The goal of the plan is to give the seven nations a more effective and aggressive role in distributing aid to Russia, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
 Germany backs the American proposal, and officials said Japan appears to be willing to go along. But Britain and France are resisting the idea on the grounds that it would create more bureaucracy in Moscow, which they maintain is already too bureaucratic. The International Monetary Fund, World Bank, European Community and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development already have aid offices in Moscow, while the Group of Seven has always acted without a permanent office or staff.
Some monetary fund officials also dislike the American proposal because they fear it would reduce the commanding role the Group of Seven gave the fund last year to oversee economic aid and advice to Russia.
 
Americans See a Missing Link
 But American officials see a missing link in the aid process: While the monetary fund provides advice on general economic policy, and the World Bank gives aid and advice for specific industries, no one is coordinating the billions of dollars in country-to-country aid the seven leading industrialized nations are providing. In addition to the United States, Japan, Britain, Germany and France, the Group of Seven includes Canada and Italy.
Officials who support a Group of Seven office said its staff would survey the Russian economy and suggest where new aid might be needed. One official suggested that the office might work with Russian officials to help them jump through the necessary bureaucratic hoops to speed aid from the World Bank and the monetary fund.
American officials say they hope their proposal to open the Moscow office will win enough backing to be approved by the Group of Seven's leaders when they assemble on July 7 in Tokyo for their annual economic conference.
The American plan was discussed Thursday and Friday at a meeting of the group's deputy finance ministers in New York, and officials said the plan was not aimed at diminishing the role of the monetary fund and World Bank.
 
Bentsen Criticizes Camdessus
 Nonetheless, the proposal comes at a time when Clinton Administration officials have publicly criticized the monetary fund for dragging its feet on aid. In an unusual personal criticism, Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen criticized the fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, by name last week for not having already provided a $1.5 billion loan promised to Russia.
Fund officials said Mr. Camdessus would ask the fund's executive board to approve the loan before the Group of Seven conference. That would enable group leaders to give the good news to President Boris N. Yeltsin at the Tokyo meeting.
Fund officials said that before seeking approval for the loan, Mr. Camdessus wanted Moscow to take certain basic steps to show its commitment to stabilizing its economy and reducing inflation, such as raising interest rates. But some American officials said Mr. Yeltsin had already demonstrated that commitment, and that the aid should already be flowing.
French and British officials said in interviews that they feared a permanent office in Moscow could be the first step in creating an official institutional bureaucracy for the Group of Seven, and that they preferred a coordinating mechanism that was less ambitious.
 
Yet Another Office
 "If you have yet another office, one labeled G-7, how is that going to help?" one European official asked.
Some Western officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said France objects to the plan in part because it fears that the group's office would be dominated by the United States. One French official said that if the group opens an office in Moscow, it might face pressure to open offices elsewhere, perhaps in Ukraine or India. British officials said they were not irrevocably opposed to the American idea, but that they remained unconvinced that a new office would improve the distribution of aid or the advice Russia receives.
Better than a new office, one British official said, would be some forum led by the Russians that would bring together the ambassadors of the seven nations to Moscow.
Jeffrey Sachs, a prominent professor of economics at Harvard who advises the Russian Government, said that a Group of Seven office was needed because, in his view, the monetary fund and World Bank have not acted vigorously enough in helping Moscow. He contends that the lending institutions are being overly cautious just when Russia is undergoing drastic change and needs quick financial aid to lessen its trauma and undertake further painful reforms.
"Maybe they were miscast as leaders," he said. "Therefore maybe the United States has become the leader. But then it needs a different coordinating mechanism."
Several officials said they expected the group to agree on a plan over the next few weeks that would be less ambitious and potentially less bureaucratic than the American proposal.

HEADLINE: Questions About Wealthy At Heart of Rent Debate

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18

 BODY:
At the heart of the legislative battle over rent laws is a basic question: Should the wealthy continue to benefit from rent regulation, a system that protects thousands of New Yorkers from drastic rent increases?
The answer is an emphatic "No," say many landlords and their supporters in the Legislature. And to bolster their arguments, they trot out the names of several well-to-do celebrities who they say milk the system by living in rent-stabilized apartments at posh Manhattan addresses. 
 But the question has been complicated by the difficulty of defining wealth in a city where real-estate prices are perceived by many to be exorbitant and where housing can be difficult to come by.
The question of whether wealthy people should benefit from rent regulation laws is one of the major issues facing the Legislature as it considers proposals that could bring some of the most drastic changes to the city's rent-control system since it was developed in the 1940's.
 
Another Deadline Looms
 Although the Legislature dodged one deadline last week involving extending or altering the system, it faces another on Wednesday. Among the proposals being considered is the ending of rent-stabilization protection for people who make more than $100,000 a year or who rent an apartment for more than $2,000 a month.
Advocates for tenants are lobbying against the slightest change in the current system, which allows anyone, regardless of income, to lease a rent-stabilized apartment. Tenants' advocates say the exclusion of some people from the system, no matter how few, would set a dangerous precedent.
They are also particularly afraid of another proposal that would end rent stabilization on apartments as they become vacant, allowing landlords to charge whatever the market will bear. Tenant supporters believe that measure would completely deplete the stock of rent-regulated apartments in 15 years.
"The judgment of 50 years of Democrats and Republicans is that this system is better than the alternative," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who along with the Democrat-led Assembly supports the tenants' position. "When you try to get the occasional movie actress who has a rent-controlled apartment, you endanger two million middle-class people."
 
No Complex Calculation
 Regulations that limit rent increases on nearly 900,000 apartments in New York City and surrounding counties came within minutes of expiring last Tuesday night, with the Assembly and several Republican Senators from New York City at odds with leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate, who support the landlords. Although a late-night compromise was struck to extend the laws by eight days, legislative leaders have only a few more days to resolve their differences before the laws are again in jeopardy.
Although complaints about wealthy people taking advantage of the system have been voiced for years, officials say this year's fight promises to be among the most hard fought. Senator Kemp Hannon, a Republican from Garden City, L.I., who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Housing and Community Renewal, said the focus on people making more than $100,000 was not based on any complex mathematical calculation.
"It was my judgment," he said, "that to objective onlookers, $100,000 in income or $2,000 in rent was certainly upper class."
Estimates of the number of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City that fit the Senator's definition range from 20,000 to 32,000 -- a small percentage of the city's nearly 800,000 rent-stabilized units. Michael McKee, a tenant advocate, said the median household income for those living in rent-stabilized apartments in New York was $21,000 a year; the median income for rent-controlled apartments, which are usually cheaper and are gradually being phased out, was $12,075.
 
'Absolute, Direct Subsidy'
 The way Senator Hannon sees it, the current system gives the wealthy a subsidy by keeping their rents lower, thereby reducing the value of buildings and decreasing the property taxes paid on them. Lobbyists for landlords, including John J. Gilbert, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, believe New York City could collect tens of millions of dollars in additional property taxes by freeing the apartments of the wealthy from rent regulation.
"It's an absolute, direct subsidy," Mr. Gilbert said. "It's a subsidy with a means test and the means test is serendipity, being in the right place at the right time."
But Mr. McKee, chairman of the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition, objects strenuously to the characterization of rent regulation as a subsidy. The system, he said, serves as a marketwide mechanism to protect all tenants from rent increases and eviction during a housing crisis.
"It does protect people," Mr. McKee said. "It protects poor people. It protects the middle class. It keeps the middle class in the city and therefore protects its economic base. It makes housing more affordable and the city more livable."
 
Definition of Wealthy
 Mr. McKee and other tenant advocates questioned the choice of the $100,000 benchmark, saying it is not necessarily a lot of money for a household in New York City, particularly if a family is caring for a chronically-ill relative or putting children through college. And what, he wonders, would happen under Mr. Hannon's proposal to a group of recent college graduates who pooled their resources to live in an apartment and, when combined, had a household income of $100,000. Would they be considered wealthy?
To which Mr. Hannon replied: "The yuppies? I'm sorry. I wish I had that out of college."
Other troubling questions, tenant advocates say, concern how such a program would be administered, who would pay the administrative costs, which agency would verify tenants' incomes and, if that verification involved the examination of confidential tax records, would it be an invasion of privacy?
Senator Hannon argues that the process could begin with a simple, annual question from landlord to tenant: Is your income above or below $100,000? For verification purposes, the process could involve any of several state agencies, perhaps communicating by computer. He said he would strive to make such a system "the least intrusive and most administratively simple."
