HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Clinton Issues Call to Arms at Northeastern U.

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 19

 BODY:
President Clinton told a cheering audience of Northeastern University graduates today that their futures depended on the ability of leaders in Washington to make tough decisions, and he challenged recalcitrant politicians in Congress to start making some.
Mr. Clinton made no effort to hide the campaign-style nature of his remarks, directing his criticism at opponents in Congress who he said have opposed his plan to reduce the deficit and raise taxes without providing workable alternatives. 
 "My job is to make your future worthy of the efforts that brought you here today, to try to help to create a national interest that triumphs over anybody's special interests," Mr. Clinton told 2,195 graduates and their guests in the sweltering Boston Garden arena. "You have done your part. It is now time for the leadership of the country to do ours."
Such a call to arms, on this occasion cloaked in the high-minded rhetoric suitable for an academic ceremony, has become common for the President. But today, Mr. Clinton had a special mission: he sought to capitalize on the week's successes, including the passage of an amended version of his economic plan by the Senate Finance Committee.
The theme of the President's remarks was repeated today in his weekly radio address, in which he accused his political opponents of "playing politics with your economic future, screaming old slogans like 'tax and spend.' "
Mr. Clinton, who received more than 200 invitations to speak at college commencements this year, said he chose Northeastern because the university required its students to work off campus.
Mr. Clinton was awarded an honorary doctorate in public service today and congratulated the graduates who greeted him with high-five hand slaps and barking cheers for "surviving the Boston traffic jams."
"That's the second greatest example of gridlock in the United States," he said.
Mr. Clinton was accompanied today by Senators Edward M. Kennedy and John Kerry of Massachusetts; Michael S. Dukakis, the former Governor of Massachusetts who was the 1988 Democratic Presidential nominee, and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, whom Mr. Clinton has nominated as Ambassador to the Vatican.
 
Northwestern University
 Georgie Anne Geyer, the columnist for the Los Angeles Times Syndicate, delivered the main address yesterday to 4,312 graduates at Northwestern University's 135th commencement exercises on the Evanston, Ill., campus.
A Northwestern alumna, Ms. Geyer was also awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree.
"The problem for the United States in your lifetime will, strangely enough, be related to the problems we see in the Yugoslavias, the Tajikistans and indeed the Russias of our world," Ms. Geyer said. "It is the problem of national and cultural disintegration. For in our own way we are allowing organizers, activists and ambition-ridden political putative leaders to divide this country in much the same ways that Yugoslavia has been deliberately divided since 1987."
In addition to Ms. Geyer, the university awarded honorary degrees to Bruno Bartoletti, artistic director of the Lyric Opera of Chicago; the Rev. Raymond Baumhart, president of Loyola University of Chicago; Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State; William J. Wilson, professor of sociology and public policy at the University of Chicago, and Richard N. Zare, professor of chemistry at Stanford University.

HEADLINE: Mayors, Meeting in New York, Have Eyes Set on Washington

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Five months after a new President took office with a pledge to tackle the problems of the nation's cities, more than 200 mayors gathered in Manhattan yesterday for a meeting dominated by the question: what happened to the early promise of the Clinton Administration?
Many at the 61st convention of the United States Conference of Mayors said that despite Mr. Clinton's stumbles, they were still optimistic that he would succeed in helping their cities. But they also said they were disappointed that some of his legislation had foundered -- although they went out of their away to avoid criticizing the President personally. 
 "As an executive I recognize that very often the initiatives that we propose are not able to be achieved," Mayor David N. Dinkins said, referring to the President's proposed economic stimulus package, which would have included grants to New York City. "The failure of that legislation meant $175 million. I am gravely wounded by it."
 
Hopes for a Reversal
 Some mayors acknowledged that they may have harbored unreasonably high hopes that a Democratic President might reverse the pattern of Republican Presidents who, the mayors said, ignored the needs of the cities.
"We were so excited after having 12 years of being out in the desert, that there was a real question of whether it was humanly possible for any individual to reach our expectations," said Mayor Jerry E. Abramson of Louisville, Ky., a Democrat.
The mayors were to have met in Colorado Springs, but after Colorado voters last November approved a constitutional amendment banning special protection for gay people under civil rights laws, Mr. Dinkins persuaded the mayors to come to New York. The mayors, and representatives of other organizations involved in urban issues, are meeting at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in midtown.
 
Anger Toward Republicans
 While there was some grumbling about the President's decision not to address the conference in person -- he will instead deliver a speech by satellite -- the mayors directed much of their anger toward Republicans in Congress who prevented passage of the economic stimulus bill in April. The legislation would have provided money for extra unemployment benefits, education, highways and other public improvements and summer jobs.
Even the president of the conference, Mayor William J. Althaus, a Republican from York, Pa., assailed his fellow party members. Mr. Althaus described the filibuster by Republican Senators that doomed the package as "unconscionable."
"When they took inner-city low-income swimming pool renovations and said, 'No, that's pork,' what I heard was, 'The United States Senate can have a swimming pool, but the poor children of my city cannot,' " he said. "And that offends."
Even though the mayors seemed sobered by the last few months, they said they had not lost faith in Mr. Clinton.
"The Cabinet that this President has is one that is tremendously receptive," Mr. Dinkins said. "The whole attitude is vastly different."

GRAPHIC: Photo: More than 200 mayors attended the 61st convention of the United States Conference of Mayors, which opened in New York. Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta listened to Mayor David N. Dinkins. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Israel Seeks to Keep North Korea From Aiding Iran

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 19

 BODY:
Although the countries have no diplomatic relations, Israel has quietly had a series of contacts with North Korea, hoping that a lure of economic cooperation may stop the Koreans from providing nuclear technology and a nuclear-capable missile to Iran, officials here say.
The missile, Rodong 1, also known as Scud-D, is still being developed. But Israeli officials have already expressed great concern because it is believed able to carry nuclear or chemical warheads and because, unlike earlier generations of the Scud, it has a stated range of about 600 miles and would put Israel within striking distance of missile sites in western Iran. 
 Similarly, Japanese officials fear that the Rodong 1 would enable the North Koreans to hit some of their most populous cities.
The worry here is that the hard-pressed Pyongyang Government plans the missile mostly for export, and intends to sell it to Iran in return for oil. "As far as I know, Iran has placed an order for 150 of these missiles and has sent five high-ranking delegations to North Korea this year," said Prof. Ben-Ami Shillony, an expert in East Asian affairs at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.
"The Iranian threat is taken very seriously," an Israeli official said, adding that the worries extend to technological help North Korea is reportedly giving to Iran's attempts to become a nuclear power. "These missiles are in a trial stage, and can be stopped if one makes an effort."
As a result, Israel has discussed possible business ventures with Pyongyang, the goal being to make it economically worthwhile for the North Koreans to abandon their planned missile sales. Officials here say the North Koreans have been eager negotiators, going so far as to offer to sell Israel a gold mine in their attempts to raise cash and ease their diplomatic isolation.
The officials said the contacts began in October with a secret visit by senior Israeli officials to Pyongyang but were suspended recently at the urging of the United States. Washington wanted to deepen the North Koreans' isolation after they had announced in March that they would withdraw from the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
On June 11 the Koreans agreed to suspend the withdrawal, although they gave no sign that they would let inspectors look at their most sensitive nuclear sites. Three days later, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel met in Vienna with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, and asked for permission to resume contacts with North Korea in light of the latest shift by Pyongyang, Israeli officials said.
Officials said this week that Washington had given them a go-ahead, confirming a report in the newspaper Davar that Eitan Bentsur, the Foreign Ministry's deputy director general, would leave soon for Pyongyang to restart negotiations.
According to press reports here, the North Koreans have discussed the possibility of $1 billion in investments, both from Israel and from Jewish-owned businesses elsewhere that might respond to Israeli appeals. But Government officials asserted that the talks have not reached that sort of detail.
"We haven't reached that phase yet," an official said. "They didn't say that if they get X billion dollars, they won't sell missiles to Iran."
In recent months, Israelis have been warning with increasing insistence about Iran's nuclear program, which has received assistance from China as well as North Korea, and the threat they say it presents to this country and to the entire Middle East. The Israelis have long been presumed to have their own nuclear capability. But they regard it as their equalizer in a hostile region, and say the balance would be lost if other countries followed suit, especially an implacable enemy like Iran under strict Islamic rule.
With North Korea, the Israelis say, their goals are limited to preventing missile and nuclear-technology sales to Teheran, and they are not pursuing formal ties. "It's a courtship with a very precise strategic aim," the official said.
Israel has diplomatic relations with South Korea.

HEADLINE: NO QUICK SOLUTION IN HAITI FORESEEN

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 18

 BODY:
Diplomats involved in efforts to resolve Haiti's nearly 21-month political crisis say they consider it unlikely that Haitian military leaders will respond positively to a United Nations oil embargo imposed on their country until the reality of functioning without fuel sinks in.
Haiti's oil supplies, needed for transportation, power generation and industry, are thought to guarantee four to six weeks of normal consumption. 
 The diplomats do not rule out the possibility that conversations with senior Haitian military officers and political leaders before the sanctions take effect on Wednesday may lead to a breakthrough. But they said there was little sign that Haiti's military leaders were ready to begin good-faith discussions on the restoration of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Father Aristide was overthrown by the Haitian Army in a violent coup on Sept. 29, 1991.
 
Role of Dominican Republic
 Diplomats involved in mediation efforts in Haiti say they will approach the Government of the Dominican Republic, Haiti's neighbor on the island of Hispaniola, to ask that it prevent overland oil shipments, which would be Haiti's only source of supply if the United Nations oil embargo is enforced.
In recent weeks the Dominican President, Joaquin Balaguer, who had a tense relationship with President Aristide during his brief tenure in office, has criticized international sanctions against Haiti's military-backed Government. But diplomats said poor roads linking the two countries, a legacy of difficult relations, would sharply limit the amount of fuel that could travel overland.
Haiti's authorities have frustrated repeated diplomatic initiatives aimed at restoring Father Aristide. Diplomats involved in the mediation said they believed that even now, given a last-minute removal of enforcement provisions in the Security Council action that would have allowed the inspection of ships steaming to Haiti, the military believed that life would continue as usual.
United Nations officials said they were confident that the Security Council would obtain international cooperation in cutting off Haitian oil supplies.
People close to the Haitian military high command said on Friday that the army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, had said in recent days that only United States military action in Haiti could force his army to accept Father Aristide's return under conditions laid out by the United Nations. Those conditions include the departure of the present high command and the return of the exiled President after he forms a new Government.
 
Aristide Cool to Direct Talks
 Diplomats said the efforts had been complicated by Father Aristide's own reluctance to take part in direct talks with the army.
Reaction among people opposed to Father Aristide in the political and economic elite has been a mixture of nervous defiance and fatalism.
"We have been under an embargo for 200 years, and we are the poorest country in the hemisphere," said Ebrane Cadet, a senator who opposes Father Aristide's return.
Among Haitian business people, many predicted the collapse of the country's currency, the gourde, and a progressive halt to economic activity if the sanctions were rigorously applied.
"I know a lot of people who are very mad and starting to be afraid," said one leading businessman, who like most spoke only on condition of anonymity. "They are afraid because sanctions will change their lives. But if Aristide comes back, it will be civil war. We will start having a lot of killings."
Many in Haiti's tiny elite strongly oppose the return of Father Aristide, a populist priest, whom they consider to be an advocate of violent class struggle. Feelings like these have not softened, even though Father Aristide, since his exile, has repeatedly spoken of his belief in nonviolent change.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Rudolph's Legacy: Triumphs Over Pain

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WILMA RUDOLPH sat in an oversized chair looking very cool, very casual. The roses that had begun to arrive that morning in honor of her 53d birthday next Wednesday accented her natural elegance. It was what Ed Temple, her track coach at Tennessee State, liked to call "that charisima."
"I thought I'd be able to sneak this birthday in," she said smiling. "Everybody knows. It's really fascinating; I still get gifts and letters from people around the world." 
 There was another gift of sorts last night when Rudolph, along with Arnold Palmer, Ted Williams, Muhammad Ali and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, received the first National Sports Awards at Constitution Hall here.
Rudolph exploded on the international scene in 1960 during the Rome Olympics when she became the first American woman to win three gold medals in one Olympics.
By 1963, Rudolph had retired from competition. Call it pride, call it vanity, but she refused to run past her prime. She left at the top, and began a multifaceted career as a teacher, an inspirational speaker and, recently, the president of her own company, which basically schedules her appearances worldwide.
Earlier this month, Rudolph agreed to assist Berlin in the city's bid to bring the Olympic Games to Germany in the year 2000. She explained that many of her greatest triumphs occurred in Germany and that the German people have always treated her royally. Asked whether the memory of Hitler's snub of Jesse Owens -- her friend and mentor -- during the 1936 Berlin Games left a troubling residue in her mind, Rudolph said it did not.
"Remember, that as a race of people we've been discriminated against all our lives," she said. Rudolph pointed out that the year she won three gold medals in Rome, several American cities -- including Nashville, where she was a student at Tennessee State -- were torn by racial tension and violence over the question of whether blacks could even eat in segregated restaurants.
"Hitler's attitude toward blacks wasn't all that different from what attitudes were in the United States," she said.
At a time when female athletes are asserting their right to equal access to and distribution of college funds, it is fitting that Wilma Rudolph is the only woman selected for an inaugural National Sports Award. Rudolph more than any other athlete stirred the interest among women in track.
Nell Jackson, the first black Olympic track coach, explained: "Wilma's accomplishments opened up the real door for women in track because of her grace and beauty. People saw her as beauty in motion."
Few who saw the beauty in 1960, and few who see the grace today knew the suffering Rudolph endured to reach international acclaim. She is a testament to overcoming obstacles by making adversity an impetus for success.
The 20th of 22 children, she contracted polio at the age of 4 and suffered from pneumonia and scarlet fever. Rudolph survived the illnesses but lost the use of her left leg and was forced to wear leg braces. Her mother drove 45 miles on her off day for therapy, and her older brothers and sisters who had learned a massage technique designed to strengthen her leg, rubbed her down several times daily.
After five years, Rudolph shocked her doctor and mother by removing the cumbersome braces and walking unassisted. She wore a supportive shoe until she was 11. By 12 she was one of the fastest runners -- boy or girl -- in the neighborhood.
What she could not remove were the deep emotional scars inflicted by cruel playmates who teased her, called her names and ostracized her.
"Back then kids were not nice to people with braces," she said.

Under the tutelage of Temple, the legendary coach, Rudolph made the Olympic team in 1956 as a high school student at the age of 16 and earned a bronze medal for her part in 4 x 100 meter relay.
While her story is inspirational, Rudolph laments that duplicating it is becoming increasingly difficult for young athletes with potential. Not because of a scarcity of young people capable of overcoming odds, but because of fewer opportunities for economically disadvantaged young people to discover themselves -- and education -- through athletics.
"Business people and community groups -- especially in the black community -- have to step up and contribute," she said. "Until they do, we'll continue to have gangs and murders."
Wilma Rudolph is now firmly entrenched and at peace with her life's work: using athletics to help young people get from point A in their lives to point B.
During the next year she plans to expand her company's mission and establish community-based track and field programs in at least two cities through the use of private funding and matching government grants.
"If I left the earth today," she said, "my great moment would be knowing that I have tried to give something to young people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Few who saw the beauty in Wilma Rudolph at the Olympics in 1960 knew that the gold-medal sprinter started her career wearing leg braces after suffering a childhood bout with polio. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Racing Report Ignoring The Key Question: How

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Many racing people reacted with skepticism yesterday to the report by the Governor's special commission on horse racing, and suggested that the commission had tried to be all things to all people in a business surrounded by red ink, an unknown future and politics.
Nobody disagreed with the warning issued by the chairman of the commission, Vincent Tese, who also serves as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's director of economic development: "Unless there is change in the way this industry does business, I can guarantee you that in three years the purses will be down. Unless there is change, this industry is in for a long, deep slide." 
 But having posed the problem, Tese and his eight fellow members of the commission produced a sweeping 100-page report that apparently tried to avoid stepping on too many political toes.
 
Real Question Is How
 For example, it ordered the New York Racing Association to open a dialogue leading to a merger with its longtime competitor, New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation. But except for visualizing a "joint venture," it gave no clue to the sort of merger that might unite two natural enemies who fight for the lion's share of more than $1 billion a year in betting money.
The title of the report was certainly soaring: "Racing Into the 21st Century. A Plan to Reform, Restructure and Revitalize the Horse Racing, Parimutuel Wagering and Breeding Industry in New York State." But the scenario for reviving the industry was often lost in a mix of facts and fantasy.
In one pointless section (paragraph 7.3 of Appendix A, which blueprints the "joint venture" between the N.Y.R.A. and OTB), the report stipulates: "Meetings of the Board of Directors. The time, place and manner of holding meetings of the Board of Directors shall be determined by the Board of Directors."
 
Praise, But . . .
 But for now, the ranking officers of both organizations were circling each other with all deliberate wariness. Both expressed approval of the concept of working together, but neither expressed a desire to be swallowed up by the other.
Allan Dragone, chairman of the N.Y.R.A., congratulated Tese and his fellow commissioners "for the time and energy which was applied to examining the problems currently facing racing in New York State." He also sent a letter to the chairman of OTB, Ed Lewis, requesting a meeting and conceding that it would be useful to consolidate "certain operations." But he did not withdraw the N.Y.R.A.'s longstanding proposal to take over off-track betting.
Hazel Dukes, the president of OTB, also said she was grateful to the commission and looked forward to "a realistic dialogue" with the N.Y.R.A. But she added that the dialogue should lead to a future "that will be advantageous to all constituents in the industry, while continuing our mission of providing needed revenue for New York City."
 
Two Dissenters
 Two members of the commission attached a memorandum to the report that endorsed the concept of a joint venture between the N.Y.R.A. and OTB, but dissented strongly on creating a new state agency to run the show and on other proposals in the report.
The two dissenters -- State Senator Ronald Stafford, a Republican from Rochester, and Willard Anderson, a businessman from upstate -- also said: "There are countless issues and concerns that need to be addressed, discussed and resolved." As a result, they added, "we could not agree on a final draft prior to further discussions."
 
Aquilegia Wins at Belmont
 Scotty Schulhofer and Julie Krone, who teamed with Colonial Affair to win the Belmont Stakes two weeks ago, teamed with the filly Aquilegia yesterday to win the 50th running of the New York Handicap at Belmont Park.
Aquilegia, a 4-year-old daughter of Alydar, snatched the victory in the final lunge to the wire after Krone escaped a traffic trap by veering to the outside. They edged Via Borghese by a nose with Ginny Dare less than a length back in third place.

HEADLINE: Sports of the Times;
Looking at New Jersey, But Thinking of Queens

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
IT happens every spring, or so it seems, the rumble emanating from the Bronx concerning a potential move by the Yankees.
This time, though, the rumbles may be for real. George Steinbrenner, baseball's version of the boy who cried wolf, may be about to unleash a bite of his own. 
 Why? The Yankees are in a foot race with the Mets with ramifications far beyond the won-lost columns. And the Yankees are losing.
The Mets, sitting a universe away from the nearest pennant race, still outdraw the contending Yankees. Through 32 home games this season, the Mets have averaged 24,730 fans a game, or a total of 791,379. The Yankees' average through 34 games was 22,151 fans, or a total of 753,137.
The primary reason given for the lukewarm support is the location of Yankee Stadium, at 161st Street and River Avenue, in one of the poorer areas of the Bronx. To get there, fans must fight through an endless number of traffic jams spilling from area bridges. Then they must deal with a neighborhood frequently portrayed as one plagued by high crime.
Whether that perception of crime is also the reality could surely be debated for days. The fact is, the Yankees have used the argument and the public appears to be listening, as the attendance shows.

 If that were not enough, now there is a potentially new and back-breaking threat on the horizon. For it is one thing to have to compete with the Mets as that team sits out in relatively better environs at Shea Stadium on Flushing Bay. It's another to look into the future and picture the Mets sitting in what may be the city's ultimate sports complex/mega convention-entertainment center.
For the Mets are talking about building anew near Shea's present site. The proposal, being vigorously pursued by the team's co-owner, Fred Wilpon, calls for a huge complex with a domed stadium, a new subway spur and tons of parking, both for baseball and hard-pressed La Guardia Airport. Preliminary discussions with the city, the Port Authority and the Transit Authority, are under way. That underscores one thing, said an executive familiar with the team's proposal: "The Mets are very, very serious about the project and equipped with a terrific concept."
Since the state and the city will have to make some tough financial calls on the proposal, one has to wonder if either level of government is economically equipped to help out both the Mets and Yankees. Assuming that there is but a finite amount of money that can be given or raised, it makes sense that Steinbrenner's eagerness to push for a solution is keener than ever.
Now both Wilpon, a developer of some renown, and Steinbrenner have clout. Steinbrenner also has to hope he has other resources. The most important, of course, is leverage. And that includes the ultimate threat: picking up and moving.
Given the scenarios, there should be some antsiness in the Bronx. Residents there see no one riding in suggesting a mammoth undertaking like the one proposed in Flushing; Steinbrenner certainly hasn't. All they hear from him and his team is talk of moving, the tone of which suggests there's more to all this than your usual bluff-calling, headline-seeking, election-year arm-twisting.
And let's face it, the Yankees do have some legitimate complaints. The area around Yankee Stadium, if not as crime-infested as touted, is, at minimum, in great need of refurbishment. The argument over who failed in previous negotiations -- the city or the Yankees -- doesn't matter, now. The fact is, the needed care hasn't come and that neglect has ushered in a crisis.
If the city won't give the Yankees the parking and safe avenues to the stadium that Steinbrenner has demanded for years, or come up with a viable alternative in Manhattan or another borough, New Jersey could.
In the past, Steinbrenner was told by at least two previous baseball commissioners he could move to the Meadowlands, where a promised 3 million fans a year await. But there was a catch -- he could go, but the team name would stay in New York. For obvious reasons, Steinbrenner didn't jump at the prospect of parting with the most famous and marketable team identity in history. Now, though, there's no commissioner to put up any such impediments. And there's little belief that Steinbrenner's fellow owners would or could stop him.
"It could happen if the city doesn't take it very seriously," said yet another executive who is acutely familiar with Steinbrenner's arguments for a change, if not a move. "And it could happen, anyway, because I think George's strategy will be to force the city into playing hardball with him if he can, then use that as an excuse to go."

 No less than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins seem to realize that, now, too. On Thursday, Cuomo said the state was willing to work with the Yankees to see what can be done to improve the current site. He also said that the state would consider offering revenue-generating bonds to both teams to assure they relocate within the state.
Now to some, it probably seems obscene that a city or a state seemingly cares more about the finances of the Yankees than about the hard-pressed families living right next to the stadium. Others might argue that the issue here is not the Yankees, but more potential flight from the Bronx. The Yankees, like any other corporation, are an integral part of the Bronx's financial web. If they leave, any dream of revival dies a little more.
"It's a very tough issue," the second executive said. "Taking a conservative view, it's difficult to justify putting public money up. The problem is New Jersey will put it up. It is, after all, a competitive world."
The Mets and the Yankees know that more than ever, especially since the arena and the prize -- New York City -- are one and the same.

HEADLINE: Sharpening the Focus and Going Global at Dresser

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE pact that Dresser Industries signed a few months ago to build gas turbines and compressors in Russia was a classic example of how John J. Murphy has reshaped the nation's most diverse supplier of energy-related equipment.
The deal required little capital from Dresser and involved a huge customer -- in this case Russia's dominant producer, transporter and distributor of natural gas, Gazprom. And some analysts think the deal will help push Dresser's yearly revenues from Russian deals above $400 million by 1996, from about $100 million last year. 
 The Gazprom deal is emblematic of Mr. Murphy's strategy since taking over as Dresser's chief executive 10 years ago in August. Since then, Dresser has become more tied to the global energy market than its three prominent rivals in the oil-field service sector, Schlumberger Ltd., the Halliburton Company and Baker Hughes Inc.
Gazprom, for instance, delivers 32 trillion cubic feet of gas a year through its pipeline system -- far more than the 20 trillion cubic feet transported last year within the United States. Mr. Murphy says there is no telling how many turbine-and-compressor units will be built or how soon, or the profit potential for Dresser. But his best guess is that Gazprom will need at least 100 new units a year, worth about $8 million each.
"It will be substantial, I'm sure, but there are just too many variables," he said. "But we're a lot happier with 20 percent of a good deal than we would be with 100 percent of zero." Dresser will own up to 30 percent of the partnership with Gazprom and Kirovsky Zavod, the operator of the former military plant in St. Petersburg where the turbine-and-compressor units will be produced.
While making Dresser more global, the 61-year-old Mr. Murphy, only the sixth person to head the company in its 113-year history, has at the same time been narrowing its focus, hoping to exclusively supply global energy producers with products ranging from the pipeline couplings it sold in 1880 to multi-million-dollar plants for processing liquified natural gas.
Since he took command he has auctioned off more than 30 units, including a life insurer, an automobile leasing firm and a maker of fire hydrants. And he has bought 24 energy-related companies, generally at conservative prices, buying as he has at a time when oil prices were heading down from an average of $34 a barrel in 1981 to below $16 in 1986. Dresser also has an interest in four large joint ventures, which contributed more than $1 billion of its $4.8 billion in total revenue last year. The transformation, Mr. Murphy said, should allow Dresser this year to exceed his elusive objective of earning at least 15 percent on shareholder's equity for the first time since 1985.
BUT Mr. Murphy's disciplined march to overhaul Dresser has not produced as much for the company's stockholders in the last year as decisions by Halliburton, Schlumberger and Baker Hughes to stick closer to oil-field services.
Surging natural-gas prices in the United States, which have nearly doubled from 15-year lows a year ago, inspired investors to stockpile shares of companies in the oil-field service industry on the logic that higher prices will raise drilling activity and orders for drilling equipment.
Shares of Halliburton and Baker Hughes have retreated somewhat from their early June highs and from their gains of about 70 percent since late last year. But they have soared far higher in that period than Dresser's, whose share price increased 36.2 percent to a high of $23.50 on June 7, from a low of $17.25 last July 8. It closed Friday unchanged, at $23.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
James L. Carroll, oil-field service analyst at Paine Webber Inc., estimated that Dresser is generating three-fourths of its operating income from projects unrelated to oil-field exploration and production, while the percentage is reversed for Halliburton and Baker Hughes. That means a rise in the drilling rate in North America, which increased for eight consecutive weeks until declining by 30 rigs this week to leave 681 exploring for oil and gas, will have a bigger and faster impact on profits for those companies than at Dresser. Dresser says acquisitions this year of TK Valve and Bredero Price should raise oil-field-related revenues to about 45 percent of the total.
"Dresser is well-positioned to participate in this long-term, downstream spending pattern," Mr. Carroll said. "It simply is not their turn yet."
Suzanne L. Cook, energy analyst at Wasserstein Perella Securities Inc., said that investors have underestimated Dresser's prospects. "We don't think Dresser deserves the price discount," she said. "Its ability to grow and show good earnings momentum is not being completely recognized today."
OVERALL, Dresser's operating earnings fell slightly, to $22.2 million, from $23.9 million in the first half of the fiscal year, but would have risen if not for a special charges of $65 million. Revenues rose by 9.3 percent, to $2.0 billion, from $1.8 billion.
Fueling the improvement is the M. W. Kellogg Company, acquired in 1987 at $115 million, or just $35 million after Dresser applied $80 million in Kellogg's treasury toward the price. Kellogg's sales and profits have risen steadily since the deal because of rising orders for petrochemical plants, liquified natural-gas plants and other big petrochemical engineering projects. Its operating profit soared to $67.3 million last year, from $53.0 million in 1991, and doubled in the first six months of fiscal 1993, which ended April 30, to $25.7 million.
According to Mrs. Cook's estimates, Dresser's earnings will reach $1.10 per share for the fiscal year, which ends Oct. 31, and at least $1.30 in 1994. Mr. Carroll's forecast was slightly lower, at $1.00 in the current fiscal year and $1.25 next year.
PROSPECTS further into the future hinge in large part on how much sales and profits eventually are mustered from Mr. Murphy's commitment to the promising but turbulent economies in Russia and China. By current measure, Saudi Arabia has the biggest oil reserves, at more than 260 billion barrels of the world's 1 trillion barrels.
But geologists for years have been intrigued by the crescent pattern in which hydrocarbon reserves have been discovered near the Persian Gulf, rising northward through Iran and into western Siberia. Many geologists at major oil companies believe the Russian reserves, currently listed at 60 billion barrels, actually exceed 400 billion barrels.
Mrs. Cook said that by some estimates 30 percent of all sales of oil-field services and equipment for exploration projects by oil companies could be focused in Russia and other former Soviet republics if political risks are reduced. Dresser has sold equipment from its Moscow office since 1930 and has the best knowledge of the Russian market, she said.
It would appear so. Mr. Murphy said that Dresser's deal with Gazprom and Kirovsky Zavod was initiated a year ago by Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, then head of the Russian natural gas ministry and Gazprom's chairman, now Russia's Prime Minister.
Mr. Murphy, who has advised the last three Administrations on Washington's policies toward Moscow, said a deal was possible partly because the Russians agreed to pay Dresser in hard currency from gas exports. He concedes that Dresser's payoff in Russia may take years to develop, but soaring orders in Southeast Asia and China have persuaded him that that region is the world's strongest emerging energy market.
"If you think that economic growth and the financial well-being of people is the important thing, then China is right. The change there is phenomenal."

HEADLINE: Don't Let the Pesticide Polluters Fool You;
We're All Lab Animals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Mother Nature's Pesticide Factory" by Michael Fumento (Op-Ed, June 9): Environmentalists are correct in wanting to ban potentially toxic chemicals, and Carol Browner, Environmental Protection Administrator, is equally justified in seeking a revision of the Delaney Clause, though not for the right reasons.
Since 1958 the Delaney Clause has allowed innacurate and misleading data to steer regulation. Until the flawed methodology behind its guidelines is replaced, humans will continue to be industry's real guinea pigs, irrespective of the chemicals tested. 
 There are some 70,000 chemicals on the market, almost half in common use. Of these, only 800 have undergone standard rodent tests used to try to predict human cancer risks.
The cost of running a typical pre-chronic and long-term rodent carcinogenicity bioassay is $1.6 million to $2.5 million per chemical in 1986 dollars. With more than 25,000 commonly used chemicals awaiting evaluation, to test them all would cost $50 billion to $75 billion, not counting inflation and administrative costs.
As we have seen in the case of such pharmaceuticals as thalidomide and Bendectin, and chemicals that commonly find their way into our food chain like Alar, Captan and Lindane, animal tests do not prevent these chemicals from being marketed.
The diverging opinions of scientists, regulators and private research organizations about rodent bioassay results have too often led to repeated testing of the same chemicals at various doses in different species. Each new generation of testing further delays regulation and allows the proliferation of potentially dangerous chemicals in our environment.
While many toxicologists believe that completely replacing animal tests remains in the future, many are merely reluctant to abandon familiar methods to explore new ground. Countless nonanimal technologies around the world are awaiting validation, while others have been validated and used. X-ray technology has been used, with human cells and subjects, to measure the mutagenic effects of chemical agents accurately.
These modern and often technically superior methods are not only cost-effective, but also allow the dangers of individual chemicals to be observed in a few hours or days, as opposed to the 8 to 10 years needed for rodent bioassays.
Ultimately, if our aim is to protect human health, we need fewer pesticides, fewer food additives and fewer toxic ingredients in household products and cosmetics. These are not the myopic desires of "environmental extremists," as Mr. Fumento suggests. They are universally embraced by concerned individuals everywhere who want to protect their health and the environment.
 
ALIX E. FANO
Washington, June 11, 1993
 
The writer is a researcher for the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
State Eases the Plight of Small Landlords

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN the final hours of the last day of the legislative session on June 9, Connecticut lawmakers made life marginally easier for the state's mom-and-pop landlords.
They passed a bill that permits direct payment of rent by city welfare agencies to the landlord after one month of nonpayment by the tenant. But measures that would speed the eviction process, and let towns require rent to be paid into the local housing court until the landlord gets a certificate of occupancy, did not reach the floor. Currently, tenants may stop paying rent when no such certificate exists. 
 The direct-payment measure, effective Oct. 1, is optional, not mandatory.
"It's not much, but it's a step," said William Cornish, president of the New London Association of Landlords. Retired from his 30-year job at Southern New England Telephone, he relies on income from 16 low-priced rental units and a small grocery store.
His association is one of several formed throughout the state to lobby the legislature. The first emerged in 1990 in Willimantic, when William C. Meehan, a former teacher, founded the Windham County Landlords Association with 10 members. It now has 150.
"This is a source of income mostly for retired people," he said. But landlords say that it has turned sour during the recession and that an influx of low-income tenants or tenants on welfare who don't pay rent has devastated small landlords.
"Tenants use their government subsidies for other things," said Mr. Meehan.
Unable to deal with unfamiliar court proceedings or because of day jobs, landlords usually hire lawyers to handle evictions. "The lawyers often can't meet deadlines, tenants don't show up and proceedings are delayed for months, costing thousands of dollars in legal fees," Mr. Meehan said.
Ted Sackowski, the Tolland County Sheriff, serves the notices of eviction and eventually removes tenants and their belongings. "There has been a dramatic increase in evictions in the past three years," he said, "about 25 percent, primarily in 3- to 5-family units with rents around $400 a month."
Most owners of such properties, bought during the 80's, now find that the buildings are worth far less. Often the rents don't cover the mortgage and tax payments and banks won't reduce interest rates as they do for one-family homeowners.
"THE banks are becoming the largest property owners in the area," said Kevin Skiest, president of the 100-member New Haven Landlords Association, formed last year. "The market adjusted the rent numbers downward, now we need to adjust the expense numbers."
A total of 3,843 evictions were recorded by the Housing Section of the New Haven Superior Court last year; through May of this year there have been 1,457.
"In the last two years there have been a lot of foreclosures," said Suzanne Colasanto, chief clerk for housing matters at the court. "The banks sometimes evict because they feel they can market the property better without tenants. They have that right if the lease subordinates to the mortgage holder." She noted that evictions could take from six weeks "to the end of time." Three months is the average.
Mr. Cornish believes the recession is only partly to blame. "Poorly written and managed laws favor the delinquent tenant," he said, "so landlords are boarding up the buildings and giving them back to the banks.
"New London has more homeless people than ever before," Mr. Cornish said, "and last year the city had its first auction of residential buildings for taxes."
A major sticking point with small landlords is the elimination of mandatory direct payment of rent to the landlord by the city welfare agencies. "It was a help," said Mr. Cornish. But last year the legislature made it voluntary, and the cities stopped doing it to avoid the clerical work.
Behind the change was a philosophical component that Claudette Beaulier, spokeswoman for the state's Department of Income Maintenance, explained. "The legislature wanted recipients to be more independent, to accept responsibility and learn to manage money."
"We reimburse the towns for 85 percent of their expenditures in General Assistance," she continued. "The towns still have the option of making direct payments to landlords."
Reductions in state benefits from $325 a month for rent to $314 has increased applications for assistance with evictions at New Haven's Legal Aid Society, a nonprofit agency serving families with incomes under $18,000 and individuals earning less than $9,000.
"Unless the landlord is not providing heat and hot water, or the rent is excessive, or there are no smoke detectors, or there is lead paint present, we can't take these cases," said Angelica Allen, head of the organization's housing unit.
WHEN such conditions exist the landlord is expected to correct them to get a certificate of occupancy, required for each new tenant. "The majority of owners don't have them," said Kenneth Rideout, head of a landlords' association in Granby, "because the process is so cumbersome, and landlords are afraid of minor reasons why a certificate would not be issued." He owns an eight-unit building.
"First thing tenants do when evicted is call us to ask if there's a C.O.," said Norman Winuk, acting chief of the New Britain Building Inspector's office. "Then they call for an inspection, which can take a couple of weeks. The tenant can be uncooperative -- make excuses not to let the landlord in to fix the violations, or he breaks whatever was fixed. Meanwhile he doesn't have to pay rent for months."
For some, of course, the very word "landlord" is a red flag. But the small army of residential landlords in Connecticut, some 600 of whom have joined regional landlord associations to date, is trying to change that.
"We call ourselves the New Britain Apartment Owners Association of Hartford County," said Mr. Rideout. "Landlord has a negative connotation. We want to focus on educational forums for members and we are working up a data base for the use of tenants and landlords alike."
Buying supplies and appliances in bulk, swapping equipment, a referral system, and property insurance are other services that the associations hope to provide.
"We don't need more affordable housing," said Mr. Meehan in Willimantic. "We need to bring down the cost of what exists."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 27, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday in copies distributed in Connecticut and Westchester, about small-landlord associations, included an erroneous status report from a legislative aide on a measure in the Connecticut Legislature. The measure, allowing towns to require tenants to pay rent into escrow accounts when landlords lack certificates of occupancy, did reach the floor, and was passed.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Railroads Are a Growth Industry, for a Change

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
IN Washington, the Virginia Railway Express is about to celebrate its first anniversary, carrying commuters from Union Station to Manassas and Fredericksburg. Amtrak is well on the way to a historic improvement in the tracks from New York to Boston, electrifying those east of New Haven with overhead power lines that will allow faster trips, possibly luring substantial patronage from the air shuttles. And in Miami, a makeshift commuter line that helped to ease traffic to West Palm Beach during major construction on Interstate 95 is now permanent.
Railroads are trying to make a comeback.
Around the country, air pollution from cars seems to be a nearly intractable problem, and society is concluding that in many places it cannot build enough highways or runways to cure congestion. The decision to build commuter rail lines, said William E. Loftus, president of the American Short Line Railroad Association, is "a recognition that you can live an hour away from work and still have a pleasant commute." 
 Washington is offering more help of late, in the guise of anti-recession employment programs. The Clean Air Act amendments of 1990 are also a factor, calling on areas with the worst pollution to reduce the number of miles cars are driven.
According to Ross B. Capon, executive director of the National Association of Railroad Passengers, plans are afoot for commuters in Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, San Jose, San Diego, Seattle and Tampa -- major cities without any commuter rail service.
New York's Metro-North Commuter Railroad is studying whether it can run to the beaches of Long Island, far from its territory. Last week it said that a bridge or tunnel across the Hudson River to the fast-growing suburbs of Rockland and Orange counties would be cost-effective, but well over $1 billion. What is striking is that Metro-North's expansion involves new tracks and new rights-of-way. The last new tracks in the area the railroad serves were laid before the turn of the century.
But it's not always easy. Boston planners are trying to determine if they can connect North Station and South Station, which would allow a traveler to go seamlessly from Maine to Miami; the only unbroken route for that journey today is the interstate highway. The connection, some of it passing underneath the subway system, is estimated to cost $1.8 billion. All the construction would be done by union workers. A hundred years ago, railroad companies took cheap labor right off the boat and laid track almost anywhere they pleased.
Hitches in Metro-North's idea for the Long Island beach train are simple but annoying, like the third rail: trains in the northern suburbs pick up power from a shoe that slides under the rail; on Long Island the train shoes slide on top.
And there are money questions. Metro-North justifies the heavy tax subsidy of its lines -- 45 percent of operating expenses and 100 percent of capital expenses -- as being a benefit to society. Specifically, each car not driven to mid-town Manhattan during a weekday rush hour is said to be worth $14.25 in reduced congestion and pollution.
Is a car not driven on the Long Island Expressway on a sunny July Saturday worth the same amount? Is a journey generated simply because the rail link is available something the rest of the region should subsidize? The questions raise deep, impassioned debates over the alternative, cars. The private auto enjoys various subsidies, from the general tax dollars that go into road maintenance to the right to pollute the air to the use of the United States Army to keep Middle East oil fields out of hostile hands.
But incrementally, train service is returning. One indication is the backlog of orders for railroad passenger cars; five years ago, as measured by Railway Age, it was 946 cars, and at the beginning of this year it was 2,221.
 
More People, Fewer Stops

 
 According to the American Public Transit Association, commuter rail trips totaled 324 million in 1991, a slight dip from the previous year, probably because of recession, but way up from the recent past; in 1975 the number was 260 million.
In the intercity market, Amtrak is now logging 6 billion passenger-miles each year. In 1970, the year before Amtrak began operating, the national total was less than 5 billion miles. The growth is particularly significant because the number of cities served has declined, which means that more people want to ride the trains even if they are going to fewer destinations.
"Many people are just beginning to realize how congested the roads and highways are," said Molly A. Hart, vice president of the Railway Progress Institute, a trade association based in Washington.
Metro-North argues that a rail line can carry a 1,000-passenger train every 2.5 minutes, or 24,000 passengers an hour; a traffic lane would carry only about 2,000 cars, the railroad calculates. At an average occupancy of six people for every five cars, that is only 2,400 people. And while the train goes a mile on three gallons of diesel oil, moving the same 1,000 people would take 835 cars, burning about 33 gallons a mile.
Mr. Capon of the National Association of Railroad Passengers noted that since 1988 Amtrak has returned to such diverse cities as Santa Barbara and Bakersfield in California, Houston, Montgomery and Birmingham, Milwaukee and Atlantic City. On other routes, frequency has increased to once a day instead of two or three times a week.
But there is still far to go. A Swedish express train, the X-2000, ran in commercial service from Boston to Washington earlier this year and attracted raves because its design enables it to travel fast around curves. Then it went on tour to Buffalo, Chicago, St. Louis and various stops in Wisconsin, Washington and Oregon; it may still go to California, New Mexico and Ohio. But most of those places have no electrification, so the train had to be pulled by old-fashioned diesel engines.
