HEADLINE: CLINTON AIDES SEE PROBLEM WITH VOW TO LIMIT WELFARE

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Although President Clinton last week renewed his pledge to "end welfare as we know it," aides drafting his plan acknowledge that the effort could be expensive and might even force him to scale back action nationwide.
The centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's plan is his pledge to impose a two-year limit on welfare benefits. It was one of his most popular campaign themes and holds a special allure for the centrist and conservative legislators he is now courting, since it sounds like a tough-talking, economizing move. 
 But the architects of Mr. Clinton's plan have something very different in mind, a program with costly new services. To justify time limits, the working group wants to expand programs that provide child care, health care and job training, and that may even offer some welfare recipients Government jobs.
 
No Way of Saving Money
 Though the planners hope to enhance the lives of the five million families that receive welfare, they recognize something that much of the public does not: it is cheaper in the short run just to keep mailing public assistance checks.
"There is a fundamental dilemma, but this has not been sold as a way of balancing the Federal budget," said David T. Ellwood, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, who is serving as co-chairman of the working group. "Nobody's talking about this as a way of saving money. We're talking about spending money."
Mr. Ellwood stressed that he remained very encouraged "about fundamental transformations of the system."
But the price tag of a bold plan may take many people by surprise.
"I fear that time limits mean very different things to people in the Administration and to their audience, the public at large," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, through which the legislation must pass.
Mr. Ellwood introduced the idea of time limits in his book, "Poor Support" (Basic Books, 1988), written while he was a professor at Harvard University. He then advocated time limits as part of a broad expansion of services, including health care and the creation of some Government jobs. His book estimated that this could cost an additional $30 billion a year.
 
Changes in Phases
 No one is now contemplating such sums. In a December policy paper, Mr. Ellwood called for imposing time limits in only a modest number of states, saying a gradual phase-in made more sense given the budget deficit and the need for states to adjust.
Mr. Ellwood wrote that a phase-in plan is consistent with the President's call for bold action.
Combined state and Federal spending on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main cash welfare program, costs about $20 billion a year. Working group members say no formal budgetary guidelines have been set, but during the campaign Mr. Clinton talked of spending an extra $4 billion a year on training programs and $2 billion on tax credits for low-wage workers.
He has already exceeded those sums by separately putting forward a tax credit plan that, when fully in place, would cost an extra $7.6 billion a year.
An expensive welfare plan would require Mr. Clinton to return to a tax-spooked Congress for money for a politically unpopular constituency.
"It has the makings of a massive misunderstanding and recrimination when it all comes out," said one Democratic member of Congress.
In the broadest sense, the outlines of Mr. Clinton's plan are clear. He has pledged to put more money into the education and training programs that each state now runs under the 1988 Family Support Act.
He has pledged to increase the collection of child support from absent parents. And he has promised to give single mothers the child care and transportation they need to work.
But the core of Mr. Clinton's promise is to insist on a welfare limit of two years, and the main, unanswered question can be summarized with two words, "Then what?" Mr. Clinton has pledged to make people then take a job, but he has not specified what he means by that.
Members of the working group have estimated that roughly three million of the nation's five million welfare families are likely to remain on the rolls when the two-year time limit ends.
Work and training programs now exempt half of welfare recipients because their children are too young. If that remains the case, the planners still face the question of what to do with 1.5 million of the nation's poorest least-skilled, least-employable families.
Proposals in Florida and Wisconsin seek simply to withdraw benefits after two years, leaving families to fend for themselves. But the Clinton planners have no intention of just dropping aid.
Carol Rasco, the White House domestic policy adviser, said that whatever occurs at the end of two years should be a meaningful experience and "a piece on a career ladder."
"I feel very strongly about that," she said.
 
Skeptical About Deadlines
 Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has also expressed doubts about time limits. "I'm not a believer in artificial deadlines of that nature," he said in an interview last week, saying that many people would be unable to leave the rolls that quickly. Mr. Cisneros said he was expressing a personal opinion, rather than Administration policy.
One possibility being considered by the working group is to withdraw cash aid after two years, and substitute the offer of a public service job.
This would insure that former welfare recipients have a source income that pays better than welfare and would provide the public with needed services.
But it could also be prohibitively expensive. Creating 1.5 million public service jobs could cost $20 billion. Mr. Ellwood said the task force might recommend some number of public service jobs.
That leaves another option: a requirement that, after two years, welfare recipients take part in workfare in exchange for continuing to receive their welfare checks. Since the average cash welfare grant is only about $370 a month, this is much cheaper than creating jobs.
But the planners have estimated that even workfare plans can cost as much as an extra $3,500 a year for each families including child care and administrative fees. That means a program for 1.5 million families would have an annual cost of $5.3 billion.
In the December paper, Mr. Ellwood warned that a large workfare program would be a mistake since it would do little to help welfare recipients or reduce caseloads. Research has show such programs have done little to move people into private employment.
In a recent interview, Mr. Ellwood said that the Clinton plan would probably include some workfare, but he would not speculate on how many people might be covered.
The working group is also headed by Bruce Reed, a White House domestic policy adviser, and Mary Jo Bane, who is a nominee to become an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Citing President Clinton's call for time limits, about 40 House Republicans have endorsed a bill that requires welfare recipients to work 35 hours a week after two years, in exchange for their benefits.
"It doesn't bring them extra income, but we get them in a culture that is a much more positive one," said Representative Richard J. Santorum, a Pennsylvania Republican a co-sponsor of the bill, which would spend $3.6 billion over five years.
But a pivotal Democratic legislator has already dismissed such a large workfare program out of hand.
"I will not even take that up in the committee," said Representative Harold Ford of Tennessee, who heads the House Ways and Means subcommittee on human resources, which oversees all welfare legislation. "We're not talking about workfare."
Mr. Ford said he is drafting his own public employment program, which could cost $10 billion a year. Time limits would be unacceptable without such support, he said.
The effort to pass a welfare reform bill will grow even more difficult if the Administration does not first pass its health-care plan, which could easily cost more than $40 billion a year.
Many women now remain on welfare in order to get Medicaid for themselves and their children. Mr. Clinton has pledged to provide health care to women who leave welfare for work.

HEADLINE: Abandoned Filipinos Sue U.S. Over Child Support

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLONGAPO, the Philippines

 BODY:
Next to her son James, what Lucia Villegas Hill prizes most may be a handful of documents identifying his father as an American sailor at the United States Navy base that shut down here last year.
"He's so far away now," she said, handing over a crinkled 1975 marriage certificate and a faded photograph of a man whose features bear some resemblance to her son's. It has been years since Mrs. Hill's husband wrote or sent money, and she clings to a scrap of yellow paper with his last known address and phone number, in Port Orchard, Wash. 
 For centuries, women in diverse lands and cultures have been left to raise children alone after being abandoned by foreign soldiers.
But Mrs. Hill and thousands of others in this town next to the former Subic Bay Naval Station have taken a novel approach. Instead of pressing individual paternity or child-support suits, they have filed a $68 million lawsuit arguing that the United States has a legal responsibility to educate and provide medical care for an estimated 8,600 Amerasians in Olongapo.
The suit, filed as a class action in March in the Federal Court of Claims in Washington, argues that the Navy effectively fostered and regulated an elaborate night-life and prostitution industry, live-in arrangements and marriages here in which servicemen fathered thousands of children.
 
Sporadic Support Payments
 Mrs. Hill, for example, says she met her husband, also named James, in the Shamrock Club, a popular night spot.
"I'm very sad because of what happened," she said. "But I still have hope, and No. 1 is for my boy to meet his father."
Many mothers subsisted for a time on sporadic payments from the fathers, pressuring Navy officials when payments lagged. But the financial support began drying up in 1991, when the Philippine Senate barred the renewal of United States leases on the sprawling naval base and other installations in the Philippines. The United States had already decided that year to abandon Clark Air Base, its other major military site in the country, after it was damaged by a volcanic eruption.
When most American ships and planes finally left last year, the decades-long party was over at the Pussy Cat Bar, the Joy Club and hundreds of other hostess clubs, discotheques, brothels, massage parlors and short-stay hotels with neon signs just outside the gates of the Subic base.
Like tens of thousands of Filipinos who had worked at Subic or Clark in maintenance, food-service or similar jobs, mothers who had supported their children by working in the clubs suddenly found themselves unemployed.
 
Suit Has Stirred Skepticism
 "Nothing is being done to relieve the human damage which was done to those who were left behind, namely the thousands of forgotten children of American servicemen," the lawsuit contends. It was filed in cooperation with the local women's groups Preda, Buklod, Gabriela and Wedpro.
The lawyer representing the women and children is Joseph W. Cotchett, a former Green Beret from Burlingame, Calif., who won an $8 billion judgment last year against Charles W. Keating Jr. and three co-defendants on behalf of 20,000 savings and loan investors.
Although the Navy has declined to comment, the suit has stirred skepticism among United States military officials and some former G.I.'s, who argue that American taxpayers are not responsible for foreigners conceived by consenting adults.
Critics also argue that the children may have been fathered by foreigners who were not Americans, and that some women tried to get pregnant in the hope of marrying or moving to the United States.
 
Hurt, Anger and Yearning
 But talk of the missing American "tatays" -- Filipino for fathers -- stirs hurt, anger and yearning among women and children who meet regularly here at the Human Development Center, perched on a hill with panoramic views overlooking the old 14,400-acre base at Subic and the deep blue bay.
"I want to get to know him, and even though he left us here, I can remind him of his responsibility to help my studies," James Hill, 16, said of his father.
Nida Havier, 35, said she had lived with a Navy man for three years before he departed. It "was very painful, it hurt me very much," she said. Their son, Anthony, now 7, asks where his father is and says he wants to see him.
Mercedes Gervacio, who has four Amerasian children, teaches other mothers how to sell candy on the street to earn $3 or $4 a day. She said one boyfriend talked of marriage, "but it was just a promise."
The center where they shared their stories is run by an Irish priest, the Rev. Shay Cullen, who describes the young Amerasians as "throwaway children."
Children of interracial unions have been common in the Philippines since Magellan and his fleet arrived in the early 16th century.
But the departure of the American troops and the emergence of child support as a national issue in the United States have focused attention on the issue now. There is growing pressure in the United States to prevent absentee fathers from evading their obligations by crossing state lines.
"It is time to demand that people take responsibility for the children they bring into this world," President Clinton said in an address to Congress in February. The lawsuit quotes Mr. Clinton and argues that the issue crosses international boundaries.
 
Government Has More Money
 The suit was filed against the United States Government mainly because the Filipino women and children cannot afford the legal costs involved in tracking down fathers or proving paternity. The average income in the Philippines is $740 a year.
Another reason the United States was chosen as the defendant, largely unmentioned, is that it has more money than the fathers do.
Papers filed in the case focus on establishing the Navy's direct role in the local bar and sex industry. The suit contends that the Navy helped regulate the clubs, some of which were owned by Navy officers or retirees; patrolled Olongapo with military police, and registered thousands of "hospitality" women and gave them information and medical care aimed at limiting venereal disease.
The Navy also approved off-base apartments where many sailors lived with girlfriends or wives.
Advocates of the class-action suit see a disparity in United States laws that exclude Filipino children from the special immigration rights granted to many other Amerasians.
 
Others Can Immigrate
 Just over a hill south of the Subic base, the United Nations runs a camp for Vietnamese refugees that still processes a trickle of Amerasians -- now adults -- who were conceived during the Vietnam War. Under United States law, they are entitled to immigrate under the sponsorship of any American. That coveted right also extends to children of American servicemen who were stationed in South Korea, Thailand, Cambodia and Laos.
But the children born to G.I.'s in the Philippines do not qualify for preferential status. The rationale is that Amerasians suffered from anti-American hostility and racial bias in the other countries but not here.
Critics say that assumption is faulty. While many Filipinos have mixed Chinese, Malay and Spanish ancestry, there is bias against people of darker skin. When the American parent is black, the child is often ostracized and taunted with racial epithets. Amerasian children are also often stigmatized as illegitimate.
Local views of the class-action lawsuit vary. The town's Mayor, Richard Gordon, himself the grandson of an American, called the suit simplistic. "It demeans us to ask for money," he said.
Mr. Gordon favors revising United States immigration laws to include the children fathered here by G.I.'s, and some lawmakers, including Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Hawaii Democrat, have expressed interest in the issue.
But Father Cullen opposes uprooting children from their culture. "Are we saying the Philippines is not good enough for them?" he said.
The Pearl Buck Foundation, which contributes to education and health care for Amerasians and helps some apply to immigrate, says its biggest program is in the Philippines.
The head of the Philippine program, William S. McCabe 2d, dismisses estimates of children fathered by American servicemen as guesses. He said that many claims are legitimate but that fraud is common. "There's a game here called 'Get Out of the Country,' " he said.
President Fidel V. Ramos has called the future of the Amerasians the most important issue remaining from the American military evacuation, "the joint responsibility of both countries." But neither side has made a proposal to address the needs of the fatherless children.

HEADLINE: Tax Increases Considered By Republicans, Dole Says

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
Planning to offer an alternative to President Clinton's budget package when it comes before the Senate on Wednesday, Republican senators are considering a proposal that would include some tax increases, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said today.
Mr. Dole suggested that he might support a package with some tax increases and sizable spending cuts as part of a broad effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit. But he hastily added that he was only "speaking for myself," not as the party's leading elected spokesman. 
 The statement is nonetheless a departure for the Republicans, many of whom forswore new taxes when Ronald Reagan was elected President in 1980, and have campaigned on anti-tax themes ever since.
In an interview on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Dole maintained that Mr. Clinton's proposed budget was "tax heavy" and short on spending cuts. The White House says its proposal would reduce the deficit by $500 billion, partly through $249 billion in tax increases over five years.
 
Debating 2 Alternatives
 Citing figures produced by the Congressional Budget Office, the Kansas Senator said Mr. Clinton's proposal would cut the deficit by $346.7 billion and raise taxes by $265 billion, not $249 billion.
"It's about three-fourths taxes and very little spending cuts, and I think that's not going to be good for the economy," Mr. Dole said. "A lot of these people, the so-called rich people who are going to be taxed, are what we call small businessmen."
Having made that point, he allowed that he could accept some taxes to reduce the deficit and said Senate Republicans were debating whether they should offer a proposed budget with taxes or one without as an alternative to Mr. Clinton's package.
"I think we could accept some revenues if we had a lot of spending cuts," he said.
Among the taxes Mr. Dole said he could support was an increase in the personal income tax from the current 31 percent maximum.
Mr. Clinton proposes raising the top rate to 36 percent for most upper-income taxpayers, but surtaxes would increase the maximum to more than 40 percent, by some calculations.
"I think people could live with" a top rate of 36 percent, Mr. Dole said, referring to members of his party.
Mr. Dole also said he might favor a surtax on households with taxable incomes of more than $250,000 a year.
Only last week, several Republican Senators complained bitterly about the unfairness of that same surtax in the Clinton package.
Mr. Dole gave few details of the Republican budget alternative but said it would include a freeze on spending for so-called discretionary programs, for which Congress sets budgets each year. He also said the plan would place a cap on the growth of Federal benefit programs.
The chairman of the Finance Committee, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, speaking on the same CBS News program, acknowledged that Mr. Dole was right on at least one point. "It is a tax bill, huge tax bill," he said of Mr. Clinton's budget plan. "It can be argued, also, that it is the most progressive change in the tax code we've seen since World War II in terms of who pays what."

HEADLINE: Sniping Is Growing At The U.N. Over Weakness In Peacekeeping

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 18

 BODY:
The fighting between United Nations forces and a warlord in Somalia and the failure of international troops to be an effective buffer in Bosnia are forcing many to rethink the organization's vastly expanded role as a global peacekeeper.
Diplomats here have publicly complained of amateurism in the peacekeeping operations, with the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, asserting recently that "ill-equipped and often unprepared troops" are often sent into the field. 
 Officials in the United Nations Secretariat grumble that member nations are piling on tasks without providing adequate forces or money to do the jobs.
Such recriminations by no means spell disaster for United Nations peacekeeping efforts, which have been revitalized over the last few years and credited for successes like the disarmament of rebels in El Salvador and the elections in Cambodia last month.
 
From Optimism to Realism
 Yet the view of global police work has shifted, from a mood of buoyant optimism at the United Nations just a few months ago to what some are calling a new realism about the difficulties.
"There's no question that for a while we hoped that simply by deploying forces a solution would magically emerge," a European diplomat said. "But it doesn't work that way."
Ms. Albright endorsed the concept of "multilateral action" in a speech to the Council on Foreign Relations on June 11, saying, But she harshly criticized the way United Nations peacekeeping efforts were organized, saying many of the 13 operations mounted in the last five years had been hampered by a "near-total absence of contingency planning," hasty recruitment and a "byzantine and drawn-out budgetary decision making process."
 
A New Cooperation
 The criticism is a change for an organization that only a year or so ago was basking in its growing responsibilities.
For decades the Security Council had been paralyzed by cold-war competition between the Soviet Union and the United States, both of which had veto power in the Council's decisions. But the collapse of Communism and the fading of the superpowers' arms race opened the way for new cooperation, leading to internationally brokered accords in Cambodia and Angola.
Some analysts worry that the organization's involvement in so many conflicts could land it in quagmires reminiscent of the United States experience in Vietnam.
"The possibilities for going wrong are numerous and the costs potentially open-ended," Laurence Martin, the director of the Institute of International Affairs in London, writes in the latest issue of The National Interest, a quarterly journal.
 
'An Endless Agenda'
 He was speaking particularly of the Security Council's willingness to send peacekeepers into countries riven by domestic conflicts that the United Nations had previously tended to avoid, like the ethnic fighting in Bosnia or the anarchy in Somalia.
To try to protect national minorities and to build governments where there are none is "to accept an endless agenda and to assume the task of state and community-building on a vast scale," he said.
Of the last nine peacekeeping operations authorized by the Security Council, seven have involved internal wars. Most of the previous missions were aimed at preventing further conflict between two countries, like monitoring the border between Iraq and Kuwait.
As its missions expand, the troops under United Nations command have expanded from just 11,500 at the beginning of 1992 to roughly 80,000 now, according to the United Nations Under Secretary General for Peacekeeping, Kofi Annan of Ghana. That number is expected to grow to nearly 100,000 once forces have been recruited to protect the six Bosnian "safe areas" designated this month by the Security Council.
 
Donors Slow to Pay
 But officials at the United Nations say it has become increasingly difficult to persuade countries to contribute modern specialized forces.
In another obstacle, the main donor nations are behind by $1.2 billion in their peacekeeping payments, with the United States alone owing $312 million. United States officials, using different accounting procedures, say the figure owed is more like $40 million, but the Clinton Administration has vowed to pay the full United States assessment.
"With the United Nations engaged in so many operations around the world, the impression has been created that it is doing exactly what it was set up to do, but it is all very fragile," Mr. Annan said in an interview.
Complicating the task is what Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, with a touch of irony, has called the "excessive credibility" that the organization has gained.
"There is a naivete that believes the United Nations is capable of just walking in and solving all problems," one official here said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "And then, at the other end of the spectrum, there is cynicism, a tendency of countries to dump responsibility on the United Nations simply to show their publics that they are doing something."
 
Little Decisive Action
 The most frequently cited example is Bosnia and Herzegovina, where Western nations have refrained from direct military intervention to halt "ethnic cleansing" by Serbian nationalists. The United States and other countries have solemnly approved one resolution after another imposing economic sanctions and declaring safe havens, but little decisive action has been taken.
"It's not fair to accuse the United States of cynical manipulation of the Security Council," one American official said. "It's unrealistic to expect that a bureaucracy created 45 years ago and moribund for so long would suddenly be able to act decisively around the globe. We're doing all we can by committing forces in some places, air power in others, money in others."
Some analysts say that peacekeeping missions of recent years have been of two kinds, one far more difficult than the other. The easier ones were what Enid Schoettle, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, calls "mopping up old regional conflicts at the end of the cold war" -- specifically, she says, in Namibia, Angola, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Cambodia.
"The great powers and the parties to the conflicts decided to end these wars and then involved the United Nations," she said.
At the same time, Dr. Schoettle said, a genuinely multinational force was mobilized with the permission of the United Nations to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait, and with that, "there was a rising curve of expectation."
 
'The Only Policeman'
 A year ago, Secretary General Boutros-Ghali issued an "Agenda for Peace," in which he proclaimed that "a conviction has grown among nations large and small that an opportunity has been regained to achieve the great objectives of the Charter -- a United Nations capable of maintaining international peace and security."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali was in a sense recognizing that for the first time since the 1950's, the major powers were more eager in some cases to use the United Nations than to act unilaterally. "Willingly or not, the United Nations has become the only policeman in the world," an official here said.
Still, Dr. Schoettle said, at just about the time that Mr. Boutros-Ghali presented his "Agenda for Peace," "the disillusion started to set in."
In part that was because the United Nations was increasingly faced with conflicts in which the major cold-war powers had never played a role -- internal wars involving collapsing governments, in Somalia, for example, or ethnic hatred, in former Yugoslav republics.
 
Lessons for the Future
 One miscalculation has been recognized in Angola, where the United Nations was able to oversee elections last year but then was unable to react when rebels led by Jonas Savimbi resumed fighting.
It is widely acknowledged here that the 298-member peacekeeping force in Angola was hampered by its size. If the United Nations had deployed a larger force with a mandate to disarm the factions, those officials say, it might have been successful in preventing Mr. Savimbi's rebels from renewing their attacks.
The lessons learned there are now in a sense being applied in Somalia, where United Nations forces have attacked the arms depots of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid.
"We've had our down sides," one United States official said. "It doesn't mean that peacekeeping has failed. It can work if it's done the right way."

HEADLINE: Hispanic Santa Fe Loses Itself as It Lures Rich

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., June 18

 BODY:
Charmed by stunning mountain vistas and the romance of ancient cultures, tourists have been coming to Santa Fe since before Georgia O'Keefe captured the mystical New Mexico skies in her paintings in the 1920's.
But now many tourists to Santa Fe are deciding they do not want to go back home. Instead, these affluent newcomers have been buying old adobe houses and building sprawling haciendas in the foothills of the Sangre de Cristo mountains. But the Hispanic culture they came to embrace has shrunk before the soaring property values and taxes they bring with them. 
 In the last census, people with Spanish surnames became a minority in this city for the first time since the 1600's, when the Conquistadors arrived here and built Santa Fe on the ruins of a Pueblo Indian village. And those who struggle to remain say they cannot afford the rising taxes that come with the influx of wealthy "Anglos."
In some neighborhoods, where fancy new homes sit down the road from modest adobes, and German cars cross paths with bumpy pickups, there have been tensions about the changes. The longtime residents say they fear the day when Santa Fe becomes another Aspen, Colo., where only the rich can afford to stay and workers are shuttled in from distant towns to make beds and wait tables.
 
Congestion of Tourists
 "The newcomers wanted to live in Santa Fe, and who can blame them," said Nora Chavez, a retired woman who saw the property taxes on her adobe house rise 143 percent last year. "But they're spoiling what they came here for."
Downtown Santa Fe, until the last decade a thriving marketplace of shops for working people, now caters almost exclusively to tourists. Big Joe's Lumberyard has become the Eldorado Hotel. The J. C. Penney store was cleared to make way for art galleries. The Sears, Roebuck store moved to a shopping mall on the edge of the city and was replaced with expensive boutiques.
Traffic around the green plaza, where a stone marks the end of the Santa Fe Trail, moves at the clip of a desert tortoise, with tour buses and out-of-state cars parading in a long line. Local officials say tourism now accounts for 50 percent of the local economy, outweighing the former leader, state government.
"There are native Santa Fe people who haven't been downtown for five or six years," said Orlando Romero, a researcher at the Palace of the Governors, the former seat of government built by the Spaniards in 1610. "There's nothing for them here anymore. Try to find a drug store -- you can't."
 
'These Are Conquerors'
 Debbie Jaramillo, a member of the City Council, said the change in Santa Fe amounted to an invasion.
"These are conquerors who did not need arms to take over the town," she said. "They have come instead with their big money and their higher education."
As the Santa Fe style of art, architecture and decor became popular in the 1980's, scores of celebrities moved to town, including recent arrivals like the actresses Shirley MacLaine and Carol Burnett. The city's population grew by 14 percent, to about 56,000. But virtually all of the growth has been among affluent whites. Since 1970, the number of Hispanic residents in Santa Fe has fallen from 65 percent to 49 percent. Indians account for only about 2 percent of the population, since most live in pueblos north of the city.
In some neighborhoods, property values have quadrupled in the last decade. While wealthy whites have moved into the old adobe houses in the foothills, Hispanic people have been settling in trailer parks on the outskirts of town, near the state penitentiary, or moving to towns like Las Vegas, N.M., an hour away.
"The whole thing makes me very sad," said Viola Lujan, a Santa Fe native who moved to a trailer 20 miles outside of town. "When I was a kid, I could walk to my grandparents' house. Families all lived close by. The way things are going, there won't be any room for the native people."
Jesse Wheeler's ancestors have lived in a modest adobe house for 100 years. Now it sits down the road from huge new houses covered with adobe-like stucco. He said that the neighborhood was once like a family, but that when he pulled into a newcomer's driveway recently to turn around, "this woman comes out shouting, 'Hey this is private property!' "
Even the Indian pueblos north of Santa Fe have been transformed by the influx of whites. In some pueblos where property can be leased, whites now outnumber Indians.
The rising land prices have also pinched owners of local art galleries. Ron and Arlene Siegel, who own a gallery downtown, now pay $2,300 a month in rent and utilities. "It's running the small businessman out of town," Mr. Siegel said.
City officials say the problem is not growth but a shortage of affordable housing. In the first quarter of 1993, the average sale price of a house in Santa Fe was $201,000, far beyond the reach of most longtime residents who typically earn $20,000 a year or less.
The city recently bought an 850-acre tract that has been reserved for affordable housing. The first of 900 units, many selling for less than $100,000, will be constructed next year. The city also imposes a tax on developers of new subdivisions that will be used to help first-time home buyers.
Adobe houses, often built by the residents, or their ancestors, have become especially coveted. "A prospective buyer comes in and offers a lot of cold cash," said Ike Pino, the city manager. "Sometimes, the enticement is too much to pass up. But these people are selling of their own free will. And some of them are picking up $250,000, even $500,000."
Not all of the longtime residents have been unhappy about the influx of wealthy newcomers. "It means a paycheck," said Frank Ortiz, a 56-year-old plasterer, who said the steady work has helped him support his family, including two deaf children who need expensive education.
As she rode through a neighborhood where expensive houses are being built alongside modest adobe ones, Gloria Mendoza said: "They say they want to come here because they love our culture.But they certainly don't live like us. They want to change it into whatever they're used to."
The buyers have lately been knocking at the front door of Jesus Rios, a 93-year-old former woodcutter who built his adobe house in 1938. He has answered with a shake of the head.
"This is my home," he said, as he sat at the kitchen table, while his wife, Theresa, cooked squash. "They could offer me $20 million -- we're not selling."

HEADLINE: A Tokyo Pol, Once Out, Is Back Leading a Revolt

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 20

 BODY:
Six months ago, Ichiro Ozawa's political fortunes had ebbed so low that when accused of seeking intervention by organized crime in a prime ministerial race, he was reduced to defending himself by saying he had been at a key meeting where the plan was discussed, but only to serve drinks and empty ashtrays.
A political cartoon subsequently depicted him as a waiter in a bar fetching drinks for a gangster, who said to a friend, "Did you see who that was?" 
 No one is making such jokes now. The politician many thought of as finished has just pulled off perhaps the most dramatic coup in postwar Japanese politics.
Mr. Ozawa has been conspicuously absent from the Japanese press coverage of the vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa on Friday. But few political experts doubt that he was in the shadows engineering the defeat of his former colleagues in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, and that he just may have ended the 38-year-old reign of the party to which he once devoted his career.
 
Election Set for July 18
 Whether he and the nominal head of his breakaway faction, former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata, will succeed in heading a coalition Government to replace the Liberal Democrats after the elections to be held on July 18 remains to be seen. But for the moment their ideas have suddenly taken on a new influence, and could have a large impact on other parties.
That could be very good news for the United States. Mr. Ozawa and Mr. Hata are, in a Japanese context, internationalists serious about instituting broad-based changes in the century-old system that has made Japanese bureaucrats more important than politicians in setting Government policies. Washington has long called for some of the same changes.
The most striking aspect of Mr. Ozawa's comeback may be that his rebel faction succeeded in part by depicting itself as the champion of reform of the corrupt ways and inflexibility of Japanese politics.
Since Mr. Ozawa, 51, rose as the protege of Shin Kanemaru, a former party kingmaker whose trial on tax evasion charges will begin four days after the election next month, his claims have understandably met some skepticism. It has not helped either that Mr. Hata, 56, is still remembered as the politician who, as Agriculture Minister several years ago, argued that Japan could not open its markets to American beef because it was not suited to unique Japanese intestines.
 
Sons of the Party
 They are both the sons of loyal governing party members of Parliament, and they were both high-fliers in the powerful party faction run by former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, the man whom gangsters had helped to power in 1987, before he was toppled in an influence-peddling scandal. That will not be forgotten quickly.
"After all, who were they just a few months ago?" Mainichi Shimbun, a leading daily newspaper, said in an editorial. "Nothing but loyal henchmen and hatchet men working for Shin Kanemaru and Noboru Takeshita."
But by the standards of Japanese politics, they are now angry young men with a forward-looking policy agenda who have seized a measure of power few would have expected even a month ago. Last year, they lost a struggle for control of Mr. Takeshita's old party faction. But the 34 votes they delivered on Friday in favor of the motion of no confidence tipped the balance in favor of the opposition parties, threatening four decades of political stability.
"In order to make something new, we have to destroy the old system," Mr. Ozawa said in an interview several months ago.
 
Accountability Stressed
 He and Mr. Hata say they want politicians accountable to the electorate to set Japan's course. Some conservatives regard that as an open invitation to more corruption, but the two men describe it as a step toward greater democracy.
Their proposals for steps toward deregulation of the economy and for the return of some of the benefits of Japan's economic success to consumers, in the form of freer competition and less expensive goods, are precisely what American trade negotiators have been advocating.
Mr. Ozawa has a track record of producing agreements favorable to the United States, though he says he took those steps only when he felt they were ultimately good for the Japanese.
He was instrumental, for instance, in persuading the Government to contribute $13 billion to support the coalition against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. He has helped to open various construction projects and Government procurement to foreign bidders. He pushed to have Japanese minesweepers sent to the Persian Gulf, and he was a strong supporter of a law permitting Japanese soldiers to take part in United Nations peacekeeping operations.
 
The Style Is Familiar
 However new their ideas, though, the style of these two politicians bears a great resemblance to that of the party they are now fighting. Often the Prime Minister in Japan has not been the most powerful politician among the Liberal Democrats. In this case, Mr. Hata, who is regarded as a likable man with a common touch because of the 10 years he spent working for a bus company, is the public face of the new faction.
Mr. Ozawa is regarded as brusque and impatient. He is more comfortable operating in the back rooms of Nagatacho, the Tokyo district where Parliament is situated. He is often pictured as a heavy-lidded, brooding presence who, though quite intelligent, often meets resistance with brute force rather than reason. He earned the enmity of some big corporations three years ago when he aggressively sought contributions for an election campaign, reportedly threatening to raise some taxes if the companies were not generous.
Mr. Ozawa had a heart attack two years ago that set back his ambitions to become prime minister, and some say he may always remain the power behind the throne.
There are some who say that while the two may have new policies to put forward, the maneuvering for the no-confidence vote reflected nothing more than brutal power politics.
 
'Power Struggle' Seen
 "This split was not over policy," said Yukio Okamoto, a former senior official in the Foreign Ministry and now head of Okamoto Associates, a business consulting company. "This was a power struggle."
"Don't get me wrong," Mr. Okamoto added. "Ozawa is a first-rate policy strategist, but this was a matter of the mechanics of power, not ideology."
Mr. Ozawa has made it clear that he is comfortable with both brinkmanship and statesmanship, that the rough and tumble of policy debates is something he wants to introduce to Japan. The reform he so strongly advocates means many different things.
"Electoral reform is simply a method to wake up a politics that has been asleep for 50 years," he said. "My aim is to make real party politics, real parliamentary politics."

HEADLINE: Bolivia's Rain Forest Falls to Relentless Exploiters

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARMEN DEL APERECITO, Bolivia

 BODY:
Almost daily here in Bolivia's dense Amazon jungle, above the sound of the rushing river, the squawking of macaws and the scolding of monkeys, the Mojeno Indians hear the buzz of chain saws slicing through six-foot-thick mahogany trees. Heavy machinery growls as it cuts 15-foot-wide paths through the forest and drags the majestic logs to collection sites where trucks take them to sawmills.
"We see the trails of the cutters all the time, almost wherever we go in the forest," said Esekiel Justiniano. He estimated that as many as 40 chain-saw gangs were cutting mahogany on the land given his tribe and three others by the Bolivian Government last year. The loggers are licensed to cut mahogany trees, but not on the Indians' territory. 
 "They come in, mark the trees, cut them down and then the companies bring in the skidders that make tracks throughout the forest," he said.
Much attention has been given to the destruction of the Brazilian rain forest, the ecological damage there and its social effects on indigenous groups. But that has overshadowed the lesser-known and little-studied cutting down of vast tracts of jungle in other Latin American countries, like Bolivia, where scientists say the rate of deforestation is nearly as alarming as in Brazil.
Indian leaders here say that over the last two years loggers have felled more than 3,000 trees, perhaps as many as 4,000, on land that belongs to the area's indigenous groups. If fair market value had been paid, they say, it would have meant more than $6 million of income for the roughly 7,000 Mojenos, Movimas, Chimanes and Yuracare who remain here.
But under pressure from Government officials working with big logging interests, the tribal leaders have agreed to compensation of only $200,000.
"They are taking the most valuable thing in our forest," Nicolas Guaji said. "They promise us to build schools and bring motors for our canoes in return, but they give us nothing."
In this primitive village, some two days' travel by dugout canoe along rivers and streams from the nearest road, many Mojenos still believe in an old legend.
Their 19th-century prophet, Noko Guahi, told of the Holy Hill, where the outside world would not intrude and where monkeys, wild boar, deer and the forest fruits would be abundant, supplying all their needs.
 
Weary of the Fight, Some Urge a Retreat
 Today, many of the 130 members of the village want to abandon their bamboo huts, the open-air chapel and the green soccer field and push deeper into the jungle in search of the Holy Hill, or Loma Santa. They say they are tired of fighting the carrallanos, or white men, over the the huge mahogany trees, trees they have used for generations to make dugout canoes, rudimentary wheels for oxcarts and large bins for grinding grain.
The plight of the Mojenos and Bolivia's Amazon jungle, called the Beni, is not an isolated problem. Other countries that hold the Amazon's headwaters -- Peru, Colombia and Venezuela -- have also suffered from deforestation and other environmental pressures.
Along many of the small and medium river systems that eventually flow into the vast Amazon, the people, the forest, the water and the wildlife are under increasing strain.
In Peru and Bolivia, growers of coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine, are clear-cutting thousands of acres a year, planting coca plants in a way intended to strip the soil of nutrients through water erosion, since coca grows best in highly acidic soil.
Jungle laboratories where cocaine is made dump millions of gallons of acids, acetone, kerosene and other hazardous chemicals into the rivers each year.
In southern Peru, migrants panning for gold have stripped entire river systems of vegetation and sent untold amounts of silt downstream. Hundreds of tons of toxic mercury, used to extract bits of gold from the sand, are dumped into the waters.
But perhaps the most destructive element in Colombian, Venezuelan and Bolivian forests are the agribusinesses and armies of colonizers who clear-cut large jungle tracts every year in a rush to plant crops in the tropical soil. Within a few seasons, the soil, which is weak in nutrients, is often so depleted that the farmers are forced to move on to another tract.
 
500,000 Forest Acres Lost Every Year
 To be sure, the destruction here and in other countries is not yet on the scale seen in some parts of Brazil. This is mainly because the populations of these Amazon basin countries are dwarfed by that of Brazil. Moreover, the forests in the basin are far from major shipping points, making the building of huge plywood and pulp mills, which consume all kinds of jungle timber, unprofitable.
But the rates of deforestation are still striking and Bolivia, according to some calculations, is among the most exploited countries. Researchers for the Inter-American Development Bank have estimated that more than 11 percent of its forests have been either wiped out or damaged by logging and agribusinesses, compared with 5 percent in Brazil.
Forestry experts say that up to 500,000 acres of native forest are being cleared every year in Bolivia. For its size, that is only slightly below the rate of deforestation in Brazil.
Around Santa Cruz, the country's southern boom town, which is thriving on agricultural exports, giant tractors working in tandem drag huge chain links along the forest floor, pulling down swaths of tropical growth. The bulldozers then pass by again, pile the trees and other vegetation into endless rows and set them on fire. The cost is negligible for developers, who are able to buy land at less than 25 cents an acre.
"You drive the distant roads and suddenly find an area of two and five kilometers completely cleared from one week to another," said Christopher R. Carden, an agronomist in Santa Cruz. "We are at the headwaters of the Amazon and are destroying it."
Groups of Mennonites who have migrated here have established farms that look like the countryside of Pennsylvania or Ohio, with soybeans and other crops growing in meticulously kept fields for miles.
In a recent report, Mr. Carden wrote: "Much of the new damage is being done by Mennonite communities who are already responsible for large-scale forest clearance and soil destruction in Santa Cruz. Most of them, when interviewed, show little understanding of or concern for the environment."
Agronomists warn that in Bolivia winds and heavy rains quickly deplete the acidic soils, forcing communities like the Mennonites to abandon their lands and look for others every few years.
 
If Rules Are Set, They Are Ignored
 In the Beni, loggers, Indians, nongovernmental organizations and agronomists make one point abundantly clear: there is almost no governmental control over the exploitation of the rain forest.
In January 1990, the Bolivian Government called for a "historic ecological pause," a period in which it would not grant further logging concessions or permit vast expansion of agriculture. But businesses disregard the prohibition almost entirely. They log in areas they do not have title to and at rates far above levels set by the Government.
"All the commercially usable mahogany is going to be gone in Bolivia in five years," said Richard Rice, director of economic policy at Conservation International, an environmental group based in Washington. "In 1989 they started logging mahogany in earnest, and they are cutting at a rate that will run through the country's supply in 10 years time. What we're looking at is timber mining. They are not driving mahogany to physical extinction, but to commercial extinction."
Agronomists note that Bolivia has given logging concessions for more than half of its forests.
Much of the pressure to cut the forest comes from the almost limitless demand for the wood in the United States. Furniture companies there will buy almost as much as Bolivian logging companies can produce.
Environmentalists have tried to persuade American importers of mahogany to require the logging companies to certify that they are not violating Government laws or overexploiting the forests. But the efforts have so far failed.
Wilson Himjosa is assistant manager of the Hervel sawmill, which sits on the edge of the Indian territory. Fifteen-foot-high mountains of scrap mahogany, discarded to rot, testify to the once relentless pace of cutting in the forest. He said that this year the company had cut only one-quarter of the mahogany it cut last year.
"The wood is almost gone," Mr. Himjosa said while giving a tour of the sawmill, which was not operating for lack of lumber to cut. "We've sent all our teams back into areas of the forest we cut two years ago looking for mahogany. I think we'll have to shut down in two years."
 
White Man's World Presses In on Forest
 The ecological pressure on mahogany is felt deep in the jungle along the Aperecito River, where the Mojeno villagers, who have seldom seen white men, worry about their ability to defend their families and their land.
Last year, the Mojenos and three other Indian tribes were given two tracts of land in the Beni about the size of Delaware -- the Chimane forest and what is called the Multiethnic Indigenous Territory. But instead of being able to live peacefully without intrusion, the Indians see the white man's world moving in more and more.
On a recent morning, seven Mojenos assembled in Carmen del Aperecito, small men with dark complexions representing half of the Indigenous Forest Police authorized by the Government to perform the nearly impossible task of patrolling their land against the mahogany poachers.
Four carried old, rusted small-caliber rifles. Some had parts of police uniforms. Two had boots; others were barefoot. They were to show a visitor where wood cutters were systematically -- and illegally -- felling giant mahogany trees.
After a two-hour hike through mud, across swamps and over small streams, they came to a two-acre clearing, scarred with broad tractor marks. Almost 100 logs, four to six feet thick, lay on the ground, their once-dark bark bleached by the tropical sun, but their blood-red interior wood still rich in color.
In a second clearing a few hundred yards away, more logs lay on their sides, next to a makeshift camp with 10 bamboo beds for the cutting crew.
In theory, the lumber should have belonged to the Mojenos. The value of the fallen mahogany was more than $100,000. But the band of forest police lamented that last year, under pressure from the Government, a tribal leader signed away the right to several logging companies to cut 1,800 mahogany trees on their land. Instead of earning as much as $2,500 a tree, they got just $120.
"Based on the agreement, the loggers come in here, supposedly to collect and mark the trees they cut last year, and cut more, and then tag them and say they are trees that belong to them," said Edmundo Jhou, a Mojeno Indian and forestry expert at the Center for Study and Documentation for the Development of the Beni, a nongovernmental organization based in Trinidad.
 
Threats of Violence Worry the Indians
 In April, the small police force began to assert itself. It seized a $1,200 chain saw from one of the groups and a shotgun from another.
A few days later, a threatening band of seven men entered the village to claim the items back, but the Mojenos held a community meeting and voted against returning them.
Still, they are visibly nervous about growing threats of violence. Some suggest that the loggers be allowed take all the mahogany they want, believing they will then be left alone. They argue there are other species of wood they can use for their canoes.
But others are not so certain that the white men will go away once they take all the mahogany. Village leaders say they hear the buzz of small planes every few days, planes used by drug traffickers that are operating cocaine laboratories nearby.
And though the community tries to keep the rivers leading to the village overgrown to make then inaccessible to boats and difficult to follow by anyone but tribal members, the elders predict that inevitably the outside world will find them.
"There is a big division in the village," Daniel Bogado said. "The young people want to fight and not be pushed off by the lumber companies and outsiders. The older people are not sure. They think it may be better to go elsewhere, to look once again for the Loma Santa."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON BURMESE POLICY

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is coming under growing criticism from human rights groups for its policy toward the military junta in Myanmar, formerly Burma, which they say is one of the most repressive governments in the world.
The groups say they are concerned that the Administration, out of deference to several of Myanmar's neighbors, mainly Thailand, is continuing restrictive policies toward Burmese refugees that were adopted in the Bush Administration. Some of the groups are also concerned over the Administration's support for an $18 million grant that was approved by a United Nations Development Program on Friday. 
 Last week, several human rights organizations and Burmese expatriate groups met with State Department representatives. Participants said they had expressed dissatisfaction with the current policy, likening it to the Administration's approach toward Haiti.
"As with Haiti, the Burmese military has been successfully defying the international community," said Michael Jendrzejczk, director of the Washington office of Asia Watch, a division of Human Rights Watch in New York. "We would hope that the Clinton Administration would be much more effective in its policy toward Burma than they have been toward Haiti."
 
Fine Line Is Seen
 Administration officials say they must walk a fine line between applying pressure on Myanmar's leaders and providing sufficient incentives to induce changes in the Government's behavior. They must also balance their human rights efforts against the needs of Myanmar's neighbors like Thailand and Bangladesh, which have been inundated with refugees.
The State Department has told relief agencies to stop distributing aid to refugees living in camps on the Burmese side of the border with Thailand. The department has also continued tight requirements for dissident Burmese who have fled to Thailand and seek asylum in the United States.
Department officials say Administration support for the $18 million grant resulted from a compromise that reduced the grant from $40 million.
"We believe that was the best we could have done without forcing the matter for a vote, which we would have lost," said a State Department official involved in the discussions.

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Christopher St. Rebounds As Thriving 'Gay Mecca'

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Three years ago, times were tough on what has been called America's Gay Main Street. Along with the rest of New York City, the six-block-long mecca for homosexuals struggled to cope with the recession, inflated rents and the drug trade, which increased crime.
But Christopher Street in Greenwich Village had special problems, too: AIDS, which took its toll on the area's business owners and their clientele, and an upsurge in violence against homosexuals. Its longtime free-wheeling image drew drunken late-night crowds. More shops were vacant than anyone could remember, nightclubs languished and a vibrant street scene turned almost somber. 
 But as Gay Pride Week begins today, the picture seems more upbeat. Merchants and residents say attacks on homosexuals are now rare. The police say robberies are down by a third over the last two years, and merchants say even shoplifting is off dramatically. Rents have descended from the stratosphere, and empty stores are hard to find, although turnover is high. Merchants have planted trees and gardens, lending the street a fresh, graceful vitality. Clubs are bustling again.
"We set out to turn the street around, and we did," said Bob Kohler, owner of The Loft at 89 Christopher Street, between Bleecker and Seventh Avenue, which specializes in whimsical outfits that patrons buy mainly to wear to gay clubs.
"I keep thinking it can't get any better and it does," said Yolanda Miller, who three years ago opened Stick, Stone & Bone, which sells moderately priced jewelry and New Age books at 111 Christopher Street, and has seen a continuing increase in sales. "When we opened, many store windows were boarded up, and it looked like a ghost town."
Store owners credit the street's greater safety to more officers on patrol, community patrols and a walkie-talkie network established by the merchants.
"We don't wait until it gets busy and noisy and rowdy," said Capt. Stephen Kennedy, commander of the Police Department's Sixth Precinct, whose station house is on West 10th Street, around the corner from Christopher. "But we try to be as sensitive as we can."
Captain Kennedy says the area is safer and has a better image because of cooperation between the police and neighborhood merchants and residents. For example, to control rowdy late-night crowds, officers can point to signs posted by merchants warning against beer-drinking.
"We wanted to control the problem without killing the mood," said Mike Mirisola, owner of Street-wise, a clothing store at 113 Christopher, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
Christopher Street resembles other small retail streets in Greenwich Village, but it became a magnet and a symbol for homosexuals after the police raided the Stonewall Inn, at 53 Christopher Street, on June 27, 1969. That led to the city's first gay-rights protests, and the emergence of a unified, forceful gay-rights movement.
"This is a gay mecca," said Mr. Mirisola. "Sooner or later, every gay man in America will pass in front of my store."
Marvin Howell, owner of World, a new clothing store at 75 Christopher, exults in the spending power many of his customers command, saying some will spend $175 for a designer T-shirt.
Much of the carnival that is Christopher Street has nothing to do with gay culture. On nice evenings, people savor ice cream and burgers in streetfront establishments. Shoppers line up at NcNulty's, a 98-year-old coffee store at 109 Christopher. Patrons fill the Lucille Lortel Theatre at 121 Christopher to see what is often first-rate off-Broadway fare. Attendees at "Tony and Tina's Wedding," a participatory play, can be seen traipsing between locales.
Paul Bellardo, owner of Bellardo, Ltd., at 100 Christopher Street, says he has been at that address since 1967 and has never particularly focused on homosexuals to sell his exquisite handblown glass vases and other handicrafts. Indeed, he closes during the weekend of Gay Pride Week. "Nothing sold," he said.
One of the oldest stores catering to homosexuals is The Loft, although a sign says straights are welcome. "Only if they behave," said Mr. Kohler, the owner, with a wry smile.
And among the newer stores that ignore sexual orientation, one sells drug paraphernalia, a rarity on Christopher, and one is a small grocery.
"Success on this street is merchandising, merchandising, merchandising," he said. He changes his window displays frequently.
 
Quirky but Affordable
 Mr. Mirisola said he has great admiration for the two women who opened Stick, Stone & Bone next door. "They've got gay women down pat, which I thought was impossible," he said, referring to the street's orientation toward men.
Ms. Miller gladly accepted the compliment, but quickly added that she and her partner, Linda Curti, also do brisk business with straight women and not a few men.
As with Street-wise, Ms. Miller said success has come through offering quirky merchandise dramatically displayed. And they are competitive. "We've always kept our prices really low," she said.
For Mr. Mirisola, who four years ago was madly searching the suburbs for a new location, a new era of success is arriving on Christopher Street. "Sales are up, and I'm really hopeful," he said.

HEADLINE: Land Claim By Indians Is a Tactic In Casino Bid

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRUMBULL, Conn., June 19

 BODY:
Last November, when a tribe of fewer than 100 Indians filed a lawsuit staking a claim to the land that downtown Bridgeport stands on, many people laughed. Given the city's financial problems, some people joked that the Indians should just take it, while others wondered in jest whether Indians hadn't suffered enough.
The laughter stopped this month when lawyers for the tribe, the Golden Hill Paugussetts, announced they were expanding their land claims to include four Bridgeport suburbs -- casting a cloud over $10 billion in Fairfield County real estate. "I think we've gone from joke to nightmare," said Bernard Wishnia, the tribe's main lawyer. 
 Whatever sympathy the Paugussetts might have had for the loss of their lands, their tactics and their goals have provoked fierce opposition. The tribe wants not just a reservation in Bridgeport, but a gambling casino. The object of the claims is not to recover ancestral lands, but to pressure officials to grant the Federal recognition the tribe needs to operate a casino. State and local officials call the suits extortion and say they will not negotiate.
 
'I Call It Judicial Terrorism'
 "They've stated that they really don't want the property, they want Federal recognition so they can get casino gambling," said David A. Wilson, the First Selectman of Trumbull, who has filed a countersuit against the Paugussetts. "To me that seems misuse of the judicial system. I call it judicial terrorism."
The land claims initially produced a wave of uncertainty among homeowners who feared that the ownership of their land would be jeopardized, and some real-estate closings fell through.
Title-insurance companies are continuing to issue policies for most properties -- but not all -- and so banks are lending money and refinancing mortgages. A legislative committee is studying how the state can help homeowners.
Still, some people remain worried about losing their homes. "They had some surveyors up at the manor, and they told us it was just for the diocese, but with all this Indian talk, it has us nervous," said Valerie Faulkner, a resident of St. Joseph's Manor, a retirement home in Trumbull.
More, though, have accepted the suits for what the Paugussetts say they are: pressure on state and Federal officials to negotiate an agreement that will give the tiny tribe Federal recognition, land and money.
"It's a nuisance suit," said David D'Ausilio, the owner of Vantage Realty Better Homes and Gardens here. "Their ultimate objective is to inconvenience everybody until they get what they want."
But the tribal council leader, a 48-year-old social worker, Aurelius H. Piper Jr., who uses the name Chief Quiet Hawk, said the state's opposition to the Paugussetts' claims were based on racism. The casino issue, he said, only intensified racist fears, because of the economic power that casinos could bring the state's smallest minority group.
Chief Quiet Hawk, contrasted the opposition the tribe has encountered with the reception that Stephen Wynn, the head of Mirage Resorts, received when he came to Connecticut to lobby for casinos in Bridgeport and Hartford.
"There were the same people who are opposing us, holding him up as a god who would bring life to the city of Bridgeport," Chief Quiet Hawk said. "But we are just a bunch of Indians. To them it is unrealistic and appalling that a minority group could have that much economic power."
Chief Quiet Hawk said he became chief in 1990 to carry on the work of his father, Chief Big Eagle, who obtained state recognition for the Paugussetts in the 1970's when he won a court battle for clear title to the tribe's one-quarter-acre reservation in Trumbull.
Illness and lack of money, however, caused Chief Big Eagle to drop his pursuit of nearly 20 more acres in Trumbull that he claimed as former reservation land; when Chief Quiet Hawk took up his work, that land was claimed in one of the first lawsuits filed by the tribe.
Despite the tribal leader's arguments local and state officials are following the lead of Connecticut's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, who has vowed to fight "tooth and nail" rather than negotiate.
"We will continue to fight relentlessly," said Mr. Blumenthal, who contends the Paugussetts have no basis to claim land until the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs recognizes them as a tribe. "As a courtesy, we certainly will hear them out, but we can't compromise the fates of thousands of innocent property owners.
"A good deal of the money funding these lawsuits," he added, "has come from out-of-state gaming interests."
At a meeting Saturday at a middle school in Trumbull, Mr. Blumenthal and other officials made clear that they consider having a casino the sole motivation of a small group of Indians who they believe have no valid claim to be a tribe.
According to a recent census submitted by the Paugussetts, the officials said, the "alleged tribe" had only 37 members.
Mr. Wishnia, the tribe's lawyer, said he was not surprised to see the Paugussetts cast as greedy villains. "Native Americans throughout the country were abused and murdered," he said. "When the survivors tried to fight back, it was the fault of the savage Indians. When tribes were forced to march across the country and resisted, it was the fault of the Indians."
Now, he said, the Paugussetts are only following the path of other tribes in applying for Federal recognition and filing land claims, with the goal of negotiating for the land, resources and Federal aid to preserve their way of life.
The tribe, he acknowledged, is supported by an investor, Impression Delivery Corporation of Minneapolis, interested in seeing a casino in Bridgeport, little more than an hour from New York City. But without their financial support, he said, the Paugussetts could not afford the detailed research needed for Federal recognition, such as documenting that they have functioned continuously as a tribe for the last 350 years, or the legal assistance to make the claims.
"We had no choice but to play the casino card in order to do this," Mr. Wishnia said. "The state of Connecticut and its landowners are apparently prepared to spend endless amounts of money to fight our claims. That's not a fight we could afford to get involved in alone."
The Paugussetts started the process of seeking Federal recognition in 1982, long before talk of casinos, Mr. Wishnia said, and their interests today are the same as then: self-preservation.
What changed, he said, was that Congress allowed Federally recognized tribes, as sovereign entities, to conduct gaming in 1988, and the Mashantucket Pequots then built a wildly successful casino in eastern Connecticut. That opened the state to the possibility of other casinos and drew investors to the struggling tribe in Bridgeport.
 
Old Law Is Cited
 Mr. Wishnia and other lawyers for the tribe say Mr. Blumenthal is simply wrong in contending that the tribe must have Federal recognition before its claims can be heard. Courts have long held that the Nonintercourse Act of 1790, on which Indian land claims are based, applies to tribes like the Paugussetts, who are recognized by Connecticut as a tribe.
They also note that states can speed the recognition process by having their Congressional delegations introduce special legislation to recognize a tribe, as happened in 1982, when Lowell P. Weicker Jr., then a senator, and Representative Sam Gejdenson sponsored such an act for the Pequots.
The lawyers also say that they are confident that their land claims are documented, showing that lands that the Paugussetts held title to were illegally bought, traded or taken from them under both the colonial government and the Federal Government that followed.
The expanded suits announced this month, covering the towns of Trumbull, Shelton, Monroe and Stratford, are based on the Paugussetts receiving title to 84 square miles here in 1637, two years before the founding of Stratford, from which the other towns later broke off.
Representative Christopher Shays, who represents the Bridgeport area, has met with members of the tribe. He insists that they must follow procedure to establish their legitimacy and their claims, rather than pressure elected officials, especially because of the money at stake in a casino.
"They wanted to tell me all the great things they wanted to do with their casino," Mr. Shays said. "That's what's motivating them. We're talking about millions of dollars, potentially billions of dollars in revenue. So this is not child's play. The real tragedy is the innocent homeowners who are being held hostage."
 
'Claims Are No Joke'
 Many lawyers experienced in defending Indian claims, however, advise their clients to explore negotiations, because claims that appear outlandish at first can turn out to be valid.
"Indian land claims are no joke," said Allan van Gestel, a Boston lawyer who is representing some property owners in the Bridgeport area. "There's been a lot of law made, and Indians have had some success."
The key issue, he said, is whether a tribe is functioning as a tribe not only when a claim is filed, but also when the contested land transaction took place. The Paugussetts' case appears weak to him, he said, because only three people could claim tribal ancestry at the time of a key sale, that of Golden Hill, the area of Bridgeport where City Hall now stands.
As for the Paugussetts today, Mr. van Gestel said, "You say they are a tribe. I say they are a group of people who by looking eastward to the Mashantucket Pequots see a way to better their lives."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
The Newspaper Industry Is At A Crossroad: Does It Take the High-Tech Highway Or Go Back to Basics?

BYLINE: By William Glaberson

 BODY:
THE newspaper industry right now is like the kid who is asked what he wants to do when he grows up.
"Make money," he says.
The newspaper industry has been a grown-up for a long time. But as a mature business in a rough economy, it is finding it difficult to find paths to continued growth. And, as in any business, there is one thing newspaper companies know they have to do: Make money. 
 Because newspapers are a mature business, with the unusual problems of changing reader and advertiser habits, it has long been obvious that newspaper owners cannot sit back as they once did and wait for business to stream in the door. But the industry's strategic compass is erratic.
One minute, it seems to be pointing clearly toward the electronic newspaper, which will be read on a personalized monitor. The next instant, printed pages seem certain to remain the delivery system of choice.
One minute, newspapers seem mesmerized by the prospect of telephone-newspaper linkups, interactive classified advertising, CD-ROM's, cable television and on-line computer services. The next, specialty publications are the rage, and there is talk about attending to the core business that has produced healthy revenues for decades.
"What you have right now is a lot of confusion in the industry," said Tod A. Jacobs, a newspaper securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company of New York City. "Long term, no one really knows what to do."
Newspaper companies are especially uncertain now because the economy's prospects are so murky. This spring, there was optimism about advertising in many newspaper markets, with New York City and Los Angeles remaining notable exceptions.
But now publishers across the country are beginning to worry because advertising shows signs of stalling again. In this strange, uncertain time, newspaper companies are trying to position themselves for the future. That task is made especially difficult because of the confusion over which way the industry will move into the next century.
Despite the frustrating times, most newspaper companies are taking steps toward reshaping themselves. And many companies are striking out in several directions at once.
Some industry giants, including Gannett, Knight-Ridder and Times Mirror, last month proclaimed their commitment to the new electronic pathways for news. They formed a consortium to explore telecommunications and computer delivery systems for the news.
This month, with its executives noting publicly that few of the high-tech newspaper projects have yet brought major financial returns, The New York Times Company announced its $1.1 billion merger with The Boston Globe. The Times Company has said it is also committed to moving into new media and recently created a business group for electronic and other information services.
Scripps Howard and the Tribune Company, along with Capital Cities/ ABC, recently invested in one of the leading companies that are moving newspapers toward competing with the Postal Service, delivering magazines and product samples to doorsteps across the country. The company, Alternate Postal Delivery of Grand Rapids, Mich., works with newspapers to fight their increasingly strong competitors for advertising dollars: direct-mail companies.
But while newspapers move in what would have once been considered the improbable direction of becoming couriers for national magazines and deodorant manufacturers, they are also nurturing new publications that are logical offspring. This fall, The Chicago Tribune will begin publication of a new Spanish language weekly, Exito!, with its own 20-member staff. The weekly will be aimed at the one million Spanish-speaking residents of metropolitan Chicago.
The Wall Street Journal recently announced that it would add on Sept. 8 a weekly Texas Journal section of the newspaper in Texas with its own staff to provide coverage of the business scene in that big state.
Analysts say there is little question that other major new newspaper ventures are inevitable. In part, that is because newspapers generate so much cash in the normal course of business.
"What a newspaper is, is a cash cow. It is an annuity," said Kenneth T. Berents, an industry analyst at Wheat, First Securities Inc. of Richmond.
Mr. Jacobs of Sanford C. Bernstein estimated that over the next five years, Gannett could generate $1 billion in excess cash flow that it would need to invest. He estimated that Knight-Ridder could produce $800 million in extra cash and the Tribune Company could have $700 million available.
Still, most analysts now believe that newspapers may never get back to the very high returns on investment that they had as recently as the 80's. That means they must transform the way they manage themselves financially to try to satisfy investors. That also means they will move down new paths, even if it is not yet clear where all those paths lead.
