HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW AGE OF FUND RAISING FOR CATHOLICS
Brother Anthony Iazzetti's latest excursion into the world of raising money for his school in the north Bronx is far removed from the candy sales and raffles that have long been a staple of Roman Catholic fund-raising drives. To be exact, it's 2,786 miles away in Los Angeles. As the president of Mount Saint Michael Academy, he recently traveled to the West Coast to meet with a select handful of alumni who he hoped would become major contributors to the school's $6 million capital campaign. Although such efforts are not unusual for private colleges or universities, a growing number of Catholic high schools, and some grammar schools, have had to turn to an array of aggressive and sophisticated fund-raising techniques. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
MEETING SCHEDULED IN WALKOUT
In an effort to end a staff walkout over safety concerns, social service officials are to meet with a union representing workers at a center that places homeless people in shelters. The center, at 78 Catherine Street in lower Manhattan, has been closed since Friday when a caseworker was assaulted by a homeless woman. The center usually serves about 75 families a day and is supposed to be open 24 hours a day. B2.
 

BETTER TIMES ON CHRISTOPHER STREET
Three years ago, times were tough on what has been called America's Gay Main Street. Along with the rest of New York City, the six-block-long section of Christopher Street in Greenwich Village struggled to cope with the recession, inflated rents and the drug trade, which increased crime. But as Gay Pride Week begins, the picture seems more upbeat. Strictly Business. B3.
 
THE DEBATE OVER TERM LIMITS
If proposed eight-year term limits were in effect, the New York City Council President, most of the borough presidents and nearly half the Council members would probably be disqualified from seeking re-election this year. Which is why a putatively populist crusade that could limit the discretion of elected officials and voters alike is supported largely by people who have been unable to win even one term or who have already held their jobs longer than the proposed limits would allow. Metro Matters. B3.
 
REGION
 
A DEADLOCK ON BANKING LAWS
With just over a week left before current banking laws expire, the New York State Legislature is deadlocked over legislation that consumer groups say will provide important protections to bank customers and that the banking industry says will determine whether thousands of banking jobs stay in the state. At stake are laws dating from 1980 that have deregulated the financial industry, allowing banking companies almost complete freedom in setting interest rates on credit cards and most types of loans. B5.
 
SAVING THAT OLD-TIME MAIN STREET
Richard Hersey is a modern-day circuit rider, going from village to village in the Catskill Mountains in an experimental program to revive the economic health of the Main Streets of such towns as Margaretville, N.Y. His official title is "Main Street Coordinator/Circuit Rider," but he describes himself as a catalyst, cheerleader, consultant and go-between for five communities trying to overcome the neglect and deterioration of their basic shopping streets. B5.
 
POLL SHOWS FLORIO WITH 5-POINT LEAD
The first public poll since the New Jersey gubernatorial primary shows Governor Florio with a five-point lead over his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, and the outcome of the November election hinging on the 9 percent of the electorate that is still undecided. The poll is the first head-to-head test of the two candidates now that they have their party's nominations. B5.
 
ANTI-ABORTION FILM STIRS OUTCRY
A teacher's decision to show an anti-abortion film to seventh-grade students has outraged some parents in Somers, N.Y., igniting a debate about how public schools should address politically sensitive issues. The Somers Central School District is weighing disciplinary action against the social studies teacher who put aside his Civil War lectures to show students a documentary film with an anti-abortion message, including images of aborted and dismembered fetuses. B6.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Sluggish European Sales Affect the Big 3 in Different Ways

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
UNFORTUNATELY for investors in American auto stocks, the budding automotive recovery in the United States has been undercut somewhat by a prostrate European market.
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company depend heavily on earnings from Europe, while the Chrysler Corporation has little manufacturing there and minimal exports. Not surprisingly, the stocks of G.M. and Ford have been penalized by the European market, while the strongly performing Chrysler shares have not. 
 But are European car sales about to turn? And when they turn, will G.M. and Ford profit from the upswing? And is the lack of a European presence actually helping Chrysler shares? These questions arose last week on Wall Street -- a week when Ford shares fell, apparently because of the perception that its results in Europe may stay depressed longer than investors had expected.
European auto sales were down 17.9 percent in May, compared with the month a year earlier. An important factor was lower-than-normal sales in Germany, which seemed to compensate for the higher-than-normal sales immediately after reunification. Elsewhere, sales were improving in Britain, were not quite as bad as they had been in France and Spain, and were worse in Italy.
Ford has higher sales in Britain than anywhere else in Europe, and some investors had been thinking that an improved British market would lead Europe out of tough times. As a result, they bid up Ford shares in early June. That confidence evaporated last week, as analysts reiterated that a European recovery might be a year away. For the week, Ford shares fell to $50, from $53.75.
In 1991 and 1992, Ford lost more than $2 billion in Europe. It said it would lose money there again this year, perhaps more than $500 million.
G.M., which earned $1.7 billion in Europe in 1991 and $1.2 billion last year, may earn less than $550 million this year, said Jean-Claude Gruet of UBS Securities Inc. That result would still be an accomplishment, he said, because it was possible that no other auto maker would make money there. It would also be significant because G.M.'s highest European sales are in Germany, where the overall market is weakest and where Volkswagen A.G. is on a crusade to cut costs.
Mr. Gruet said some investors might be thinking of taking profits in Chrysler, which has more than doubled in price over the last year, and buying G.M. and Ford to take advantage of coming improvements in Europe. "Right now, Chrysler being a pure North American play is very favorable," he said. When Europe recovers, though, investors who want to hold an automotive stock may look for a way to tap into European profits, he said.
Analysts caution that the timing and magnitude of Europe's auto-market recovery will be crucial to investors. While the Bundesbank has been lowering interest rates, consumers may wait to respond; their fears of rising unemployment may outweigh the low rates. Moreover, Japanese auto makers are building more vehicles in Europe and are growing stronger by the month.
"Next year should be better, but I'm thinking that the improvement may be no better than 5 percent; it may not come until the second half of the year," said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch & Company. He recently lowered his recommendation on Ford to hold.
Wendy Needham of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said a more robust North American market should overshadow European developments for the next 18 months or so. On that basis, she is recommending G.M. and Chrysler.

HEADLINE: British Air Joins Chase In Card Deal

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
In a move to strengthen its growing presence in the United States, British Airways has joined with the Chase Manhattan Bank to issue a joint Visa credit card that will earn users frequent-flier miles on international and domestic United States flights.
Most major United States airlines have similar affinity cards with banks, for which card owners typically pay an annual fee of $50 and accrue one frequent-flier mile for every dollar charged. This is the first such arrangement between a big American bank and a large foreign airline. 
 It comes at a time when frequent-flier miles are increasingly being dangled as lures for everything from hotel stays to magazine subscriptions -- and at a time when frequent-flier programs are growing among carriers in Europe and Asia.
 
 
Becoming 'Americanized'
 Noting the recent $400 million investment by British Airways in the USAir Group, Randy Peterson, the publisher of Inside Flyer, a monthly guide to frequent-flier programs, said: "With USAir in the fold they've become more Americanized in the mind of travelers. Now the alliance with Chase will strengthen that feeling."
Joe Brancatelli, executive editor of Frequent Flyer magazine, said the arrangement might help British Airways' marketing but might do little for Chase. "The affinity card has generally been a mirage," he said. "The volume is there but not the profits, because the people who own them tend to pay their bills within 30 days, so the banks can't collect interest on the balance."
Banks pay the airlines about 1 cent for each frequent-flier mile they award to card holders, and hope to make money through the annual membership fees and in their percentage of merchants' receipts from customers' using the card. Citibank's Mastercard and Visa affinity cards with American Airlines are thought to have about a million members, who on average spend enough money to qualify for a free domestic flight every 18 months. Mr. Peterson said he expected to see affinity programs between airlines and brokerage houses or insurance companies.
Under most such programs, it requires $20,000 in card charges to qualify for a free domestic United States ticket, and $40,000 for an international flight.
Chase Manhattan exudes optimism about its new affinity partner. "We're looking in the area of hundreds of thousands of new members over time," said Thomas C. Lynch, executive vice president of Chase. Many will be leisure travelers, Mr. Lynch said, because they not only take more flights on vacations than in decades past, they tend to take more family members with them.
 
T.W.A. May Offer One
 Chase previously had an affinity card with Trans World Airlines, but it expired last year, when T.W.A. was in bankruptcy protection. Now out of bankruptcy, T.W.A. said it expected to offer an affinity card soon with another bank.
The only other leading airline without an affinity partner is Delta Air Lines, although it participates in American Express Membership Miles and Diners Club Rewards. Both those programs award frequent-flier miles for use with a variety of participating carriers, and American Express's two-year-old program already has 1.7 million members -- despite having lost Pan American and Midway when those airlines went out of business, and MGM Grand, which went into the cargo business.
Last week, American Express added USAir as a partner, although the Diners Club program still has more than twice as many airlines.
"We'll consider ourselves successful if we hit 60,000 to 75,000 cards by the end of the year," said Chris Vukelich, director of business programs for British Airways. He added that its existing frequent-flier program, begun in February 1992, has about 500,000 members in the United States, and the affinity card is intended primarily at enrolling even more frequent business travelers.
British Airways is the leader in flights between the United States and Britain, with about 40 percent of the traffic, and has as many as 29 daily flights.
Under the affinity card program and British Airways' existing frequent-flier program, the carrier will provide up to four additional credit cards without charge to the primary card holder's account, allowing households to combine the miles they earn. Card holders can also earn miles on British Airways, USAir, USAir Express and Alaska Airlines, and they can redeem miles on those four carriers as well as on American Airlines.
Many foreign airlines are creating or improving frequent-flier programs, and their target is often Americans, who represent about 40 percent of all airline passengers (compared with about 30 percent for Europeans).
Japan Airlines recently broadened the definition of family members eligible for miles in its program, and for the first time included economy fares in computing mileage. Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific and Malaysia Airlines are banding together to offer a frequent-flier program this summer, while Korean Air's frequent-flier program offers miles for passengers who stay not only at hotels in Korea but also at the Los Angeles Hilton.
Most European frequent-flier programs have been more restrictive than those of United States carriers, but they are becoming more liberal.

HEADLINE: Legislature Is Deadlocked On Banking Deregulation

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 20

 BODY:
With just over a week left before current banking laws expire, the State Legislature is deadlocked over legislation that consumer groups say will provide important protections to bank customers and that the banking industry says will determine whether thousands of banking jobs stay in the state.
At stake are laws dating from 1980 that have deregulated the financial industry, allowing banking companies almost complete freedom in setting interest rates on credit cards and most types of loans. 
 Before deregulation began in 1980, the state limited the interest that banks could charge on credit cards and most loans. Rates for most types of consumer loans, for example, could not go above 12 percent. The state also restricted the length and types of loans banks could offer.
 
Deadline for Decision
 The Legislature must decide by June 30, when the current laws expire, whether to make deregulation permanent, simply to extend it or to allow it to lapse.
Consumer-protection groups say deregulation allowed banks to charge excessive fees for services like writing checks and they have called for new laws requiring all banks to offer low-cost or free accounts. "Banks are gouging consumers," said Travis Plunkett of the New York Public Interest Research Group.
But banking companies, who want deregulation made permanent, have said deregulation has led to lower interest rates on loans and a wide variety of new products, including variable rate loans. They say many banks will restrict credit or move operations to other states if deregulation expires and the old system of caps on interest rates is reinstituted.
"Permanent deregulation provides an economic incentive for banks to stay in New York," said Michael P. Smith, executive vice president of the New York State Bankers Association, which represents most of the state's 292 commercial banks.
No matter what happens with the law, it is unlikely that banks would move jobs soon, but bank officials say their concern is long-term planning.
 
Strong Sentiment
 There is strong sentiment in both the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate for allowing deregulation to continue. But the two houses remain far apart on how long it should be extended and on what strings can be attached.
To the dismay of bank companies and their Republican allies, the Assembly Democrats have turned deregulation into what a lobbyist called a "honey pot": a bill so important to the banking industry that legislators swarm around it with amendments providing goodies for constituents.
Urban legislators want banks to give more loans to women and minorities and new protections against what they consider racially discriminatory banking practices. Consumer advocates want banks to support a statewide advocacy group for bank customers by listing its toll-free telephone number on bills. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo wants a multimillion-dollar loan fund for small businesses.
The amendments have caused angry rumblings from Republicans who say banks want only limited concessions and then only if deregulation is made permanent.
"If they hang too many Christmas tree bulbs on this, the Senate will not approve it," said Senator Hugh T. Farley, a Schenectady Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.
With just over a week to go, many legislators feel they may have only one option: extending current laws for another limited period, without adding new consumer protections. "It would be the worst of all worlds because it will mean we're stuck with a law that doesn't work for consumers and that banks don't want," said Mr. Plunkett.
Banking deregulation came about after banks complained in the late 1970's, when interest rates skyrocketed, that regulation was squeezing profits and forcing them to constrict credit. Several companies, including Citibank and Chase Manhattan, moved credit-card operations to states with less restrictive laws, taking thousands of jobs with them.
But the Legislature, fearing sharply higher interest rates and fees, refused to make deregulation permanent, allowing it to expire periodically, first in 1983, again in 1987 and now this year. The fears interest rates remain even though rates on credit cards and loans have been dropping in recent years, for that decline is largely due to changes in the economy not related to deregulation.
 
Campaign Contributions
 For their part, banks and their lobbyists have been able to exert considerable power in the Legislature by spending heavily on campaign contributions. Last year, a political action committee controlled by the New York Bankers Association spent $111,000 on Legislative campaigns. The largest chunk of that, more than $18,000, went to the Senate Republican campaign committee.
But the industry has failed to persuade Legislators to make deregulation permanent, largely because many Democrats fear losing powerful leverage with a powerful industry.
"I'd like to see them come back every six years," said Assemblyman Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat. "If you give away your options on that, you give away everything."
Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., a Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the Assembly Banking Committee, has negotiated a compromise with banking lobbyists and Mr. Farley, the Senate Banking Committee chairman. The plan would make deregulation permanent and would require all banks to offer low-cost checking accounts. It would also require banks to open accounts for anyone living in the surrounding county, a safeguard against racial discrimination, Mr. Farrell said.
But many Democrats say the proposal does not go far enough toward protecting consumers.

HEADLINE: Circuit Rider Trying to Save That Old-Time Main Street

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., June 16

 BODY:
Richard Hersey is a modern-day circuit rider, going from village to village in the Catskill Mountains in an experimental program to revive the economic health of the Main Streets.
His official title is "Main Street Coordinator/Circuit Rider," but he describes himself as a catalyst, cheerleader, consultant and go-between for five communities trying to overcome the neglect and deterioration of their basic shopping streets. 
 "I am trying first and foremost to encourage people to use their own resources to sustain their local economies," he said. "The objective is to rebuild the spirit of their Main Streets."
From his base at the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development, based in Arkville, Mr. Hersey drives 5,000 to 6,000 miles a month to meetings with merchants, public officials, Chambers of Commerce and Main Street committees in three counties.
 
Competition From Malls
 The longest trip he makes in his 1986 Saab is 50 miles to Jeffersonville (population 484) in Sullivan County. It's about 45 miles to Cairo (population 1,273) in Greene County, 35 miles to Walton (population 3,326) and 25 miles to Delhi (population 3,084), both in Delaware County, but only about a mile to Margaretville (population 639), also in Delaware County.
Like cities everywhere in the United States, the small villages of the Catskill Mountains have seen their downtowns falter largely because of the competition of large shopping malls and discount houses. Some have empty storefronts, others have ugly signs, many have inadequate parking spaces. All complain about too few shoppers.
Despite problems elsewhere with attempts to reinvigorate downtowns, particularly in nearby Hudson River cities like Newburgh, Hudson, Poughkeepsie and Troy, Mr. Hersey is optimistic that the smaller Catskill villages have a better chance.
Among their advantages, he says, are the scenic beauty around them, relatively low crime rates, the growth of second-home residences and a neighborly atmosphere.
 
Part-Time Residents
 "The obvious future economy of the Catskills is tied to tourism and second homes," Mr. Hersey said. "Even if it has a smaller population, it can have a stronger economy because of the part-time residents and visitors."
An urban planner by profession, Mr. Hersey, 44, worked in large and small cities before coming to the Catskill Mountains in February. A native of Beverly, Mass., he graduated from Columbia University and received a master's degree in urban planning from the University of Southern California.
His job is a cooperative venture of the Catskill Center and the New York Main Street Alliance, based in New York City. The alliance, which was formed in 1990, also operates Main Street aid programs in Jackson Heights, Bay Ridge, Staten Island and Harlem.
The Catskill circuit rider program is financed by local contributions and money from the O'Connor Foundation and the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation. Its budget for the current year is about $45,000, said Peter Mosbacher, of the Main Street Alliance.
 
A Visit to Main Street
 Sitting in the sun on a bench, one of the amenities of an uncrowded and pleasant-looking Main Street here in Margaretville, a resident, Helen Kern, said she liked to come downtown every day to buy a newspaper and pick up her mail.
"I do most of my shopping here but I have to go to Oneonta or Kingston every once in a while," she said. "I had to go to Delhi recently to buy an ironing board because it wasn't available here. We need more things available on Main Street."
To her left, Main Street stretched south to a supermarket. To her right, it ended three-quarters of a mile away in a farm. In between, it had a mix of locally owned establishments: a pharmacy, a liquor store, a hardware store, a bank, a small department store, several restaurants, a J. C. Penney catalog store, a lawyer's office and the Galli-Curci Theater, now converted into an antique center. Only two stores were vacant, one being remodeled.
 
Traffic Flow and Parking
 Sitting on the same bench, Brian Millen, owner of the local department store and co-chairman of the Main Street Subcommittee of the Greater Margaretville Chamber of Commerce, said, "The major problem in town is traffic flow and parking."
Walking down Main Street, Mr. Hersey said the five communities now have opportunities to cooperate and develop special market niches.
He said he saw Margaretville as a regional retail center, Jeffersonville as an arts center, Cairo as a multipurpose downtown, Delhi as a connection between its branch of the State University and local government, and Walton as a center for both youth and retired people.
"Remaking a downtown is never complete," he said. "It's like weeding a garden."

He spoke with Helen Wern, Brian Millen and Peter Sluites, residents of Margaretville, N.Y. (Dan Cronin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Paris Air Show Ends on Optimism

BYLINE: International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: PARIS, June 20

 BODY:
The 40th Paris Air Show -- one of the world's most prestigious showcases for aircraft -- wound up today with the aerospace industry in its deepest trough since World War II but with its optimism still largely intact that the good times will roll round again.
Both Jean Pierson, managing director and chief executive of Airbus Industrie, and Philip M. Condit, president of the Boeing Company, predicted that the industry's business cycle would be swinging upward when the next Paris show took place in 1995. 
 Their prediction appeared to be based more on the certainty that aircraft wear out and need to be replaced, and on the likelihood of rapid growth in the Asian market, than on any confidence that American and European airlines will have emerged from their catastrophic losses by then.
The Paris show underscores a trend that has become increasingly apparent in the last few years: The cost, size and complexity of major aerospace projects will lead to increasing international and, indeed, intercontinental cooperation.
 
Pooling of Resources
 Even Boeing and Airbus have pooled resources to study the feasibility of jointly building an airliner capable of carrying more than 600 passengers. With a market for no more than 500 such aircraft, analysts say it would be economically impossible for either company to build one alone.
Despite the possibility of such cooperation, Boeing says Airbus is unfairly subsidized by European governments, while Airbus asserts that its American rivals are propped up with handouts from the United States military budget.
As Boeing lays off 28,000 workers to cope with a sharp fall in orders, Airbus rejects the claim that European competition is to blame. It says it provides jobs for thousands of American workers. It also makes the point that Boeing laid off 64,000 workers between 1968 and 1971, before a single Airbus had been delivered.
Airbus has successfully penetrated the United States market, with sales of more than 400 aircraft. But Boeing and McDonnell Douglas are even more dependent on the European market, with more than 2,100 aircraft in service with, or on order from, airlines here.
 
Airbus Parts Made in U.S.
 And the rivalry obscures the fact that Boeing and McDonnell Douglas are not as all-American nor Airbus as all-European as politicians make them out to be. Companies in 35 American states provide 20 to 40 percent of the content of Airbus aircraft, including key elements in their computer systems. More than 30 percent of the Boeing 767 airframe and more than 65 percent of the McDonnell Douglas MD-80 airliner are built outside the United States.
If a superjumbo ever goes into production, it will probably be powered by the mammoth GE-90 jet engine, being jointly developed by General Electric of the United States and Snecma of France.
To survive, aerospace component manufacturers have to build and trade on a world scale. For instance, Dowty Aerospace, which makes landing gear, propellers, hydraulic systems and engine rings, is British but does much of its manufacturing in Canada, Pennsylvania and North Carolina and is in more than 30 other countries.
On the military front, the cost and complexity of developing warplanes and related projects is forcing European countries toward more extensive cooperation. France's Rafale and Sweden's JAS 39 Gripen are probably the last big fighter projects that any country, outside the United States and Russia, will embark upon alone.
 
Cooperation on Missiles
 Aerospatiale of France and Deutsche Aerospace are likely to team up soon to develop and build missiles. Eight European countries have been discussing building a military transport to replace the Lockheed C-130, which will be 50 years old next year. Lockheed, meanwhile is developing new engines and avionics to take its workhorse well into the next century.
Discussions are also under way to build a joint European maritime aircraft.
Because most countries see their defense needs differently, cooperation on military projects, while necessary in the present economic climate, is complicated.
The four-nation European jet fighter has had to be redefined because Germany found the original concept too expensive. Italy is wavering on the project because it needs to replace its aging F-104 jets quickly as a result of security threats stemming from the war raging across the Adriatic in Yugoslavia.
